DOC.HEAD: Khomeini's Ghost Still Stalks Iran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The ghost of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini stalks the Islamic republic a year after his death, in the form of a power struggle among the Imam's disciples that remains unresolved. The revolution Khomeini began 11 years ago survives,however, frustrating the doomsayers who predicted it would fall apart when he was no longer there to unite the factions. Moves by President Hashemi Rafsanjani and his ``pragmatists'' toward a more liberal course have been stymied by anti-Western radicals who accuse him of straying from ``the path of the Imam,'' as Khomeini was known. Both groups claim to be Khomeini's true ideological heirs and invoke his commandments to justify their actions. An Iranian official, speaking anonymously, said Rafsanjani sought to legitimize his more liberal policies through subtle interpretations of Khomeini's teachings. In response, the 270-member parliament passed a law in May that makes changing Khomeini's writings a crime. The parliament is dominated by radical followers of Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a former interior minister. The radicals include Ahmad Khomeini, 44, the ayatollah's only surviving son. He has made no apparent effort to claim his father's mantle and is overshadowed by Mohtashemi. In a clear warning to Rafsanjani, Ahmad Khomeini recently told the 350,000-strong Revolutionary Guards Corps, which could hold the balance of power: ``Do not deviate from the Imam's path. If others do, I trust you will not let them.'' During the revolution, the Revolutionary Guards swore personal allegiance to Ayatollah Khomeini. Rafsanjani, elected in July 1989 to a presidency with greater power than before, is trying to revitalize the economy after a decade of inefficient management and eight years of war with Iraq that ended in August 1988. Included in his 5-year reconstruction plan is $27 billion of foreign investment to rebuild industry. Radicals fear Rafsanjani's policy of improving relations with the West to obtain investment and technology will lead to renewed relations with the United States, which Khomeini called the ``Great Satan.'' The president's influence is believed to have been critical to the release of two American hostages in April by pro-Iranian Shiites in Lebanon. Mohtashemi, who has close ties to Lebanese Shiite militants, denounced the releases and 170 members of the parliament signed a protest demanding the government not involve itself in the hostage issue. Diplomats in Tehran say Rafsanjani appears determined to show the West he is moving the country away from isolation. In an effort to create a more liberal social and political climate, he has eased restrictions Khomeini placed on Iran's 55 million people. He cannot move quickly because of radical opposition and faces growing discontent from a populace whose expectations were raised when he gained power. There have been demonstrations against shortages, unemployment estimated at 4 million, and high inflation. Opposition groups say the Revolutionary Guards killed several protesters and arrested scores. Some progress has been made. Diplomats estimate inflation was trimmed from 30 percent to 20 percent in the past year and the government has contracts for major investment projects estimated to be worth billions of dollars. Rafsanjani's plans depend on oil revenue. It is expected to be about $15 billion this year, but nothing is certain in the volatile oil market. ``The authorities know they have at best one or two years grace before economic problems produce dangerous political dissatisfaction,'' Vahe Petrossian, an Iranian analyst based in London, wrote last month in the Middle east Economic Digest. A waiter named Khosrow in a Tehran restaurant said: ``All I want are three square meals a day for myself and my family. Someone has to rule, but I don't really care who it is so long as I have enough to provide a roof for my family. ``During the war I never complained, but enough is enough.'' Mehrdad, a taxi driver, said: ``I think most of the people are behind Rafsanjani and they know he's trying to do something good for us.'' Asked if restoring relations with the United States did not go against Khomeini's teachings, he replied: ``The Imam said we must strike a blow against the United States. How are we hurting the United States when we pay triple the price for American goods because we buy them through middlemen? ``We would strike a more effective blow if we resumed ties and rebuilt our economy and industry so we become truly independent and powerful.''

DOC.HEAD: Wildfires: One Of Drought's Biggest Threats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The four-year drought has parched the countryside that's home to nearly a third of Californians into a tinderbox the likes of which has not been seen this century, fire officials say. Worse, there have never been so many homes in the fast-growing rural areas, where few residents take enough safety measures to protect their property or themselves. Fire officials delivered a prophetic assessment of the state's fire risk on Tuesday, the day before wildfires ignited by arsonists began destroying hundreds of homes in Southern California. ``Our experience tells us that this year the stage is set for possibly having fires of disastrous proportions,'' said Dave Mack of the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection. On Thursday, fire agencies from throughout the state shifted their forces to the south, leaving fire-prone Northern California with fewer forces to respond to blazes there. The Southern California fires, the worst of which was in Santa Barbara County, conformed ominously to the forecast issued Tuesday by an unprecedented task force of statewide fire agencies. The task force announced new strategies for the summer, including hitting wildfires faster with larger forces than during the past three drought years. Pat Kidder of the U.S. Bureau of Land Management said that ``all the indicators show we could have the potential for the worst fire season on record'' this century. One indicator during this fourth and driest year of the drought, the Palmer Index, shows that ``it's drier than any time this century on a statewide average,'' said state forestry spokeswoman Karen Terrill. The Palmer Index _ which employs mathematical formulas to examine rainfall, soil moisture, humidity, and other conditions _ indicates that conditions are drier than those in 1924, when more than a million acres burned, and in 1987, when more than 800,000 acres were charred. Fire experts said other longtime indicators of fire danger, such as those which measure moisture in live and dead vegetation, appear to support those conclusions. They also said the drought is killing forests and brush. There are an estimated 1 billion board feet of dead timber standing on public and private lands, with another 1 billion board feet expected to die by the end of the year, said U.S. Forest Service spokesman Matt Mathes. A board foot is a piece of wood that is 1 foot square and 1 inch thick. In certain areas, some scientists believe, one out of every three trees is dead or dying, victims of the drought or the resulting disease and beetle infestation. At the same time, up to 50 tons per acre of dead branches in same areas litter the countryside, sheared from trees by a particularly heavy winter storm. Together, the dead trees and branches could fuel especially hot, swift fires. In addition, above-normal temperatures are forecast throughout much of the summer. Reacting to the threat, local, state, and federal fire agencies formed the task force to assess drought conditions, budget needs and firefighting strategies. Fire officials said that in some particularly endangered areas they will send more ground and air forces to fires as soon as they break out. But they acknowledged that they will be running a calculated risk because that will pull firefighters out of other areas that, in turn, could catch fire.

DOC.HEAD: Sacrificial Sheep To Be Sent To Poor Moslems
DOC.TEXT: Meat from half a million New Zealand sheep ritually slaughtered during this year's Moslem pilgrimage will be distributed to poor Moslems in 24 countries, a senior official said. Ahmed Mohammed Ali, president of the Islamic Development Bank which oversees the Sacrificial Meat Utilization Program, said Thursday that the operation will cost $37 million. The project _ a joint venture between the government and 45-member Islamic Development Bank _ was started in 1983 to make use of the meat that was otherwise left to rot in the desert. That year, only 63,000 sheep were slaughtered to mark the climax of the monthlong pilgrimage to Islam's holiest sites at Mecca and Medina. The meat was sent to three countries. The slaughter commemorates the willingness of the Prophet Abraham to sacrifice his son for God.

DOC.HEAD: Fires Destroy Hundreds of Homes, Scorch Thousands of Acres
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with number of homes destroyed in Santa Barbara now at 567, number in Glendale at 66; picks up 14th graf pvs, `Firefighters controlled ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphics; LaserPhotos STB1,3,4,7,8; LaserColor STB110
DOC.TEXT: Wildfires ignited by arson and accident crackled across Southern California on Thursday after ravaging more than 560 homes and other buildings in Santa Barbara County and more than 90 homes elsewhere. A U.S. Forest Service firefighting helicopter crashed in San Marcos Pass northwest of Santa Barbara, and the pilot broke his leg. The aviator was taken to a hospital, said Santa Barbara County spokesman Bill Douros. The National Weather Service said a return of gusts that fanned flames Wednesday was unlikely. Hot, dry winds had fanned the flames, which scorched 14,000 acres of brush in a four-county area north, east and south of Los Angeles. Fires also burned in Arizona, Colorado, Montana, Utah and Texas. A destructive blaze in the Los Angeles suburb of Glendale was contained after destroying or damaging 66 hillside homes Wednesday. No deaths were immediately reported. One person was severely burned in Santa Barbara and three firefighters were seriously injured in Riverside County, authorities said. Santa Barbara County, where rugged brush-covered hills rise sharply from the coastline, was hit hardest. A 4,000-acre arson fire that broke out late Wednesday near Santa Barbara and the nearby town of Goleta was one of the worst on record here. It continued to burn Thursday afternoon, and firefighters would offer no estimate of when it might be contained. ``The fire is incredible. It came down from the mountains. It spread everywhere. It burned everything in its path,'' said county sheriff's department spokesman Tim Grasey. The fire destroyed some neighborhoods; in other cases, it leaped over houses and left them standing improbably amid ruins. Desert winds up to 60 mph pushed the fire through the hills Wednesday night, giving some residents little time to flee. ``You're just lucky to have your life,'' said Kay O'Brien, who fled her home with her husband carrying only family pictures and a retirement watch. The home and all their possessions were lost. ``We woke up this morning and wanted to brush our teeth, but we didn't even have a toothbrush,'' she said. The toll in the Santa Barbara area was put at 567 homes and other buildings. Bill Wallace, a county supervisor, said the homes alone were worth $190 million, and said the damage figure could go as high as $500 million. Firefighters controlled blazes in Utah and at Yellowstone National Park in Montana, but other fires raged unchecked in Arizona, Texas and Colorado. In Arizona, where six firefighters died Tuesday, a lightning fire in the Tonto National Forest destroyed a cabin built in the 1920s by Western novelist Zane Grey. Two units of specially trained Wyoming Air National Guard firefighters have been ordered to California to help fight the wildfires raging out of control near Santa Barbara, said John Cornelison of the Wyoming Adjutant General's office. The soldiers will travel to the West Coast in two C-130 aircraft equipped with firefighting systems capable of dumping 3,000 gallons of fire retardant in less than eight seconds, Cornelison said. California Gov. George Deukmejian toured Santa Barbara and Glendale and declared states of emergency to release additional state money and pave the way for federal assistance. Deukmejian also authorized a $50,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the arsonist. Fire danger loomed high throughout Southern California, where the brush is parched by four years of drought. A heat wave entered its third day after setting record highs over 100 degrees in many areas. In Los Angeles County, a blaze in the hills above Clareont threatened a school and 10 houses. The 50-acre blaze started in the afternoon, and burned out of control, authorities said. In Glendale, residents of the hilly neighborhood struck by an arsonist sorted through the ashes, all that was left of many expensive homes. ``I guess we'll just tighten our belts and get on with life,'' said Dennie Gill, a produce wholesaler whose home was destroyed. ``It was a nice house.'' Witnesses said they saw one of two young men in a car toss a butane lighter into the brush off Verdugo Road, where the fire started, said Chris Gray, a battalion chief in the Glendale Fire Department. In Riverside County, a controlled burn that got out of hand when winds unexpectedly changed bore down on the city of Corona after destroying 12 homes and charring 2,200 acres, said Corona police Sgt. Rick Bourgault. ``Some of the smoldering areas came right up to the back yards of houses,'' said Bourgault. ``There's lots of smoke and hot spots. Some of the hot spots whipped up into pretty good fires.'' An arson blaze in the Carbon Canyon area of San Bernardino County blackened 6,640 acres and destroyed at least 14 homes, with hundreds more threatened, said Orange County Fire Department spokeswoman Maria Sobal. The fire was 50 percent contained and firefighters worked feverishly to beat rising winds, said California Department of Forestry spokeswoman Sharon Sellers. ``To make matters worse, fireworks go on sale today,'' she said. ``We're not happy about that.'' A man described as a transient was arrested for investigaton of arson in the Carbon Canyon blaze. Authorities said he sparked the blaze while trying to make coffee with two camp fires. Three inmates working as firefighters were in good condition recovering at Sherman Oaks Community Hospital after suffering first- and second-degree burns Wednesday in a 150-acre fire near Hemet, said hospital spokeswoman Johna Rogovin. ``The wind shifted on them really quickly and there was nothing they could do,'' said Riverside County Fire Department spokeswoman Deborah Bennett. The fire was contained early Thursday, she said. In the Moreno Valley area of the county, fire destroyed three homes and three outbuildings. Four firefighters were injured. In San Diego County, a fast-moving blaze erupted near Lake Henshaw, consuming 75 acres and forcing the evacuation of a Boy Scout camp, said California Department of Forestry spokeswoman Audrey Hagen. Four earlier brush fires blackened about 1,700 acres before firefighters contained the blazes.

DOC.HEAD: Latin Leaders Welcome Bush's Debt Plan For Latin America
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of Latin America's three biggest debtor nations all hailed President Bush's proposal to forgive billions of dollars of Latin American countries' foreign debt. Bush's plan to forgive part of the $12 billion owed by Latin American and Caribbean nations to the U.S. government was welcomed, too, by the head of the biggest American creditor bank. Latin American leaders also praised Bush's announcement Wednesday that the United States would work with Western European nations and Japan to channel up to $300 million annually to Latin America to spur foreign investment. Bush urged that work begin on a ``hemisphere-wide free trade zone,'' but this was received more cautiously by some Latin American governments. Latin American experts noted that Bush's proposal affects only a small part of Latin America's total foreign debt of more than $400 billion. Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello told Bush in a telephone call that his proposal was ``comprehensive, bold and innovative.'' Brazil's foreign debt of $114 billion is the biggest among developing nations. A spokesman for Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari _ the Third World's second-biggest debtor at $93 billion _ said Salinas considered Bush's speech ``a very important redefinition of the U.S. position regarding economic development in Latin America.'' President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina said he was ``satisfied'' with Bush's speech. Argentina's foreign debt of $66 billion ranks third in Latin America. Menem's spokesman Humberto Toledo said Bush's statements showed that the United States was not going to overlook the problems of Latin America because of changes in Eastern Europe, where formerly Communist nations also are seeking aid from the West. However, Argentine Economy Minister Antonio Erman Gonzalez said Bush's plan for a hemisphere-wide common market ``is not for the immediate future, it is a look at the medium- and long-term.'' John Reed, president of Citicorp, a large U.S. commercial bank that has $8 billion in loans to Latin America, said he welcomed Bush's initiative as a way to bring economic growth and prosperity to the region. Reed said Bush's proposal would meet the objections of commercial banks to the U.S. government's Third World debt plan outlined last year by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. Brady's plan offered incentives for commercial banks to write off some of their $1.3 trillion in Third World debt, but did not address the debt owed to the governments of the United States and other industrial nations. Commercial banks had argued they were being forced to shoulder the entire burden of debt reduction. American officials said smaller countries such as Honduras, El Salvador and Jamaica would benefit the most from Bush's debt forgiveness plan because a higher percentage of their foreign debt was to the U.S. government. Honduran President Rafael Callejas called Bush's announcement ``encouraging news.'' Officials said the United States would propose substantial writeoffs in the $7 billion in aid loans that U.S. government agencies have made at below-market interest rates to the most heavily burdened countries. The amount of debt forgiveness would depend on each country's willingness to undertake economic reforms under the supervision of the International Monetary Fund. The officials said the United States will also sell a portion of its $5 billion in market-rate loans to help facilitate debt-for-equity and debt-for-nature swaps. Bush said some of the U.S. government debt could be swapped to set aside environmentally endangered land.

DOC.HEAD: 320,000 Marooned In Flood
DOC.TEXT: Floods in northern Bangladesh have stranded more than 320,000 people, destroyed hundreds of homes and flooded thousands of acres of rice fields, news reports said. The most seriously affected areas were Sirajganj, 65 miles north of Dhaka, and the neighboring district of Bogra. Two children drowned in Sirajganj earlier this week. The Bengali-language newspaper, Sangbad, said Thursday that more than 300,000 people were marooned in Sirajganj and 20,000 people in Bogra. The newspaper said the Jamuna river and tributaries of the Barahmaputra breached their embankments, sweeping away mud-and-straw homes and flooding rice fields. The rivers began swelling last week with the onset of monsoon season and overflowed their banks on Monday. Bangladesh alternates between floods and droughts. The country is one of the world's poorest, with an annual per capita income of $168.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Inspect Damage After Devastating Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The 3,500-acre ...,' to UPDATE that 4,000 acres burned; SUBS 7th graf, `About 500 ...,' to UPDATE with 567 homes in Santa Barbara County, about 91 elsewhere destroyed.
DOC.TEXT: Neighbors along Via Las Padres consoled one another and surveyed the embers and ash that remained of their homes Thursday after fire swept down from the mountains and burned everything in its path. ``It was a beautiful neighborhood,'' Eric Lim said, as the remains of his house steamed behind him. ``It was a great place to grow up.'' The 4,000-acre brushfire that started Wednesday night cut a vicious swath through the suburban foothills of this coastal city, leveling entire neighborhoods. Few areas were harder hit than Park Highlands, a tightly knit enclave of $750,000 homes about 5 miles northwest of the city, with dramatic views of the coast below. Eighteen of 19 homes on one block of Via Las Padres were wholly consumed by flames. Lawns burned as though made of straw, and shrubbery and trees, parched from a 4-year-long drought, ignited like matches. The intense heat left a pool slide in one yard melted on its frame like a giant marshmallow. ``The fire is incredible. It came down from the mountains. It spread everywhere. It burned everything in its path,'' said Tim Grasey, spokesman for the Santa Barbara County Sheriff's Department. The fire destroyed 567 homes and other buildings in Santa Barbara County; county supervisor Bill Wallace said the homes alone were worth $190 million. Ninety-one homes were ravaged elsewhere in the region. ``I started reading the paper after I came home from work and then my 12-year-old said, `Daddy, the back yard is on fire,''' said Bryan Gaggs, whose home was untouched while those of two of his nearest neighbors were gutted. The Lims lost their home of 14 years, salvaging only a few personal effects and their cats. Across the street the Harveys stirred the ashes of what was once their dream home, filled with antiques and personal mementos. ``I can't find anything, there's nothing,'' Nancy Harvey said as she picked through what was once her kitchen. ``I'm hoping to find my address book.'' Her daughter, Tiffany, poked around the spot in the living room where the family's television set had stood. ``I'm looking from my necklace,'' she told her mother. ``I left it here last night.'' Don Anderson, who lives next to the Lims, said he stayed on his roof with a hose in hand until the heat and smoke became intolerable. ``I stood up there and for a while I though we were going to be OK, that we would be at the bottom of the fire and that it would miss us,'' he said. ``And then it suddenly got very smoky and I yelled back to the Lims `Can you see the flames?' When he said `Yes' I knew it was time to go.'' Anderson's home was leveled. The skeletal remains of a Jacuzzi tub were the only signs of a recent $250,000 remodeling job. ``I think the water shortage definitely contributed to this fire,'' said Dale Hanst, whose house survived. ``If people had been able to water their foliage, a lot of the homes would have been saved.'' While some families wept hopelessly over their losses, others kept their sense of humor. Nancy Harvey said she was confident that valuables in the family safe were unharmed. ``But I had the combination for it written in the bottom of my desk drawer,'' she said with a laugh.

DOC.HEAD: On Sunday, A Major Stride Toward German Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The two German states on Sunday take their biggest step toward ending the four decades of division imposed after World War II, once again sharing a common currency and economy. They will also share uncertainty: over everything from a united Germany's military role to their new nation's name. East Germans worry about their jobs. West Germans wonder if their Eastern cousins remember how to work. Many Germans are still stunned by the pace of change since the ouster of East German Communist leader Erich Honecker last October. His downfall ended 40 years of iron-fisted Stalinist rule that followed the war. Merging the two nations without skipping too many beats in West Germany's mighty economic rhythm is going to be difficult. Even Theo Waigel, the passionately pro-unification finance minister in Bonn, has acknowledged that Germany is embarking on an ``economic adventure.'' In one stroke Sunday, most East Germans will get thousands of dollars' worth of West German marks, which will become the common currency for both sides. The West German mark will replace the virtually worthless East German currency, and state-run businesses in East Germany will be forced to compete for customers to survive. There are countless scenarios of what might happen between Sunday and early December, when Bonn hopes to see full unification completed. Depending on who is talking, unemployment in East Germany could hit several hundred thousand, 4 million, or almost anywhere in between. Unrest and disturbances are possible, some experts say, as East Germans come back from their newly affordable summer vactions in Venice, Mallorca and elsewhere to find they have no jobs. Others see inflation topping 10 percent, or nearly three times its current pace. In Berlin and at other points along the rapidly disappearing border between East and West, Germans are eager to talk about their concerns. ``Basically, we are happy,'' says Wilfriede Dybowski of East Berlin. ``But we don't know what's going to happen to our jobs, or whether we can face up to the new competition. We're pretty worried.'' Ms. Dybowski works for Deutsche Schallplatten GmbH, a company that makes and assembles compact discs and records. Like thousands of East German businesses, it must get rid of the country's own products to make way for Western goods. ``We also have to cut the number of workers to the minimum possible,'' said the smiling, 55-year-old Ms. Dybowski. ``We hope to stay in business.'' Just 100 yards away from Ms. Dybowski on the Western side of the Berlin Wall, an elderly West Berlin man gave a gloomy assessment. ``The East Germans have forgotten how to work,'' said Hubert Enzenross, 70. ``And my pension won't be going up that much. All the money has to go over there to the East.'' Enzenross added: ``It's good that communism has fallen. As for the rest, it's just not clear.'' The Berlin native stood in the shadow of the Reichstag, the imposing, history-laden parliament building that could one day become the seat of the new country's legislature. The euphoria over the crumbling of the Berlin Wall last fall has been replaced by a sober realization that unification will cause discomfort in the short term. Still, virtually everyone agrees the bold experiment will pay off in the long run. ``We are hammering Berlin back together,'' has become the city's motto. That saying is both figurative and literal, as work crews rejoin pipes, wires, subway lines and other vital links hacked asunder in 1961. Along the borders between the two countries, the once impenetrable Communist fences and walls are being hauled into the scrapheap of history as quickly as crews can work. Pedestrians and passenger cars at many points cross freely back and forth, as bored East German guards stroll around or listen to the latest Western rock music on the radio. Thousands of details remain to be worked out in the coming months, ranging from placating Soviet objections to NATO membership for the joined country to meshing the two legal systems. West Berlin Mayor Walter Momper infuriated many by proposing that West Germany adopt some East German laws, specifically a highway speed limit and a ban on drinking and driving. It is uncertain what the new nation with nearly 80 million people will be called. Some have objected to the single name ``Deutschland,'' or Germany, saying it would call to mind too many memories of the same-named country that unleashed Nazi terror on Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Paul McCartney Gives Concert In Liverpool
DOC.TEXT: Paul McCartney returned to Liverpool, the birthplace of the Beatles, and staged a concert that rolled back 30 years for 50,000 delighted fans. ``We're going back through the mists of time to a place they call the '60s,'' he told the cheering capacity audience Thursday in the stadium built specially for the concert in the northwestern port city. The 2{-hour concert was part of McCartney's world tour, which began last September. It featured Beatles hits from the 1960s, music from McCartney's group Wings and from his solo career. Two giant video screens at each side of the stage offered shots of vintage stage performances mixed with grim images from Vietnam, and last year's massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. When McCartney took the stage, 20,000 helium-filled balloons were released into a sky cleared of traffic by flight controllers to permit the spectacular stunt. Hits like ``Jet'' and ``Band On The Run'' from the Wings era warmed the audience up for the music most had really come to hear _ the classic Beatles sounds. As dusk fell, McCartney sang the Beatles tune, ``The Long And Winding Road'' and then announced: ``I want to dedicate the next one to three mates of mine, John, George and Ringo.'' He then launched into ``The Fool On The Hill,'' followed by ``Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band,'' ``Good Day Sunshine,'' ``Can't Buy Me Love,'' ``Eleanor Rigby,'' ``Let It Be,'' and ``I Saw Her Standing There.'' Then came McCartney's promised tribute to songwriting partner John Lennon, slain by a gunman in New York City on Dec. 8, 1980. He then sang Beatles songs composed by Lennon such as ``Strawberry Fields'' and ``Help,'' and concluded with ``Give Peace A Chance.'' The most spectacular piece of the show was his James Bond movie theme ``Live and Let Die,'' sung to a dramatic accompaniment of fireworks and laser beams. As an encore, McCartney returned alone to perform ``Yesterday'' on solo guitar before being joined by the rest of the band for a rousing rendition of ``Get Back.'' The Beatles _ McCartney, Lennon, George Harrison and Ringo Starr _ split up in 1970 amid bitter wrangles over money.

DOC.HEAD: If There's Intelligence in Baseball and Baseball at the CIA ...
DOC.TEXT: About 500 people employed by America's top spy agency gathered at CIA headquarters this week for some high-powered talks. The subject? Baseball. ``Many here have found that baseball is particularly compatible with intelligence,'' CIA Director William Webster, a die-hard St. Louis Cardinals fan, told the group. ``Both could be called `the sport of the long season,''' Webster said. ``Both demand the long view, a need for teamwork, a demand for individual performance. Both require excellence and precision.'' Webster had invited Eli Jacobs, owner of the Baltimore Orioles, intelligence expert and well-known figure in some Capitol Hill circles, to talk to CIA employees about ``The Art, Science and Philosophy of Baseball.'' Jacobs was joined at the Langley, Va., headquarters by Orioles manager Frank Robinson and syndicated columnist George Will, an Orioles director and a Chicago Cubs booster. Addressing men and women whose lives often are filled with the international intrigue that make thriller novels, Webster said of Jacobs: ``It is as owner of the Baltimore Orioles that he has come closest to living out our dreams. To have your own baseball team _ now that's something to aspire to.'' Webster, who was a federal judge in St. Louis before he came to Washington, also made some lighthearted remarks about his team _ they're last in the National League East these days. As a lawyer, the CIA chief handled the estate of legendary general manager Branch Rickey, best known for integrating baseball by hiring Jackie Robinson for the Brooklyn Dodgers. According to CIA spokesman Mark Mansfield, Webster also did some work for the old St. Louis Browns, who later moved to Baltimore and became the Orioles. While many of the nation's spies _ Webster included _ are mesmerized by baseball, Jacobs has spent a lot of his time recently on intelligence matters. The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence named Jacobs head of an unpaid blue-ribbon panel to study future counterintelligence needs. The group has recommended ways to crack down on spying. And the revolving door doesn't stop there. Sven Holmes, a protege of Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., and the committee's former staff director, now does legal work for Jacobs and the Orioles. Boren is chairman of the intelligence committee. In a bipartisan vein, Jacobs recently hired Tom Daffron, former administrative assistant to Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, as the Orioles' senior vice president. Cohen is the ranking Republican on the intelligence committee. ``I have two great passions _ politics and baseball,'' Daffron said. ``I've gotten to work in both areas.''

DOC.HEAD: West German Marks Are Bigger And Better
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Germany-Unification
DOC.TEXT: Just by looking at and holding the two German currencies, you know which one is more important. West German bills are bigger and West German coins are better than their flimsy, soon-to-be-extinct counterparts across the border. Take the 10-mark bill. Worth about $6, the 5-inch by 2.5-inch western edition is illustrated with a curly haired, anonymous renaissance figure. On its back, there's a historic sailing ship. The East German version, now worth about $1.50, is half an inch narrower and slightly shorter, and has a portrait of Clara Zetkin, a Communist figure from the 1920s. The rear side shows a young woman wearing a white laboratory coat and glaring at a battery of dials and buttons that could be straight out of a bad science fiction movie. Presumably, she symbolizes science. Like other Eastern European currencies, most East German coins are made of featherweight aluminium, prompting a giggle from most Western visitors. By coincidence, the West German central bank is issuing a new 100-mark bill, worth about $60.60, which shows the city of Leipzig, now in East Germany. The bill will come into circulation on Oct. 1 but had been planned long before the July 1 currency union was announced, according to the bank.

DOC.HEAD: Vavuniya One of Hundreds of Ghost Towns Emptied by War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers clad in black T-shirts reading ``We kill for peace'' lounge near a Buddhist temple, smoking cigarettes and cracking jokes. Their automatic weapons lean against a nearby wall. Shops and offices on the town's narrow main street are boarded up and deserted. A sole army jeeps speeds along the road. Welcome to Vavuniya, one of hundreds of cities left ghost towns by a 7-year-old civil war. More than 450,000 people have fled the country's northern and eastern sectors since a resurgence of fighting June 11 between militant Tamil separatists and government troops. At least 1,679 combatants have been killed since the fighting broke out, including civilians killed during government raids on rebel hideouts. The government acknowledged it killed civilians during such raids this week on the city of Jaffna. Vavuniya, 135 miles northeast of Colombo, is the first northern settlement on the road to the Jaffna peninsula, a stronghold of Tamil rebels fighting for an independent homeland. Rebels seized Vavuniya shortly after they began overrunning police stations and attacking military camps June 11. Government troops counterattacked five days later, recapturing the town after a battle in which nine soldiers and at least 67 rebels were reported killed. Twelve civilians also died in the fighting. Since then, the town, which once had 18,000 residents, has emptied. Most people have gone to distant villages to live with relatives. ``We cleared the town of people and have sealed off the three main entrances after recapturing the area,'' said Brig. Sathis Jayasuriya, army chief in Vavuniya. ``But the rebels are still capable of laying ambushes on the outskirts of the town,'' he added. The fight for Vavuniya is typical of combat ravaging hundreds of villages, which has left hundreds of thousands of people homeless. After taking Vavuniya, Tamil rebels built sandbagged bunkers on the streets and painted colorful pictures of dead comrades on building walls. Now Vavuniya is occupied by government troops, who man posts at three strategic junctions. At one, a government soldier draped a belt of machine-gun bullets around his neck. ``We have to be extremely careful since it is easy for the rebels to gain access to (the) town and attack civilian targets with bombs,'' the soldier said. On Tuesday, rebels ambushed and killed five soldiers on a road clearing operation at Madukanda village, north of Vavuniya. ``We have learned from our past mistakes and are now capable of destroying the rebels,'' said a young colonel, Parami Kulatunga. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The rebels claim they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of the population. In Vavuniya, long considered rebel country, nearly 80 percent of the population was Tamil. The rest were Sinhalese and Moslem. ``The (Tamil) Tigers have to be destroyed,'' said Kirith Seneviratne, a Sinhalese clerk who fled Vavuniya for a refugee camp. ``Both communities have lived together for so many years, but now it is a case of finishing them off.''

DOC.HEAD: British Political Journalist Robert Carvel Dead at 71
DOC.TEXT: Robert Carvel, one of Britain's best-known political journalists, has died, his family said. He was 71. Carvel was hospitalized last week after a heart attack. He suffered a second heart attack that proved fatal Thursday. The Scottish-born Carvel became political editor of the Evening Standard in 1960. Before that, he had worked for the Daily Express. Carvel retired from his post with the Evening Standard in 1985 but continued to serve as a political consultant for the paper. He also worked for the British Broadcasting Corp. For many years he was the main anchor for BBC radio's weekly program on events in Parliament, ``The Week in Westminster.'' He also appeared regularly on other news and current affairs programs on BBC radio and BBC TV, and his Scottish accent became well known to a generation of listeners and viewers. He is survived by his wife and a son who is a senior journalist with The Guardian.

DOC.HEAD: Course Opens Early Tee Times To Women
DOC.TEXT: Fearing pickets on the links, a Veterans of Foreign Wars post lifted a policy banning women from its golf course before 11 a.m. on weekends and holidays. The Hickory VFW Golf Course adopted the policy after its nine-man governing board claimed women play too slowly during the prime hours for duffers. At least one woman who plays the course frequently protested the policy, spawning publicity that drew television crews, telephone calls and letters. Course manager Don Wilson defended the policy but decided to change it Thursday when some players threatened to picket the course this Saturday. ``With the letters I'm getting and the statements I'm getting from some of the men, I don't want to see those two groups get together,'' he said. ``If somebody got hurt out here, I would take it personally.'' He had said the no-women policy was designed to enable more people to play on the course at peak times, keeping costs down.

Midway Returns to Sea After Explosion
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. aircraft carrier Midway returned to the western Pacific today for routine flight operations, nine days after an explosion that killed three crewmen. The cause of the June 20 blast, which also injured 15 crew members, is still under investigation, said Senior Chief Petty Officer Gary Gunderson at the Navy's public affairs office. After the 67,000-ton vessel returned to port last Thursday, joint exercises with Japan's Maritime Self-Defense Force were canceled. The explosion occurred in an emergency equipment storeroom when a firefighting crew opened the hatch to investigate smoke. Navy officials have said the room was near lines carrying steam heated to 850 degrees Fahrenheit for the ship's plane-launching catapult system.

DOC.HEAD: As The Cameras Roll, `You're Under Arrest!'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Note contents throughout
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Barry Trial Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The people of Washington have now seen _ over and over _ their mayor on television, acting very unmayorlike. Marion Barry is in a hotel room with a beautiful woman, in shirtsleeves, engaging in, the government says, a criminal act: smoking crack cocaine. The videotape picture is from the three hidden cameras used in an FBI sting operation. The picture is fuzzy. The jurors will have to decide what it proves. But the mayor already has admitted he smoked crack in the Vista International Hotel on the evening of Jan. 18 with ex-model Rasheeda Moore. She is the magazine covergirl and mayoral girlfriend who cooperated with the FBI in setting up the sting. On the tape, the smoking is quick and perfunctory _ a puff or two, the mayor prepares to leave, and the police burst in. ``FBI! FBI!'' they shout, running past the secret cameras. ```You're under arrest!'' But the high drama comes in the mayor's reaction. He knows he is trapped, but he can't accept it. He curses his fate, he curses Moore, he curses the situation. ``I'll be God damned,'' he says. ``She set me up.'' He says it over and over. Barry, 54, is in his third term. Before that he served on the city school board. The son of a sharecropper, he was a civil rights activist in the 1960s. He used to wear a dashiki around town. He once lectured a welfare mother for having too many children. Until his arrest he lectured schoolchildren about drugs. Dubbed ``mayor for life'' by a local alternative weekly newspaper, City Paper, Barry seemed unbeatable. Now he is on trial charged with perjury and drug possession. He has pleaded innocent and renounced re-election plans. There had been rumors for years about his personal life. They were given substance by the tape, played over and over on local stations from the moment it became evidence at his trial Thursday afternoon. He asks Moore, ``Can we make love before you leave, before you leave town? It would be a good idea just for old time sake, you know, catch up.'' She spurns him. They are on the bed. He is in a suit, minus jacket, and she is wearing billowing pants and a silky jacket. He asks: ``I can't caress your breast?'' She changes the subject. Moore has testified that their romancing and their use of drugs started in 1986. She said they used drugs together ``at least 100 times,'' in 22 different places. She once delivered drugs to him in his office, she said. On the tape, they drink cognac. He paces. He sits on the bed. He preens before a mirror. He gives her some money for ``Wanda'' _ an FBI plant _ to make a purchase. When Wanda delivers, they argue over who will fill the crack pipe. ``You do it,'' he says. ``No, you do it,'' she says. He does it. The pipe is smoked, Barry puts on his jacket to leave, and the lawmen have seen enough: they break in. Moore is hustled out of there. The mayor knows what's up. ``That was a good setup, wasn't it?'' he says. He is told to put his arms against the wall. He complies. His situation sinks in. ``I shouldn't have come up here,'' he says. ``I'll be damned.'' ``How'd I get tricked into this stuff?'' An agent reads him his rights, but Barry pays no heed. He is still establishing the dimensions of his dilemma. ``That was a setup,'' he says. ``You have the right to remain silent...,'' says the agent. ``I'll be God damned,'' says the mayor. ``... You also have the right to stop answering ...'' ``Bitch set me up.'' ``... at any time until you talk to a lawyer.'' ``She set me up.'' The FBI worries about its suspect's health. He has a history of heart trouble. He lets medical technicians take his blood pressure, monitor his heart, check his vital signs. He curses: ``I shouldn't have come up here.'' The lawmen call him, ``Mr. Mayor.'' They explain they will provide ``a maximum of decorum, under the circumstances.'' ``We're not going to parade you through the lobby,'' an agent says. The FBI, he says, will provide cars with blacked-out windows. Barry will be booked and brought before a judge and will not have to spend the night in jail. He is not listening. He has one thing on his mind. ``I should have stayed downstairs,'' he says. ``God damn.''

DOC.HEAD: Renaissance Ship, Once Embarrassing, Now Celebrated
DOC.TEXT: What was a national embarrasment three centuries ago _ a warship that sank 15 minutes into its maiden voyage _ is now prominently displayed in a new museum. The dockside museum opened this month to display the Vasa, which capsized in Stockholm harbor in 1628, killing about 50 of the dignitaries and sailors on board. The 200-foot-long warship bore the family name of King Gustavus II Adolphus, who had ordered it built to support his military campaigns in eastern Europe. Nobody dared tell Gustavus _ eager to get the vessel into action _ that it was dangerously unsteady. A test involving 30 men running from side to side across the Vasa's deck was halted when it appeared that one more run would tip her over. It took only a puff of wind to capsize the Vasa barely a mile from where it was launched. It sank in 110 feet of water and remained there until 1961, when it was raised and placed in an aluminum shed. Now, in the $35 million museum, tourists can use computer simulations to try to make the Vasa seaworthy. Using computer screens, museum-goers can add ballast, remove guns and change the boat's dimensions. Using mathematical formulas, the computers tell visitors whether their redesigned boat will float and whether the king would have been satisfied. Two years and 1,000 oak trees were invested in the Vasa. The ship's commanders simply loaded 64 heavy cannons on board, hoisted sail and hoped for the best. Shipbuilding was not an exact science in those days and there are several possible reasons why the Vasa turned out badly even though it was neither larger than other ships of the period nor of a radically different design. One of the factors might have been the death during the project of the Dutch shipbulder who supervised the job. Another may have been an order by Gustavus to add a second gun deck, thus making the Vasa unusually top-heavy. A royal inquiry found no one guilty in the ship's sinking. The court could not determine whether the Vasa was too narrow below the waterline, too heavy above it, or whether it needed more ballast to make it sail upright. The new museum tells the story with slides and ship models. Frescoes and full-size human carvings recall intellectual and political themes of the 17th century, and give the flavor of life in old Stockholm. Some visitors have criticized the building, which they say is as poorly designed as the Vasa. The museum resembles a copper-clad barn with masts. Inside, some exhibits are dimly lit and some explanatory labels are placed at knee-level. But the museum allows visitors to see the Vasa close up, from all sides and on several levels. The ship came largely intact from its centuries in the mud, because the Baltic Sea's water has little salt and wood-eating marine worms don't live there. Its once-gaudily painted hull is blackened but hundreds of sculptures that adorned her stern and upper decks survived in remarkable detail. Objects recovered from the Vasa on view include sailors' clothes, tools and games. Visitors can walk through a replica of the upper gun deck and examine a 23-foot-long model of the Vasa, which took 13,000 hours to build and shows the 20,000 nails used in the original. Swedish engineer Anders Franzen, an amateur marine archeologist, found the Vasa in 1956. The vessel was raised five years later and placed until two years ago in a temporary aluminum shed, visited by more than 11 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Tape: Plenty of Grist, But No Compelling Evidence of Entrapment
With PM-Barry Trial Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: A videotape showing Marion Barry smoking crack cocaine gives defense lawyers plenty of grist but little compelling evidence to argue that the mayor was entrapped by the FBI. The tape, played Thursday for jurors at the mayor's drug and perjury trial in U.S. District Court, shows Barry taking a makeshift pipe, putting it to his mouth and inhaling the smoke of burning crack cocaine. Barry takes a second ``hit'' on the pipe and puts on his suit jacket before FBI agents and police storm into the downtown hotel room to arrest him. R. Kenneth Mundy, Barry's chief defense lawyer, has argued that the mayor was an inexperienced drug user who was lured to the hotel room by a former girlfriend, Rasheeda Moore. The former model testified that Barry was reluctant to come up to her room at the Vista International Hotel. In a recorded telephone call, the mayor said ``there are too many nosy rosies around.'' This and other comments by the mayor before he smokes the crack will undoubtedly be cited by Mundy to try to convince jurors that Barry was pressured into doing something he didn't want to do. The videotaped conversation between Barry and Moore gives Mundy some basis for this argument. But it also contains statements from Barry that prosecutors can cite to argue that the mayor was an experienced drug user who willingly purchased and smoked the illegal drug. For instance, Barry alludes to prior drug use, saying at one point, ``I don't smoke no more, honey.'' At another point, he tells her: ``Go get some. Go get it.'' At another, the mayor asks Moore if she has a pipe to smoke the crack. The mayor voices reluctance to smoke the cocaine unless Moore joined in. But Moore spurns his repeated requests, saying ``it makes me too hyper, I get really hyper.'' ``If you don't do it, I'm not going to do it,'' the mayor says. Richard Ben-Veniste, a Washington defense attorney, said Mundy can ``highlight the means under which the recorded portion of the evidence was set up.'' ``You can point to the fact that the government brought the witness here, to be used as a decoy, paid for her bills at the beauty parlor, babysat her children'' to help the FBI catch the mayor, he said. ``In this case, I think there is substantial ammunition if you are dealing only with that incident,'' Ben-Veniste said. But the law of entrapment requires the defendant to show that he would not have performed the illegal act unless pressured by the police. Moore has testified that she and the mayor used cocaine more than 100 times on previous occasions. Convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis recounted a series of episodes of cocaine use with Barry. ``The amount of information that has been brought forward is staggering in terms of the extent of drug use that is now alleged by witnesses under oath,'' Ben-Veniste said. ``It certainly helps them (prosecutors) rebut any argument of entrapment on the basis of disposition,'' he said. Joseph diGenova, a former U.S. attorney who investigated Barry for many years without bringing any charges, said the tape doesn't help the entrapment argument. ``He gave her money for the drugs, he waited for the drugs, he never said during the entire time, `I don't do drugs' or `take those away,''' diGenova said. ``She didn't force it on him,'' the former prosecutor said. ``He goes over and picks up the pipe and lights it himself.'' Even though Barry tried in vain to persuade Moore to take the pipe first, ``he didn't walk out, he didn't say `I won't use it,''' diGenova said. ``She decided not to, so he went first.'' ``It's very interesting, he never puts his coat on to leave until he takes the second hit of the cocaine,'' diGenova said. ``Then he puts the coat (on) ... That's the image that the jury is going to remember.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: James Rowley covers the Justice Department for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: But Once The Party is Over ...
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Of all the places to go on the Fourth of July, it's London that President Bush heads for while Americans at home pack their picnic baskets and take to the park to watch the fireworks. London is where George III operated and, if you believe what they told you in the sixth grade, gave the orders oppressing the American colonists until they threw him overboard along with the tea and formed these United States. Bush, who raised flag-waving to a campaign issue in 1988, is not the sort to forget such patriotic events as Independence Day. But the celebration he will attend on July 5-6 in London is of an entirely different sort. After 41 years of nuclear standoff and tensions, the Cold War struggle with the Soviet Union is over. All that remains of the Berlin Wall is a cold slab that symbolizes the past but no longer blocks transit from East to West. Last week, the sentry post Checkpoint Charlie was hauled away. The Warsaw Pact is disintegrating. East Germany is on the brink of absorption into West Germany. While some Soviet troops may remain on East German soil for a transitional period, the new and larger Germany appears headed for NATO membership. The Soviets are trying to delay the process while also appealing to the Western allies to withdraw all foreign forces from Germany. The strategy is not succeeding, even though Russians are not the only people in Europe worried about German resurgence. The Western leaders concluded the best insurance is NATO membership for Germany and letting the Germans decide whether they want Western troops on their territory. Hungary is heading for the exit, too, leaving the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact with a future that could be brief. Without two of its seven members, and some of the others fitfully restive, the alliance is dwindling into an inconsequential state. Bush and his summit partners no doubt will toast their victory, with perhaps a bit of gloating. The phrase ``Europe, Whole and Free,'' already a cliche, will resonate throughout the two-day London summit meeting, with just a proper amount of mournful warnings that the Soviets still have 5 million men under arms and an arsenal of 25,000 nuclear weapons. The American president and his partners will talk about reshaping NATO, trying to find a way to keep the Western alliance in business even after its principal task _ containing the Soviet Union _ may soon be academic. Much will be said about two key NATO doctrines: flexible response and forward basing. The first refers to deploying nuclear weapons in Europe along with conventional arms, and threatening to use them. The second refers to the strategic commitment to defend the West German border with East Germany. The nuclear threat is supposed to offset the Warsaw Pact's advantage in non-nuclear forces. There are 398,000 American, British, French, Belgian, Canadian and Dutch soldiers in West Germany _ 18,000 more than the 380,000 the Soviets have in East Germany. But the Warsaw Pact has an advantage of about 2 to 1 in tanks and artillery. Most of the Soviet troops will leave, either under the pressure of German unification or through a treaty being negotiated between NATO and the Warsaw Pact in Vienna. So will a lot of tanks and artillery pieces. The question facing Bush, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, President Francois Mitterrand of France and the other allied leaders is whether to revise NATO doctrine and remove, or at least play down, the nuclear threat. As for NATO strategy, it obviously no longer makes sense to make plans to defend a border between East and West Germany that will soon disappear. But those are the kinds of tough questions that will take a long time to answer. Right now, celebration is the order of the day.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid will report on the NATO summit for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Vacation in Maine, Prepare for NATO, Economic Meetings
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Bush leaves Washington 12:15 p.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is spending a long holiday weekend at his Maine vacation home to enjoy some recreation and bone up for a busy week of meetings with international allies. Bush was flying today to the resort town of Kennebunkport, Maine, where he vacations every summer at his family's oceanfront home on Walker's Point. The president had no business scheduled for the weekend. But he will be joined by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other advisers from Washington on Monday for strategy sessions before next week's NATO summit in London, and the economic summit of seven industrialized nations in Houston beginning July 9. Cheney and Bush are expected to discuss, among other things, the East-West conventional force reduction talks in Vienna and the alliance's response to the dramatic changes that have swept the Soviet bloc. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft was accompanying Bush to Maine for the full six days there. Scowcroft frequently serves as a golf partner for the president during Kennebunkport vacations. Bush this weekend also was expected to engage in his usual smorgasbord of fishing, running, tennis, swimming and racing around in his speedboat Fidelity. The president will fly from Kennebunkport to London on Wednesday evening July 4, and from London to Houston on Friday. On that Saturday, July 7, he is expected to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu in advance of the meetings with the other economic summit partners. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Thursday that Bush likely will ask the NATO allies to issue a declaration that they do not pose a threat to nations of the Warsaw Pact. The declaration would be intended to calm Moscow's anxieties about a united Germany being a military and political member of the 16-member NATO alliance. Looming for likely discussion in both London and Houston is the suggestion by some allies that a package of economic aid be presented to the Soviet Union to help its ravaged economy. But Baker told reporters it is premature for the United States to give cash aid to the Soviet Union. Instead, he suggested that the economic summit nations consider guidelines for financial assistance for Moscow. Western European leaders on Wednesday agreed in principle to aid Moscow but have not considered specific proposals or amounts, and some analysts have suggested trading such aid for Soviet military cutbacks. West Germany already is guaranteeing loans to the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Shoe Leather for East Asia Equals More Money for U.S. Cattlemen
DOC.TEXT: A strong demand for cattle hides used to make shoes in several East Asian countries has translated into extra money for U.S. beef producers, according to Agriculture Department economists. It's a package deal, though, because hides are simply the outside wrappers for cattle. And it's what inside that counts most for American beef eaters and producers. For example, according to analysts in the department's Economic Research Service, if an 1,100-pound steer sold for $70 per 100 pounds of live weight, it brought its owner $770. As a rule of thumb, the hide is worth about $1 per pound, with its weight at around 55 pounds, on the average. So $55 of the $770 would be for the hide. When cattle go to the packing plant, they are paid for on the basis of live weight. That is what the farmer, rancher or feedlot operator is paid as owner of the animals. The packer kills and separates various parts, including the red meat for consumers, tallow, hides and other offal. Economist Larry Duewer said that as of June 9 the offal value in a typical slaughter steer averaged about $8.50 per 100 pounds of the animal's live weight. That included the hide. ``If cattle are selling for $70 (per hundredweight), $8.50 of that is the hide and offal value, and I think at least half of that $8.50 is hides,'' Duewer said Thursday in a telephone interview. The producer is paid on the basis of the live weight of the whole animal. Consumers, however, buy only the edible parts of cattle, which are segregated by the packer from the offal and have their own prices. Thus, Duewer said, higher prices for hides are not supposed to be linked with the cost of red meat at the supermarket. But the hide market is important to the cattle producer. ``It definitely gives him more money, and technically, it shouldn't affect the price of beef for consumers,'' he said. Christine Bolling, another USDA economist, says the American demand for high-priced sports shoes has helped buoy the hide market, particularly exports to South Korea and Taiwan. Those countries import the hides, make them into shoes and ship them back to the United States. These are quality athletic footwear selling for $50 and up. South Korea, second only to Italy as a shoe exporter, shipped more than 150 million pairs valued at $2.3 billion to the United States in 1988, compared with 25 million pairs in 1982, Bolling said in the July issue of Farmline magazine. Taiwan shipped 120 million pairs of leather shoes to the United States in 1988. Those had an export value of $1.4 billion. Japan is the third major importer of U.S. cattle hides among the Asian nations, but its footwear emphasis differs from that of South Korea and Taiwan since it focuses on meeting domestic footwear needs. With rising per capita disposable incomes, the Japanese are ``demanding more upscale products like leather shoes,'' Bolling said.

A new survey by the Agriculture Department shows corn farmers have planted 74.6 million acres for 1990 production, up 3 percent from last year's 72.3 million acres. The new plantings figures announced Thursday were down only fractionally from 74.8 million acres of corn indicated in a March survey of farmers, despite delays in some areas because of wet weather. Soybean plantings were estimated at 58 million acres, down 4 percent from 1989, the report said. And that was down from the 59.4 million acres of beans farmers had indicated in the March survey. Cotton plantings, at 12.4 million acres, are up 17 percent from last year and the same as indicated in March. The 1990 tobacco crop is being planted on 725,000 acres, up 7 percent from 1990 but down from the 731,000 acres indicated by the March survey. All wheat plantings were shown at 77.3 million acres, up 1 percent from 1989. The March survey showed total wheat at 77.6 million acres. The report did not include 1990 production forecasts. New wheat figures will be issued by USDA on July 12, and estimates for corn and other spring-planted crops on Aug. 9. Meanwhile, a related report showed the nation's corn inventory as of June 1 was an estimated 2.84 billion bushels, down 17 percent from a year earlier. Of the total, 1.62 billion bushels were stored on farms. The use of corn in March, April and May was estimated at 1.97 billion bushels, up 11 percent from ``disappearance'' in the second quarter of 1989, the report said. Stocks of old-crop wheat on June 1, the beginning of the new wheat marketing year, were reported at 535 million bushels, down 24 percent from a year ago and the smallest carryover since 1975. Even so, that was much larger than the 452 million bushels estimated previously. The soybean stockpile at 596 million bushels on June 1 was up 28 percent from a year earlier.

A one-year experiment to exempt imports of Canadian meat and poultry from U.S. border inspection is being considered by the Agriculture Department as a move toward freer trade between the two countries. Ronald J. Prucha, associate administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said Thursday the products would still be thoroughly inspected at slaughter and processing plants in Canada under a system that is nearly identical to U.S. inspection. However, he said, Canadian products in the proposed one-year experiment would no longer be randomly sampled at the border. A reciprocal arrangement would be used for U.S. meat and poultry products entering Canada. Prucha said the proposal would help implement the United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement. The proposal will be open for public comments through July 30 before a final decision is made. Comments can be sent to: FSIS Hearing Clerk, Attn: Linda Carey, Room 3171, South Building, USDA, Washington, D.C. 20250.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett: More Drug Treatment Needed, But Not `Treatment on Demand'
DOC.TEXT: The country needs to boost the number of drug treatment slots, but ``treatment on demand'' is a bad idea, the nation's drug control policy director says. Taxpayers should not be asked to support a program ``governed by the whim and caprice of people who are on drugs,'' William J. Bennett, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, said Thursday. Many drug abusers start and stop treatment programs repeatedly without ever completing one, he said at a White House news conference. The goal, Bennett said, is ``to have sufficient capacity to provide treatment for people who will benefit from it and who are serious about undergoing the process of treatment.'' The Bush administration is seeking $1.5 billion for drug treatment next year, a 68 percent increase over the budget when President Bush took office. If the money is approved and states match the federal effort, there will be treatment slots for 1.9 million people by the end of fiscal 1991, said Dr. Herbert Kleber, Bennett's deputy director for drug demand reduction. Kleber estimated that up to 2.5 million people need treatment. The most recent treatment capacity figure is for 1987, he said, when there were slots available for 800,000 people. The government estimates there are 4 million to 6 million addicts nationwide, of whom about one-quarter can stop using drugs on their own and another quarter won't stop using drugs no matter what, Kleber said. The rest need formal treatment programs, he said. Bennett and Kleber spoke at a news conference with Louis W. Sullivan, secretary of health and human services, to announce the publication of a report called ``Understanding Drug Treatment.'' Bennett conceded the report does not break any new ground but instead is a compilation of knowledge on the matter written in layman's terms to prompt interest in the subject. The report notes that some hindrances to increasing the number of treatment slots are a lack of trained staff and community resistance to locating new treatment programs in neighborhoods where they are needed. Bennett dismissed arguments often raised by congressional Democrats that he cares more about law enforcement than treatment, and that the drug war budget reflects that bias by devoting 70 percent to law enforcement efforts. ``I have always believed that effective drug treatment must be an integral part of any successful national drug control strategy,'' Bennett said. ``And the more I've seen and learned about good drug treatment, the more convinced I've become.'' Sullivan called treatment ``one of the most important tools we have in alleviating the pain and misery that drug addiction has wrought upon our nation.'' But it isn't easy, the report said. ``Success often comes only after a relapse into drug use and further treatment, which complicates attempts to measure the efficacy of any single treatment program,'' the report says. ``... Drug treatment may be deemed successful when, three to five years after treatment, a former addict is no longer using drugs.'' Said Bennett: ``For some who get into drugs, there is no salvation. We believe very much in treatment's possibilities, but we also know that some stories that begin with drugs do not, and will not ever have happy endings.'' The report noted that people with more resources and more at stake ``do much better than those who have nothing to lose.'' Bennett has asked Congress to require that states develop treatment plans and he wants federal funds spent only on programs that work. He acknowledged that different measures of success would be needed based on differing clienteles. Kleber said an index has been developed that accounts for differences in patient backgrounds and ``enables you to start with a level playing field'' in comparing programs. Bennett said accountability is essential, and that no one at the 20 treatment programs he has visited has objected to the idea of evaluation. ``The people who run good treatment programs want to be evaluated because they are proud of what they do,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Blamed For Car Bomb That Kills 14
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded on a busy street outside a police station in the cocaine capital of Medellin, killing 14 people and wounding 30, many of them children, police said. No group claimed responsibility for Thursday's bombing but police blamed drug traffickers, who are waging a terror campaign in response to a 10-month-old government crackdown on the narcotics trade. People screamed hysterically, crying and searching for loved ones after the blast. One man screamed: ``They've done me in! They've done me in! They killed my son!'' as he dropped to the ground weeping. A day earlier, security forces deactivated a car bomb loaded with a half ton of dynamite in a parking lot near a city government building in Medellin, police said. Col. Jorge Ferrero, who Thursday became police chief in Colombia's second-largest city, said four of those killed and many of the wounded were children. Others slain included a reporter and the wife of a senator, he said. The blast occurred minutes after Ferrero was sworn in as Medellin's new police chief several miles away. The explosion destroyed at least 10 cars and left a crater five-feet deep and 12-feet wide. It also damaged several nearby stores. Witnesses told radio networks that minutes before the bomb exploded, they saw a man running away from a small sedan parked in front of the police station. Police said the car, which had false license plates, was packed with 330 pounds of explosives. The bomb set fire to several nearby cars. Four people were pronounced dead at the scene and the others died in hospitals, Bernardo Guerra, president of the Medellin government's Emergency Committee, told RCN. Guerra said 30 people were injured, and many of them were in critical condition. One of those injured was a policeman. Medellin, 160 miles northwest of Bogota, has 3 million residents. It is home to the cocaine cartel of the same name that before the crackdown supplied about 70 percent of the drug sold on U.S. streets. At least 285 people have died in hundreds of bomb attacks in Colombia over the past 10 months since the cartels began fighting the government's efforts to extradite suspected traffickers. In April, the drug cartel announced it would pay $4,300 for each police officer slain. Since January, 150 policemen have been killed in the state of Antioquia, and all but 17 in the state capital of Medellin. Colombia has sent 15 drug suspects to the United States since last August, when President Virgilio Barco ordered the crackdown in retaliation for the slaying by traffickers of a presidential candidate. President-elect Cesar Gaviria, who takes office Aug. 7, has said he will continue the war on trafficking, but has hinted he will not make extraditions a major part of that war without more foreign aid and preferential trade status.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves $83.6 Billion for VA, HUD, Independent Agencies
DOC.TEXT: Veterans, space scientists and those in need of housing will gain most from a spending measure passed by the House. The House voted 355-48 Thursday to spend $83.6 billion next year for the Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development departments, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and 19 independent agencies and offices. The bill covers the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Spending this year is set at $71.3 billion. An increase of $15 billion for veterans, housing and space and science programs is offset by cuts elsewhere. The Senate must come up with a spending plan for the same departments and agencies, however, and no action is expected before September. Also, the housing component is bound to change, since a housing bill outlining the kinds of programs that will exist in 1991 still must clear both chambers. The Senate version was passed Wednesday, and the House must still vote on its version. The House spending plan is calculated using current programs. Highlights of the spending bill: _$26 billion for HUD, compared with $15 billion this year. The 1991 bill raises spending for housing assistance to the poor, elderly and disabled from $7.8 billion to $11.6 billion. The bill also includes $340 million to help the homeless, an increase of $56 million over this year. _$31.3 billion for the VA, a $1.6 billion increase over this year. It includes $15.7 billion for compensation and pensions, along with a record $12.3 billion for medical care. The bill also includes $572 million for construction, including nearly $250 million for a new veterans hospital in Detroit. _$14.3 billion for NASA, a $2 billion increase over the current year. The amount includes $2.3 billion for the space station. The amounts, however, are less than those requested by the Bush administration, which had sought major increases for exploration of outer space. The House also raised spending for the National Science Foundation by more than a quarter-billion dollars, close to what President Bush requested. The House cut out $6 million requested by the administration to search for signs of intelligence in outer space. _$1.6 billion for the Environmental Protection Agency's Superfund to clean up toxic waste. This is $130 million less than what the administration had requested but $80 million more than this year. _$37 million for the Consumer Product Safety Commission, $1 million more than sought by the administration. _$10.8 million in new spending for an Office of Inspector General in the Resolution Trust Corp., a government agency that is managing the savings and loan bailout program.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Keeps Curbs on Semis in Crime Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after lede and SUBS 5th graf pvs with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Senate rejecting anti-death penalty amendment; picks up 6th graf pvs, bgng: The Senate ...
DOC.TEXT: The Senate beat back an effort Thursday to scrap curbs on nine semi-automatic assault weapons and voted for tougher penalties for firearms violations. Senators also rejected a move to drop death penalty provisions and replace them with mandatory life sentences. ``The drug traffickers have not stopped using assault weapons, they're not going to stop using assault weapons but at least we can stop them from using these assault weapons,'' declared Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. The Senate voted 50-48 in favor of keeping the restrictions as the members resurrected a broad crime bill. After that vote, it went on to add tougher mandatory sentences to the bill by an 87-12 vote. Forty-two Democrats were joined by eight Republicans in upholding the semiautomatic restrictions. Thirty-six Republicans and 12 Democrats voted against. As the Senate worked into the night, it rejected 73-25 a move by Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., to drop the numerous death penalty provisions in the bill and replace them with mandatory life sentences. Hatfield said the death penalty represented ``a primal urge for revenge, sadistic revenge'' and Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., said the Senate seemed ``to be on a death penalty rampage today.'' The Senate also approved an amendment that would allow Indian reservations to decide for themselves whether to impose the death penalty in local murder cases that ordinarily would come under federal law. The measure would not affect provisions of the bill calling for the death penalty for presidential assassination, treason, espionage and other crimes. Sen. Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M., said Indian tribes should have the same rights as states in deciding whether to impose capital punishment for murder. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., countered that it would ``have the effect of exempting Indians who commit heinous, vicious murders from the federal death penalty simply because their tribes don't like it.'' The bill appeared dead several weeks ago when the curbs on semiautomatic weapons were accepted. Vice President Dan Quayle was presiding and critics of the restrictions had said earlier that if called upon to break a tie he would vote for an amendment that would drop the weapons restrictions. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, had urged the Senate to drop the restrictions in favor of tougher mandatory sentences for gun-related offenses. ``Those who are going to violate the law and use super-sophisticated weapons are going to violate gun control laws,'' said Gramm. The penalty provision, contained in Gramm's amendment, would impose a mandatory 10 years in prison to life for federal crimes involving firearms and the death penalty for killing anyone with a firearm in the most serious federal cases. ``We are talking about a choice between gun control on one hand and criminal control on the other hand,'' Gramm said. ``Here we are talking about criminal control.'' Major provisions of the bill call for the death penalty for 30 federal offenses and would streamline the appeals system with an eye to ending delays of a decade or more in carrying out death sentences. The measure also would make minor changes in the money-laundering laws. The measure started as part of President Bush's anti-crime package but has largely been rewritten on Capitol Hill. The administration is opposed to many of the provisions. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, won approval of an agreement under which lawmakers would work on the crime bill Thursday and again on Friday before leaving for their Fourth of July recess. The Senate would not vote on final passage on the measure, however, until July 12 when the lawmakers will have returned from the holidays. The Senate turned to the crime bill after hours of last-minute negotiations. The measure stalled two weeks ago when Senate supporters of the National Rifle Association failed to kill restrictions on assault weapons, and hundreds of amendments flowed into the hopper. Mitchell was unable to break a likely filibuster and halted action on the bill while lawmakers sought a deal to pare down the number of amendments. ``We have done a brutalization job to get it down from 187 to nine,'' said Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., speaking only of the proposed Republican changes. Mitchell finally won approval of a complex agreement under which lawmakers will be able to offer amendments on topics ranging from savings and loan fraud to victims' rights and tent prisons. As debate got under way, Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., read what he said was a letter from a constituent who belongs to the association that said ``the NRA has worked itself into a frenzied paranoia'' over the crime bill. The letter apologized for an NRA letter critical of Pryor that was mailed to gun owners in Arkansas. DeConcini praised Gramm for moving to stiffen criminal penalties but said ``law enforcement is asking us to help them'' by resisting efforts to drop the assault weapons curbs. ``The drug traffickers have not stopped using assault weapons, they're not going to stop using assault weapons but at least we can stop them from using these assault weapons,'' DeConcini said. Under the agreement reached by the Senate, lawmakers would drop provisions of the package that would permit searches with flawed warrants and create an elite federal force of drug and organized crime prosecutors.

DOC.HEAD: Army's Decontaminant: Another Agent Orange?
DOC.TEXT: In the event of chemical warfare, the Air Force will clean its military equipment with hot, soapy water. The Navy will use a bleaching agent similar to most household products.
