But the Army and Marine Corps, according to a longstanding policy, will opt for a decontaminant solution that six years ago ate through an electronic cable on an M-1 tank in about a half hour. The practice of using so-called DS2 prompted congressional investigators on Thursday to urge Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to direct the two services to find a safer, cheaper alternative. It also drew the ire of the chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on environment, energy and natural resources, who berated an Army brigadier general for his response to the investigators' findings. ``Based on the General Accounting Office report, the testimony, it appears there are equally effective and less hazardous alternatives that are already available,'' said Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla. ``Can I get a commitment from you the Army will consider alternatives without waiting 10 or 20 years to develop a new decontaminant?'' Brig. Gen. David A. Nydam, commanding general of the U.S. Chemical Research, Development and Engineering Center, said he could not commit the Army to ``such action like that.'' ``We have looked at all the alternatives _ DS2 continues to be the best that there is available,'' Nydam said. Synar responded angrily: ``If you don't have the serious commitment to change the potential environmental health exposure to our fighting men and women you need to check your credentials at the door,'' the congressman said. ``It could be, literally, another Agent Orange sitting out there,'' he said. The criticism came as representatives from GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, detailed serious problems with the solution ranging from leaking containers that were improperly stored to sales to private individuals who were never informed of the hazards. In defense of their selection, Army officials said that unlike the Navy and Air Force, the service's forces live in the field and must take their equipment with them. ``This requires the availability of a decontaminant which can effectively be used in an efficient and immediate manner in locations where water may be severely limited in availability,'' Nydam said. The military services have purchased about 5 million gallons of DS2 since the early 1960s with the Army requiring the largest amount _ 666,000 gallons at a cost of nearly $18 million. The chemical solution is manufactured by Dalden Corp. of Roanoke, Texas, and Poly Research of Holtsville, N.Y. The GAO found that DS2 is toxic and highly corrosive and can cause severe burns, liver damage and reproductive or birth defects. Based on the problems, the Air Force and Navy have opted for less toxic alternatives. The Army, despite its own tests that show bleaches were just as effective as DS2, continues to stick with the chemical solution. In addition, the GAO found that at five of the U.S. facilities the DS2 was improperly stored and in some cases, the cans were leaking. At Fort Sill, Okla., the chemical was stored with supertropical bleach, a combination that could set off an explosion. Meanwhile, at Fort Lewis, Wash., cans of DS2 were stored in a shed without walls, exposing the material to the elements. Nydam said the Army was aware of the problem and was correcting the mistakes at the storage facility. The GAO also found that the Army sold cans of the chemical to private citizens but failed to provide them with Material Safety Data Sheets, which identify the health and environmental hazards associated with DS2.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Fewer Stars, Please
DOC.TEXT: There will be fewer stars in the armed forces in the coming years, now that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says cuts in the military must start at the top. Approving a recommendation made by Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the chiefs of the branches of the services, Cheney decided to cut 78 generals and admirals from the top levels of the nation's military leadership. The decision would result only in a 7 percent cut in the number of men and women who wear the gilded stars and braid of the military's highest ranks. The reduction is a far cry from the much larger cuts in store for most of the services. Army officials have predicted that they may be cutting one soldier in four from the ranks over the next five years. Currently, there are 1,073 top-level positions in the military _ 407 generals in the Army, 338 in the Air Force, 70 in the Marine Corps and 258 flag officers in the Navy. The cut will bring the new level to 995 such slots by 1995, according to Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. At the end of April, there were 2 million men and women on active duty in the nation's armed forces. Williams said the move is part of the Pentagon's effort to cut back its forces amid the drive to save money and adjust to lessened East-West tensions. He said it was only the first of the cuts that can be expected in the Pentagon rolls, including slots in the department's top civilian leadership. Powell, in a statement released at the Pentagon, said his proposal reflects the need for economies in the current budget-cutting climate. ``The Joint Chiefs and I believe this plan reflects an appropriate balance between continuing requirements and changing force structure,'' Powell said. ``In light of anticipated force structure changes, we recognize the necessity for general and flag officer requirements and inventory to drop below current levels.'' Williams said Cheney and Powell wanted to emphasize that it was appropriate to begin force level reductions ``at the top'' and among all the services. The cut means the elimination of 33 generals from the Army, 27 from the Air Force, three from the Marine Corps, and 15 flag officers from the Navy. A total of 20 positions will be eliminated before the end of 1991, an additional 20 in each of the next two years and 18 in 1994, Williams said. The spokesman said that an attempt would be made to reduce the numbers through retirement and attrition, but that additional steps may have to be taken to make the cuts. ``I don't think retirement and attrition are going to do it,'' he said. Williams said the exact job positions have not yet been designated for elimination and that such decisions will be left to the various services. In a related development, the Army announced that it has proposed cutting about 7,000 civilian jobs. The decision primarily affects jobs at Army Materiel Command, which is the Army's largest civilian employer. Many such announcements affecting the Pentagon's 1.1 million-strong civilian work force are expected in the coming months and years, given the Pentagon's current budget cutting drive. The personnel announcements came as new chiefs prepared to take over the top leadership positions with the Navy and Air Force this weekend. Adm. Frank Kelso was being elevated to chief of naval operations today at a ceremony at the Naval Academy, taking over from another submariner, Adm. Carlisle Trost. Kelso, born in Fayetteville, Tenn., most recently served as the head of the Navy's Atlantic Command. Gen. Michael Dugan, most recently the commander in charge of the U.S. Air Forces in Europe and the Allied Air Forces in Central Europe, assumes the command held by Gen. Larry Welch. Dugan, of Albany, N.Y., is a former combat pilot during the Vietnam war who flew more than 300 missions.

DOC.HEAD: Crippled Telescope Still May Search for Planets Around Nearby Stars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for item listed on PM-News Digest as PM-Hubble-Hopes.
DOC.TEXT: The crippled Hubble Space Telescope's main camera still may be able to search for other solar systems, a step toward determining if life exists elsewhere in the universe, a scientist with the project said. To conduct the search, Hubble was designed to watch six to eight stars for several years to see if they slowly wobble _ a sign that the stars are being tugged by gravity from orbiting planets, said Jim Westphal, principal scientist for the Hubble's wide-field and planetary camera. Despite a flaw that prevents proper focusing of the observatory's mirrors, ``It's entirely possible we can still do that,'' said Westphal, a professor of planetary sciences at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. ``We should know a week from now,'' after computerized tests are completed. To learn if a star wobbles, the telescope simply must accurately determine the star's position relative to stars around it. ``We don't really care how sharp the image is,'' Westphal said Thursday by phone from Maryland, where he was helping NASA officials deal with the Hubble's troubles. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced Wednesday that an apparent flaw in manufacturing one of the $1.5 billion telescope's mirrors left the wide-field camera virtually useless, while its faint-object camera would perform no better than a telescope on Earth. The performance of two of three other instruments also will be impaired, NASA said. The wide-field camera, built by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, already was scheduled to be replaced in June 1993 by space shuttle astronauts who were to install a more advanced camera now under construction at JPL. The agency now expects to change the optics in the new camera to compensate for fuzzy focus caused by the mirror defect. Until then, the telescope will be unable to study the age of the universe, distinguish individual stars in distant galaxies or learn more about incredibly bright light sources called quasars, Westphal said. Scientists felt ``pretty gloomy,'' Westphal said _ but still optimistic the search for other solar systems can proceed. The search is important because ``if lots of stars have planets, then the chances that some of those planets might have life on them is better, and ultimately the chance there might be intelligent life somewhere is greater,'' he said. Even if it worked perfectly, the Hubble couldn't detect life on other planets. But Westphal said it could bring scientists one step closer to ``the answer to one of the most interesting of all questions: is there anybody else out there.'' Despite the focusing problem, the main camera still should be able to search for planets outside our solar system five times more effectively than any telescope on Earth, Westphal said. Test photographs show that about 85 percent of the light that enters the camera ``is not properly focused, but about 15 percent is where it belongs, and makes a nice little sharp image,'' he explained. ``So we anticipate that we can probably use that little sharp core to watch for stars to wobble.'' Trying to see a Jupiter-sized planet orbiting a nearby star often has been compared to a person trying to see a speck of dust miles away when that speck is sitting next to a 1,000-watt light bulb. During the past decade, astronomers found indirect evidence that more than three dozen stars seem to be surrounded either by flattened disks of dust _ possibly young solar systems in the process or forming planets _ or by planet-like objects known as brown dwarfs. Westphal said plans call for Hubble to observe only one of those, Barnard's star, which ``has a tantalizing wobble to it.'' The others are too far for Hubble to observe. The stars Westphal hopes the telescope can observe are all considered ``nearby,'' or within 10 light years of Earth. That's almost 60 trillion miles.

DOC.HEAD: Dingell Calls for Reconsidering Official's Security Clearance
DOC.TEXT: A House committee chairman wants the Energy Department to reconsider the security clearance of Victor Stello Jr., the administration's failed nominee to head nuclear weapons production. But a spokesman says the department has no such plans. Stello allegedly told Congress contradictory statements and therefore may not qualify for a high-level job, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., wrote Energy Secretary James D. Watkins. Dingell's letter, released Thursday, noted that the Energy Department's requirement for high-security jobs bans an individual who is ``not honest, reliable, or trustworthy, and there is no adequate evidence of rehabilitation or reform.'' Amid controversy in April, Stello withdrew his name for consideration to become assistant secretary of energy for defense programs. ``We do not question Mr. Stello's loyalty to this country. Nevertheless, in view of the derogatory information now in the possession of the department ... Mr. Stello may not be qualified'' to hold a high security job, wrote Dingell, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Dingell said his panel's oversight and investigations subcommittee, which he also chairs, had learned that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's inspector general found that Stello made contradictory statements to Congress and to NRC investigators. The letter did not elaborate on what the statements involved. Energy Department spokesman Tom Olson said the agency had no plans to withdraw Stello's security clearance and that it disagreed with Dingell's reading of the inspector general's report. ``We're very familiar with the facts of the case. The facts have been aired a number of times. There's nothing in the report that shows that there is any reason to believe that he's been dishonest,'' Olson said. Stello has just under gone several security checks and investigations, Olson said. During the administration's 10-month fight to win Senate confirmation of Stello, the nominee was accused of improprieties in his 24 years with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which has jurisdiction over civilian nuclear reactors. Among the accusations was that Stello altered agency rules at the request of nuclear utilities, to the detriment of safety, and that he authorized cash payments to an informer as part of a personal vendetta within the NRC as its chief staff official. Stello went to the Energy Department on temporary assignment last July after Bush nominated him for the weapons chief's job. When he withdrew his nomination, the Energy Department said Stello would stay on in a civil service job whose duties include overseeing efforts to restart idled reactors at the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina. The job does not require Senate confirmation. Dingell called the NRC inspector general's report ``disturbing,'' especially coupled with earlier complaints that Stello's allegedly supported a plan to allow major security problems to go uncorrected at the Rocky Flats facility in Colorado, which makes triggers for nuclear weapons. The chairman asked Watson to advise the committee by July 13 on whether Stello would maintain access to classified information.

DOC.HEAD: Conferees Reject US Membership in International Oil Spill Accords
DOC.TEXT: Congressional conferees are refusing to approve trial U.S. participation in international oil spill accords, thereby clearing a major hurdle in legislation to compensate victims of accidents. The conferees, set to meet again July 12, now can turn to the two remaining issues in the bill: amounts of penalties to be assessed against those responsible for spills, and whether to require double-hulled vessels. The conference, by voice vote on Thursday, did approve non-binding language stating it's in ``the best interests of the United States'' to participate in two international compensation agreements. But Senate conferees refused to approve actual membership, partly because the chamber has been unable to exercise its right to approve international treaties. The senators, led by Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, also wanted to preserve rights of states to impose their own liability rules for spills in their waters. Two international agreements, called protocols, were negotiated in 1984 and 41 countries have ratified them. But they won't become operational unless the United States approves its participation. Rep. Gerry E. Studds, D-Mass. proposed that the United States join the international agreements on a trial basis for five years, if they were modified to comply with federal and state liability laws. If the modifications were not made at the end of five years, the nation would have withdrawn from the agreements. The House conferees unanimously approved the proposal but the Senate members voted unanimously for rejection. The House side then came back with the ``sense of Congress'' advisory provisions that won acceptance. With no international agreements, Alaska, for example, was able to impose unlimited liability on the operators of the U.S.-registered Exxon Valdez, the tanker that spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil in Prince William Sound last year. Alaska could have held the operators of a foreign-flag vessel to the same standard, but would not be able to if the international limits were in force. Under the international accords, those hurt by an oil spill could first seek compensation from insurers for the responsible party, with a ceiling of $75 million. The applicant then could seek up to $260 million from an international fund that already has been established without U.S. participation. As a third step, those affected could try to tap a U.S. domestic fund that would allow collections of up to $1 billion per spill. The domestic fund already has been established from a nickel-a-barrel fee on oil transporters, although no money has been spent. It would become operational under the new legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Joan Rivers Wins Talk Show Daytime Emmy
With PM-Emmy-List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A Martinez in 7th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A tearful Joan Rivers reached the end of a long road back when she stepped forward to accept her first Emmy Award. ``Two years ago I couldn't get a job in this business ... people said I wouldn't work again,'' she told the audience at Thursday's 17th annual Daytime Emmy Awards, recalling how Fox Broadcasting dropped her late-night talk show. Rivers won the Emmy for best daytime talk show host for her syndicated ``The Joan Rivers Show.'' She wept when she alluded to the suicide of her husband, producer Edgar Rosenberg, in 1987. ``It's so sad that he's not here because he ... always said, `You can turn things around,''' she said. ``I'm so sorry he's not here.'' NBC won four Emmys for its soap opera ``Santa Barbara,'' including best directing team and, for the second consecutive year, outstanding dramatic series. A Martinez, who plays Cruz Castillo on the show, won the best actor Emmy, and Henry Darrow, who plays his father, Rafael, won as best supporting actor. Susan Lucci, nominated for best actress a record 11 times as the bad-tempered Erica Kane of ABC's ``All My Children,'' came up a loser for the 11th time. That Emmy went to Kim Zimmer, the Reva Shayne Lewis of CBS' ``Guiding Light'' who told the audience she's leaving the show. ``I will be back some day,'' she said, without elaborating. The show also won for best writing. Julia Barr, who plays Brooke English on ``All My Children,'' won for best supporting actress. In the juvenile performers category, Cady McClain won best actress for her role as Dixie Martin on ``All My Children'' and Andrew Kavovit won outstanding young actor as Paul Stenback on ``All My Children.'' Alex Trebeck of the syndicated ``Jeopardy!'' won the best game show host Emmy for the second consecutive year, but shared the honor with Bob Barker of ``The Price Is Right.'' ``Jeopardy!'' also won the game show Emmy. PBS' ``Reading Rainbow'' won for best children's series, and a CBS ``Schoolbreak Special'' titled ``A Matter of Conscience'' won as best children's special. Two ABC shows, ``Beetlejuice'' and ``The New Adventures of Winnie the Pooh,'' shared the Emmy for best animated program. A lifetime achievement Emmy went to game show producer Mark Goodson, 75, whose shows include ``What's My Line,'' ``To Tell the Truth,'' ``The Match Game'' and ``The Price is Right.'' ``The Sally Jessy Raphael Show,'' a competitor of Rivers' show, won the Emmy for best daytime talk show. Raphael, who won last year's Emmy for best talk show host, was asked whether she would ever run out of topics. ``When the world runs out of love stories and people run out of their need for each other, we'll run out of topics,'' Raphael said. Rivers, who dedicated her Emmy to her late husband, had regained her high spirits when she spoke later to reporters about her image on the troubled Fox show and her new daytime environment. ``On the Fox Show, where I was being careful because they said `Be careful,'' people said, `What happened to the old, outrageous Joan?' ``Then I went on, I did something at the beginning of our show, they said, `Why she's outrageous! Whatever happened to that wonderful warm, gentle Joan?' ``So whatever I do is wrong. So do what you want to do: And those that like it like you, those that don't, don't.'' ``Daytime is a tough nut to crack and we came in with tremendous amount of people telling us, `You can't break in, there's no more room,''' she said. ``I'm thrilled that they found room for me.'' The ceremonies were jointly presented by the Los Angeles-based Academy of Television Arts & Sciences and the New York-based National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. The prime-time Emmy nominees are to be announced Aug. 2 in Los Angeles, and the prime-time awards show is scheduled to air Sept. 16 from Los Angeles by Fox Broadcasting Co.

DOC.HEAD: Cure For Common Cold Eludes Researchers; Center Closes
DOC.TEXT: After thousands of volunteers sneezed, sniffled and coughed their way through years of tests, researchers are conceding what conventional wisdom said all along: There's no cure for the common cold. After 44 years, the Common Cold Research Center is closing Saturday, conceding defeat in the cold war. But the center's administrator, Arthur Amos, insists that the 18,000 volunteers who passed through the hospital near Salisbury, 80 miles west of London, did not suffer in vain. ``Going back in time, we used to think there was only one cold virus. Now we know there are nearly 200, so there is no chance of finding a vaccine,'' Amos said. ``We've been trying to find a compound that acts on a family of viruses, but we've had no luck.'' Some of the center's discoveries cannot be explained, Amos said. Why, for example, did one-third of volunteers never show any signs of a cold, while the others, exposed to the same virus, coughed, sneezed and felt miserable? ``Blood tests at the beginning of the trial and at the end often show changes in antibody levels, which means even if it didn't seem like they have a cold, they have a subclinical cold,'' Amos said. The volunteers received no medication, Amos said, unless they were in extreme discomfort, in which case they got aspirin. The research center was housed in the Harvard Hospital, so named because it was sent to Britain by the Harvard Medical School in 1940. During World War II, it was an American military field hospital, and in 1946 it was turned over to the common cold project. The volunteers, who learned of the project through newspaper advertisements and word-of-mouth, ranged in age from 18 to 50, and some were repeat participants. One couple met there and returned the following year for their honeymoon. One man went through the 10-day quarantined program 26 times, but Amos said he was ``a rather odd sort of person.'' Many participants came to vacation at the center, nestled in rolling countryside in the shadow of the 404-foot spire atop Salisbury Cathedral, England's highest spire. Two or three volunteers shared each of the center's 12 apartments. ``We usually have a flat empty in reserve in case they're imcompatible... but in the main they usually get along,'' Amos said. The volunteers were barred from Salisbury and neighboring villages and had to keep at least 30 feet away from anyone but their roommates or the gowned, masked medical staff. ``If they were on a walk and couldn't avoid meeting someone, they were told to put a paper tissue over their nose and walk by quick,'' said Amos. Most volunteers came out of curiosity, Amos said, not for the money, a paltry daily sum of pocket money now set at $3. Amos, who has had only one cold in his six years at the center, will work for three more months overseeing its closure. The Medical Research Council, which had provided the center's $1 million in annual funding, decided the unit would close after director David Tyrell retired. ``It was so much his work, that it was not really viable without him,'' a council spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Ecuador's President Predicts Release of Kidnapped American
DOC.TEXT: President Rodrigo Borja is predicting that Communist guerrillas will soon release an American gold miner they kidnapped more than two months ago. Borja said Thursday he had been receiving reports on the progress of talks to free Scott Heimdal, who reportedly is being held in a rebel camp across the Colombian border. Heimdal, 27, of Peoria, Ill., was kidnapped April 28 while riding in a dugout canoe near the small mining camp where he worked in the jungle 100 miles northeast of Quito. Heimdal's parents, Roy and Marge, arrived in Quito on June 18 to take charge of negotiations to free their son. ``I think the negotiations are going well,'' Borja said in an interview. ``I'm confident that he will be returned safe and sound.'' Borja's remarks were the first he's made to the foreign press concerning the kidnapping. He did not say to what extent Ecuadoran authorities were involved in efforts to release Heimdal, and has not met with Heimdal's parents. The kidnappers, who have identified themselves as members of the People's Liberation Army, asked the equivalent of $612,000 for Heimdal's release, according to his employer, the IMINCO mining company. Heimdal's parents raised about $60,000, mostly in community donations, and that money has reportedly been turned over to the kidnappers. Heimdal was in charge of starting up dredging operations for IMINCO, and was leaving the company's camp to return to Quito when he was abducted. On another matter, Borja said he has asked the United States to help build a jungle radar system to monitor drug-smuggling planes in his country's airspace, but has gotten no response. President Bush has proposed spending $2.2 billion over the next five years in military, police and economic aid to fight narcotics trafficking in Bolivia, Peru and Colombia. Borja said Ecuador's drug-trafficking problem is far less serious than that of its neighbors, but added: ``This is the moment in which our country has to begin battling this plague. Later will be too late.''

DOC.HEAD: Study: Candidates, Parties Get $11.6 Million From S&Ls in 1980s
DOC.TEXT: The two major political parties and congressional candidates accepted nearly $12 million in contributions this decade from fund-raising groups and individuals connected to the savings and loan industry, according to a new statistical analysis. Common Cause, which compiled the figures from public records, said the contributions helped influence legislation and other actions that loosened regulation of the S&L industry. The industry now is subject to a government bailout estimated to cost $300 billion or more. Using Federal Election Commission data, Common Cause said it identified 157 political action committees and 1,074 individuals associated with savings and loans. The PACs contributed $6.2 million to congressional campaigns and party organizations in the 1980s and the individuals provided $5.4 million, it said. Current members of Congress received $6.7 million, of which $3.8 million went to Democratic incumbents and $2.9 million to Republicans. Political parties received $2 million from S&L interests in the 1980s, Common Cause said, including $1.1 million that went to Republican committees and $891,000 to Democratic coffers. Five senators are under ethics committee investigation for intervening on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., the owner of a failed California S&L whose rescue is expected to cost the government more than $2 billion. Keating and his wife donated $97,950 in their names to candidates and political party committees during the 1980s, Common Cause said. Keating also helped raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for a handful of candidates. Four of the so-called Keating Five were among the top 10 senators in receiving S&L-related donations in the 1980s, according to the Common Cause analysis. According to Common Cause: _Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., now chairman of the Banking Committee, received $200,900 from S&L interests in the 1980s, the second-highest total among senators. _Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., $143,700, fourth. _Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., $84,200, seventh. _Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., $80,393, eighth. The fifth member of the group, Ohio Democratic Sen. John Glenn, ranked 30th among senators, receiving $32,600 from PACs and individuals associated with S&Ls in the decade, Common Cause said. The overall Senate leader in such receipts was Republican Sen. Pete Wilson, now California's GOP gubernatorial nominee. Common Cause said S&L-related contributions to Wilson in the 1980s totaled $243,000. On the House side, the top six incumbents in terms of S&L-related contributions in the 1980s all were from California. According to Common Cause, they were: _Republican Rep. William Lowery, $85,088. _Republican Rep. David Dreier, $75,150 _Democratic Rep. Mel Levine, $69,250. _Democratic Rep. Richard Lehman, $68,090 _Republican Rep. Norman Shumway, $67,425. _Democratic Rep. Esteban Torres, $60,950.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Some Species Of Dolphins Being Slaughtered To Extinction
DOC.TEXT: Some species of dolphins are being slaughtered to near-extinction by the international fishing industry, according to a report published today by a conservationist group. The Environmental Investigation Agency said at least 500,000 dolphins, porpoises and small whales are killed around the world each year but that this figure could be three or four times higher if undocumented kills are included. The London-based agency called for the International Whaling Commission to impose immediate worldwide controls on the killing of small cetaceans, as the animals are collectively known. The International Whaling Commission is scheduled to meet in the Netherlands next week. ``Unless international action is taken immediately to roll back the intense pressures threatening the survival of Earth's most delightful species,'' the report said, ``many populations of cetaceans are likely to disappear or become extinct before this century is finished.'' The study called Japan the world's biggest killer of small cetaceans, slaughtering at least 100,000 a year and thereby threatening the survival of three types of small cetaceans in the region. It said Peru kills 50,000 a year by hunting. In British waters all small cetaceans are protected by law and that there is believed to be no intentional killing, the report said. But it said that in Ireland about 1,000 porpoises a year are killed in nets. The report said small cetaceans are slaughtered for human consumption and for pet food. It said others are used as bait or are caught accidentally in nets intended to trap other creatures. It said small cetaceans are also hunted because fishermen see them as fish-eating rivals. The study said many die from modern fishing methods, becoming entangled in tuna nets or in drift nets up to 40 feet wide that allow no means of escape.

DOC.HEAD: `Fluke' Sequence of Supreme Court Decisions Blocks Execution
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors were disappointed that the U.S. Supreme Court permanently blocked the execution of convicted killer John Harvey Adamson a day after upholding the law under which he was sentenced to die in the gas chamber. ``I'd just liked to have gassed him,'' Attorney General Bob Corbin said. ``The Supreme Court upheld the death penalty statute in Arizona on Wednesday so we figured that since Adamson is coming up on the same issues, they'd do the same thing,'' Corbin said after the ruling was released Thursday. Two of the justices who voted with the majority in the 5-4 decision upholding the state law did not take part in Thursday's action, turning Wednesday's dissenters into a 4-3 majority that spared Adamson's life. Adamson was convicted in the 1976 car-bomb death of newspaper reporter Don Bolles, who had investigated organized crime for The Arizona Republic. Prosecutors said Adamson was paid $100,000 to attach a bomb to Bolles' car. Adamson said he was pleased by Thursday's ruling but declined to comment further, Department of Corrections spokesman Michael Arra. Corbin said Adamson will be removed from death row but still faces about 10 years in prison. Adamson began serving his sentence in December 1978. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals threw out Adamson's death sentence in 1988, striking down a provision in Arizona law that lets judges, instead of juries, choose between life and death for convicted murderers. The appeals court's ruling questioned the validity of death penalty laws in Idaho and Montana, which also allow for sentencing by judges. The Supreme Court in another case Wednesday declared the Arizona provision constitutional. But in a brief order Thursday, the justices ruled 4-3 against reinstating Adamson's death sentence. Two justices who had voted to uphold Arizona's death penalty law, Sandra Day O'Connor, a former state judge in Arizona, and Anthony M. Kennedy, a former 9th Circuit court judge, did not participate in Adamson's case. Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens, who voted a day earlier to strike down the law, also voted to void Adamson's death penalty. Idaho's attorney general, Jim Jones, called the sequence of events ridiculous, but predicted the decision would affect no other death row inmate. ``It really means not too much more than Adamson is going to get off because of a complete fluke, and the work of the judges of the 9th Circuit court,'' Jones said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,940.24, down 165.95 points or 0.52 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Changes in Tampons Lead to Decline in Toxic Shock Syndrome
DOC.TEXT: Changes in tampons have led to a 93 percent drop in toxic shock syndrome since 1980, when the disease was linked to tampon use, federal officials say. Just 61 cases of toxic shock syndrome were reported last year, compared with 890 cases in 1980, the Centers for Disease Control said Thursday. Toxic shock, a bacterial infection found most often in menstruation-age women, was linked especially to the most absorbent brands of tampons. CDC researchers are convinced that the decrease is real, and that tampon characteristics had been much of the problem, said Dr. Anne Schuchat, a CDC infectious disease specialist. ``Our initial concern was that after the public attention and the media attention went away ... people were not bothering to report cases,'' she said. But a 1986-87 study, which actively sought to locate cases across several states, found one case per 100,000 women between the ages of 14 and 44 _ a tenfold drop from the 1980 rate, Schuchat said. The United States recorded 45 cases of toxic shock in menstruation-age women last year, and 16 non-menstruation cases. A decade ago 812 of the 890 cases were associated with menstruation. Three important developments occurred in tampons in the 1980s, the CDC said: _The brand implicated in many early cases, Rely, was taken off the market. _Tampons became less absorbent. In 1980, 42 percent of tampon users used very high absorbency products _ the type considered most risky for toxic shock. By 1986, it was 1 percent. _The material makeup of tampons changed. Rely consisted of polyester foam and carboxymethylcellulose. Tampons containing polyacrylate were withdrawn in 1985, and current tampons are made with cotton or rayon. The withdrawal of Rely and the drop in use of high-absorbency tampons ``correlate with a marked decrease in incidence of menstrual toxic shock syndrome,'' though it's still unclear why those types of tampons increased the risk, the report said. The Food and Drug Administration declared last year that tampon makers must use uniform labeling terms for absorbency ranges, allowing women to compare brands. Federal health officials recommend that women who use tampons rather than sanitary napkins _ which have no known risk of toxic shock _ should use the lowest absorbency product effective for them. In its report, the CDC said other factors may have contributed to the drop in toxic shock. After the highly publicized concerns over the disease, tampon use may have decreased, and milder cases may not be reported as often.

DOC.HEAD: Police Get Credit as Senate Again Backs Curbs on Assault Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Police groups who have campaigned against semiautomatic assault rifles are getting the credit following a narrow vote by the Senate to maintain curbs on nine such weapons in an omnibus anticrime bill. ``Why we won is that law enforcement did a better lobbying job than the National Rifle Association,'' Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., said Thursday after the Senate voted 50-48 to maintain the curbs. Tougher penalties for federal firearms violations, sexual abuse of children and selling the new narcotic drug ``ice'' also went into the bill as senators worked past midnight this morning. The Senate also rejected efforts to drop numerous death penalty provisions in the anticrime bill. It did vote to let Indians decide for themselves whether to impose capital punishment for murders committed on reservations. Central provisions of the bill call for capital punishment for 30 federal crimes and streamline the appeals process with an eye to ending delays of up to a decade in carrying out executions. The Senate, adjourned until after the Fourth of July recess, plans to vote on passage of the overall anticrime package when it returns. Forty-two Democrats and eight Republicans voted to uphold the ban on import or manufacture in this country of the nine semiautomatic assault weapons while 36 Republicans and 12 Democrats voted against. The result was a further blow to the National Rifle Association which has been fighting the restrictions. The Fraternal Order of Police, the International Association of Chiefs of Police and an array of other law enforcement groups have been campaigning against assault weapons. They say the military-style rifles and semiautomatic pistols are too dangerous to be on the streets. The anticrime bill had appeared dead when the gun provisions survived previous moves to scrap them and the threat of an unbreakable filibuster materialized. Two weeks of bargaining, however, produced agreement to resurrect the bill _ once part of President Bush's anticrime package but now largely rewritten. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, led off Thursday's debate with a plan to scrap the assault weapons provisions in favor of mandatory sentences ranging from 10 years to life for firearms-related federal crimes and the death penalty in some gun killing cases. ``The sad, cold reality is that drug felons that are smuggling tons of illegal drugs into the country will smuggle firearms,'' said Gramm. `` ... They are going to have guns. The question is, are we going to have the stiff, mandatory sentences for those who violate the law? ``We are talking about crime control on one hand and criminal control on the other hand,'' Gramm said. The Senate's 50-48 vote to uphold the gun curbs came on a DeConcini move to combine both the restrictions and Gramm's tougher penalties. The success of that effort frustrated the move to delete the restrictions and the Senate then quickly adopted both the restrictions and the tougher penalties. ``The drug traffickers have not stopped using assault weapons, they're not going to stop using assault weapons but at least we can stop them from using these assault weapons,'' DeConcini said. Vice President Dan Quayle was presiding over the Senate when the vote came and was in position to cast the deciding vote if there had been a tie. The Senate later rejected, 73-25, a move by Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., to drop its death penalty provisions and substitute instead mandatory life sentences. Hatfield said the death penalty provisions represented ``a primal urge for revenge, sadistic revenge,'' and added that it placed the United States at odds with western European nations and in a category with Syria, South Africa and North Korea, among other countries. ``We seem to be on a death penalty rampage today,'' Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., declared. ``We seem to have applied the death penalty to everything except school truancy.''

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Strike At U.S. Banana Giant Threatens To Spread
DOC.TEXT: About 660,000 union members in this country of 4.8 million people are threatening to launch a crippling sympathy walkout if the U.S. banana giant Chiquita does not raise wages for its striking workers. The Chiquita strike that began Thursday is the latest _ and potentially most serious _ labor unrest to hit the 5-month-old administration of President Rafael Leonardo Callejas. Chiquita's 10,000 union members, including banana cutters, railway workers and administrative personnel averaging about $15 a day, struck for a 60 percent salary increase, paralyzing operations. The 70,000-strong National Federation of Workers' Unions, which includes the Chiquita workers, said members of other unions would begin walking off their job today, beginning with 2,000 Texaco refinery workers. The refinery supplies the entire nation. Other labor groups, including the 600,000-member Workers Confederation, have said they will strike if Chiquita refuses to negotiate. The president of the national legislature, Rodolfo Irias Navas, said the labor unrest could destabilize Honduras, the poorest nation in the hemisphere after Haiti with an annual per capita income of only $740. ``The crisis created by unionism is putting the stability of the government in danger,'' he said in a telephone interview. Workers at Chiquita Brands International Inc. make an average $15.32 a day and have not had a raise for six years, while inflation has climbed 50 percent annually. Their union asked the company for a higher pay in October. Company officials calculated the raise would cost $4.6 million a year and had not made a counterproposal Thursday after four days of negotiating. ``The strike is illegal; it doesn't make sense. We aren't going to pay higher salaries to our workers,'' Chiquita Vice President Eduardo Aragon said in a telephone interview. Company officials refused to comment further on the strike. Bananas are Honduras' leading export and the Cincinnati-based Chiquita, formerly United Brands, is one of the most powerful institutions in Honduras. President Callejas was trying Thursday to stop the strike from spreading. He sent a high-level delegation to the northern coastal town of La Lima, headquarters of Chiquita, to mediate talks between union and company officials. He also kept in close telephone contact with union leaders, military officials and key advisers. Callejas said he was sympathetic to the strikers, calling their demands for higher pay just. But he said there was no need for a strike. ``The unions are a fundamental piece of our democratic process,'' he told said in a phone interview. ``But with me there is no need to strike because the unions can achieve their goals through dialogue, without resorting to force.'' About 4,000 health care workers have been on strike since June 11 to protest the privatization of support services in six of the nation's 19 public hospitals. Army troops are occupying the main hospital in San Pedro Sula, the nation's second-largest city, and army medics are providing emergency care. Chiquita, which owns the country's only railroad, has enjoyed a near monopoly on the banana business in Honduras since 1912. It currently controls 60 percent of the bananas exported from Honduras. U.S.-based Castle and Cook controls the other 40 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Stomach Reducers Recalled
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturer of a stomach reducing device is recalled 700,000 of them because of several incidents in which consumers were hurt while using them. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Thursday that Harrison-Hoge Industries Inc. recalled the ``New Gym Stomach Eliminators'' after the company and agency learned of 62 incidents in which consumers using the exercisers suffered ``serious facial or body injury'' after a spring or clip broke. The devices, sold nationwide from 1985 to December 1989 by mail and in retail outlets, are composed of three 12-inch black metal springs attached to a black plastic handlebar and footbar. The footbar, footstrap or handlebar are marked ``Made in Italy'' or ``Brevattato'' Consumers should immediately discontinue use of the exercisers and contact Harrison-Hoge for a refund or credit toward other company products, the agency said.
DOC.HEAD: AT&T Cutting Evening Interstate Rates About 5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. says it will reduce its evening interstate long-distance rates by about 5 percent and daytime rates by about a 0.5 percent. The company also announced Thursday that it will reduce the prices of operator-assisted calls, calls to Canada and its Reach Out America long-distance calling plan. The cost of a 10-minute, direct-dialed evening call anywhere in the country will drop to $1.49 from $1.58, or less, from 5 p.m. to 11 p.m., Sunday through Friday. AT&T's prices have dropped nearly 43 percent since the demise in 1984 of the old Bell system, primarily because of FCC-ordered reductions in local access charges. The FCC last week ordered the nation's local telephone companies to reduce by $1.1 billion, effective Sunday, what they charge long-distance companies to connect with local phone networks. Long-distance carriers typically pass along to their customers savings from these reduced ``access charges.'' Other long-distance companies, such as MCI and US Sprint, usually follow AT&T's lead in rate reductions.
DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Who Survived Bizarre Ocean Plane Crash Loses FCC Rights
DOC.TEXT: Thomas L. Root, the lawyer who survived a bizarre ocean plane crash last summer, has been barred from practicing law before the Federal Communications Commission. The action effectively ends Root's communications law practice as of July 6, officials said Thursday. Root was scheduled to be sentenced Aug. 6 after pleading guilty to five felony counts of counterfeiting and forging federal documents, defrauding clients and lying to the FCC. Root, the Alexandria pilot who survived the crash of his private plane, but suffered a gunshot wound, had asked the commission to allow him to practice until his sentencing so his clients would have time to transfer to another lawyer. But the commission gave him from June 21 _ the date of the order _ to July 6 to notify his clients. Root pleaded guilty June 5 to five felony counts of counterfeiting and forging federal documents, defrauding clients and lying to the FCC. He faces up to 35 years in prison and $1.2 million in fines. On Wednesday, a federal grand jury in East St. Louis, Ill., indicted Root on four counts of mail and bank fraud and interstate transportation of stolen property involving $15,000 that he tried to obtain from clients. The maximum penalty for each offense is five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. On Monday, Root pleaded not guilty in North Carolina to 445 counts of securities fraud and related charges in connection with his handling of radio station licensing cases before the FCC.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Stocks Slip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen Friday, and the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index declined moderately. The dollar finished the week at 152.85 yen, down 1.57 yen from Thursday's close of 154.42 yen. After opening at 153.20 yen, it ranged between 152.40 yen and 153.25 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 165.95 points, or 0.52 percent, closing at 31,940.24. The index shed 206.56 points on Thursday. The Nikkei's decline Friday came despite a rise of 65.79 points in morning trading. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 86.25 points as of 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT) from Thursday's close of 86.75. The yield stood at 7.345 percent, up from the previous day's 7.240 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar's retreat followed its downswing overnight in overseas markets, where must of the buying activity centered on the Japanese yen. ``The dollar's weakness was basically carried over'' from the previous day, said Yutaka Hayashi, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. ``But the currency has yet to find its direction because there is also the demand for dollars coming at the end of the month.'' The Bank of Tokyo's Masato Hayashi said the dollar's downswing was accelerated by the outcome of the U.S.-Japan trade talks, in which Japan promised to increase public works spending to $2.8 trillion dollars over the next 10 years. After four days of the Structural Impediments Initiative trade talks this week, Japanese and U.S. officials produced a final report that included President Bush's decision to raise tax revenues to help tackle the federal budget deficit. Hayashi said investors expect the increase in public spending in Japan will lead to interest rate hikes to stem inflation that could result from more public spending. Japan's discount rate, the key rate set by the Bank of Japan, now stands at 5.25 percent, one of the lowest among major industrialized coutries. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told a regular news conference Friday morning that it is up to the Bank of Japan, rather than the ministry, to set monetary policy, and brushed aside rumors of an immediate Japanese discount rate increase. An official of the Bank of Japan, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the central bank has ``no plans at all'' to change the discount rate now. On the stock market, the Nikkei index rose slightly more than 200 points in early trading before easing toward the end of morning session on profit-taking, securities dealers said. Yozo Asai, an analyst with Yamaichi Securities, said the stock market ``remains firm but not too strong.'' Asai said the yen's appreciation against the dollar was seen favorably by the market, but an increase in the yield on long-term interest rates was a negative factor.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Volunteers Begin Leaving Philippines; Rebels Vow More Attacks
DOC.TEXT: American Peace Corps volunteers began leaving the country today, a day after soldiers wearing masks and civilian clothes fired on mourners carrying the coffin of a slain Communist rebel. The attack illustrated the pattern of violence that prompted the decision to suspend Peace Corps operations and led the U.S. Embassy to warn Americans to take extra safety precautions. The rebels vowed to avenge the attack at the funeral, in which two people were killed when officials say rebel suspects resisted arrest. ``The revolutionary justice the people demand will not go unheeded,'' said a statement today from the Manila branch of the rebel New People's Army. U.S. officials said the first of the Peace Corps volunteers left the Philippines for Honolulu today and the rest were departing on commercial flights over the next few days. The 261 volunteers were ordered to leave because intelligence reports indicated the New People's Army planned to kill or kidnap them. U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt said the United States planned to return volunteers as soon as possible ``to continue their efforts in development, in education programs side-by-side with their Filipino colleagues and friends.'' U.S. officials said the Peace Corps office in Manila would remain open as a sign that the withdrawal was temporary. Office Director Jim Lehman said there was no timetable for resuming operations. U.S. officials declined to elaborate on the alleged threat to Peace Corps members. Communist rebels are believed to have killed eight Americans since April 1989 but had made no public threat against the Peace Corps. Police arrested 21 people after Thursday's funeral attack and today charged them with inciting sedition. Three of them, identified as rebels, would face additional charges, police said. Police Lt. Col. George Alino said the shooting erupted when mourners tried to throw grenades at police. But news photographers and other witnesses said they saw no grenades. The Philippine Constabulary today appointed a board of officers to investigate the incident. Brig. Gen. Marino Filart, chief of the Capital Command, said the authorities stood by their actions. Filart said mourners were ``openly displaying their flag and openly displaying their revolutionary intent which is against the law.'' The funeral was for Benjamin Tabuena, 42, a former member of a rebel assassination squad killed by police last week. Tabuena was a member of the Alex Boncayao Brigade, the Manila wing of the New People's Army. The brigade is believed to have killed scores of police and soldiers in the capital this year. International and local human rights groups have frequently accused police and soldiers of violating civil rights in their counter-insurgency campaign, despite President Corazon Aquino's oft-stated pledge to respect individual liberties.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: In editor's note, CORRECTS date item was sent. Members who used the third item of a0441, PM-Names, sent June 25 under a Dallas dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press story June 25 about counterfeit baseball and football cards gave incorrect descriptions of the differences between the fake and legitimate Score cards featuring Bo Jackson. On the back of the legitimate baseball card, the word ``BO'' appears with the B in blue ink and the O in black ink. The fake baseball card back has the word printed all in black. Both the fake and legitimate cards have white borders. The legitimate football card has a purple border around a black-and-white photo of Jackson, and the back has a color photo of Jackson. There is no color printing on the fake football card, Score said.

DOC.HEAD: Kids At Jane Fonda's Camp Recount Their Survival Experience
With PM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The children of actress Jane Fonda's camp for the arts hugged, cried and vowed to come back someday as their idyllic summer escape to the mountains of Santa Barbara went up in smoke. The 48 boys and girls at Laurel Springs Camp were only four days into their two-week stay when ferocious brush fires sweeping through the mountains of Santa Barbara forced their evacuation. The fire that has destroyed 567 homes and businesses and caused hundreds of millions of dollars of damage also signaled the end of a dream for the youngsters, including a group of underprivileged kids who had come to the camp on scholarships. ``I'm really bummed out about this fire,'' said 11-year-old Maya Hawkins, who burst into tears as the children sat in a circle at their evacuation center sharing their feelings about the disaster. Laurel Springs, owned by Miss Fonda, seeks to bring children of varying backgrounds together in a program focusing on self esteem and the arts. The campers, ages 9 to 11, come from all parts of California. ``This camp is her secret,'' said camp director David Hodges. He said Miss Fonda was told about the fire and expressed concern. Hodges said he reluctantly called parents on Thursday and asked them to pick up their children. Although he hoped to reconvene the group later, smoke and flames made an immediate return to the camp impossible. Authorities also were unable to get to area to determine if the camp was damaged, though they didn't believe it was. The 4,000-acre arson fire that broke out late Wednesday in a valley between Santa Barbara and the nearby town of Goleta was still burning today. The children's drama began Wednesday at dinner time. ``We saw this large billowing cloud of smoke in the distance but we thought it was far away,'' Hodges said. ``We went in to dinner, but in the middle of dinner the fire department notified us we had to evacuate.'' Driving down the darkened hillsides, they saw flames shooting skyward and smoke was everywhere. ``When I see things like fires on the news, I never think it will happen to me,'' said one girl. ``And now it was happening to me and I was real scared.'' For Hodges, the question was what to do with 48 kids in the middle of the night. A teacher at nearby Santa Ynez High School, he decided to take them there. ``We brought some food with us and picked up some more from the supermarket,'' he said. Then, the community pitched in. A restaurant sent enough pizza for all the children, and the Elks Club sponsored a dinner Thursday. The youngsters unrolled their sleeping bags and slept in the gym. By morning, they were organizing into groups to swim and play games. All of the children said they wanted to finish out their two-week stay and were sad to go. ``I think this is the weirdest week I've ever had,'' one girl declared. Counselor Colleen Shelley addressed the children with tears in her eyes. ``We have handled this disaster like pros,'' she said. ``This is a memory that we'll all share forever. Years from now when people talk about the great Santa Barbara fire, we will say we were there and we survived it.''

DOC.HEAD: Seventeen Americans Honored As Heroes
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 people saw five men jump a teen-ager, but only James Schmitt jumped in to help. ``Everybody else was standing around watching. I figured the kid needed help,'' said Schmitt, 20, of Philadelphia. He was among 17 Americans honored Thursday by the Carnegie Hero Commission. More than $18.6 million has been awarded in one-time payments or pensions to 7,460 heroes or their survivors since the commission was founded by Pittsburgh industrialist Andrew Carnegie in 1904. One of those honored Thursday died in a rescue attempt in Louisiana. Schmitt, a sophomore at La Salle University, said he was waiting for his friend Bryan Moshinski, 15, outside a high school following a dance on Dec. 1, 1989. About eight young men associated with a rival high school chased and tackled Moshinski, and began beating him as parents and bystanders watched. ``I ran over and started throwing kids off of him,'' Schmitt said. ``I didn't mean to get involved. I just wanted to make it a fair fight, not five to one.'' The men turned from Moshinski and beat Schmitt before fleeing. Schmitt was knocked out with a baseball bat, and was hospitalized in critical condition with skull fractures, fractured ribs and a collapsed right lung. He also lost his vision in his right eye. Moshinski was bruised and suffered a slight concussion. Also recognized Thursday were: _Clyde E. Smith, 36, of Confluence, Pa., who waded through icy water flooding a road to rescue a woman trapped in her car in Ursina, Pa., on Dec. 31, 1989. _Christopher Ferland, 16, of Riverside, R.I., and Matthew T. Silvia, 17, of North Smithfield, R.I., who saved a 15-year-old girl swept away by a large wave in the Atlantic Ocean in Narragansett, R.I., on May 7, 1989. _Roger Kujawa, 32, and Kerry R. Ramey, 38, both of Peoria, Ill., who helped rescue a sheriff's deputy from his burning patrol car following an accident in Edwards, Ill., on Sept. 18, 1989. _John S. Montegna, 43, of Bend, Ore., who saved a 9-year-old girl who had fallen into the rough, cold water of the Deschutes River in Maupin, Ore., on May 21, 1989. _Darwin Nissen, 40, of Billings, Mont., who pulled a man who was on fire from his burning truck following a highway accident in Council Bluffs, Iowa, on April 3, 1989. _Elbon J. Ducote, 62, of Bunkie, La., who died trying to save an 8-year-old boy from drowning in a branch of the Old River in Bunkie on July 21, 1989. The boy was rescued by others. _James Bowman, 41, of Marysville, Calif., who rescued two women from a burning mobile home in Marysville on May 17, 1989. _Ceasar Rodriguez, 23, of Los Angeles, who rescued a youth being assaulted by a gang in Los Angeles on Jan. 27, 1989. _Christine Duemler, 33, of Monroe, Wis., who saved a woman in a runaway automobile in Madison, Wis., on June 13, 1988. _William M. Arndt, 26, of Middlebury, Conn., who saved a man trapped in a burning car in Middlebury on April 27, 1989. _Lawrence J. Shiner, 41, of Shorewood, Ill., who rescued a woman trapped in a burning minibus following a highway accident in Minooka, Ill, on Oct. 24, 1989. _Gary D. Knight, 40, of Medford, Ore., who rescued a man in an apartment fire in Portland, Ore., on May 25, 1989. _Glenn H. Peterson, 34, of Marquette, Mich., who crawled into a smoke-filled, burning home and rescued a woman in Harvey, Mich., on Sept. 12, 1989. _Earnest Bleach, 23, of Savannah, Ga., who tried to save a 9-year-old boy carried away from his raft by a tide in the Skidaway River in Savannah on June 30, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Says He'll Await Go-Ahead of Superiors Before Surrendering
DOC.TEXT: An officer charged with taking part in a cover-up in the slayings of six Jesuit priests says he is awaiting orders from superiors before turning himself in to authorities. Authorities say a military death squad went to the Jesuit-run Central American University before dawn and shot the priests, their housekeeper and her teen-age daughter. Lt. Col. Camilo Hernandez _ who allegedly ordered the burning of military log books that traced troop movements on the night of the massacre _ said Thursday he is waiting for a go-ahead from the defense minister or head of the joing chiefs of staff to submit to arrest. Defense Minister Gen. Humberto Larios has repeatedly pledged full military cooperation with the investigation. Judge Ricardo Zamora, who is in charge of the investigation into the Nov. 16 murders, issued a warrant for Hernandez's arrest on Wednesday. The slow pace of the investigation along with the disappearance of evidence and witnesses has been criticized by a U.S. congressional committee and officials of the Roman Catholic Church. The right-wing government of President Alfredo Cristiani is the largest recipient of U.S. aid in the Western hemisphere. Rightists considered the left-leaning priests subversive, because the clerics had said El Salvador's decade-long insurgency was a war on social and economic injustice rather than a reflection of international Communist expansion. Meanwhile, a colonel has denied having any information that a colleague was involved in the massacre, judiciary officials say. Army Col. Carlos Aviles had been considered a crucial witness against Col. Guillermo Benavides, a colleague who along with three lieutenants and five soldiers has been charged with the Nov. 16 murders. Sources close to the case described Aviles' denial, made in sworn testimony Wednesday, as a blow to successful prosecution of the case. ``With the colonel's testimony, the case becomes even more difficult. Based on the evidence we have now, I'd say there is about a 10 percent chance of taking the case to trial,'' one prosecutor said. The military at first denied any connection to the killings, which took place amid an offensive by leftist rebels in the capital. The military had said the priests were rebel sympathizers. The case broke after a U.S. military advisor said Aviles told him on Dec. 20 that Benavides was involved. U.S. Army Maj. Eric Buckland, in sworn testimony, said Benavides confessed his role to an officer who then told Aviles. No Salvadoran officer has ever been prosecuted for a human rights crime, despite the deaths of tens of thousands of people at the hands of death squads linked to the armed forces and to President Cristiani's ARENA partyd during the decade-long civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's President Says Bush Plan Will Aid In Drug War
DOC.TEXT: President Alan Garcia says a U.S. plan to forgive much of Latin America's foreign debt will help with the war on drugs. President Bush said this week the U.S. government would forgive or reschedule most of the $12 billion it is owed by Latin American nations, and also called for creation of a hemisphere-wide free market. The region owes a total of about $300 billion to foreign lenders. With the debt forgivenesss plan, Latin American countries will have less need ``to produce dollars through the perverse manner of growing coca,'' Garcia told reporters Thursday. Coca leaf is the raw material of cocaine. ``As far as drugs are concerned, we've finally made the American government understand that this is an economic as well as military problem,'' Garcia said. Garcia, who in 1985 stopped Peru's payments on its $22 billion foreign debt, strongly praised most elements of the Bush plan, unveiled Wednesday. ``For my government, which for five years has said the foreign debt is unpayable and must be substantially reduced, this is a transcendental act,'' said Garcia, who on July 28 will turn over the presidency to Alberto Fujimori. The president-elect is now on the first leg of a trip to New York and Tokyo seeking economic aid. When Garcia came to power five years ago, he said he would limit debt payments to 10 percent of the country's export earnings. He called on other Latin American nations to follow his lead. The move was strongly condemned by lenders and in 1986 the International Monetary Fund suspended relations with Peru. Savings that resulted from the cut in debt payments led Peru into a two-year economic boom. But the economy turned bad in 1987 when no new loans were forthcoming. The country has now fallen into its worst economic crisis in history. Four of five people lack steady work, inflation is 2,000 percent annually and the government is bankrupt and selling gold bars to import food. Drug trafficking has become Peru's second-biggest export earner, after the mining industry. The country takes in an estimated $1 billion annually from sales of coca, the main ingredient in cocaine. Fujimori has indicated he will sign a $35 million military agreement with the United States calling for U.S. army instructors to train Peruvian soldiers in anti-drug and anti-rebel warfare. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, along with Peruvian police, runs an anti-drug airbase in Peru's northern jungle. Maoist Shining Path rebels are active in most areas where coca is grown. They provide protection for drug traffickers in exchange for guns and money.

DOC.HEAD: Company `Deeply Offended' by Pickens' Accusations
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese auto parts manufacturer has angrily accused its largest stockholder, Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens, of ``slanderous and false charges'' that ``deeply offended'' company officials. The Koito Manufacturing Co. withdrew an invitation to Pickens to visit a company plant today, a day after a messy confrontation with Pickens over his efforts to win seats on the company's board of directors. The debate between Pickens and Koito has come to symbolize for many Americans the difficulties faced by U.S. investors in Japan at a time when many Japanese companies are buying up American companies and real estate. The debate points up the fundamental differences between the way Japanese and U.S. businessmen operate and how they accumulate wealth. Pickens, accompanied by 32 other American investors, had come to Japan for the Japanese auto parts company's annual stockholders meeting. He again raised his demand for four seats on the 20-member board of directors, and presented proposals for changes in company policy. Pickens and the other Americans stormed out before voting on his proposals was finished, claiming that Koito was taking his suggestions lightly and discriminating against foreigners. ``It was a sham, an absolute farce,'' he told reporters. ``Here today, Koito completely showed the world what it's all about in corporate Japan.'' Koito President Takao Matsuura, in a statement sent Thursday night to Pickens' hotel, said the charges were ``completely baseless and untrue,'' adding: ``Koito is deeply offended by your public remarks.'' Pickens declared that he would take his case against corporate Japan's ``closed system'' to Washington and to the upcoming Houston summit of advanced industrial democracies. ``We're going to tell it just like it is,'' he said. Pickens, who now owns 26 percent of Koito's shares, has insisted that as its largest stockholder, he has a right to influence its policy. Koito officials say they doubt Pickens is a long-term investor with a genuine interest in helping manage the company. In the weeks before the shareholders meeting, Pickens had undertaken a publicity campaign to convince individual Japanese shareholders of his sincerity in advocating shareholders' rights. Matsuura said after the meeting that Koito had taken pains to answer Pickens' questions and had carried out procedures agreed to during meetings with a court-appointed inspector. ``While we were prepared to extend you every courtesy, we will not allow Koito employees, shareholders and management to be crudely insulted as part of your continual harassment of the company,'' he wrote.
