DOC.HEAD: In The Path of Flames, Radio Helps Community Find Itself
DOC.TEXT: The fires raged, but most people, cats and dogs were safe. They just needed to find each other. People pinned their hopes and messages on a broadcast bulletin board Thursday as Santa Barbara residents opened their homes, hearts and corrals to victims of a fire that razed more than 550 homes in this seaside city. Cafes offered free meals to emergency workers. A hardware store sent buckets and shovels to the Earl Warren Showgrounds for cleaning up after wayward horses. And the local bird lady took in a pigeon whose owner had flown to Italy. Everybody in Santa Barbara heard about it on radio station KTMS, which pulled the plug on commercials shortly after the fire broke out and turned itself into a community billboard. ``How do you say no to that?'' said Jim Rome, the all-news station's sports director. ``We're a community radio station and the community is devastated. We all have to pull together.'' Calling home was impossible, so hundreds of people took to the airwaves. ``Michelle and Angie Douglas, call Nancy ... Nancy is looking for you.'' ``David ... Karen has your dog. Anna, call Karen's mom.'' The station raised $20,000 in donations and $14,000 for the arrest and conviction of the arsonist who started the fire. Big and small chunks poured in _ $50, $100, $5,000, and $5.17 from a 7-year-old who raided his toy bank vault. People offered rooms for the night. The American Red Cross, Salvation Army and other organizations alerted evacuees to emergency shelters. Sometimes, things didn't work so well. A call for volunteer firefighters was quashed because of the danger and liability. A notice that a hospital wanted to be contacted by an injured man's insurer turned out to be bogus. But everyone was listening. ``It's the news line of the town,'' said Board of Realtors president Cyndee Eliassen, who got word out that several property owner groups and real estate firms had compiled a computer list of available housing. ``This is a community that I've never seen fail,'' Eliason said. ``Once people calm down, the hurt begins and then the need begins.'' Tim and Juli Alward, chased from their home Wednesday night, returned to find it safe and offered their spare room to those not so lucky. ``There's a lot of real good people up here. We could have lost our home and I don't know where we would have gone,'' Mrs. Alward said. Horse owners offered empty corrals and listeners learned of space at the Earl Warren Showgrounds. And there was concern for smaller animals. Linda McCarthy, a self-described ``bird woman,'' dispensed advice on Macaws, African gray parrots and nervous flocks of cockatiels through her organization, ECHO _ The Everyone Can Help Organization. ``We've given lots of advice,'' McCarthy said. ``A lot of times, the birds are really upset and bashing their cages.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets May Declassify Cold-War Documents
DOC.TEXT: Scholars of the Cold War say new insight about the era could be gained as Soviet authorities move to declassify Stalinist-era documents. But documents won't tell the whole story, they said. U.S. historians including Arthur Schlesinger Jr., a former White House adviser to President Kennedy, took part in a three-day seminar with their Soviet counterparts to examine the origins of the Cold War 45 years ago. The U.S. historians said at a press briefing that participants discussed whether the Cold War could have been avoided and what role national leaders, including President Truman and Soviet dictator Josef Stalin, played in creating superpower hostility. A follow-up seminar will be held in Washington at the end of July. Soviet Foreign Minster Eduard A. Shevardnadze told the visiting Americans at a meeting Thursday morning that the Supreme Soviet legislature would consider measures to declassify post-war documents, Schlesinger said. ``We were assured that the law will go through,'' Schlesinger said. ``We were told they will be declassified in the not-too-distant future.'' Alexander Chubaryan, a member of the Soviet Institute of World History, said the Soviets have been slow in making original documents available to historians. ``The Soviet side is lagging behind in the sense of using archival documents,'' he said. But ``the seminar has shown that we have made progress and we were able to introduce several new documents for discussion.'' Several of the American participants, though, said that getting access to Soviet documents was not going to answer all questions about the causes of the Cold War. ``Don't kid yourself that all history is in documents,'' said Walt Rostow, and economist and former adviser to President Johnson. ``We are not naive enough to believe that if you collect enough documents, you will know ever everything.'' Even so, the seminars symbolize the movement from confrontation to cooperation between the two superpowers, said Allen Weinstein, a member of the U.S. Institute of Peace, which is co-sponsoring the meetings along with the Soviet Research Coordination Center. The Cold War, the two sides agreed, is basically over. But Schlesinger said there were still some residual effects. ``Some wheels are still spinning,'' he said without elaborating. Harvard historian Richard Pipes, an East European specialist who served as an adviser to President Reagan's National Security Council, said one of the causes of the Cold War was the ``demonization'' of the two countries. ``They thought capitalism was a demon, we thought communism was a demon. We demonized each other,'' Pipes said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Defends Plan To Kill 30,000 Seals
DOC.TEXT: Despite angry protests from environmentalists, the government said today it will go ahead with plans to kill 30,000 baby and adult seals next month. Government officials say the seal population of 1.2 million on the cosat must be reduced because the animals were depleting fish stocks. Some 25,000 baby seals and 5,000 adult male seals are to be slaughtered for leather and chicken feed at Port Nolloth on the west coast. ``The government seems to be totally insensitive to conservation. This deal has to be very lucrative if they simply ignore local and international opinion on this barbarity,'' said Christine Berry of Beauty Without Cruelty, an animal rights group. Press reports said petition drives were being organized and that some activists had vowed to try to physically stop the killings. South Africa's Department of Environmental Affairs said the killings would be carried out humanely, first by clubbing the seals to stun them and then stabbing them in the heart. The government said it would intervene if the killings were not carried out humanely.

DOC.HEAD: Cease-Fire Could Be Negotiated, ANC Official Says
DOC.TEXT: The white-minority government and the African National Congress could soon negotiate a cease-fire after almost 30 years of hostilities, a leading ANC official predicts. Joe Slovo, an ANC leader and the head of the South African Communist Party, said Thursday the government and the ANC would seek to work out a cease-fire once they resolve several preliminary issues. In another development, President F.W. de Klerk declared six neighborhoods open to all races as part of the government's plan to ease four decades of strict residential segregation. On Thursday, the president approved the integration of six relatively small neighborhoods that include one suburb each in Johannesburg and Cape Town, a rural area outside Durban, and parts of three small towns, Knysna, Messina, and Zuurbekom. The government opened four neighborhoods to all races in November. Neighborhoods, along with public schools and the political system, are the main institutions still segregated in South Africa. The government and the ANC held their first talks in May and have since worked together on a document to remove the obstacles to full-scale constitutional negotiations. Slovo, in an interview, expressed optimism about negotiating with the government on a new constitution and an end to apartheid. ``There is a good chance that if the obstacles are removed we will at a very early stage move toward ... the negotiation of a suspension of hostilities,'' he said. The obstacles, he said, include the return of 20,000 ANC exiles and the release of about 3,000 activists convicted of politically motivated crimes. The government wants the ANC to renounce its largely dormant guerrilla campaign in order to improve the climate for negotiations. The question of violence has been one of the most contentious issues between the government and the ANC. President Bush, who hosted ANC leader Nelson Mandela at the White House on Monday, also urged the organization to disavow violence. However, Mandela and other ANC leaders continue to support the armed struggle, saying it is necessary to maintain pressure on the government and also as a measure of self-defense. The ANC, the country's largest opposition group, has not carried out any major attacks this year. Dozens of anti-apartheid demonstrators have been killed by police during the same period. The government says it approves of the document, while the ANC has requested until July 10 to respond. No details have been released. Slovo fled South Africa in 1963. He returned from the ANC's exile headquarters in Zambia as part of the 11-member delegation that met with the government last month. He previously headed the ANC's armed wing, which was launched in 1961, a year after the ANC was outlawed. His influential South African Communist Party has been closely allied with the ANC since the 1920s and several people hold top posts in both organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Apartheid Leader's Visit Inspires Blacks, Offends Cubans
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's brief visit here was shunned by local politicians and denounced by Cuban exiles but hailed by blacks as a triumphant message of hope in racially divided South Florida. The South African anti-apartheid leader enjoyed warm receptions in every other city on his U.S. tour. But most elected officials here boycotted his speech to a labor convention. About 300 protesters denounced him. Concerned for his safety, a State Department security team persuaded the 71-year-old Mandela to leave for Detroit on Thursday without stopping at a park in Miami's predominantly black Liberty City neighborhood where about 1,500 supporters had hoped to catch a glimpse of the South African anti-apartheid leader. ``I'm very embarrassed,'' said Willie Haywood, a 34-year-old postal worker who joined more than 2,000 supporters trying to offset the official neglect with a festive rally outside the Miami Beach Convention Center. ``They had ticker-tape parades for him in New York and hundreds of thousands saw him speak in Boston,'' Haywood said. ``Now we have the distinction of being the most racist city in America.'' Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez and every other Cuban-born politician in the area rescinded welcome plans last week after Mandela refused on national television to disavow his gratitude toward Cuban President Fidel Castro for past support. In the same broadcast, Mandela also cited Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi for their help in the early years of the anti-apartheid struggle. While area Jewish leaders said the comments were troubling, only a few Jewish people joined the demonstration against Mandela. Mandela did not directly acknowledge the controversy in his speech to the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees union. ``To be welcomed by those who hold the reins of power in this area, to be warmly received by residents of Miami is a source of great inspiration to us,'' Mandela said to the cheering crowd inside the cavernous hall. Out in the street, his supporters strained to listen to portable radios as protesters traded slogans on megaphones. Many blacks said they were embittered by the experience and chanted ``Free South Florida.'' Others promised to retaliate on election day and hoped Mandela's visit would prove a powerful force for change. ``The spirit of unity is here. The sleeping giant is awake. And it's going to reflect itself in the reconstruction of the black community in South Florida,'' said Ray Fauntroy, director of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in Miami. Blacks and Hispanics have long been at odds in the metropolitan Miami area, where inner-city riots erupted three times in the 1980s and only two black elected officials remain in local governments dominated by Cuban-Americans. But racial divisions seemed particularly stark Thursday as police set up barricades and struggled to keep the mostly black pro-Mandela crowd separated from the Cuban exiles, who burned a Soviet flag and shouted ``Down with Mandela.'' ``We're not singling out Mandela's cause. We are opposed to anyone who does not oppose Castro,'' said Rafael Cabezas, a veteran of the failed Bay of Pigs invasion. ``They should be here with the keys to the city,'' countered Joe Cook, 40, who wore long dreadlocks and an African medallion on his chest. ``Anybody who turns his back on him is a little bitty man.'' Police broke up several scuffles between the factions and quickly ushered away two self-described white supremacists who carried signs saying ``Fight Communism: Support the Afrikaner Resistance Movement.'' Mandela supporters sang and musicians in traditional African costumes pounded a steady drumbeat as they waited for the anti-apartheid leader's motorcade. Hundreds of people sprinted around the block in hopes of catching a bit of history when he finally pulled into a side entrance. ``I saw him! I saw Mandela!'' shouted Rovan Locke, the publisher of Miami-based Caribbean Commentary magazine. ``Such a great human being in my midst. It's the greatest feeling in my life.''

DOC.HEAD: Mass Grave With Bodies of 14 Policemen Found
DOC.TEXT: Government troops in a northeastern village have discovered a mass grave with the bodies of 14 Sinhalese policemen captured by Tamil rebels, military officials said today. In another development, the government declared an indefinite curfew today in the coastal town of Batticaloa, 135 miles east of Colombo, and conducted house-to-house searches for rebels. The officials in Colombo, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the policemen's bodies were found Thursday at Uppuveli village near Trincomalee, 145 miles northeast of Colombo. The victims, who had been fatally shot, were among 46 policemen captured by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam when the rebels took over the Uppuveli police station two weeks ago, said the officials. The fate of the others was not known. The Tigers overran a string of police stations along the eastern coast starting June 11 after a Tamil man in Batticaloa told the rebels he had been manhandled by Sinhalese police. Government forces launched an offensive and soon forced the rebels to retreat into the jungles and swamps in the east. Military officials believe the Tigers' retreat may be a tactical move to launch a protracted guerrilla war. At least 1,731 combatants and an unknown but large number of civilians have been killed in the fighting. In Jaffna town, 185 miles north of Colombo, rebels continued their siege of a garrison in a 200-year-old fort in the center of the town, pounding its stone walls with mortars and rockets. About 225 policemen and soldiers are holed up in the fort. Its capture by the rebels would be a major blow to the government, which now has only four military installations in the north under its control. The Palali airfield near the fort is also besieged. The government controls two naval bases in the peninsula. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne acknowledged Thursday that many civilians were killed when the air force strafed and bombed Jaffna town in an attempt to break the siege. He blamed pilot error. The rebels have said ``hundreds of houses'' have been burned by incendiary bombs. Tamil rebels have waged a war for a separate homeland in the north and the east since 1983. The fighting has claimed more than 12,600 lives. The latest round of fighting ended a 13-month cease-fire negotiated by the government of President Ranasinghe Premadasa in May 1989 with the Tamil Tigers. Tamil separatists claim their community is discriminated against by the majority, predominantly Buddhist Sinhalese. Accounting for 75 percent of the island's 16 million people, Sinhalese dominate the government and the military. Tamils, who are mostly Hindus, comprise 18 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Voices From the Inferno
With PM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Heat, drought and arson have again formed a disastrous combination in Southern California's brush-covered hillsides. Here are the voices of some of those affected:
``It's just a disaster. Everything just exploded.'' _ Dennie Gill, a produce wholesaler whose home was destroyed in the Los Angeles suburb of Glendale.

``There's a lot of real good people up here. We could have lost our home and I don't know where we would have gone.'' _ Juli Alward, who was chased with her husband from their Santa Barbara home Wednesday night, returned to find it safe and offered their spare room to those not so lucky.

``I'm really bummed out about this fire.'' _ Eleven-year-old Maya Hawkins, whose summer escape to the mountains of Santa Barbara at actress Jane Fonda's Laurel Springs Camp for the arts went up in smoke.

``This is a memory that we'll all share forever. Years from now when people talk about the great Santa Barbara fire, we will say we were there and we survived it.'' _ Camp counselor Colleen Shelley, consoling 48 boys and girls who were evacuated from Laurel Springs Camp.
``To make matters worse, fireworks go on sale today. We're not happy about that.'' _ California Department of Forestry spokeswoman Sharon Sellers.

``We're a community radio station and the community is devastated. We all have to pull together.'' _ Jim Rome of radio station KTMS, which pulled the plug on commercials shortly after the Santa Barbara fire broke out and turned itself into a community billboard.

DOC.HEAD: Meador Confided in Friend About Smuggled Medieval Art
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. soldier accused of smuggling medieval treasures out of Germany near the end of World War II confided to a longtime friend that he took the trove, a newspaper reported today. For years before his death in 1980, Joe T. Meador was torn over whether to keep the artwork or return it, Owen Hunsaker, Meador's college classmate in the 1930s, told The Dallas Morning News. ``When he looked at it he'd get a dreary, transported look on his face because he knew what he had _ he loved it _ and he couldn't part with it,'' Hunsaker was quoted as saying. ``He struggled with that a lot,'' said Hunsaker, a 71-year-old retired airline executive who lives in New York. Hunsaker said his friend told him he found the treasures in a cave in 1945 in Quedlinburg, now in East Germany, and had simply wrapped them in brown paper and used an Army post office to ship them to his home in Whitewright, 60 miles north of Dallas. Hunsaker is the first person to explain how Meador allegedly discovered the artwork and moved it. Reports about the case first surfaced in The New York Times two weeks ago. The treasures included manuscripts, crucifixes and ancient coins, which church officials said were gifts to the Quedlinburg Cathedral from Germany's earliest kings. Lawyers for the Lutheran Church of Quedlinburg contend that Meador stole the treasures while serving as an Army lieutenant among troops that occupied the area in April 1945. Meador left the cache to his brother and sister, Jack Meador and Jane Meador Cook. They are disputing the church's claim of ownership and trying to keep the items, which are worth millions. The Meador family is asking the church's permission to display the treasures at the Dallas Museum of Art or the Kimball Art Museum in Fort Worth while the lawsuit over ownership is pending, the News reported today. ``We have not as yet spoken with either museum,'' the family's attorney, Randal Mathis, told the newspaper. ``We think that they would be appropriate places for safekeeping.'' Hunsaker was in the Pacific during World War II while his friend fought in Germany. He said that during a visit to Whitewright in 1948, Meador showed him artwork that he said he had wrapped in brown paper, marked as ``old books'' and deposited in a mailbox at Army headquarters. He said Meador told him that he found the artwork in 1945 in a cave filled with treasures of gold and silver, and filled his Army jacket with ``as many treasures as he could hold'' before returning to his headquarters. U.S. Army reports indicate the treasures were removed from a mine shaft near Quedlinburg within three days after Allied troops occupied the area in April 1945. Hunsaker, the News reported, said Meador did not tell him whether anyone helped him remove the artwork or whether he returned to the cave later to get more items. He said they sat for hours paging through a manuscript with an elaborate cover of gold encrusted with jewels, and highlighted with a silver figure of Jesus Christ with his hand risen in benediction. ``It was unbelievable,'' Hunsaker said. ``I knew I was touching ancient history.'' Hunsaker said he frequently tried but failed to persuade Meador to turn over the artwork to authorities. ``Joe knew he had a hot potato,'' said Hunsaker. ``He couldn't let everybody know about it, and he certainly couldn't sell it.'' Hunsaker said he last talked to Meador a few years before he died.

DOC.HEAD: Remains Brought By Vietnamese Refugees Not Those Of U.S. MIAs
DOC.TEXT:
Human bones brought by Vietnamese refugees earlier this month were not those of U.S. servicemen missing in action, the U.S. Embassy said today. The refugees had said the remains were those of American MIAs. Embassy press officer Meg Gilroy said the 32 sets of remains had been examined by a forensic team from the Army's Central Identification Laboratory in Hawaii. ``They did not find the remains of any Americans,'' she said. On June 12, nine Vietnamese refugees landed on Tanjung Sedili Beach, 150 miles southeast of Kuala Lumpur, with seven barrels stuffed with bones. They claimed the bones were those of soldiers killed in Vietnam. The skeletons had dog tags on them. But Gilroy said none of the names on the dog tags were those of Americans missing in action in the Vietnam War, which ended with the Communist victory in 1975. The United States now lists 2,303 Americans as missing in the Indochina War. These include 1,678 in Vietnam.
The refugees said they had intended to bring the remains to Singapore and hand them over to U.S. officials, and in exchange seek preferential treatment for settlement in the United States. They said they landed in Malaysia instead of Singapore because their boat began to leak. Singapore is about 60 miles south of where they landed. Embassy officials said even if the remains had been those of American servicemen, it would not have affected the refugees' applications to enter the United States. The refugees were taken to a Malaysian refugee camp for screening.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Midwest, Intense Heat in Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Scorching heat persisted in the desert Southwest and western Plains today, and rain fell across the Great Lakes region. Meteorologists say the prolonged heat and drought that have sparked forest fires across the Southwest will remain over the region. Unseasonably warm weather also is expected along the East Coast. Today's forecast calls for thunderstorms in parts of Montana and the Dakotas, over much of the Great Lakes and New York. On Thursday, tornadoes touched down in Iowa at Ackley, Owasa and near Van Horne, but there were no reports of injuries or major damage. More than 2 inches of rain fell in parts of southeastern Minnesota. High temperature records for the date were broken or tied in dozens of towns Thursday. Alamosa, Colo., recorded a high of 91 degrees, up from 89 in 1974; Amarillo, Texas, tied its 1929 record of 102. The high temperature for the Lower 48 was 118 degrees in Arizona at Phoenix, Bullhead City and Gila Bend. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Edging Higher In Quiet Trading, Gold Little Changed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged higher against most currencies in quiet European trading this morning as the market awaited the start of German monetary union this weekend. Gold prices were little changed in modest trading. Foreign exchange dealers said activity was subdued by over what monetary union on Sunday will do to the German mark. ``The mark is unusually vulnerable in the current situation,'' said one dealer at a West German bank. The yen was being bid higher because of bullish interest rate expectations following Thursday's U.S.-Japan economic accord aimed at trimming Japan's massive trade surplus with the United States, and this in turn was bolstering the dollar against the mark,'' he said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 1.57 yen to a closing 152.85 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 152.35 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.6719 West German marks, up from 1.6675 _1.4150 Swiss francs, up from 1.4125 _5.6183 French francs, up from 5.6015 _1.8810 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8772 _1,226.00 Italian lire, up from 1,224.25 _1.1685 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1692 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.7434, compared with $1.7400 late Thursday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $352.10 an ounce, down from $352.25 bid late Thursday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a higher recommended price of $352.40. In Zurich, the bid price was $352.25, down from $352.60 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.40 to close at a bid $352.74. Silver was selling in London at a bid price of $4.83 an ounce, down from Thursday's $4.85.

DOC.HEAD: Convention Brings Strategy Experts to the Game Table
DOC.TEXT: It's not all nerds and Napoleons when the masters of fantasy and war games hold a convention. But the masked people in black capes and uniformed guys hunched over little battlefields enjoy being bizarre. According to best-selling author Tom Clancy, who was scoping out the scene Thursday, some even look neurotic. ``There are some bona fide nuts here, people who think Dungeons and Dragons is real,'' said Clancy, author of ``The Hunt for Red October,'' ``Clear and Present Danger,'' and other military thrillers. ``But there are also some bona fide experts from the military, and what they have to say is real.'' The 16th annual ``Origins '90'' convention gives ``gamers'' from all over the country a chance to see who's the best wizard, warrior or soldier in their favorite games. Three hundred companies are showing their new wares at the Atlanta Hilton, and the opening day crowd numbered in the thousands. ``What, is it Halloween already?'' shrieked a hotel guest as she almost ran into a Ninja-looking creature with a skull for a head. ``This is weird.'' Military strategy games have been around as long as the ancient Egyptians, who planned battle moves with clay figures in the sand. The military still uses similar tactics to a degree. Fantasy games are largely the invention of Gary Gygax, who invented the popular Dungeons and Dragons role-playing game in 1974. Fantasy players like to dress up and wander around. ``It's probably kind of weird if you don't know about role playing,'' said Ben Rhoades as he prepared to play a three-day marathon Ars Magica wizardry game. ``You probably think we're all nerds. We're not mainstream.'' Then there's the board game Warhammer 40,000K, where players Fred Shallowford and Charlie Traylor insist that the 20th century as we know it doesn't actually exist because aliens transformed the Milky Way in the Middle Ages. The Earth is now dominated by Gene Stealers and Imperial Space Marines. The battles take place on painstakingly realistic miniature battlefields. ``It's a way of life. Some people fish. This is what I do,'' Traylor explained. Then there are the battle strategy games where the military buffs shine. Retired Marine Maj. Robert Murawski took a long look at the game On Watch, where American soldiers in World War II were trying to take over a Gestapo unit's headquarters, and fired one of his tanks. The result, as determined by tape measure: total destruction of a natural gas pump, the German soldiers hiding at its top and a cloud of smoke that would obscure the American platoon as it advanced. ``This is war. You take what you can when you can,'' said Murawski, a former project manager for the Marine Corps' war games. That is what Clancy came to see. He doesn't have time to play war games, but Clancy, who taught himself the intricacies of military technology through books, concedes he might learn something for a future book. ``There are some really smart people here, but there are some even bigger nuts. But even some of the nuts are experts.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Prince Takes Commoner As Bride in Ancient Ceremony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 15th graf `The princess...' to ADD no foreign ambassadors invited; pick up 16th graf `Japan's television...'; ADDS 1 graf at bottom with crowds along motorcade route.
DOC.TEXT: Sipping sacred rice wine in a shrine to the sun goddess, Emperor Akihito's youngest son and his college sweetheart were wed today as millions of Japanese watched on television. Flanked by imperial ritualists, Prince Aya, 24, and Kiko Kawashima, 23, knelt together in the Imperial Palace shrine to the goddess Amaterasu, from whom legend says the royal family is descended. Miss Kawashima, a graduate student, is the second commoner to marry into the royal family, and the marriage was seen as another step in bringing the imperial palace and Japan's people closer together. The ceremony also was being hailed as the public's first taste of the new imperial era, called Heisei or ``achieving peace,'' which began with the death of Emperor Hirohito on Jan. 7, 1989. The new emperor, Akihito, has been credited with trying to create a more open, softer image for Japan's often distant and mysterious imperial family. Still, much of today's wedding cermony was in line with Japanese traditions going back more than 1,000 years. The prince, speaking the classical Japanese used by priests of Japan's indigenous Shinto religion, recited vows to the sun goddess. The couple sealed their nuptial bonds by sipping sacred rice wine from a white ceramic cup. Aya was clad in a black silk robe and cap with an arched tailpiece signifying his royal rank. The bride wore a green, maroon and orange kimono, nearly a dozen layers thick and reportedly weighing 50 pounds. The princess' preparations for the wedding, which began before dawn, included a purification ritual and the coiffing of her hair in the elaborate court fashion of a thousand years ago. Police say that because of threats from leftist radicals, 9,000 officers were assigned to guard the wedding activities, though most were being held at either the Imperial Palace, which is surrounded by a moat and forbidding stone walls, or the Akasaka Palace, the well-secured residence of the emperor and empress. The wedding was the first for an imperial family member in six years, and the first in three decades for a prince of Aya's rank. Aya is second in line to the Chrysanthemum Throne after his elder brother, Crown Prince Naruhito, 30, who has yet to marry. Empress Michiko became the first commoner to marry into the family when she and Akihito, then crown prince, wed in 1959. In keeping with tradition, the emperor and empress were absent from the ceremony at the shrine, but were receiving the couple later at the palace. ``I am praying for their happiness,'' the emperor said in a statement after the ceremony. The princess followed a few steps behind the prince as they entered the outer sanctuary of the wooden ``Kashikodokoro'' shrine. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other government leaders and imperial family members were among about 150 guests watching from outside. Foreign ambassadors were not invited to the ceremony, but were to attend a tea party at the palace on Saturday. Japan's television networks pre-empted regular programs to carry the ceremony and related events live. Aya was given a new title, Prince Akishino, to mark his establishing of an independent household. Akishino is the name of a town in western Japan with close ties to the imperial family. ``This is the first big event of the Heisei Era,'' said former imperial chamberlain Minoru Hamao, who served as a close attendant to Akihito for 20 years. ``The princess is the perfect person for today's imperial household, and I'm sure that as time goes on she will gradually help bring the monarchy even closer to the people,'' he said in an interview. Miss Kawashima has won public affection with her warm smile and quiet manner. Because of her relatively humble background _ her father is an economics professor at Gakushuin University, a former peers school _ she was called a modern-day Cinderella. She was also dubbed the ``Apartment Princess'' because she lived with her family in faculty housing on the Gakushuin campus, where she is working on her masters degree in social psychology. ``I feel tense as I think about becoming a member of the imperial family, and recognize the responsibilities,'' the princess wrote in a letter carried today by the daily newspaper Asahi Shimbun. She said she wanted to lead ``a happy life with Prince Aya under the refreshing sky.'' Aya, a Gakushuin graduate, met Miss Kawashima at a bookstore on the campus in 1985. Their engagement was approved by the government in September. The royal couple's first trip together will be to the Grand Shrines of Ise and the tomb of the Emperor Jimmu, both in central Japan. Emperor Jimmu, according to myth, was Japan's first monarch and ascended in 660 B.C. After the ceremony, the couple went by motorcade from the Imperial Palace to Akasaka Palace, where they will live near the emperor and empress. Crowds lined the motorcade's route, and the new princess, wearing a diamond diamond tiara, smiled and waved.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Propose Alternative For Defense Spending
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and four fellow Democrats are calling for the United States to use resources and technology from military cutbacks to improve the environment. Majority members of the Senate Armed Services Committee, led by panel chairman Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia proposed on Thursday creating a Strategic Environmental Research Program to use the skills of the Defense and Energy departments and some elements of the intelligence community. The resources once used in a military role would be directed to environmental programs under the proposal to be included in the 1991 defense spending bill. ``I believe that one of our key national security objectives must be to reverse the accelerating pace of environmental destruction around the globe,'' Nunn said in a speech on the Senate floor. Sen. Albert Gore, Jr., D-Tenn., said the nation is realizing that its security can be threatened by other forces. ``We must certainly give the highest standing to the consequences of a damaged and destabilized natural environment,'' Gore said. A new Defense Environmental Research Council would develop a five-year program for environmental research using data collection and analysis, alternative energy technologies and environmental cleanup technology. The purpose of the council would be to coordinate research on the link between human action and the environment, assess the damage done by the Defense and Energy departments to the land and water, develop technology to correct the problems and then give that information to the private sector and other countries. ``Our real peace dividend will consist of the research talent that will be made available as our defense establishment is reduced _ thousands of highly trained and educated scientists, engineers and technicians,'' Nunn said. The proposal, which carries no cost estimate, will be ironed out as the Senate committee begins crafting a defense bill sometime next month. Joining Nunn and Gore in proposing the legislation were Sens. James Exon, D-Neb., Jeff Bingaman, N.M., and Timothy Wirth, D-Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian President Praises Foreign Aid; Admonishes Critics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Rafsanjani comment; edit for transition. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `The official...'
DOC.TEXT: President Hashemi Rafsanjani said today that Iran should be thankful for foreign aid for earthquake victims, defending the help against hard-liners who oppose it. Rafsanjani, speaking a weekly prayers at Tehran University, cited an editorial in a radical newspaper last week that denounced assistance from countries like the United States and said people chanted ``Death to America'' even from under the rubble. ``I don't think we see the people who are under the debris saying, `No we don't want foreign aid,'' the president said. ``The response and activities of the foreigners were really good and acceptable.'' The anti-Western faction in the Iranian government, led by lawmaker Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, opposes any form of foreign assistance to the Islamic Republic in the wake of last Thursday's devastating earthquake. Rafsanjani has sought to open Iran to more foreign investment as a means of gaining technology to rebuild the sagging economy. He made no link today between Western aid and the release of U.S. and other Western hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. But Iran has said Western gestures of goodwill could prompt Iran to further help obtain the hostages' freedom. The United States broke diplomatic relations with Iran after Islamic radicals seized the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in November 1979 and held 52 hostages for 444 days. Recent emergency aid from Western countries, including the United States, for the hundreds of thousands of victims of the earthquake has raised speculation about a possible thawing of relations. ``The assistance has an effect, nobody can say it doesn't,'' said an Iranian diplomatic official, speaking on condition of anonymity. But he added that the U.S. government has missed an opportunity because of the small size of its donation. ``The $295,000 the United States is giving is like a joke,'' he said. ``It's the amount of one house in California.'' He was referring to the value of supplies donated by the U.S. government that was airlifted to Iran on Sunday on a Red Cross charter flight. The shipment included blankets, tents, water jugs, and search-and-rescue equipment. The United States on Wednesday announced it would send another shipment of emergency supplies, bringing the total U.S. government contribution to about $760,000. But that figure is still below the aid provided by some other countries. Sweden has already donated $3 million in quake aid, and North Korea announced it would give $1 million worth of supplies. The official said the main issue in improving U.S.-Iranian relations is the freeing of Iranian assets frozen in the United States. ``It would have a positive effect,'' he said. Although some claims were recently settled with Iran, the bulk of the assets remain frozen. The official indicated that the release of the six remaining American hostages in Lebanon was an issue separate from earthquake aid. He said Iranian officials did their best to obtain the release of two U.S. hostages, Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, who were freed in April by their pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem kidnappers in Beirut. But he indicated that Iran's help in gaining the release of more U.S. hostages is contingent on U.S. efforts to help free four Iranians kidnapped in July 1982 by Lebanese Christian militiamen. ``We were surprised at the lack of response from the United States over the recent release of U.S. hostages with Iranian help,'' the official said. ``In some ways we have influence (over the release of additional hostages), but this is the time for you to do something.'' The Bush administration recently provided information to Iran, through the Swiss government, which Washington said indicated the four men were dead. But Iranian officials insist they are still alive. Sixteen Western hostages are believed held by Shiite Moslem militants in Lebanon. The longest-held hostage is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped in March 1985.

DOC.HEAD: State Senator's Proposal: `Will You Marry Me?' On Electronic Message Board
DOC.TEXT: A 29-year-old man looking for a nice spot to propose marriage to his girlfriend decided to use his workplace _ the ornate, 111-year-old Senate chamber. ``Carolyn, will you marry me?'' State Sen. Stephen Somma of Waterbury asked 26-year-old Carolyn Miller on Wednesday, using the Senate's electronic message board to spell out the words. Without debate, Miller pressed the green button on Somma's Senate desk, lighting up the message board with a ``yes.'' ``She did not remark,'' said Somma, using the formal language of the Senate. He added: ``She was floored.'' Somma said he planned the proposal for nearly a month. He asked Senate staff members to program the message board with the proposal, and then brought Miller to the Senate chamber on the pretense of looking at photographs for a campaign brochure. Miller works in public relations for the Connecticut Food Stores Association, a lobbying group. ``I wanted to do something unique, and I chose the Capitol because we both spend a lot of time up here,'' said Somma, a freshman Republican.

DOC.HEAD: De Maiziere Echoes West Germany's Call For Unification This Year
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's prime minister is predicting a full merger by the end of the year, calling for the same timetable as West German officials, a newspaper reported today. Lothar de Maiziere, the country's first democratically elected leader, also added that a compromise must be found to eliminate Soviet objections to NATO membership for unified Germany. On Sunday, East Germany and West Germany embark on the mammoth task of joining their two economies, the former troubled weakling and the latter a world-leading powerhouse. In an interview with the East German newspaper Neue Zeit, de Maiziere predicted that a 35-nation European summit will approve the unification plan at its meeting in Paris in November. He said he was ``confident that by the end of the year we can clear up all of the internal and international problems'' to complete unification, according to Neue Zeit, which is closely allied with de Maiziere's Christian Democrats. West German officials have called for combined German elections for early December, with full national unification to take place the following day. De Maiziere, however, did not offer any specific ways to overcome Soviet reservations to unification. The Soviet Union has 380,000 troops stationed in East Germany, once the front line of the Cold War with the West, and the Kremlin has balked at allowing a united Germany to be exclusively a member of the Western NATO military alliance. In the final days before currency union, leaders from both sides today urged East Germans to be cautious in spending the thousands of West German marks most of them will get Sunday. Financial experts are worried that a sudden unfettered buying spree would derail efforts to join the two economies smoothly. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel urged East Germans to save or invest their money as their country shifts from 40 years of socialism to capitalism. Waigel's East German counterpart, Walter Romberg, provided some of the most elementary advice to a people long accustomed to snatching up whatever they can to hedge against frequent shortages. ``The market economy will allow us to buy what we need and to choose among many offers,'' Romberg said. ``So, no more buying at any price, and no more uneconomical stocking up.'' De Maiziere came to power after the country's first free elections in March that ousted the Communists. The balloting followed last fall's ouster of Communist hard-liners amid massive demonstrations.

DOC.HEAD: Police, Troops Storm Campus In Wake Of Food Riots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with witnesses saying student killed, others wounded in assault on campus. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `This week's...'
DOC.TEXT: Troops and paramilitary police shut down the nation's main university campus today after a predawn assault in which they beat many students and ordered thousands to pack their bags. Witnesses said one student was killed, but this report could not be immediately confirmed. At least 27 students accused of inciting four days of bloody unrest were dragged from their rooms, beaten and taken into custody, the students said. Thousands of students were herded with their belongings onto the main lawn of the campus, where they were surrounded by police and troops in full combat gear, witnesses said. A senior police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the campus had been closed indefinitely. Groups of students were ferried to bus stops at gunpoint. There was no immediate comment from university authorities on the shutdown of the school. One student said students barricaded themselves in their rooms when security forces launched their predawn assault, but that troops broke down doors and fired their weapons. The action came after student-led protests against cuts in food price subsidies earlier in the week that flared into countrywide rioting against the one-party socialist government of President Kenneth Kaunda. At least 23 people died in the violence. Elsewhere in Lusaka, the capital of this south-central African nation, residents returned to work and schools reopened. Kaunda had said that he would disclose today the date for a referendum on whether the country should restore a multiparty system. The students are demanding Western-style democracy. In addition to the 23 people killed, hundreds of alleged looters were wounded in rioting this week, the bloodiest urban unrest since independence from Britian in 1964. This week's unrest began after the government cut subsidies for corn meal, doubling the price of the staple. More than 30 student leaders have been detained under security laws and at least four were shot and wounded in clashes with armed police since Monday. On Thursday, as an uneasy calm returned to most major cities and towns, defiant students demanding Kaunda's resignation prepared gasoline bombs and vowed to defend themselves against the security forces. Students appeared not to have used petrol bombs early today as troops destroyed banners that said ``Down With Kaunda'' and ``Kaunda Must Resign, The Murderer Must Go.'' Throughout the capital, work gangs cleared rubble and makeshift barricades from the roads and some public buses were running. The main courthouse was sealed off and officials said some demonstrators would be brought before magistrates later today. Kaunda has promised to crack down on what he described as criminal stampedes and thuggery by protesters. Kaunda led the former British colony of Northern Rhodesia to independence as Zambia 26 years ago. He declared a one-party state in 1972. The increase in the price of corn meal was announced as part of an economic reform program aimed at reducing government subsidies and making the economy of Zambia, one of Africa's poorest nations, more commercially viable. The program was recommended by financial agencies and donor nations. However, it increased popular discontent with Kaunda, who is among a group of African rulers besieged by demands for democratic reforms. Kaunda said the economic reform program would continue despite the unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Couple Wed in Ancient-Style Costumes
With PM-Japan-Royal Wedding, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kiko Kawashima married the emperor's second son today wearing a kimono set of a dozen layers, with a train reported to weigh 50 pounds. With help, it takes about two hours to put on the outfit, which reportedly cost more than $229,000. Prince Aya also wore a traditional Japanese court costume, although his was simpler. He was in a black robe with large sleeves _ with the design of cranes flying into clouds _ and a cap with an arched tailpiece, a symbol of his status as an imperial prince. He is second in line to the throne. A lady-in-waiting carried the train for the new Princess Kiko, whose kimono resembled those worn by court ladies for weddings during the Heian Period, from 794-1192. She wore her hair with a long braid down the back and a gold headpiece in front, and held a folded fan wrapped with colorful strings. Under a light green silk outer jacket was an orange kimono. Inside were additional layers of silk robes in solid colors such as green, orange, maroon and burgundy and a bottom layer of white. Each color could be seen at the edges of the sleeves. To go with the colorful tops, she wore a dark burgundy silk hakama, or pleated baggy long pants. For a formal call later on Aya's parents, Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko, she changed into a white, Western-style evening dress with gold and silver embroidery. It was a present from Prince Aya at their engagement ceremony in January. She also wore a diamond-studded tiara, necklace, bracelet and earrings _ all custom-made for the occasion. Kyodo News Service estimated the cost at $130,000.

DOC.HEAD: Search Ends with 24 Dead, Nine Missing
DOC.TEXT: Two weeks after a flood that devastated an eastern Ohio village and killed at least 24 people, the search for victims has ended. By nightfall Thursday, the Army Corps of Engineers and a private contractor had given up sifting through debris for victims at the Hannibal locks and dam on the Ohio River. The search had been centered on the dam, about 27 miles downstream from Shadyside, since flooding on June 14. Cranes mounted on barges were used to scoop through debris that collected around the intake of a power plant at the dam. As of Thursday night, nine names remained on the list of those missing since the flood. Only two of those were known to live in the area before the flooding, said Army Corps of Engineers spokesman Steven Wright. The other seven were people who had lived in the area at one time for whom their current residences are unknown, authorities said. ``The other seven were unconfirmed, but I think authorities erred on the side of safety in reporting the possible missing,'' Wright said. ``They put out the names and got no response.'' Wright said only a small amount of the 20,000 cubic yards of debris remained, leaving little hope that any other victims would be found there. ``I don't know what else can be done, '' Wright said.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Pact Seen as Landmark at Beginning of Long Road
DOC.TEXT: Officials and newspaper commentators today welcomed an agreement on economic reform in the United States and Japan as a first major step toward easing trade tensions. Expectations of higher interest rates here linked to the trade agreement, however, dealt a blow to the dollar and to Tokyo stock prices, analysts said. Japanese and American trade officials promised drastic changes in both countries after four days of negotiations that ended late Thursday. The final report on the talks, called the Structural Impediments Initiative, ended a series of negotiations on policy changes aimed at shrinking Japan's $49 billion trade surplus with the United States. Officials acknowledged that the agreement appeared to amount to meddling by each country in the other's economy, but they stressed that the success of the talks indicated the approach was constructive. The agreement could serve as an example in approaching economic disputes among other countries, Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said today. ``I think it's going to be accepted that we can do these sorts of things globally,'' he said. ``No economies are completely isolated.'' At Japan's urging, the United States agreed to take stronger action to reduce the federal budget deficit. Washington pledged to pursue policies aimed at promoting exports, increasing the competitiveness of U.S. businesses and improving education and worker training. Japan said it would adopt wider-ranging reforms aimed at stimulating demand for imports and improving living standards. They included much higher levels of public spending, changes in regulations on land use and retail distribution and harsher measures against unfair business practices. ``In this age of mutual economic dependence, we hope that the SII talks will serve as a new international model for economic administration. ... As nations increasingly bond together to form common markets, the need for such a model grows,'' the mass-circulation Yomiuri Shimbun said in an editorial. ``We are now in an economic era without national borders,'' said the Asahi Shimbun. ``Sovereignty is no longer what it used to be for any nation. We feel inclined to accept as a product of such a new era the SII talks.'' The English-language Japan Times said, ``The long and difficult process of the talks has clearly shown that these two Pacific trading partners are entering a new phase of their mutual relationship.'' But it said the ``real SII talks may have just started. ... The two nations will probably ... need to carry out even more drastic structural harmonization.'' Watanabe said the real impact of the agreement would depend on actions taken to carry it out. ``We've got to be dead serious in implementing what we have agreed. That's something to be concerned about now,'' he said. Japanese officials played down suggestions that the agreement, given Japan's wider concessions, was one-sided. Watanabe said Japanese officials viewed Bush's decision to relax his ``no new taxes'' stand and accept raising tax revenues to reduce the budget deficit as a sign that ``the Americans were very serious about the reciprocity of the talks.'' ``Our side also made suggestions that might be construed as an interference in U.S. domestic issues,'' Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said. ``If the people are fully informed of the new measures, I believe they will understand that these measures are something that must be implemented in order to improve their own living standard,'' he said. The immediate economic impact of the agreement was fear that increased public spending would lead to higher interest rates in Japan to curb inflation, analysts said. This discouraged both Japanese stock investors and potential dollar buyers, they said. The dollar closed the week at 152.85 yen, down 1.57 yen from Thursday's close of 154.42 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average, the key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, fell 165.95 points, or 0.52 percent, to 31,940.24.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS NYACK, N.Y.-dated 2nd item in rdp to RECAST.
DOC.TEXT: Helen Hayes, the grande dame of American actresses, is leading efforts to renovate a turn-of-the-century theater that once played silent movies into a $5 million arts center in her name. Hayes, 89, welcomed more than 100 friends, including actors Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Colleen Dewhurst and Jose Ferrer, to a fund-raising fete Wednesday at her Victorian river mansion in this Hudson River town about 30 miles north of New York City. ``This theater was born the same year I was, and I think it will outlive me,'' Hayes said. The 500-seat Helen Hayes-Tappan Zee Performing Arts Center, to open in 1991, is to offer theater, children's events, music and film. So far, more than $1 million has been raised.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Rejects Pardon of Billy the Kid
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Garrey Carruthers has rejected a writer's request that Billy the Kid be pardoned for his role in the 1878 shooting death of Sheriff William Brady. A letter is being prepared telling Las Cruces author Opal Lee Priestley of the governor's decision, B.J. Wagner-Adam, the governor's administrator of pardons and extraditions, said Thursday. Ms. Priestley is the author of ``Billy the Kid: The Good Side of a Bad Man.'' Hundreds of living people have clemency cases pending with just six months left in the Carruthers administration, said Ms. Wagner-Adam said. She said a full investigation of all facts surrounding the case would be impossible because it happened so long ago. ``There's such a volume of information out there and so much we don't know,'' she said. The writer contended that the Kid was denied a fair trial. ``It was generally considered by those who attended the trial that he got token representation, and it was a foregone conclusion he would be found guilty,'' Ms. Priestley said. ``There was not much doubt the cards were stacked against him.'' He escaped after the trial, killing two Lincoln County deputies. Ms. Priestley said perhaps hundreds of people knew where he was after that but would not betray him for a $500 reward. ``And $500 in those days was a fortune,'' Ms. Priestley said. The Kid, whose real name was said to be William Bonney or Henry McCarty, was shot to death in Fort Sumner, N.M., by Lincoln County Sheriff Pat Garrett in 1881.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Dissident Says He is Recovering From Ordeal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Fang saying he is in good health; pickup 2nd pvs, `Fang, a...'
DOC.TEXT: DELETE last graf to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON5
DOC.TEXT: Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi said today he is recovering from his yearlong ordeal in China and is looking forward to some peace and quiet at Cambridge University. Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, took refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing on June 4, 1989, during the Chinese government's military crackdown on pro-democracy students. They were allowed to leave for Britain only on Monday. China said the couple were released for medical reasons. Fang made no mention of any problems today and said ``my health is good.'' U.S. media reports said Fang recently suffered a mild heart attack and had refused to undergo treatment in a Chinese hospital. Fang, a 54-year-old astrophysicist, had been China's most vocal and eloquent dissident since late 1986, when he supported student pro-democracy protests. China's decision to allow the couple to leave eliminated a major obstacle to better relations with the West. Fang read a brief statement in English as he posed for pictures outside the Royal Society in central London with his wife and son Fang Ke, who flew to London from the United States on Wednesday. A second son remains in China. ``My wife and I have now had a few days' rest to recover from our ordeal,'' he said. ``We now look forward to going to Cambridge to pursue our academic work. We do not wish to answer any questions about political matters or to give any interviews. We look forward to a period of peace and quiet.'' He appealed to the media ``not to press me further'' and not to pursue him in Cambridge. Fang said there had been ``a very happy family reunion'' with his eldest son, whom he and his wife had not seen for four years. Fang Ke is a student at Wayne State University in Detroit. ``We now look forward to our second son's departure from Beijing to study in the United States,'' he said. The couple's younger son, Fang Zhe, is a student at Beijing University. Fang and his wife thanked the Royal Society, Britain's oldest and most prestigious scientific organization, and Cambridge University for inviting them to Britain. Fang will take up a Royal Society guest research professorship at the Institute of Astronomy at Cambridge on Monday. His wife, a physicist who co-authored one of his books, is also expected to continue her academic career. An agreement among China, Britain and the United States allowed the couple to leave the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. The official Xinhua news agency said they were given permission to leave China for medical reasons after showing ``signs of repentance.''

DOC.HEAD: Lack of State Support for Culture Protested in Soviet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS overline.
DOC.TEXT: Theatrical productions and concerts across the country were halted for five minutes to protest state neglect of culture, television reports and the Tass news agency said. Tass also said rallies and meetings in defense of culture were held at unions, publishing houses, museums, libraries and parks on Thursday. According to the protesters, the government spends only 16 cents per person each year for cultural institutions including state-run theater, concert halls and museums. They complained that artists and workers in the cultural arena were underpaid, citing as an example a museum curator's pay of $145 a month, the television report said. Tass said Nikolai Gubenko, the minister of culture, joined the protest, observing five minutes of silence with ballet dancers at the Bolshoi Theater who were performing ``Giselle.''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Offers Farmers Drought Help
DOC.TEXT: Land taken from production under the Conservation Reserve Program may be used for haying and livestock grazing in qualified counties where drought has reduced feed supplies, the Agriculture Department announced. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said late Thursday that all determinations would be on a county-by-county basis. The CRP, as it is called, allows farmers to take highly erodible cropland from production for 10 years and collect annual rental payments from the government. In return, the land must be planted to protective grass or trees. ``We would prefer not to hay or graze CRP lands,'' Yeutter said. ``We are responding to isolated situations with a cautious, prudent program that sustains the environmental protections that are the heart of the CRP.'' To be eligible, counties must use updated data to show rainfall and-or forage production is at least 40 percent below normal. In general, the restrictions are much tighter than those governing haying and grazing on CRP land in previous drought situations, the announcement said. The program will be handled by state and county offices of the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Exults in Detroit After Miami Rebuff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf, `Flanked by...' to UPDATE with comments from morning news conference. SUBS 10th graf pvs, `Many who...' with 3 grafs to add Mandela quoting Marvin Gaye song.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT1
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela received a tumultuous welcome in the nation's industrial heartland, revitalizing the South African anti-apartheid leader's U.S. tour after political leaders in Miami rebuffed him. In Florida on Thursday, Cuban-American mayors snubbed Mandela because of his support for Cuban leader Fidel Castro. But later in the day, Detroit showered Mandela with affection and at least $1.5 million to support his dream of a racially united South Africa. ``We appreciate your efforts, especially in this time of industrial retrenchment. In the face of your problems and difficulties, you have not forgotten us. We will never forget you,'' Mandela told a crowd of 49,000 at Tiger Stadium. Shortly after dawn today, Mandela left his downtown hotel for a half-hour stroll along the Detroit River, which marks the border between Detroit and Windsor, Ontario. Flanked by police and State Department security agents, he shook hands with well-wishers and signed autographs. He wore a Detroit Pistons jacket and cap that members of the championship pro basketball team gave him Thursday night. In a morning news conference before departing for Los Angeles, Mandela said the first six stops of the U.S. tour have ``been successful beyond our wildest dreams.'' He said the twin messages of ending racial separation in South Africa and continuing economic sanctions against the white-minority government have been heard. Detroit was the sixth stop on Mandela's eight-city U.S. tour and the only Midwestern city. He was scheduled to speak at a news conference this morning before heading for Los Angeles later today. Weary from the rigors of his tour, Mandela, 71, seemed energized by the wildly cheering crowds that greeted him in Detroit, which he called ``Motor Town.'' ``Thank you for giving us your support when we need you most,'' Mandela said at Tiger Stadium. ``Right now, I wish I could climb down from the stage and join you in the stands and embrace you, one and all.'' Mandela referred to words of a song by Motown's Marvin Gaye. ``It says, `Brother, brother, there's far too many of you dying; mother, mother, there's far too many of you crying,''' Mandela said, quoting the late singer's 1971 classic, ``What's Going On.'' Many who glimpsed Mandela said they were overwhelmed. ``He has touched my life in an unforgettable manner and has made me so proud of our heritage,'' said Wynetta Frazier of Chicago, a professor at the University of Illinois. ``I've never felt that before.'' Mandela was freed in February after 27 years in a South African prison for plotting sabotage to overthrow the country's minority white government. In his first stop here, Mandela donned a United Auto Workers jacket and cap as he addressed about 1,300 people at a suburban Ford Motor Co. assembly plant. ``The man who stands before you is not a stranger,'' Mandela told cheering auto workers. ``I am a member of the UAW; I am your flesh and blood. I am your comrade.'' It was the first ceremonial shutdown of the assembly line since a tribute to mark the death of Henry Ford II in 1987. Employee Dellar Lewis, 51, said just being in Mandela's presence was an honor. ``I'm proud to be a part of it.'' Mayor Coleman Young, Detroit's first black mayor, predicted before Thursday that Mandela would leave Detroit with at least $1 million for his African National Congress, which is pressing for an end to South Africa's apartheid system of racial segregation. But at least $1.5 million had been raised by Wednesday, with more expected after donations given at Tiger Stadium were counted, Young spokesman Bob Berg said. Mandela continued to urge economic sanctions against South Africa. ``We don't want apartheid to survive even one more day,'' he said. ``So long as it survives, it will continue to shed the blood of our people, including children.'' The warm reception in Detroit, where Young and Gov. James Blanchard greeted Mandela as he stepped off the plane, was in sharp contrast to Miami. Angered by his statements last week praising Castro, Palestine Liberation Organization head Yasser Arafat and Libya's Moammar Gadhafi for their aid to the ANC, mayors of the Miami area's major cities refused to greet Mandela. However, about 2,000 supporters gathered outside the Miami Beach Convention Center and along his route. Mandela made no direct comment on the official slight. ``To be welcomed by those who hold the reins of power in this area, to be warmly received by residents of Miami, is the source of great inspiration to us,'' said Mandela. He appealed for help from U.S. labor unions in a speech to delegates at the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees convention. About 300 anti-Mandela demonstrators, mostly Cuban-Americans, waved placards blasting him for his defense of Castro. Police kept the two groups separated, although they shouted back and forth with megaphones and at least one fistfight was broken up.

Here is a transcript of President Bush's news conference Friday at the White House: BUSH: Good morning everybody. And I'm leaving in a few hours and will be gone from Washington for several days. Congress is about to close up shop for the 4th of July holidays and so I thought it would be a good idea to bring you up to date on a wide array of current topics and respond to your questions. During the next two weeks the US will join its allies in considering a number of crucial political security and international economic issues. And seldom in the last 40 years have such questions had such direct impact on the lives of all Americans. Today in the US we are carefully examining the historic changes in Eastern Europe, the size of our military forces, our ability to compete in world markets, the assistance that we provide to help emerging democracies, and the size and priorities of our own budget and how to continue the 90 months of economic expansion that we've enjoyed. These issues are not abstract. Every American has a stake in how we as a nation address these very complex questions. On July 5th and 6th in London the NATO alliance will gather to forge a new direction for the future. And at the Houston economic summit we will press for progress in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, discuss economic support for various countries, and review progress on the environment. These international concerns are reflected in many of the decisions I made just this week. First, we are doing what is necessary to assure continuation of the economic expansion, now in its 90th month, and we want to keep it going. We now estimate a deficit of over $150 billion in fiscal 1991, not counting the costs of the savings and loan cleanup. And this means that unless Congress acts, there will be a cutoff in October of nearly $100 billion in government services under the sequester provisions of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings. The potential results are Draconian cuts in defense, student grants and a wide array of other necessary domestic services, and to avoid this, tough decisions must be made. And leadership is needed, and that is exactly what administration officials are seeking to provide and indeed, in these talks, I believe are providing. The budget negotiations now under way are a make-or-break effort at responsible government. The congressional budgeting process must succeed and the negotiators are facing tough questions about where to make cuts and where to raise the revenues, and these are not decisions that anyone relishes. They are decisions that Democrats and Republicans alike have got to face with candor and courage. And frankly, I believe that ultimately good politics is rooted in good government, and I'm optimistic that we can get a budget agreement legislated which not only tells the world that America puts its fiscal house in order, but also will garner the full support of the American people. Secondly, this week we reached an agreement with the Japanese on (the) Structural Impediments Initiative that's going to help to open markets and create new opportunities for business and commerce. Next, we took an important step toward increasing jobs, opportunity, and economic prosperity throughout our own hemisphere _ Enterprise for the Americas, an innovative and I think visionary plan for increased trade and investment with Latin America and the Caribbean, and the response from south of our border has been overwhelmingly positive. And this included a new proposal on official debt in the hemisphere which will help our neighbors in Latin America and the Caribbean resume the process of growth. We developed a plan for protecting our coastal resources _ this OCS decision _ while also endeavoring to protect energy independence. And as I leave for the 4th of July holiday, and then from there to the NATO summit, and then to the Houston economic summit, I just wanted to assure you that the America _ America will squarely face the challenges of leadership that are before us, both domestically and in terms of international affairs. Q. Mr. President, I'd like to ask you about your reversal on ``no new taxes.'' Do you consider that a betrayal of your promise, and what do you say to Republicans who complain that you've robbed them of the same campaign issue that helped get you elected? BUSH: Well, I don't. I think what I consider it is a necessary step to get stalled budget negotiations moving. And I am very encouraged with the approach taken now by Republicans and Democrats in this _ in these important discussions that are going on. I'm not going to discuss details, what I'll accept and what I won't accept, but things are moving, and I think that much more important today is getting this deficit down, continuing economic expansion and employment in this country. So that's the way I'd respond to it. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Prince In `High Spirits' But Will Remain in Hospital
LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with further comment from spokesman, polo and health officials and Diana visiting today, sub 4th graf pvs, `There is...' with 4 grafs and ADD one new last graf. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles was in ``high spirits'' today following surgery on his right arm, which was badly broken when he fell off his horse during a polo match, his spokesman said. But the 41-year-old prince, an avid polo player for 25 years, will remain hospitalized so doctors can keep an eye on his arm, spokesman Dickie Arbiter said. ``He is in good form and high spirits, chatting away to staff and doctors, but there will be no departure today,'' the spokesman said. ``There is nothing ominous in no departure today. It is a bad fracture, a bad break and his arm is swollen,'' Arbiter said. Charles underwent a 45-minute operation under general anesthetic Thursday to set two breaks above the elbow of his right arm. He is being treated free by the state-run National Health Service. Arbiter said the heir to the British throne was in pain today and had been sedated with painkillers. Princess Diana, who celebrates her 29th birthday on Sunday, spent nearly three hours with her husband this morning. Buff Crisp, the secretary of polo's governing body, said a broken arm is the most common injury suffered by polo players. The accident occurred during a polo match at Cirencester Park, Gloucestershire, seven miles from Highgrove, the country home of Charles and his wife, Princess Diana. Highgrove is 70 miles west of London. ``The prince was in the process of making a shot when he lost his balance,'' Arbiter said. ``His horse just trotted away.'' Diana left during a performance of ``La Boheme'' at the Royal Opera Thursday night and drove to the hospital just before midnight to see her husband. Charles' mother, Queen Elizabeth II, was informed in Canada where she is visiting. Charles was riding his pony, Echo, and playing for his team, Windsor Park, in the semifinal of the Warwickshire Cup against Hildon when he fell. Hildon won the match 7-6. Charles, who once joked he would continue playing polo ``as long as I bounce when I fall off,'' lay motionless for some time before being put on a stretcher and taken by ambulance to Cirencester Memorial Hospital, a witness said. David Leahy, head of the local health district, said the prince told him during a visit that he felt ``jolly lucky'' after the accident. ``He told me it had to happen some time,'' Leahy said. ``He is extremely cheerful. He is a very stoical man as he must have been in a great deal of pain.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Governor Asks to Withdraw Guilty Plea
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. said he was pressured into pleading guilty to five federal corruption charges and wants to withdraw the pleas. The Justice Department will ask U.S. District Judge Walter Hoffman to deny Moore's request to rescind his guilty pleas and sentence him July 10, said U.S. Attorney Michael Carey on Thursday. Moore's lawyer filed a motion Thursday claiming prosecutors gave Moore one day to consider a plea bargain, and threatened to lodge at least 28 charges against him if he didn't agree. The former three-term Republican governor pleaded guilty May 8 to extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice. Moore, 67, admitted extorting more than $500,000 from Beckley coal operator H. Paul Kizer in return for a $2.3 million refund from the state's Black Lung Fund, which provides benefits to coal miners. He also admitted trying to block a federal grand jury investigation into corruption in his administration. Moore could get 36 years in prison and $1.2 million in fines if the guilty pleas are upheld, officials said. Hoffman was brought in to handle Moore's case after West Virginia's federal judges asked to be excused, officials said. In a six-page motion filed by lawyer William G. Hundley, Moore claimed prosecutors told him at 10 p.m. on May 7, the day before he pleaded guilty, they would charge him under federal racketeering laws if he did not plead guilty to the five counts. The motion noted Moore's pleas were not entered immediately after he signed an agreement to admit guilt, but ``these time pressures alone are sufficient to warrant the withdrawal of the pleas.'' But Hundley, in the motion, acknowledged that he had advised Moore ``in the strongest of terms'' to enter the guilty plea after the government revealed ``surreptitiously recorded tapes.'' Hundley did not describe the tapes, but Moore's indictment said he met secretly last February with former 1988 campaign manager John Leaberry to discuss how they would both lie to a federal grand jury. The government said the meeting, allegedly held in a gas station parking lot, was secretly recorded by FBI agents and Leaberry, who was wearing a hidden microphone. Moore was governor from 1969 to 1977 and again from 1984 to 1988.

WASHINGTON: to it. Q: Well, what do you say to _ can people trust politicians if they make statements and are willing to break them? PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, you know, I recall a previous flurry when I was vice president, and there was some economic plans proposed back in 1982 that caused a furor something like we're hearing now. And the President, in my view, did what was right, and so I _ I think that _ I think that we're on the right track. And I think that the arrows have been flying, front, back, sideways, but that's what I get paid for. And I think _ I think we're on the right track now. And I think we'll have strong support from both sides of the aisle. Q: Mr. President, do you will believe it will hurt your credibility? BUSH: No, not in the long run. Q: Why not? A lot of people are already _ BUSH: Because what people are interested in are jobs, economic growth. People know this deficit is bad. People know that we are going to have to take some action, and that's why I think not. Q: But what will you say to American people who said you may have promised not to _ no new taxes _ not _ BUSH: I'll say I take a look at a new situation. I see an enormous deficit. I see a savings and loan problem out there that has to be resolved. And like Abraham Lincoln said, I'll think anew. I'm not _ but I'm not violating or getting away from my fundamental conviction on taxes, anything of that nature. Not in the least. But what I have said is on the table, and let's see where we go. But we've got a different _ we've got a very important national problem, and I think the president owes the people his _ his judgment at the moment he has to address that problem. And that's exactly what I'm trying to do. And look, I knew I'd catch some flak on this decision _ just those two words. But I've got to do what I think is right, and then I'll ask the people for support. But more important than posturing now or even negotiating is the result. Do we continue to provide jobs for the American people and do we continue to provide economic growth, and do we try to stop saddling the generations on the way up and the young people with absolutely unacceptable deficits? Q; What will you do with the savings and loan situation? Is there any way to do a budget with that still coming out of general revenue or do you have to push the whole issue off to the side? BUSH: Well, we're _ we can't push it off to the side. We've got to solve the problem. My interest on that one, incidentally, is to protect the depositor, put the people that broke the law in jail.
