And that is exactly what the policy that we proposed did. We came in here 18 days after taking office, initiated a very important savings and loan policy. And the size of the savings and loan problem is terrible, and we are trying very hard to go after the criminals and to have in place rules and regulations so that this will never happen again and to protect the depositors. Those are the three key elements of what I'm trying to do. Q: But where do you pay for it? Is it out of the taxes the government takes in every year from the American taxpayer? BUSH: Well we have to. People are going to have to pay for it. And that's _ it goes as a part of all our expenditures I'm talking about. There has got to be a remedy. Q: Mr. President, on another subject. Prime Minister Shamir has sent _ BUSH: Good, Michael. I was hoping we'd get to another one. Q: Well, we can go back to these taxes later. But Prime Minister Shamir has sent you a _ what appears to be a pretty tough letter ruling out flatly talks with any Palestinian with any sort of authority. Do you feel the peace process is deadlocked and are you concerned that the hardliners, the voices of extremism now have the upper hand throughout the region? MORE

DOC.HEAD: Unknown Hepatitis Perplexes Stormie's Doctors
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, is battling a perplexing infection attacking her second transplanted liver but isn't likely to need a third transplant soon, doctors said. ``We have no silver bullet for this type of hepatitis. We don't have a specific drug that we can give,'' Dr. Andreas Tzakis of Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh said Thursday. ``At this moment, she's not at a great risk of transplantation,'' Tzakis said. ``The damage is such that she can completely recover. She's not jaundiced. She's feeling well. She's actually bored being here in the hospital.'' Stormie, 13, of White Settlement, Texas, received her first injections Wednesday of a protein-type substance that bolsters the immune system to fight the unknown type of infectious hepatitis that threatens to destroy her liver. She was released from the hospital late Thursday, but doctors said they want her to stay in Pittsburgh until the infection is controlled. Her mother will continue giving Stormie the injections every three days. Doctors slightly reduced the anti-rejection medication that suppresses the immune system so her body can combat the hepatitis. If the anti-rejection medication is reduced too much, though, it may lead to the organ rejection Stormie has struggled with in the past. ``She's not in imminent danger of (losing) her life,'' said Tzakis. ``She's well. She's eating. She wants out of here. But six months from now we want to make sure she's well. If we let this continue, it will destroy her liver.'' Doctors have determined Stormie developed the same type of hepatitis that damaged her first transplanted liver in February. How she contracted the disease is a mystery, said Dr. John Fung. Stormie received the world's first heart-liver transplant in February 1984 at the age of 6. She received a second liver transplant six years later but returned to Children's Hospital last month after routine tests showed she apparently was rejecting that liver. Doctors gave her more of an experimental anti-rejection drug approved for use by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration only at Children's and nearby Presbyterian-University hospitals. She returned to Pittsburgh on Saturday after tests showed higher enzyme levels, indicating infection. Stormie also felt fatigued.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Begins Deliberations in Marcos-Khashoggi Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with jurors resuming deliberations.
DOC.TEXT: The judge in the trial of Imelda Marcos told jurors the former Philippine first lady could be convicted of fraud even if she didn't loot the Filipino treasury herself. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan told the jury before it began deliberations Thursday that Mrs. Marcos can be found guilty if she ``closed her eyes'' to the theft. Deliberations resumed this morning. She is accused of having helped her late husband, former Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos, embezzle more than $220 million from their country. The money allegedly was invested in U.S. real estate, jewelry and artworks with the help of Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. The jury was to resume deliberations today. Jurors were sequestered in a hotel when not deliberating. Mrs. Marcos, who turns 61 Monday, faces up to 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine if convicted of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstructing justice. The jurors also were considering mail fraud and obstruction of justice charges against Khashoggi, 54. He could draw a 10-year prison term and $500,000 in fines if convicted. Khashoggi allegedly served as a front to conceal the Marcoses' ownership of four New York buildings and artworks after the couple were ousted from power in February 1986 and the new Philippine government sued to recover their riches. Keenan dismissed five alternate jurors and requested they not discuss the case with reporters until after a verdict. As jurors filed from the courtroom to hold their first meeting, friends and well-wishers embraced Mrs. Marcos, whose eyes brimmed with tears. ``Pray for me a happy birthday,'' she told a reporter.

DOC.SECOND: Two Teen-agers Plead Guilty to Attacking Legislator
DOC.TEXT: Two Maryland teen-agers pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court today to assaulting Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., on a Washington street corner June 7. James L. Byrne and Thomas E. Carter Jr., both 19, confessed to misdemeanor charges of assault and battery on a congressman. They told the federal magistrate they were drunk when they attacked Studds, who they said did not provoke them. Studds was not seriously injured in the attack but was punched in the face and knocked to the ground. Assistant U.S. Attorney Eric Marcy said witnesses who heard Studds call for help also allegedly saw the young men kicking Studds. Byrne and Carter denied the allegation. ``Tom hit him first, then I hit him,'' Byrne told U.S. Magistrate Patrick Attridge. He said Studds was ``walking toward us ... I saw that (Carter) had hit him and then I went over and hit him again. He began to call for help and we walked away.'' Carter said that he, Byrne and other friends had been drinking at a nearby bar prior to the early morning attack in the city's Dupont Circle neighborhood. ``We were pretty intoxicated,'' he said. ``We were looking for the car. I guess we were pretty frustrated ... I took the first swing.'' Attridge asked the defendants whether Studds had done anything to provoke the attack. ``You just picked him out of the blue?'' the magistrate asked. Both teen-agers replied yes. Byrne and Carter apologized to Studds in a written statement. Both are high school graduates who work for a microfilm company in Maryland. Sentencing was scheduled for Sept. 7. Each could face maximum penalties of a year in jail and a $100,000 fine. But Byrne's attorney, Michael McCarthy, said because neither defendant had a prior record he believed they would receive sentences of no more than four months.

WASHINGTON: has been. Q: Mr. President, if it was so comforting and good for the country, why didn't you do it a year ago? BUSH: Because we've got a problem that is of far greater magnitude today because we've had a much slower economy than anybody predicted, and that has meant revenue shortfalls. And that means bigger budget deficits. And that means more burden for future generations of Americans and unacceptably high interest rates. And so that is why I _ Q: Are you saying the economy, then, is in some kind of trouble now that these problems are _ BUSH: I'm saying the economy is sluggish, and I think a deficit package that takes care _ that is seen to be a real one will have an ameliorating effect on that and, hopefully, will result in lower interest rates and thus have a more vibrant, a more robust economy. Q: You talked about the next NATO summit as a milestone. Next Friday, what are we going to see? Are we going to see a totally different NATO? How different will it be? BUSH: No, but we're going to see a NATO that makes very clear to the world: one, that it's purely defensive, and two, that it has a broadened agenda beside just military, building on Article II of the NATO document, the founding document. That's what you'll see. And I can't help you with the details because we obviously haven't even met yet. Q: Will there be any American proposals there on NATO _ BUSH: Well, I was asked the other day at a meeting with some foreign journalists whether there would be _ I thought _ I don't know if they used the word ``bombshells,'' but big surprises. I don't anticipate that, but let's wait and see what happens when we get there. But I don't _ our _ the NATO goal at this juncture should be to convince President Gorbachev that a reconstituted NATO, with Germany as a full member, is not a threat to the Soviet Union but rather is a _ provides stability for Europe and thus will guarantee the continuance of the longest peace that Europe has had in its history. Q: Mr. President, you're a great student of the American electorate. Have you concluded that the American public is more willing to consider and accept new taxes to deal with the deficit? BUSH: Not particularly. If you say to a guy, ``Do you want to pay more taxes?'' I haven't found anybody that would say that. But I think if we do our job properly and they understand the magnitude of the problem at hand in terms of this deficit, and then we make a proposal that is fair on the revenue side, on the spending side, and then on the reform side so that we don't get in this mess again _ and I'm going to restrain myself from putting the blame on Congress _ because it's hard to constrain spending so we need some reform, then I think if they see all three of these things and they see it's fair, that people will support this. Q: Would you under any circumstances consider increasing income tax rates? BUSH: I've said and told the leaders that I'm not going to go into the details. They are not going into the details of what they will or won't accept. And the only way to accomplish a negotiation is to keep faith with that approach, and they are doing that, Republicans as well as Democrats. So I'm not going to go into the details. Q: Income taxes are on the table, too? BUSH: I'm not saying what's on or off. I've made my statements on that, and I'm just going to go forward. I've got preferences, strongly-held preferences that people are familiar with, but I'm not going to reiterate them, because more important than my posturing or protecting from arrows coming from one direction is getting a deal that's fair and good for the American people. Q: Mr. President, I wonder if you can try to explain today why you made the ``no new taxes'' promise in the first place. At the time, the deficit was absolutely horrendous, the savings and loan situation was absolutely horrendous, and most people greeted your promise with a fair amount of cynicism, saying taxes were eventually going to be needed to bring down the deficit. Can you sort of blame people for now _ BUSH: No, I don't want to blame anybody _ Q:I'm just saying can you blame people for looking back and saying, ``Well, maybe he didn't really mean it the whole time''? BUSH: I can understand people saying that. I think it's wrong, but I can understand it. I'm presented with new facts. I'm doing like Lincoln did, think anew. And I'm thinking anew. I've still got the principles that underlie my political philosophy and haven't changed my view about whether _ you know _ taxes. But we've got a major problem facing this country. And I have the responsibility, leading the Executive Branch, to get things moving to get a solution. And the budget deficit is bigger, far bigger. I thought I could do a better job on getting spending down and perhaps getting the reforms of the budget process that I also talked about. So we're not talking about _ just in the campaign talking about one aspect, I was talking about reform, I was talking about spending constraints. And not having everything go exactly my way, now we've got to address ourselves to a worse problem, Maureen, than any of us visualized back then. Q: r. President, throughout the '88 campaign _ BUSH: I'll come back. Q: _ you kept saying, and this was a quote: ``The surest way to kill economic growth in this country is to raise taxes.'' Now you're telling us that the reason you're thinking anew about raising taxes is to make sure that you sustain economic growth, and yet you also told us that you're not changing your views about taxes. Exactly what are your views about taxes and what are _ BUSH: Wait till you see the agreement that comes out. That will be my views as to what has to happen _ hopefully within a month _ of 1990. That will be my views faced with a problem very different than the problem facing the presidency in the end of 1988. Q: Well, do you believe that taxes kill economic growth or do you believe that higher taxes _ MORE

DOC.HEAD: Havel Proposes Deep Cuts in Army, Calls for Building of Democratic State
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel today proposed deep cuts in the nation's army and urged the first freely elected Parliament in four decades to help create a modern democratic state. ``The disintegration of totalitarian systems in our part of Europe allows ... dramatic reductions in our army, shortening of (mandatory) military service, finally abolishing it altogether and adoption of the principle of a small but high-quality professional army,'' Havel said. He said those reforms would occur ``in such a short time that all those who know about these things will be amazed.'' However, he gave no time frame. Havel addressed the two chambers of Parliament six months to the day after being inaugurated as president following the peaceful revolution in November that overthrew Communist rule. ``We want to build a modern democratic state,'' Havel said in a 90-minute speech. ``In the realm of freedom of speech, association and assembly, room must soon be created for real political pluralism.'' Before speaking, Havel swore in the new 16-member Cabinet of Prime Minister Marian Calfa for the second time in two days in response to charges by some deputies that the initial ceremony late Wednesday was unconstitutional. According to the statute, the government can only be sworn in after the first session of Parliament has ended. Extensive procedural debate Wednesday delayed proceedings until late in the evening. Government members slipped out of Parliament for the brief swearing-in ceremony. The regional government of the Czech republic was also appointed today. The Slovak government was announced Wednesday. Calfa had been scheduled to deliver his government's program to Parliament today, but he asked for time until Tuesday to finish preparation of the document expected to outline an ambitious program of economic reform. The 300-member national Parliament, chosen in the first free balloting since 1946, is to elect a new president Wednesday. Havel told the state CTK news agency today he would accept the candidacy when he is sure Parliament accepts the government and its program and considers him most suitable. Havel termed the planned economic reform _ expected to be a testing ground of the new government's competence _ ``fundamental.'' He dubbed the interim Cabinet the ``government of national understanding'' and made clear he expects Calfa's new Cabinet to have different priorities, referring to it as the ``government of national sacrifice.'' The introduction of a market economy ``is a process which has no historical precedent, something that has not been fully accomplished in any country so far,'' Havel said. Other East European countries have embarked on market reforms, but none has yet developed a model for economic transition. Havel also emphasized the importance of developing education, culture and spiritual values in a country where these areas were suppressed or bent to suit the precepts of totalitarian rule.

WASHINGTON: higher taxes _ BUSH: I think taxes wrongly applied can kill economic growth. And yes, I do think that. So I think we've got to be very careful as to how we get this formula to see that we don't kill off economic growth. You've got to look at the overall gross national product when you talk about that, too. Q: Mr. President, why didn't you say that during the campaign then? BUSH: Well, I don't think anybody did such a good penetrating job of questioning _ and because the problem is different, the problem is quite different, Owen, today than it was then. Q: Some members of Congress and some members of your own staff are saying that your three able negotiators, as you just described them, have signaled one important possible deal, and that is if you _ if the Democrats will give you your capital gains tax cut you're prepared to go along with eliminating the bubble on the high end of the tax rate scale. Is that a fair _ BUSH: We're going to leave all _ no it's not a fair _ and I'm not sure your dope is correct, either. But the _ I just don't want to violate this concept of confidentiality while we're in the negotiating stage, and so I can't respond to it. But I wouldn't put too much trust in that one. Q: Mr. President, if your statement here this morning represents your latest thinking, why is it that a whole block of conservative Republicans have already disavowed your position, considering it a tacit request that, you know, taxes will be increased? BUSH: Well, for the same reason that that _ that same response occurred in 1982, John. And we have people who feel very strongly on this question, and I'm one of them, but I've got to make the case for the broader _ addressing ourselves at this problem here. But I can understand that. Q: It doesn't give you any pause that this fall you're going to be out campaigning for Republican candidates who disagree with you on taxes _ BUSH: No. Q: _ abortion, and perhaps other issues? BUSH: No, we've already had _ we've always had differences with me on all those issues. One way or another, one side or another, but we also have a matrix of a party that is opposed to tax-and-spend, who wants to constrain spending, and who wants reform. And I still feel a fundamental part of that, even though we're talking now about an agreement that will hopefully cover all three aspects of that. If it _ if it doesn't, there won't be an agreement, I guess. Q: Mr. President _ Secretary _ uh _ President _ BUSH: You have a message for me? This is going to work out, don't worry about it. Q: Yesterday, the Secretary of State Mr. Baker seemed to duck questions that encompassed two of your dilemmas. One is the specter of taxes, but the other is pressure from the allies, which you'll see in NATO and then again in Houston, to help the Soviet Union, to give them some _ actually more than technical aid. Have you changed your thinking? Are you moving towards some sort of agreement with the allies? BUSH: We have some differences in the alliance on this question. You're talking about on _ just strictly the aid to the Soviet Union? I've tried to be very frank and up-front, not only with the allies but with the Soviets on the difficulties we have at this juncture, because there has got to be economic reform there, market reform, and all kinds of changes that I believe Gorbachev wants to see take place. But they have to be in place for the United States to go forward. Then we have a political agenda that we've tried to be very frank about. Secretary Baker has presented it in considerable detail to Mr. Shevardnadze, and I had a chance to touch on it with President Gorbachev. And you see, it is hard for the American people to say, ``Why put X-billions of dollars of money into the Soviet economy when it's not reformed, when they're spending 18 percent of their gross national product on military, and when they're spending an estimated $5 billion in Cuba?'' We have _ some of our allies might not be as concerned about that last point as we are. I'm very concerned about it. So, we want to try to be of assistance in reform. We can do a lot in terms of helping institutionally. The EBRD, in which we are a partner _ a participant now, has in place some _ a facility for future lending. But I don't want to misrepresent this to our allies, nor to the Soviets. And that's why I say we've got difficulties with this that perhaps transcend the difficulties that others have. Q: You will not oppose the allies giving direct aid, though? BUSH: Well, I want to talk to them about it, but I don't think we should _ we should tell Mr. Kohl what his lending policy, or finance policy should be. It's understanding _ he's a neighbor, they've got quite different problems with the Soviet Union than we do. But normally it's best to have the alliance act in concert. And I expect we'll be talking about this not only at Houston, but perhaps at the Summit at NATO. Q: Mr. President, do your believe that we reporters are being somewhat naive when we suggest in our stories that _ BUSH: Yeah, because I didn't recognize you, I recognized him. BUSH: I'll come back to it, Frank. Q: Okay, thank you. BUSH: Go ahead. Q: Oh, okay. A senior economic advisor in the last administration was fond of telling us that ``economic expansions don't die, bad policies kill them.'' Now that you're admitting that the economy is growing sluggish enough that tax revenue increases are needed, what policies went wrong? Why do we need this budget agreement so badly now? MORE

DOC.HEAD: Prisoners Hijack Backhoe In Escape Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Five prisoners hijacked a backhoe in an attempted jailbreak today but were foiled by a guard who blocked their path with a truck, authorities said. Other guards overpowered the prisoners in hand-to-hand fighting that left at least four officers injured, they said. The incident, at Wandsworth Prison in south London, happened when the five prisoners grabbed an officer leading a work force through the exercise yard, stole his keys and got into a sealed area near the perimeter wall, according to Terry McLaren, secretary of the guards' trade union, the Prison Officers' Association. The driver of the backhoe, or mechanized digger, was forced out of his cab. The inmates got the backhoe moving, apparently hoping to break through the wall, but a guard jumped into a dump truck and blocked their path, McLaren said. When the alarm was sounded, some of the 150 other inmates in the yard formed a protective semicircle around the would-be escapees. One of the guards who moved in to seize the offenders had his arm broken and another was hit on the head with a bottle, McLaren said. Both were hospitalized, he said. Order was restored after 20 minutes, he said, adding that the escape appeared to have been planned because the inmates, all maximum-security prisoners jailed for armed robbery, had hoods and masks. McLaren said seven officers were injured. Prison Governor Graham Clarke said four officers and the digger operator, a non-inmate, were injured. Wandsworth, a Victorian prison with 1,389 inmates, is famous for its tough regime. Last year it was criticized in an official report for failing to meet ``basic standards of humanity and decency.'' Judge Stephen Tumim, the chief inspector of prisoners, wrote that two-thirds of the inmates have no work, and many are locked in cells for 23 hours a day and allowed to shower twice a month at most. Inmates wait up to nine weeks to visit the library, the central bath house is ``a ghastly place with an atmosphere of an earlier century,'' and the kitchens show evidence of mice and cockroaches, Tumim wrote. McLaren warned of possible trouble during the weekend, when only 95 officers would be on duty, half the normal number. He said today's incident was the third in 10 days involving assaults on staff. In one incident two prisoners tied up a catering manager, took his keys and locked him in a refrigerated room, but were stopped just before they got away, he said. Last weekend inmates failed in a bid to grab a guard's keys, McLaren said.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Struggle for Compromise on Ozone Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Environmental officials worked behind closed doors today to reach a compromise on an agreement to ban chemicals that destroy the Earth's fragile ozone shield. A major issue is a proposal that would ban a broad range of chemicals and establish a global environmental fund to help developing nations switch to technology that would protect the environment. When the meeting opened June 19, there appeared to be broad consensus on many recommended changes to the Montreal Protocol of 1987. The international treaty controls chlorofluorocarbons _ or CFCs _ and other ozone-depleting chemicals used in electronics, foam blowing, fire extinguishers, aerosols and refrigeration. Scientific evidence has left little doubt that the ozone layer, which shields the Earth from harmful ultra-violet rays, is eroding. Virtually all of the nearly 100 countries at the meeting recognize that the problem is global and life-threatening. Prospects for agreement seemed good, but coming negotiations on global warming will be more complex, and the current conference was viewed as a dress rehearsal. Delegates said that in working sessions, countries often appeared more concerned about defending their own interests, and that a conflict was emerging between developed nations of the northern hemisphere and poorer southern countries. ``There was definitely more North-South rhetoric here than in Montreal,'' said Richard Benedick, who headed the U.S. delegation at the Montreal conference and is in London as an observer. Participants from China, a major CFC consumer, said it would recommend that Beijing sign the treaty. But India issued an ultimatum, saying it would sign only if developed nations guaranteed to make alternative technology available. Maneka Gandhi, India's environment minister, said the new global ozone fund, predicted to be worth at least $160 million, was not enough. ``Money is irrelevant if we don't have access to knowledge. Survival is about the spread of knowledge,'' she told Western reporters. ``We did not destroy the ozone layer, you have done that already. Don't ask us to pay the price.'' The Montreal Protocol, signed by 56 nations, called for halving the use of eight chemicals, including CFCs, by 1996. Participants at the current conference were expected to agree to a ban on other chemicals, including halons and carbon tetrachloride, _ both used in firefighting _ by the year 2000, when CFCs are to be phased out entirely. The United States and environmentalists were united in their wish to add to the protocol the new chemical substitutes being developed to replace CFCs. These chemicals, called HCFCs, also destroy ozone, although at a much slower rate. The European Community, led by Britain, France and Spain, are all heavily involved in HCFC production and opposed adding them to the treaty. Conference sources said agreement had been reached to mention the CFC alternatives in a non-binding resolution. ``Still, this will be an extraordinary achievement,'' said Benedick, a senior fellow of The Conservation Foundation and World Wildlife Fund on assignment for the State Department. ``The environmental fund is a tremendous breakthrough. We know ultra-violet radiation will kill millions and millions of people. So progress toward saving the ozone shield is not a trivial achievement.''

We have a law requiring us to get the deficit down to certain levels. And so you've got a combination: the discipline that Gramm-Rudman-Hollings causes, and economic growth not being as robust as we predicted. And that is why we've got to do something right now. Q: Mr. President, in your research of what's happened to others, have you concluded that we're naive to suggest that the public takes campaign promises seriously? BUSH: No. I think people are _ people are smarter than a lot of us think they are, including me, and I think they're fair. And I go back to the experiences of previous people that have been in this office who say one thing in a campaign, come in and keep their _ keep that pledge, if you're talking about taxes, for quite a while, and then see that there's an enormous problem facing the nation that requires a bipartisan answer. And if I could _ if I had control of this Congress, both houses, we might not even be talking about this today, but there's a different feeling here, and I've got to see the country go forward. And I've got to take the heat that comes from certain quarters, political and other, and I'm prepared to do that because I think I'm on the right track and I think, in the final analysis, the American people will understand that. Q: And you think the public understands this and takes this into account when they hear campaign pledges? BUSH: Well, I've seen _ I've seen polling figures that indicate that. But I don't want to _ I don't want to suggest that all politicians are cynical. Certainly when I was making _ making comments of that nature, I was convinced that I could stay the course, and we did for a long time and we may now. But let's see where we go on this negotiation, because more important than how people look at what I've said is what happens to the economy, what happens to jobs, what happens to economic growth. So, when you _ when you make a change that people see as a dramatic shift, you've got to batten down the hatches and take the heat. But I really _ I'm not trying to misrepresent my position. I feel comfortable about that because I've gone back and done a little research and seen these firestorms come and go, people who feel just as strongly on one side or another of an issue as I do and haven't gotten their way exactly. That's the American system, and I've got to work with it. Congress can _ they can go out _ everybody up there can go out and take a position, but it's only the president that has the responsbility for _ you know, for the whole executive branch approach to it. Q: Mr. President, how do you explain to the country why you're treating this as essentially a Washington insider's game right now? Why not explain to the public what your list of priorities are within the spending and tax issues? Are there no longer any lines to be drawn in the sand based on your convictions on these areas? BUSH: Yeah, and they will be drawn in the negotiations. But then I'd _ I'm going to do exactly what you're talking about. I'm going to tell the American people why this bipartisan agreement, which I'm still hopeful we'll get, is essential to the national interest. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Building Collapses, At Least 29 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE toll. Pickup 5th, `Officials said...'
DOC.TEXT: A four-story building collapsed after monsoon rains in this western Indian city, killing at least 29 people and injuring 107, officials said today. Police and fire brigade officials said many of the victims of Thursday's accident were goldsmiths and diamond cutters working on the third and fourth floors. Firefighters using cranes and blowtorches rescued about 150 people trapped in the debris of the 70-year-old Yusuf Patel building in southern Bombay, said the officials, who by custom spoke on condition of anonymity. A senior fire department official said more people were feared trapped. By tonight, 29 bodies had been taken out of the collapsed building. Officials said the accident occurred at 8:30 p.m., 15 minutes after dozens of workers on the first and second floor left the building after their shift. ``The building came down like a pack of cards,'' Press Trust of India news agency said. Thirty-three people were hospitalized and the rest of the injured were given first aid, a doctor at the local hospital said. He also spoke on condition of anonymity. There was no official word on the cause of the collapse. But the building was 70 years old and crumbling, and rescue workers said the heavy rains hastened its fall. The building was near Zaveri Bazaar, Bombay's biggest bullion center. The city, known as the commercial and financial capital of India, is 700 miles southwest of New Delhi. It was the first major disaster in Bombay during the annual monsoon that hit the city last week, disrupting road and rail traffic. The weather office said Bombay received 4.17 inches of rain on Thursday, raising the total this monsoon season to 42 inches. The total so far is more than 24 inches above average, the office said.

DOC.HEAD: Deaths Prompt State of Utah To Restrict Activities In Teen Survival Programs
DOC.TEXT: Officials have ordered nine Utah-based wilderness therapy programs to bring their 400 young clients out of the desert heat in the wake of the death of a Florida girl, the second death in six weeks. The body of the 16-year-old girl was taken to the Utah Medical Examiner's Office for autopsy after she collapsed Wednesday while hiking on the Kaiparowits Plateau, a desert bluff about 300 miles south of Salt Lake City. The medical examiner's office was checking on the girl's medical history and the autopsy report was not expected to be made public for a day or two. The girl, Christen Chase of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., died while participating in the in the controversial Challenger wilderness program, said Kane County Sheriff Maxwell Jackson. Challenger founder and director Stephen Cartisano, a former Army Ranger, said the girl had been in the program only four days. He said she was nearing the end of a 4{ mile hike when she became dizzy and collapsed unconscious. He said that, even though a Challenger-owned helicopter was on the site within half an hour, she never regained consciousness. Charles Brofman, the program's attorney, said Miss Chase ``was absolutely not hiking in the heat of the day.'' He said counselors watch weather reports and ``hike around the high temperatures.'' Miss Chase is the second participant in a Utah wilderness program to die. In May, 15-year-old Michelle Sutton of Pleasanton, Calif., collapsed and died while hiking in northern Arizona with 14 other patients in the Summit Quest program based in St. George, Utah. An autopsy showed she died of dehydration due to exposure, said Mojave County, Ariz., sheriff's spokeswoman Jewell Potter. Temperatures in Utah's southern desert have peaked near 110 degrees for the past week, although it has not been determined whether the heat played a role in the most recent death. Utah Department of Social Services spokeswoman Terry Twitchell said directors of the nine Utah wilderness experience groups will be called to a meeting to try and establish ``stringent guidelines'' on their activities. Meantime, she said, the department's division of licensing has ordered that all of the groups bring their charges into base camps with food, water and supervision. ``It would seem to me common sense would tell you that when the heat gets this high, you have to be careful about hiking,'' she said. ``That's why we took immediate action until we can determine what exactly happened.'' Twitchell said Utah has been ``flooded'' with the wilderness groups, which promise to tame unruly teen-agers by teaching them survival skills and responsibility for inappropriate behavior. In most cases, the youngsters are taken into the desert with minimal equipment, such as clothes and a sleeping bag, and are forced to forage for their survival under the supervision of counselors. ``Part of the reason is because we have a lot of wilderness,'' said Twitchell. ``Another reason is you can make a lot of money at them. There's not a lot of overhead.'' Challenger, for instance, charges $15,900 for a 63-day experience.

BUSH: Some will say so but not if I go out and do my part and if I remind them of history. Take a good look at the reaction in 1982, and it didn't have that kind of an adverse effect. Q: Mr. President? BUSH: Sarah? Sarah, you thought I'd never _ Q: Thank you. Here'think you can solve your problem. Research shows _ you're going to NATO and you're going to try to reform it _ but research shows that you can save 150 billion to 160 billios a way, sir, I n by cutting out the support that we give to other foreign countries by preparing for their defense of Europe. Now why, in the name of God, don't you cut down the spending that you're putting on NATO when we're really paying this for other countries that are going to a summit with you? BUSH: Because I believe that a strong NATO is in the national security interests of the United States. I think it is in our interest that Europe has kept the peace for 40-some years, 's got to go forward. DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Open Murder Probe Against Honecker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 3rd, `Honecker could...,' to UPDATE with details of Honecker's health problems. Pickup 4th pvs, `Acting chief...' DELETES redundant 8th graf. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's top prosecutor has opened a murder probe against former Communist leader Erich Honecker stemming from the deaths of people who tried to flee the country, the nation's news agency said today. Honecker is believed to be the first hard-line Communist leader ousted in the pro-democracy revolutions that swept Eastern Europe to be targeted in a murder investigation. Romania's former leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, was executed on Christmas Day after a quickly arranged trial on genocide charges. Honecker could receive a life prison term if he is formally charged and convicted of murder charges. Whether Honecker is ever brought to trial, however, is unclear because of his failing health. He has been suffering from kidney cancer and other problems and is in a hospital in the East German town of Beelitz. Acting chief prosecutor Guenter Seidel also is investigating soldiers suspected of having killed would-be escapees, according to the news agency ADN. More than 200 East Germans were shot to death or killed by land mines as they tried to escape from East Germany and East Berlin under more than 40 years of Communist rule. Bringing those responsible to justice has been one of the most bitterly debated issues in East Germany today. The 77-year-old Honecker, whose hard-line regime was toppled in a peaceful revolution in October, already is the target of other criminal probes, including a West German one for allegedly harboring West German terrorists. Meanwhile, in Czechoslovakia, the trial of Miroslav Stepan, the former Prague Communist Party boss charged with abuse of power by a public official, was opened to the public today after four days of closed-door proceedings. Stepan, 44, the first Communist to be put on trial in Czechoslvoakia after last year's peaceful revolution toppled Communist rule, was accused of instructing former Prague police chief Bohumil Carda to use water cannons and tear gas against demonstrators in Prague's Wenceslas Square on Oct. 28, 1988. Stepan was also charged with ordering the transport of 195 demonstrators 30 miles outside Prague on Jan. 15-17, 1989, for failing to obey police orders to disperse during a banned rally. He could be jailed for up to 10 years if convicted. The trial, which opened Monday, was closed to the public because court officials said it might deal with classified information related to the Prague Defense Council that Stepan at one time headed. However, the state CTK news agency had reported that it would be open starting today. Czechoslovak media had criticized the secrecy of the trial. But the CTK report said public access to the courtroom may be limited whenever witnessess touch upon topics related to state secrets. So far, 29 witnesses have been heard, CTK said. The final verdict is expected July 4.

DOC.HEAD: Rasheeda Moore Says FBI Told Her to Keep Barry in Room
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs; editing throughout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The FBI frantically tried to keep Marion Barry in a hotel room with ex-model Rasheeda Moore to avoid the collapse of its undercover sting operation against the mayor, Barry's lawyer said today in federal court. R. Kenneth Mundy zeroed in on the FBI videotape which was played Thursday at Barry's cocaine and perjury trial showing the mayor smoking crack cocaine Jan. 18 at the Vista Hotel. On the tape, when Barry announces that he was preparing to leave Moore's hotel room, an female FBI undercover agent telephones Moore. ``You told the agent'' you were coming downstairs and the agent said `No, no, don't,''' suggested Mundy. ``That's correct,'' said Moore. ``The plan was to keep Mr. Barry in the hotel room,'' said Mundy. ``That is correct,'' said Moore. ``The plan was not to let him get down to the lobby,'' said Mundy. Moore agreed. After the agent's call, the undercover agent known as Wanda Moore delivered crack to the room and Barry smoked it. Wanda was posing as a friend of Moore's. Mundy suggested Moore's testimony against Barry has been bought and paid for by the FBI. Mundy brought out that even the clothes on her back used in the sting operation were purchased by the government. ``As a model you know what a wardrobe is don't you?'' inquired Mundy. ``Clothes for the operation were provided by the FBI,'' admitted Moore. Mundy also focused on Moore's efforts to coax a reluctant Barry up to her hotel room to begin the sting. ``Who gave you instructions that you had to get Mr. Barry into the hotel room?'' Mundy demanded to know. ``I was told by the FBI,'' said Moore. But in testimony earlier to a grand jury, she said the opposite, Mundy said. ``The FBI told you not to persuade Mr. Barry to come up to the hotel room,'' said Mundy, referring to her earlier grand jury testimony. ``That's correct, I was told not to be persuasive,'' admitted Moore. Such instructions would indicate the FBI was being careful to avoid accusations that it was entrapping the mayor. When Mundy suggested she was either lying now or had lied to the grand jury, she said she was confused by his questions. Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin objected several times to Mundy's questioning, saying the defense attorney was interrupting the witness before she could answer. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson overruled the objections. Barry's lawyer depicted Moore as a down-on-her-luck ex-model who had lied about her own drug use as recently as January. She had been introduced to freebasing crack cocaine in the summer of 1987, she told the grand jury. ``You didn't want the grand jury to know that you had been freebasing crack cocaine for 14 years,'' Mundy told her. ``That was not the case, Mr. Mundy,'' replied Moore. She admitted she had been freebasing for that long, but said that for a period leading up to the summer of 1987, she had not done it. ``It was inaccurate,'' she said of her grand jury testimony, but ``I was not choosing to be dishonest.'' In the videotape played Thursday in court, the female FBI agent posing as Moore's friend brings a bag of crack cocaine to the hotel room. Barry told Moore, ``I don't smoke no more, honey'' and the undercover agent left the room. But Barry told Moore to call her back. ``Go get some. Go get it,'' the mayor told Moore, and the deal was consummated, with Barry paying for the drugs. Barry and Moore each wanted the other to be the first to smoke the crack. ``I thought you bought this because you wanted to take a hit,'' Moore told Barry on the videotape. ``Aw, naw, you do it,'' the mayor replied. ``If you don't do it, I'm not going to do it,'' said the mayor, who finally walked over to a dresser and inhaled twice deeply from an FBI-supplied crack pipe. Moments later as Barry and Moore prepared to go downstairs, FBI agents burst into the room and arrested the mayor. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine-possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. One possession charge stems from the night of his arrest on Jan. 18. Barry acknowledged a month ago that he smoked crack that night, and said federal prosecutors were trying to kill him by providing a potentially lethal dose of the drug.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Trouble Pinpointed to Grinding, Polishing of Mirrors: Expert
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 3 new grafs after 4th graf pvs bg'ng, He said ... to UPDATE with testimony at today's hearing; picks up 5th graf pvs bg'ng, Two senators ...; Lennard in 5th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: An error in the grinding and polishing of the main mirrors aboard the Hubble Space Telescope has been pinpointed as the cause of a focus flaw that crippled the $1.5 billion orbiting observatory. An official of Hughes Danbury Optical Co., which manufactured the mirrors, said Thursday night that experiments with signals from the Hubble have confirmed that a mistake was made in the tedious three-year process of making the primary and secondary Hubble mirrors. ``With fairly high certainty, we have concluded that ... the shape of one of the mirrors is not correct,'' said Terence Facey, a Hughes Danbury engineer who helped NASA isolate the source of the Hubble focusing problem. He said it was not known which mirror is flawed, but that may be discovered by searching the Connecticut company's records of tests conducted during the months of grinding and polishing required to turn foot-thick, spherical glass blanks into the telescope mirrors. Those records and equipment used in making the mirrors have been impounded by NASA as the first step in an investigation of what went wrong with the expensive satellite, the agency's chief scientist, Lennard Fisk, told a Senate committee today. But Fisk said he was ``somewhat concerned that we are going to try and reconstruct an event that took place a decade ago.'' And he sought to put the best face on the problem, telling Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., that much excellent scientific work will be unaffected. ``We will adjust the observing program to emphasize the things that Hubble does well today,'' such as ultraviolet imagery, Fisk said. Two senators who oversee the space program, meanwhile, reacted angrily to news of the Hubble focusing flaw and ordered hearings on the mistake. ``I'm very outraged at what has happened to Hubble,'' said Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md. ``They have had 10 years to put this together and spent $2.8 billion to be able to get it right. ``Now we find that the Hubble telescope has a cataract,'' she said. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has said the telescope cost $1.5 billion, plus $600 million for operations and maintenance. Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate subcommittee on science, technology and space, called a hearing on the Hubble problem for today, with NASA's chief scientist, Lennard Fisk, as the lead witness. Mikulski said she and Rep. Bob Traxler, D-Mich., also plan an investigation. NASA engineers discovered the focusing flaw in Hubble after they were unable to coax the telescope into capturing crisp, clean photos of distant stars. Facey said he assisted the space agency in the tests and helped to confirm that the problem was in one of the two mirrors. It was a tough job, he said in a telephone interview. ``It's always difficult to conclude that you've made a mistake.'' Meanwhile, The New York Times reported in today's editions that NASA decided against using top-secret, ground-based military testing equipment that likely would have detected the problem before the Hubble was launched. The Times quoted a scientist involved in the agency's deliberations, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Facey said that although the main Hubble mirror can be adjusted slightly from the ground by moving actuators that cause the glass to flex, the system will not correct the focus enough to eliminate the problem. He said only about 10 percent of the focus error could be corrected. NASA has started a formal investigation of the Hubble problem. Lew Allen, head of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., was named chairman of an engineer review committee that space agency officials said will include outside experts. Meanwhile, astronomers are scrambling to find ways to salvage some use from the Hubble, despite the loss of precise focus. Ed Weiler, a NASA scientist, said three of the five instruments on board will be able to get 50 to 75 percent of their planned scientific studies. Two of the instruments are spectrometers, which can measure the temperature, composition and movement of stars. Another instrument, a photometer, will be able to measure stellar brightness and to look for black holes. Most seriously hurt by the loss of focus are two cameras designed to capture visual images of distant stars, galaxies and other objects. The $40 million wide-field planetary camera will be of only small use without a precise focus, and Weiler called it ``a significant loss.'' A replacement wide-field camera is scheduled to be installed in Hubble in June 1993. Weiler said a new optical lens, which will correct the focus flaw from the mirror, will allow the new camera to take sharp pictures. The fifth Hubble instrument, a faint object camera that can gather images in invisible ultraviolet light, will be able to do about 50 percent of its planned studies, he said. Weiler said that though the focus flaw causes big problems for Hubble, the error actually is minute. He said the telescope misses precise focus by a distance of only 4 percent of the diameter of a human hair.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Cause Flooding, Extensive Damage in Iowa, Wis., Ill.
DOC.TEXT: Creeks roared out of their banks in eastern Iowa today after thunderstorms that extended east into northern Illinois and southwest Wisconsin, where flooded roads, mudslides and a tornado were reported. Five people were injured today when high wind swept through an industrial park in Streamwood, Ill., a western Chicago suburb. Humana Hospital in Hoffman Estates reporteda 21-year-old man was in critical condition and four others were in good or fair condition. Steve Kahn, a weather service forecaster in the Chicago area, said a small tornado or a ``downburst'' of wind damaged buildings in the industrial park. Elsewhere in Illinois, heavy early-morning thunderstorms knocked out power to thousands of homes and caused delays of up to a half-hour at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. Police in Janesville, Wis., said a tornado touched down there early today, causing damage to homes, schools and other business, but no injuries. Up to 4 inches of rain today flooded the Wapsipinicon River, Duck Creek and Silver Creek in eastern Iowa. Many of the people evacuated also were flooded out of their homes on June 17. ``People were just beginning to clean up and get back into their homes and they've had water rising very rapidly out there again,'' said Dave Whan, assistant Scott County administrator. In north-central Iowa, gusty wind and tornadoes ripped down trees, power lines and buildings Thursday. One tornado was spotted southwest of Ackley, about 60 miles north of Des Moines, and a second one seen northwest of Ackley moved southeast over the town Thursday afternoon, causing considerable damage. ``Hundreds of buildings and hundreds of acres of crops were lost due to Thursday's storms,'' state Rep. Robert D. Fuller said. In addition to leveling barns and other farm buildings in Franklin and Hardin counties, the wind took the roof off an apartment building in Ackley and broke windows at a car dealership and many downtown buildings. It also tore down power lines and hundreds of trees. ``All at once I seen things a flying,'' said Ackley resident Dorothy Belle Sugar, who said she was indoors when she heard sirens go off and looked out her kitchen window as the tornado passed through the town.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0568 to restore cycle designator and keyword slug
Two Teen-agers Plead Guilty to Attacking Legislator
DOC.TEXT: Two Maryland teen-agers pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court today to assaulting Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., on a Washington street corner June 7. James L. Byrne and Thomas E. Carter Jr., both 19, confessed to misdemeanor charges of assault and battery on a congressman. They told the federal magistrate they were drunk when they attacked Studds, who they said did not provoke them. Studds was not seriously injured in the attack but was punched in the face and knocked to the ground. Assistant U.S. Attorney Eric Marcy said witnesses who heard Studds call for help also allegedly saw the young men kicking Studds. Byrne and Carter denied the allegation. ``Tom hit him first, then I hit him,'' Byrne told U.S. Magistrate Patrick Attridge. He said Studds was ``walking toward us ... I saw that (Carter) had hit him and then I went over and hit him again. He began to call for help and we walked away.'' Carter said that he, Byrne and other friends had been drinking at a nearby bar prior to the early morning attack in the city's Dupont Circle neighborhood. ``We were pretty intoxicated,'' he said. ``We were looking for the car. I guess we were pretty frustrated ... I took the first swing.'' Attridge asked the defendants whether Studds had done anything to provoke the attack. ``You just picked him out of the blue?'' the magistrate asked. Both teen-agers replied yes. Byrne and Carter apologized to Studds in a written statement. Both are high school graduates who work for a microfilm company in Maryland. Sentencing was scheduled for Sept. 7. Each could face maximum penalties of a year in jail and a $100,000 fine. But Byrne's attorney, Michael McCarthy, said because neither defendant had a prior record he believed they would receive sentences of no more than four months.

DOC.HEAD: Central Committee Clears Way for Communist Party Congress Next Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Central Committee apparently not discussing proposals to postpone meeting, more Tass report on congress, recasts lead to move up reference to Tass commentary. Pickup 8th, `Tass warned ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Communist PartyCentral Committee today cleared the way for an important party congress on Monday, the Tass news agency indicated. Tass also warned of ``disaster'' if the party ousts Mikhail S. Gorbachev as its leader or derails his reforms. The policy-making Central Committee tentatively approved a report President Gorbachev will deliver at the 28th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party. However, the 249-member committee ordered the Politburo to ``rework it taking into account the discussion'' that took place during a five-hour, closed-door meeting in the Kremlin, said Alexander Kapto, head of the Central Committee Ideological Department. Boris N. Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic, and some fellow reformers had urged the committee to postpone Monday's party congress until autumn to ``stabilize the political situation.'' But other reformers, as well as hard-line Communist foes of Gorbachev, opposed a delay. The Central Committee ended its meeting today without discussing the proposals to delay the congress, meaning it will proceed as scheduled on Monday. Tass reported that the meeting will open Monday and will last for about 10 days. Reformers say Gorbachev's foes could dominate the gathering, undermine him as he tries to pull the country out of a deep economic and political crisis, and force progressives to quit the party. Tass warned today in a sharply worded commentary that ousting Gorbachev as head of the Communist Party or derailing his reforms could spell ``disaster.'' At the congress, Gorbachev is expected to come under renewed pressure from hard-liners who say he should not hold both the post of party chief and the Soviet presidency. Tass commentator Andrei Orlov was highly critical of those seeking to unseat Gorbachev as party head or undermine his reform efforts. ``There is an obvious discrepancy between the correct decisions and open resistance to reforms on the part of some party functionaries, who are increasingly aware of the real challenge to their once undisputed power,'' he wrote. ``A lapse, or a deliberate rejection of perestroika, is fraught with disaster, and not for the party alone,'' he said. A day earlier, Communist reformers struggled to find common ground to unite them against a resurgent traditionalist wing that is sharply critical of Gorbachev's economic and political changes. Radicals of the Democratic Platform faction said Thursday they expected to walk away from the party's congress of 4,700 delegates. ``In reality, despite the many statements of leaders, the Communist Party has shown it is simply incapable of reforming itself,'' said Vladimir Lysenko, a leader of the Democratic Platform. Lysenko told reporters Democratic Platform's 100 delegates will fight for its program, but ``if it proves impossible, there will be a statement that either the Communist Party has split or a new party is starting.'' Leaders say a poll of party members indicates about 40 percent identify themselves as supporters of Democratic Platform. But they acknowledge many people support the faction not because of its program but simply because it represents a formal challenge to the party bureaucracy. The proposed split in the Communist Party would be the first since 1922, and Gorbachev has warned it would divide and weaken the forces struggling for reform. Gorbachev, speaking last week to a congress of Communists from the Russian republic, warned a split in the party would be ``a gift'' to opponents of reform. In a nationally televised debate, Fyodor Burlatsky, a respected lawyer and editor of the Literaturnaya Gazeta newspaper, appealed for unity between radical reformers, or ``leftists,'' and moderates led by Gorbachev. ``There are no fundamental differences between the center and the left,'' he said. ``The center is no longer afraid of a regulated market economy, a multiparty system, a new treaty between the republics.'' Despite arguments that Gorbachev is not moving fast enough with economic reforms and restructuring of the political system or that he is moving closer to the traditionalists, Burlatsky said decisions made in recent months prove the Soviet leader is pushing hard for reform. However, new party documents fall far short of Democratic Platform's demands that the party give up its claim to try to organize Soviet society, and party cells at workplaces, in the army, the police and the KGB. ``If the right wing at the Communist Party Congress presses for the election of their man as general secretary, then the center and the left should counter by supporting Gorbachev,'' Burlatsky said. Instead of reformers like Democratic Platform members splitting off, it could be the traditional hard-liners, or right wing, who leave the party, he said. Burlatsky is known as an influential and loyal backer of Gorbachev. His remarks could signal a trend among influential moderates to seek common ground with radicals to counter the traditional Soviet-style Communists who dominated a gathering of party members from the huge Russian republic last week.

DOC.HEAD: City Official, Two Women Killed in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: An unidentified youth shot and killed a Moslem official, and suspected Moslem separatists killed two Hindu women in Kashmir state today, witnesses and officials said. Additional Deputy Commissioner Abdul Aziz Khan, a senior civil administrator, was shot in the abdomen as he walked out of his home in a Srinagar suburb, said a neighbor who witnessed the attack. The youth, who fired only one shot with a revolver, escaped down a side street after Khan fell to the ground, said the neighbor, Mala Begum. Mrs. Begum said she summoned help and took Khan to a hospital where he died about four hours later. In neighboring Pulwama district, suspected Moslem militants shot and killed two women, said state government officials who cannot be identified under briefing rules. They identified the women as Rupavati and her daughter-in-law, Babli. Only their first names were available. It was not immediately clear why the women were killed. Both were Hindus. Moslem militants usually attack security forces but are increasingly turning their guns on Hindus in their campaign for secession of the Kashmir valley from Hindu-dominated India. Sixty-four percent of Jammu-Kashmir state's 6 million people are Moslem, making it the only state in India with a Moslem majority. Nationwide, Moslems account for 12 percent of India's 880 million people and Hindus comprise 82 percent. At least 655 people have been killed in Kashmir since Jan. 20 when the government began a crackdown on the separatist movement. Most of the victims have been militants or their supporters shot while defying curfew restrictions. The separatism movement has been simmering since 1947 but flared last winter with a wave of bombings and assassinations. Kashmir was a princely state that opted for merger with India when the British-ruled Indian subcontinent was divided into India and Pakistan. Kashmiri separatists earlier wanted union with Pakistan, an Islamic country, but have lately demanded independence and the status of a neutral country.

DOC.HEAD: Former Police Chief Given 10 Years for Cocaine Theft
DOC.TEXT: A former police chief who once said he was ``possessed'' by cocaine was sentenced to 10 years in prison for stealing the drug from an evidence room. Richard J. Sproules, a 22-year police veteran, is believed to be the highest ranking Massachusetts police officer to be charged with drug offenses. Plymouth Superior Court Judge Suzanne V. DelVecchio sentenced Sproules on Thursday to two concurrent seven- to 10-year state prison sentences for the cocaine offense and for embezzling city funds. DelVecchio also sentenced Sproules, 46, to concurrent sentences of three to five years on two counts of intimidation of a witness and on one count of attempting to get another person to commit perjury. In a plea for leniency, Sproules told the judge, ``My actions are inexcusable. For all the youngsters who looked up to me, I'm ashamed.'' ``You look at me a ruined and destroyed man _ but there's no one to blame but me,'' he said as his voice shook with emotion. A grand jury indicted Sproules last year on charges of larceny of cocaine, attempting to get another person to commit perjury, obstruction of justice, larceny of more than $250 and two counts of intimidation of a witness. The same grand jury indicted him on a charge of embezzlement last March. Police arrested Sproules, who was once a leader in the fight against drugs in Brockton, in his office Oct. 24.After his arrest, he admitted to a five-year cocaine addiction that he said ``possessed me.'' Sproules' arrest shocked this city of 95,000 people, located about 23 miles south of Boston. He was proclaimed the city's best hope in the fight against drugs when he was appointed police chief in 1987. Prosecutor John Kivlan said the perjury charge arose from an incident in which Sproules tried to persuade one of his detectives to testify that a cocaine package Sproules had partially used and resealed was in the same state as it had been when it was seized from a suspect. Sproules was charged with intimidation of a witness after trying to get two detectives not to testify against him and telling them evidence from the case was not available, Kivlan said. Prosecutors said in court Thursday that $75,000 in city funds controlled by Sproules are still unaccounted for. But Sproules' attorney said all but a small amount of the money was accounted for.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill One, Wound 15 Near Courthouse
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen opened fire with automatic weapons Friday in front of Istanbul's main courthouse, killing at least one person and wounding 15, the Anatolia news agency reported. It quoted witnesses as saying the incident occurred after a hearing in the trial of Cemal Sincar, who is charged with the murder of newsman Sami Basaran last year. The witnesses were reported to have said that two men opened fire indiscriminately on a crowd that had gathered in front of the courthouse. The assailants escaped, Anatolia said. Authorities theorized the gunmen may have planned to create panic and try to get Sincar away in the confusion. Basaran, a reporter for the now defunct Gazete newspaper, was shot to death at Sincar's business office in November. A photographer who was with him at the time was seriously wounded. The newspaper for which Basaran worked had romantically linked Sincar with a movie actress.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Kills Five at Fireworks Plant
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire in a fireworks factory killed five employees and injured five others Friday in central Japan, police said. The explosion ignited a flash fire that within half an hour destroyed two of the 14 factory buildings of fireworks manufacturer Toyohashi Enca, police said. One of the injured was in critical condition, officials said. The cause of the explosion has yet to be determined, they added. They said the factory is in a mountainous area and surrounded by fields and orchards on the outskirts of Toyohashi, 188 miles west of Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Sculptor Requests Political Asylum In The U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet sculptor requested political asylum in the United States on Friday after arriving in Turkey from the Soviet Union, the Anatolia news agency reported. The dispatch said Sergei Fedorov, 27, relayed his request to Turkish police authorities at Esenboga airport after disembarking from a Soviet passenger plane. ``My goal is to live free. You have to live in the Soviet Union to understand my feelings,'' Fedorov told Anatolia. Fedorov was taken to a police station for interrogation. No other details were given.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General of Indonesia Dies
DOC.TEXT: The attorney general of Indonesia died Friday after suffering a heart attack, an official in his office said. He was 50. Attorney General Soekarton Marmosudjono, a navy commodore, was a law graduate of the state-run Gajah Mada University in Jogjakarta, Central Java. He was named attorney general in March 1988. Soekarton died at a hospital in Jakarta. He is survived by his wife and five children.

DOC.HEAD: Global AIDS Total Increases, American Increase Cited
DOC.TEXT: More than 3,000 new cases of AIDS have been reported to the World Health Organization this month, increasing the global total to 266,098 since the start of record-keeping in 1981. In its monthly update published Friday, WHO said new reports from North and South America were largely responsible for the increase. The U.N. agency said the United States registered 1,453 new cases in June. This raised the official number of U.S. victims to 133,889 since reporting began in 1981. Brazil was the second-worst affected country in the Americas, with 11,070 cases reported, WHO said. Worldwide, Uganda has the second-highest AIDS toll behind the United States. By the end of last year it reported 12,444 AIDS victims, followed by neighboring Zaire with 11,732. At the end of May, the global total of registered AIDS cases stood at 263,051. But WHO officials estimated the real figure is closer to 700,000. The WHO reports cover only victims of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome and not people infected with the virus that causes the deadly disease. WHO estimates that 6 million to 8 million people may carry the virus, which is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Troops Arrest 125 Thais for Illegal Logging
DOC.TEXT: Burmese troops have arrested 125 Thais and 25 Burmese for illegal logging along the border between the two countries, a government spokesman said Friday. Troops made the arrests while breaking up three major timber smuggling camps near Myawaddy, across from the town of Mae Sot in Thailand, Col. Than Tun told a news conference. Sources in Thailand say that in addition to illegal logging, Thai companies that have been granted vast concessions along the border are destroying the last of the world's great teak forests. They say the Burmese military government abandoned conservation practices in favor of easy revenue from foreign loggers after coming to power in September 1988. The Burmese government denies it.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Grounds Shuttle Fleet
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: America's space shuttle fleet has been grounded until engineers can correct a hydrogen leak that has been found on a second spacecraft, officials said today. William Lenoir, NASA's space flight chief, said that the agency has no choice but to stop space shuttle launches and allow engineers to study the leak problem and fix it. ``We can't fly until we can get hydrogen in the tank and we're having a problem with that right now,'' said Lenoir at a news conference from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The announcement came after engineers conducted a leak check on space shuttle Atlantis, which is on the launch pad awaiting a planned mid-July launch. The test, involving pumping up to 200,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen into Atlantis' giant external tank, was intended ``to establish confidence in the hardware,'' NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said. Malone said a concentration of hydrogen was found near a four-inch disconnect valve in the area of a 17-inch-diameter valve, the same that appeared responsible for the leak that grounded Columbia. The leak was detected by one of two sensors mounted between the orbiter and the tank about 18 minutes after the test began. An additional 21 sensors had been installed in the orbiter's aft compartment to sniff for leaks. Before the leak was discovered, NASA had hoped to launch Atlantis on a secret military mission in mid-July. The leak check was ordered as a precaution after a similar hydrogen leak stopped the countdown for the shuttle Columbia six hours before its intended launch May 30. Columbia is now grounded until at least mid-August. The leak was spotted moments after the slow filling of the tank was switched to fast pumping, at precisely the point in the tanking where Columbia's leak was discovered. NASA officials, including launch director Bob Sieck and Kennedy Space Center Director Forrest McCartney were monitoring the test from the firing room. The tank, only about 5 percent full at the time the leak was sensed, was to be filled further in an effort to isolate the leak, Malone said.

DOC.HEAD: Grandson Born to Reputed Crime Boss John Gotti
DOC.TEXT: A certain godfather is a grandfather once more, the New York Post reported Friday. An 8-pound, 1-ounce boy was born to John Gotti Jr. and his bride of three months, the former Kim Albanese, the Post said. The newest Gotti was born Thursday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre on Long Island, the newspaper said. ``There's no information I can give on a patient by that name,'' hospital spokeswoman Carol Parker told The Associated Press on Friday. The Post said that the baby's father and grandfather, reputed Gambino family mob boss John Gotti, arrived at the hospital with two bodyguards in a black Lincoln Continental. The Post said they entered the hospital through an emergency entrance and headed straight to the maternity ward, which had been cleared out by more security guards. But the 26-year-old father was not present in the delivery room, the Post said. The Gottis left after admiring the still-unnamed baby for 20 minutes, the Post said. It said the new arrival made Gotti a grandfather ``for at least the third time.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Lithuanian Parliament Adopts Independence Moratorium
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits to restore byline.
DOC.TEXT: The Lithuanian parliament agreed today to put a 100-day freeze on its declaration of independence in return for an end to the Kremlin's economic blockade and the start of negotiations on secession. The move could end the breakaway Baltic republic's 3{-month-old standoff with Moscow over its drive toward independence. If the agreement is approved by Moscow, it would resolve one of the most contentious regional disputes facing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as he prepares for a key national Communist Party congress Monday. The resolution accepting a proposed compromise was approved by a vote of 69-to-35, with two abstentions. It called for the 100-day moratorium to begin simultaneously with the start of negotiations with the Soviet government. The deal was worked out at two meetings between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis this week, according to Lithuanian officials. But there was no immediate comment from Soviet authorities on whether the Lithuanian vote would be sufficient to end the embargo and start talks. It also was not clear when those negotiations could begin, because Gorbachev was expected to be tied up with the national party congress, where his reform effort is expected to be attacked by hard-liners. ``We had hoped that it would end today,'' Prime Minister Kazmiera Prunskiene, who also had backed the compromise, said of the embargo. The move by the parliament came hours after Landsbergis reversed his position and endorsed the compromise plan on the March 11 declaration. ``Two years ago, we chose the peaceful route to independence, the route of negotiations,'' Landsbergis told the republic's lawmakers. ``Now the condition for negotiations is a moratorium.'' The Lithuanian president said he changed his mind because the draft resolution does not support an immediate or unconditional moratorium. ``It proposes declaring a moratorium in some conditions,'' he told reporters after speaking to parliament. Under the plan, talks would begin on a date agreed to by both sides. The moratorium would freeze ``all the legal actions'' of the independence declaration itself. But under the resolution, laws passed by the Lithuanian parliament since the declaration of independence will remain in effect, including the replacement of the Soviet Constitution with the Lithuanian one. The moratorium could be prolonged or canceled by the Lithuanian parliament, and would be automatically be rescinded if the Lithuanian parliament for some reason were unable to perform its duties. Landsbergis and Mrs. Prunskiene were expected to fly to Tallinn, Estonia later today for the opening of a festival. They were expected to meet the leaders of the other Baltic republics, Estonia and Latvia, to discuss the status of their talks with the Kremlin. Outside the Lithuanian parliament earlier today, protesters criticized the compromise. ``A moratorium is the death of independence,'' read one sign. Lithuania was an independent country between the world wars but was occupied by Soviet soldiers in 1940 and absorbed into the Soviet Union. About 50,000 workers have lost their jobs since the Kremlin cut all oil, most natural gas and other raw materials and manufactured goods 10 weeks ago. The blockade is barely visible in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital. Most workers still are earning vacation pay, hot water is flowing, and there is no need for heat. But Mrs. Prunskiene told parliament it must accept a deal because the West is demanding a compromise, and the economic blockade could turn Lithuania into a disaster area by winter.

DOC.HEAD: Imperial Wedding Steeped in Tradition
LaserPhotos TOK7,9
DOC.TEXT: Often lavish to the extreme, the Japanese wedding isn't just ceremony. It's theater. Enter a prince, dressed in black and red silken robes, with the curved black tailpiece of his royal cap bobbing with every step and a mace held straight up before his chest. A few steps behind, a princess-to-be, her hair coiffed in ancient court fashion, her kimono a rainbow of nearly a dozen layers colored green, burgundy, maroon and orange. The stage: a quiet, mysterious shrine tucked away in a small wood behind the moat and high stone walls of the Imperial Palace. Then there is a Cinderella plot line, the sipping of sacred rice wine and the reading of solemn vows to a sun goddess. It is the ultimate in Japanese nuptials, the royal wedding. On Friday, the $1 million affair was for Prince Aya, Emperor Akihito's youngest son, and his college sweetheart, 23-year-old graduate student Kiko Kawashima, only the second commoner to marry into Japan's imperial family. While on a smaller scale, many wedding customs practiced by the average Japanese reflect those of the imperial family. Possibly because the wedding was the first for an imperial family member since 1984 _ and the first for a prince of Aya's status in nearly three decades _ Japan's media rushed to chronicle it and the trends it spawned. Newspaper readers have been informed of hurried engagements of famous entertainers, booming sales of pearl necklaces like the one Princess Kiko was wearing and rising prices for stock shares in bridal companies. A rental business even sprang up for the bulky ``junihitoe'' style kimono that Princess Kiko wore. The traditional Japanese attire now is reserved mainly for special occasions. The rental fee for the kimono, makeup and wig is $2,600 _ only a fraction of the $58,000 the average Japanese will spend on a wedding and honeymoon, says the Japan Institute for Social and Economic Affairs. Miss Kawashima began Friday in a pink dress and hat, became Princess Kiko in the multilayered kimono, and then greeted her imperial in-laws in a white evening dress replete with diamond-studded tiara and necklace. Most brides in Japan change clothes at least once during their reception, often beginning with a kimono and switching to a cocktail dress. The reappearance, made as a mist from dry ice spreads across the hall, adds a theatrical touch. After the end of World War II, nearly all weddings were performed at shrines to the gods of Shinto, Japan's indigenous religion. Sake-sipping before the Shinto gods, however ancient it may sound, was an innovation made for the wedding of Aya's great-grandfather in 1900. Shinto-style weddings still are the most popular, accounting for 55 percent to 60 percent of the total, says Keiko Shimizu of the private Wedding Advice Center. But they may be on the way out. ``Young women these days prefer church weddings, not because of any particular religious beliefs, but because they want to wear wedding dresses,'' Ms. Shimizu said. ``They are used to Western-style clothes and just don't feel comfortable in kimono any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Romance Takes Over This Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Forget Valentine's Day: this is the most romantic weekend of the year. More weddings will occur Saturday than any other day this year, estimates Barbara Wilson of the National Center for Health Statistics. About 44,000 marriages will occur on this date, speculated Wilson, who keeps track of marriage and divorce statistics for the government. June is the most popular month for weddings, she explained. Saturdays are the most popular day, with the last Saturday in June leading the pack. The fact that next Wednesday is the Independence Day holiday adds to the number of marriages this weekend by giving people a chance to have a holiday honeymoon, she added. The average bride is expected to be about 24.5 years old and the bridegroom 26.4 this year, Wilson said. And if current statistics hold true, about half the couples who tie the knot this week will untie it by the turn of the century. On occasion St. Valentine's Day falls on Saturday, and when that happens it usually jumps into first place in marriages. That happened in 1987, but won't occur again until 1998.

DOC.HEAD: Yale Review Falls Victim to Budget Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Yale University will shelve a 79-year-old literary tradition this fall when The Yale Review falls victim to budget concerns.
