The magazine, the oldest literary quarterly in the country, has featured works by Eugene O'Neill, Edith Wharton, Virginia Woolf, Wallace Stevens and Leon Trotsky. Author John Hersey, who taught at Yale and whose essay ``First Job'' was published in the Review, called the decision ``symptomatic of what is happening in publishing, where money has become more important than words.'' Yale President Benno C. Schmidt Jr. announced Thursday that the Review will cease after the issues in progress go to print. He cited the magazine's deficits that the university must absorb, its limited readership and the absence of any direct tie to Yale's academic programs. ``The time has come either to make significant changes in the magazine or to discontinue its publication in a dignified way,'' Schmidt said. ``I have chosen to do the latter.'' The Review began in 1819 as The Christian Spectator and became The Yale Review in 1911. It is considered the grandparent of other literary journals including the Kenyon, Georgia, Southern and Suwannee reviews. Over the years, the magazine has showcased a blend of criticism, essays, poetry and fiction by known and emerging writers. Poet John Hollander, who is the A. Bartlett Giamatti Professor of Comparative Literature at Yale, called the decision deplorable. ``I hope that the university can change its mind,'' Hollander said. ``The news is depressing because it seems, on the whole, part of the American problem with illiteracy,'' said Robert Giroux, senior editor of Farrar, Straus and Giroux publishers in New York. ``It is an anti-literate action.'' Schmidt said he talked with many faculty members and did not reach the decision ``without misgiving.'' But he said he was not convinced Yale could raise $1 million from donors to endow the quarterly's annual costs. The Yale University Press publishes the quarterly, which has a paid circulation of about 4,200. Editor Penelope Laurans said she was saddened by the Review's end. ``The Yale Review is a cultural institution which has linked the university to a world of art beyond it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-ager Pleads Guilty to Slashing Actress Viveca Lindfors
DOC.TEXT: A judge deferred sentencing for at least a year after a teen-ager pleaded guilty to slashing actress Viveca Lindfors and another victim in January. Peter Bedford's guilty plea Thursday to one count of first-degree assault would ordinarily mean a mandatory prison term of up to 15 years, said Gerald McKelvey, a spokesman for the Manhattan district attorney. But acting Justice Renee White promised the 18-year-old Brooklyn man that if he met conditions set by the court during the year, he would be allowed to plead guilty to second-degree assault. That charge does not mandate prison time. Bedford was accused of slashing Lindfors across her left ear and cheek as she was walking with friends. The actress also suffered scrapes and bruises after she was knocked her down. Minutes earlier, McKelvey said, Bedford had encountered Dennis Beale and slashed him from the right ear down to the chin. Police arrested Bedford seven days later after receiving an anonymous tip. The judge's conditions include Bedford getting psychiatric treatment, remaining employed or in school, and not committing any crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Milwaukee City Council Votes To Censure Embattled Alderman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with 2 grafs to CLARIFY difference between repudiate, censure is one of language; no practical difference.
DOC.TEXT: The city council vote 11-3 today to censure an alderman who ignited a poisoned sausage scare and has threatened violence through a black militant group he has started. The council failed to approve a weaker resolution that would have repudiated Michael R. McGee, but not censure him. The motion failed 8-6 on the first vote. McGee, who earlier this week resigned his council committee assignments over the sausage incident, left the meeting with several members of his Black Panther militia and refused to speak to reporters. ``This hearing means nothing to me whatsoever. Whoever votes for this, I could care less,'' he said during a speech from the floor. ``It just confirms my statements of how racist this city is.'' About 15 militia members attended the council meeting, holding up signs and applauding frequently when McGee spoke. The resolution approved by the council also called on McGee to temper his future statements to promote the good of the city. One of the three council members who opposed the resolution, Alderman John Kalwitz, said McGee had been found guilty without due process or trial. The vote to censure was the first of its kind in the council, City Clerk Ronald D. Leonhardt said. The censure vote was a criticism of the way McGee handled and an anonymous phone call he said he received from a militant underground group claiming that products of Usinger's Famous Sausage Inc. had been injected with rat poison. The warning forced Uinger's, a century-old family-owned business, to recall 80,000 pounds of meat from 150 stores. A preliminary inspection has found none of the meat was tainted. Usinger's and other downtown companies have opposed McGee's proposal to rename all of Third Street for the late civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. Segments of the street are already named for King. Mayor John O. Norquist and some city council members said they want to punish McGee for what they say is an unsubstantiated threat and malicious prank. At a news conference, Norquist called McGee a ``demented'' person who fabricated the warning to gain media attention. ``It's a hoax. It's phony,'' Norquist charged. ``What he's really doing is scaring the hell out of people, which feeds racism and bigotry.'' McGee, one of only three blacks on the 16-member city council, earlier this year started a Black Panther Militia group which he says will use violent, terrorist strikes beginning in 1995 if inner city conditions in Milwaukee don't improve. McGee has claimed his militia already has about 500 members, including many young street gang members. Censure is a symbolic action with no legal or practical effect other than to rebuke a member's actions. The failed motion to ``repudiate'' McGee was similar but used less strong language. McGee did not take part in the censure vote. Of the other two blacks on the council, one voted against censure and the other was not present.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker To Be Investigated On Murder Charges
DOC.TEXT: Former East German leader Erich Honecker will be investigated for murder in the deaths of people who were shot or killed by land mines as they tried to escape Communist rule, the state news agency said Friday. Acting East German chief prosecutor Guenter Seidel also is investigating individual soldiers suspected of having killed would-be escapees, according to East Germany's ADN news agency. More than 200 East Germans were shot to death or killed by land mines as they tried to escape from East Germany and East Berlin during more than four decades of Communist rule. Bringing those responsible to justice has been one of the most bitterly debated issues in East Germany since the fall revolution toppled the Communist government. Honecker is believed to be the first Communist leader ousted in Eastern Europe's pro-democracy movement to be targeted in a murder investigation. Romania's former leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, was executed on Christmas Day after a quickly arranged trial on genocide charges. If convicted, the 77-year-old Honecker could receive life in prison. However, it is unclear whether he will ever be brought to trial because of his failing health. He has been suffering from kidney cancer and other problems and is in a hospital in the East German town of Beelitz. Honecker already is the target of other criminal probes, including a West German investigation for allegedly harboring West German terrorists. ``The personal guilt of Honecker for the deadly shootings at the Berlin Wall and the German-German boundary is to be investigated,'' said Seidel's spokesman, Dieter Plath, at an East Berlin news conference carried by ADN. He added that Honecker's poor health has made it impossible to interrogate him. He also said many records of the old East German leadership were destroyed by the secret police when it became clear the Honecker regime was crumbling. ``This makes the investigation very difficult,'' Plath said. It also makes it difficult to determine when the investigation might be completed, he said. For months there have been growing demands for legal action against Honecker, who was ousted in October. Honecker supervised construction of the Berlin Wall in 1961 and maintained shoot-to-kill orders after taking over as the country's leader in 1971. However, even before Honecker's ouster, the land mines and automatic shooting devices on the German-German border had been removed and Honecker claimed the shoot-to-kill orders had been lifted. The chief prosecutor filed a criminal complaint against Honecker. That procedure institutes a criminal investigation that could lead to an indictment and trial. ``One reason for this complaint at this time is to counter speculation about an amnesty for those responsible for the shootings,'' Plath said. East Germans have been infuriated by a military prosecutor's decision to rule out court-martials for those involved in the shootings. The prosecutor, Col. Karlheinz Boesel, said it was too difficult to pin down exactly who fired the deadly shots. The shoot-to-kill orders formed one of the major sources of tension between East Berlin and Bonn for years. They were also the primary reason why successive U.S. administrations refused to invite Honecker to Washington. In other developments Friday: _Shopping ground to a halt in East Germany as stores closed to take inventory and restock almost empty shelves with Western goods, just two days before the introduction of the West German currency. _East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere predicted full German unification by the end of the year. That is the same timetable outlined earlier in the week by the West Germans. _The Bonn government said Chancellor Helmut Kohl will visit Moscow on July 15 and 16 to discuss economic support for the Kremlin. West German officials said agreement was reached with the Kremlin on financing the costs of the 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany for the second half of this year.

DOC.HEAD: American Finishes Bike Journey on Great Wall
DOC.TEXT: American cyclist Kevin Foster, dodging startled guards who wanted to arrest him, whizzed down the last stretch of the Great Wall to reach the ocean Friday, completing his end-to-end journey on the ancient monument. Four people who were waiting to greet Foster were questioned for about an hour, including two American businessmen who helped sponsor his journey. ``It was kind of an exciting ending but not the ending I planned,'' a sunburned and scratched Foster said after returning to Beijing by train. The scratches came from bushes along the last stretch of wall. He said the guards at Shanhaiguan, where the wall ends at the ocean, were startled to see him and a Chinese companion come shooting down the wall from a direction other than the ticket booth and turnstile for tourists. Foster said he ducked out of sight while the guards questioned Professor Li Wenyan of the Chinese Academy of Science's Institute of Geography, Foster's Chinese sponsor; a Chinese television reporter; and Bill and Laroy Van Dyke, brothers and top officers of the U.S.-based Bike-o-Matic company. The company helped sponsor the trip. Foster, 30, a part-time actor from Ojai, Calif., set out May 11 to become the first person to bicycle on top of the wall from one end to the other. He started at the wall's westernmost pass, Jiayuguan, in Gansu province, but had to skip a large stretch of wall that traverses a closed military area. He walked alongside other portions of wall that are in ruins, altogether bicycling 1,174.8 miles of the 3,700-mile-long wall. Foster is the first person to bicycle any substantial distance on the monument, which China's emperors built more than 2,000 years ago to keep out foreigners. ``I was the first to do it, that was the dream,'' he said. ``If someone else wants to do what I just did _ good luck.'' ``The last few days I've been thinking not just about ending it but about taking a shower,'' he added. The 12 days he spent bicycling from Beijing east to the ocean were the toughest, he said, because the wall snakes through mountainous terrain. In places, the man-made wall simply stops and yields to sheer cliffs. ``I carried the bike more than rode it,'' Foster said. ``There were a couple of times I went to take a step and there was a 20-foot drop. I was able to grab the bushes and hold on.'' He also encountered the worst bureaucratic barriers of the trip, when local police began demanding he obtain a separate travel permit for each county he passed through. They also said he could not sleep in villages near the wall but had to travel each night to the county seats. ``I didn't enjoy the authority part,'' he said. ``Meeting the people along the wall _ those were the best times.'' Foster said he is thinking about writing a book about his experiences. Chinese all along the route were fascinated by his custom-built aluminum mountain bike, much lighter than the black steel bicycles that are the main mode of transportation in China. He is hoping his journey will be included in the Guinness Book of World Records.

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Supreme Court Justice Resigns After Fighting Mandatory Retirement
DOC.TEXT: A 71-year-old Vermont Supreme Court justice is stepping down from the bench after successfully fighting against the state's mandatory retirement law. Justice Louis Peck said he has notified Gov. Madeleine Kunin of his intention to retire effective Oct. 1. The state decided earlier this month not to appeal a federal court ruling upholding Peck's right to remain despite a constitutional provision that all judges in Vermont retire at age 70. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled this spring that a federal law restricting mandatory retirement covers appointed state judges. When Peck turned 70 in December 1988 he refused to retire. ``I felt strongly that if a person is in good health that person ought to be allowed to remain on the bench,'' Peck said Thursday. ``I kind of have mixed emotions. My primary motivation was to test the law. ``I have done that and now I feel I can retire,'' he said. The federal appeals court decision allowed Peck to remain on the bench until his term ends in three years. Peck is considered the most conservative member of the state's highest court. He has written several stinging dissents to court decisions that he felt unfairly usurped the power of the Legislature. Peck was appointed to the court in 1981 by then-Gov. Richard Snelling, a Republican. At the time, Peck was Vermont's chief assistant attorney general. His decision to retire means that Kunin, a Democrat, can appoint his replacement before she leaves office in January. In doing so, Kunin will have named three of the court's five justices. Peck said his decision was prompted in part by early retirement incentives being offered in state government. The program is part of an effort to reduce the number of state employees.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Police Break Up Sit-in Strike By Farmers at Ministry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE police moving in. Pickup 3rd pvs, `The growers...''
DOC.TEXT: Police smashed open a door of the Agriculture Ministry with a sledgehammer tonight and stormed into the building to end a three-day, sit-in strike by farmers seeking guaranteed prices for their goods. Officers broke open a locked ministry door shortly before 7:30 p.m., and scores of uniformed officers entered the building in central Warsaw. The move came after efforts to persuade the farmers to leave of their own volition failed. It was not immediately known if officers encountered any resistance inside or if there were any arrests. The government steadfastly had refused to negotiate with the protesters while the occupation continued. Earlier in the day, police who had ringed the ministry withdrew after the 600 farmers had agreed to admit employees. The police wagons had roared off on a ranking officer's signal as the ministry workers filed in through an iron gate hung with a strike banner. A parliament delegation also was admitted to meet with the farmers. The growers are demanding minimum prices for their products as a shelter from the government's shock economic reform program. They occupied the ministry Wednesday afternoon following a protest march through Warsaw. They shut the building to employees on Thursday. Agricultural Minister Czeslaw Janicki and his deputies were permitted in this morning as the workers waited outside. Two dozen police vehicles then surrounded the building. The government conditioned the start of serious negotiations on the farmers allowing the resumption of normal work at the ministry and ending their sit-in. The farmers, who clustered in several ministry conference rooms, said they would not conduct talks until the police were removed. But they appeared divided over whether to agree to admit the workers, and reversed their decision several times before allowing them in at mid-afternoon. Polish Peasant Party Chairman Roman Bartoszcze met with the protesters late Thursday to report on his discussions with Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, President Wojciech Jaruzelski and Solidarity leader Lech Walesa. Walesa, who was to return tonight from Vienna, said he would be available to help resolve the conflict, Bartoszcze said. The Solidarity leader's personal appeal won suspensions of the two other serious challenges to the Mazowiecki reform program: a strike by railway workers that disrupted transport across northwest Poland in May, and a blockade of the main Warsaw-Gdansk highway by dairy farmers in mid-June. Mazowiecki ``will not give up on issues linked with guaranteed minimum prices, and there will be no talks as long as farmers are occupying the ministerial building,'' Bartoszcze said, according to the official PAP news agency. The farmers seek the government-set minimum prices as a buffer against the effects of post-Communist Poland's drive to create a market economy out of the centralized, socialized system of the last four decades. A complex web of economic factors has pushed down farm prices. One problem is that consumption has fallen in the face of price increases of up to 1,000 percent in a year. There is also a competitive glut of food donations from Western nations, who rushed to offer support to the new government. The Mazowiecki Cabinet has repeatedly rejected demands for special treatment of any sector of the economy. It has also refused to speak with railway workers or dairy farmers under the pressure of strike, saying yielding once would produce a torrent of requests from other groups. The government compares demands for minimum farm prices to the system of subsidies that the Communist regime used to satisfy farmers while keeping consumer prices well below the actual cost of production. The reform program cut most subsidies, lifted price controls, let interest rates rise to reflect the level of inflation and opened the economy to private ventures.

DOC.HEAD: Montrealer Jumps Tracks in Philadelphia
DOC.TEXT: An Amtrak train carrying at least 94 people derailed Friday as it approached 30th Street Station, injuring the engineer, authorities said. The engine and the first three cars of the eight-car Montrealer derailed near the Philadelphia Zoo, 1{ miles northwest of the station, shortly after 1 p.m., said Amtrak spokesman Clifford Black. Black said there were no immediate reports of injuries to passengers. The engineer suffered bruises on his legs and upper body, none of which appeared serious, said police Sgt. Christopher McCabe. The derailment occurred at a track switch, but the cause was not known, Black said. The cars remained upright. A manifest listed 94 passengers, but there may have been more aboard, Black said. The Montrealer was heading to Washington, D.C., from Montreal when the derailment occurred. Black said the accident probably would not cause a major disruption in northeast corridor service because adjacent tracks can be used.

DOC.HEAD: No Complaints About Mayor's Language, Networks Say
With AM-Barry Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Washington Mayor Marion Barry's language on the videotape was strong, but no viewers complained to the networks for airing it, network officials said Friday. ABC, CBS and NBC on Thursday evening broadcast excerpts of the FBI videotape showing Barry smoking what authorities said was crack just before he was arrested at a Washington, D.C., hotel on Jan. 18. He cursed when he was arrested and characterized the woman who helped an undercover FBI operation as a ``bitch.'' The tape was played Thursday at Barry's cocaine and perjury trial in Washington. ``We didn't get any complaints at all,'' NBC spokesman Marc Bien said when asked if any viewers had called to gripe about the mayor's strong language. CBS and ABC officials also said they received no complaints. Cable television's C-Span ran the entire 82-minute tape Thursday night and again Friday morning, preceding it with disclaimers and periodic warnings about Barry's language. C-Span, which serves more than 47.2 million homes, also received no complaints, said Kathy Murphy, who handles viewer calls at the Washington-based service. But there were a couple of calls Friday from reporters asking if there had been any complaints, said Susan Swain, who moderated a C-Span call-in show following Friday's rerun of the tape. C-Span will rerun the complete tape twice on Sunday, at 11:25 a.m. and 7 p.m. EDT, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian President Urges Thanks for Quake Aid in Rebuff to Hard-Liners
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Insert graf after 14th, ``It's the...' to move up announcement of increased U.S. aid; SUB grafs 17-18 with 2 grafs to ADD State Department comment on private aid. Pickup 19th pvs, `The president...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XTEH1,2; TOK2
DOC.TEXT: President Hashemi Rafsanjani challenged anti-Western radicals in the government Friday and said Iran should be thankful for foreign aid for earthquake victims, even if it comes from Iran's foes. ``I don't think we see the people who are under the debris saying, `No we don't want foreign aid,''' the president said at a Moslem prayer gathering at Tehran University. His comment rebutted an editorial that appeared last week in the newspaper Jomhuri Islami. The newspaper said people buried under rubble from the June 21 quake would still chant ``Death to America'' and refuse aid from Iran's enemies, such as the United States. ``Logic says if our people have no tents and the weather is bad, we should accept foreign aid,'' Rafsanjani said. ``The response and activities of the foreigners were really good and acceptable,'' he added. Aid has poured into Iran from dozens of countries since the temblor, which measured 7.3 to 7.7 on the Richter scale, devastated cities and towns in northern Iran. The epicenter was about 125 miles northwest of Tehran and mainly affected the provinces of Gilan and Zanjan. The Iranian Red Crescent has put the casualties at 40,000 dead and 60,000 injured. The official Islamic Republic News Agency said three more aftershocks were felt Thursday night. One measured 5 on the Richter scale. Nations that have offered relief help include the United States, Britain, Saudi Arabia, Israel, and other countries considered Iran's foes. British author Salman Rushie, condemned to death by Iranian leaders last year for allegedly insulting Islam in his novel ``The Satanic Verses,'' also has contributed money. Hard-liners in Iran's parliament last week said the offers of help should not lead to improved ties with the West. Anti-Western radicals in the government oppose any form of foreign assistance to the Islamic Republic. Newspapers aligned with differing factions in the government have debated whether the aid should be accepted. So far, Iran has only rejected aid from Israel and South Africa. Rafsanjani did not comment Friday on whether Iran should improve relations with the West, but he called for an end to criticism of the earthquake relief effort. ``If someone comments only about the negative issues, it will disappoint the people who have been working hard in the relief effort,'' he said. On Thursday, an Iranian diplomatic official told The Associated Press that Iran wants to improve its ties with all nations except for archenemies Israel and South Africa. But he said the U.S. government had spoiled an opportunity for better relations by giving only $295,000 for quake relief. ``It's the amount of one house in California,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The United States announced Wednesday it would send another shipment of emergency supplies, bringing the total U.S. government contribution to about $760,000. Western diplomats in Iran believe the quake aid will provide Rafsanjani with the lever gradually to introduce more Western investment in Iran. Rafsanjani seeks foreign investment as a means of gaining technology to rebuild Iran's economy, which was badly damaged by eight years of war with Iraq. He made no link Friday between Western aid and the release of Western hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. But Iran has said Western gestures of good will could prompt Iran to further help obtain hostages' freedom. In Washington on Friday, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said aid from private American groups exceeds $4 million, in addition to the government aid. She denied she was volunteering the figures in response to Iranian official's allegation that Washington had not sent enough aid and refused to comment on that criticism. The U.S. government aid is still less than other countries. Sweden has donated $3 million, and North Korea announced it would give $1 million. The president praised the relief efforts and noted the Iranian people were also generous in their donations, despite the hard conditions in the country due to the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. Thousands of people, kneeling in rows under a canvas to ward off the sun, listened to Rafsanjani. They cheered and thrust their fists in the air when Rafsanjani praised the Iranian people and their sacrifices for the Islamic revolution. In other parts of the campus, tens of thousands of others, including women with their heads covered and wearing full-length black chadors, listened over a public address system. Rafsanjani also said Iran should be better prepared for future earthquakes. ``A quake is a natural phenomenon and of course everything is done by God,'' Rafsanjani said. ``But that does not mean we should confine ourselves to prayers alone.'' ``Many buildings were destroyed which were not built according to specific, scientific plans in this respect,'' the president said. ``In the future, engineers and masons should keep these factors in mind.'' Rafsanjani pointed out that losses in California, where a major earthquake struck in October, were much reduced by such preparations. The Oct. 17 earthquake in the San Francisco Bay area killed 68 people. It measured 7.1 on the Richter scale. Shoddy construction was also blamed for the high death toll in the December 1988 earthquake in Soviet Armenia. That quake measured 6.9 on the Richter scale and killed an estimated 25,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Roller Coaster Boasting-Rights Suit
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday rejected an amusement park's attempt to reopen a lawsuit against a Texas park over roller coaster boasting rights. Dorney Park of Allentown claimed that Six Flags of Texas, of Arlington, Texas, violated their April 11 out-of-court agreement by falsely saying its Texas Giant is ``the largest structure of its kind in the world.'' U.S. District Judge Franklin Van Antwerpen rejected Dorney Park's attempt to reopen the case, saying the Six Flags claim did not violate the agreement. Nothing in the agreement ever mentioned ``structure,'' according to Dorney Park lawyer Richard Stevens, defender of the park's Hercules roller coaster. Dorney Park had sued Six Flags in April, saying the Texas park was falsely advertising it had the tallest wooden roller coaster in the world. According to the April settlement, Six Flags acknowledged that Dorney's Hercules has the highest drop of any wooden coaster in the world, at 157 feet, while Six Flags' Texas Giant has the highest lift of any wooden roller coaster, at 143 feet. The judge dismissed the suit in April.

DOC.HEAD: Pieces of Stolen Van Gogh Frame Found, But No Solid Leads
DOC.TEXT: A woman walking her dog found frame sections from one of three stolen van Goghs, but police said Friday they had no solid leads to the third van Gogh theft from Dutch museums in 25 months. A 25-member police task force was questioning museum staff Friday, although police said they believe Thursday's post-midnight theft from the Noordbrabants Museum was not the work of insiders. ``We've gotten tips in from all over the country and we're busy checking them out right now,'' said police spokesman Jacques Brummans. ``But the golden tip still hasn't come in.'' The thieves _ police believe there were three _ jumped several fences and smashed through a reinforced ground-floor window to gain entry to the museum. A sophisticated alarm system was not functioning in the gallery where the paintings were kept. Stolen were three early pre-impressionist works by the 19th-century Dutch artist _ ``The Sitting Farmer's Wife,'' ``The Digging Farmer's Wife,'' and ``Wheels of the Water Mill in Gennep.'' The museum in this city 53 miles south of Amsterdam set the total worth of the paintings at between $2.7 million and $5.4 million. It was the third theft of van Gogh works from Dutch museums since May 1988. Four paintings stolen earlier from the Kroeller-Mueller museum in Otterloo in the eastern Netherlands and Amsterdam's Municipal Museum have all been recovered. Police arrived at the scene of Thursday's theft within minutes of receiving phone calls from neighbors, who reported hearing glass shatter. The museum said two separate security systems to detect intruders _ seismic sensors to measure movement and infrared eyes to measure body heat _ failed. Peter Veenland, the museum's deputy director, said Thursday there were indicators that should have signaled the faults in the systems, and those indicators failed as well. A 24-year-old art student told police she found pieces of the van Gogh picture frame early Thursday in a street behind the museum, Brummans said. Police confirmed the segments were from one of the stolen paintings. ``It didn't look so nice so I just left it there,'' Anita van de Ven told Amsterdam's De Telegraaf newspaper. Brummans said police were investigating the woman's report that she saw a white Mercedes speeding by her near where she found the frame pieces.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Restaurants Gear Up For Annual Chowderfest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Chowderfest listed on AM-News Advisory
DOC.TEXT: It's chili in Dallas, sourdough in San Francisco, pizza in Chicago and jambalaya down New Orleans way. But in this New England city, clam chowder is what's famous and having the best is a restaurateur's dream. That's why chefs were slaving Friday over steaming 150-gallon vats of soup for this weekend's annual Chowderfest, whose winner will be judged by about 15,000 amateur tasters. ``Having the best chowder in Boston pays off big,'' said manager Steve Bidgood of the Chart House, which won last year. ``Our chowder business went up by 50 percent last year.'' Of course you've got to take the risk before reaping the return. Entering this competition, which is in its ninth year, requires hundreds of dollars and hours of work. ``It cost close to $2,300 last year,'' said Bidgood, whose restaurant is part of a nationwide chain. ``And that doesn't include the $2.50 entry fee or the insurance binders for employees in case one of them gets hurt.'' His chef, John Doherty, requires among other things 30 pounds of bacon, 50 pounds of onions, eight cases of heavy cream, 100 pounds of potatoes, a rowboat full of clams and a very, very big pot. Doherty's product will be among a dozen entries Sunday at City Hall Plaza, where for $6 each, everyday folk become instant judges _ and fill their bellies with chowder to boot. Their votes are scribbled on ticket stubs and tallied by the accounting firm Ernst & Young. ``We take this seriously,'' said spokeswoman Toni Pollak of Boston Harborfest, a week-long festival featuring the chowder challenge. Restaurant managers and their staff become carnival barkers of sorts, wooing votes with smiles, songs and, of course, creamy clam chowder. ``There's quite a bit of rivalry,'' Pollak said. ``It hasn't gotten cut-throat yet, but the hawking sometimes gets pretty loud.'' A lot more than a silver Revere bowl is at stake. ``Restaurants use it for marketing throughout the year because obviously it's nice to say you've got the best in Boston,'' Pollak said. ``We were very disappointed coming in only second last year when we were number one in 1988,'' said Debbie Allen, who manages The Last Hurrah at the 134-year-old Omni-Parker House. So what exactly is in the brew? Restaurateurs will give you the basics, but admit with a sly smile that just a couple of secret touches might be omitted. For the whole story you might try Turners Fisheries, which was taken out of the competition and inducted into the Chowderfest Hall of Fame after taking consecutive victories in 1984-86. Turners Fisheries prints its recipe on the backs of menus that disappear at a rate of about 20 a day. The restaurant will give out samples but won't compete Sunday. ``I think they were getting a little upset with our sweeping three years in a row,'' said Ellen Lynch, spokeswoman for the downtown Westin Hotel that houses the restaurant. But it's the people's choice, afterall. ``When you come to New England you want that thick, creamy, clammy _ lot of clams _ chowder,'' Bidgood said. ``People are picky. They'll tell you if they think your potato chunks are too big.''

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Try to Unload Old Money in Empty Stores
With AM-Honecker, Bjt
LaserPhoto BER5
DOC.TEXT: East Germans tried to unload their Communist currency Friday on enough food to get through a historic weekend, but stores shut down to wait for the fatter profits of the free market. Stores all week have been clearing shelves and closing doors to wait for Western products that they can sell to East Germans who will suddenly have Western currency. The trend has created severe shortages of food and household products, a situation that peaked in East Berlin and other cities Friday. East Germany ends four decades of socialism and its economic autonomy as a nation Sunday, when it merges its economy with West Germany's. The cornerstone of the economic union is the conversion of East Germany's nearly worthless marks into West German marks. Banks will be open Sunday so East Germans can withdraw their first convertible cash, and stores will open Monday filled with products from the West. East Berliner Johanna Suska said she was spending the last of her East German currency on enough food to get through the first week of the economic union. ``Our local department store is completely empty,'' she said. ``There is just some bread and milk, sugar and flour.'' Mrs. Suska, a mother of five, said she welcomed the economic union even though she already has been laid off from her job at an agricultural research firm. Analysts predict that 1 million to 4 million East Germans will lose their jobs as their inefficient enterprises face competition from the West. West German officials sought to assure East Germans that the widespread factory closings and joblessness expected in the coming weeks will coincide with a surge in Western investment. East German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said 500,000 new jobs could be created in the short-term future and that an East German ``boom'' is imminent. Long lines continued at banks as people filled out applications to convert their savings. East German lawmakers tried to prevent former Communist officials who may have accumulated large amounts of money from benefiting from the currency conversion. Parliament voted Friday to require the East German State Bank to report the names of East Germans with more than 100,000 marks in their bank accounts. The average bank account has between 5,000 and 10,000 marks. Officials are encouraging East Germans to be thrifty with their new West German marks. Economists fear a mass spending free will dilute the strength of the mark and lead to inflation. Sigfried Guterman, a spokesman for the West German central bank, the Bundesbank, said there are early indications that East Germans will save their money. People who have been filling out the currency conversion forms are required to list the size of their initial withdrawal. The average amount East Germans plan to withdraw is about 800 marks, or $500, Guterman said. ``People seem to be quite thrifty,'' he said. ``The figure is far below what was expected. We do not expect a spending spree.'' Stores have been snubbing both the old Communist currency and the electronics equipment, household goods and food produced by their countrymen. At a paint and wallpaper shop in the city of Bernau north of Berlin, owner Rainer Selch said he shut his store this week to renovate and keep from accumulating East German marks. He was expecting a delivery of West German paint on Monday and said he had no qualms about cutting his orders for East German paint. ``People want the West products,'' he said. ``If you try to keep these factories when they should fail, it will only harm people more,'' he said. ``Radical, fast change is best. Going slow will only be worse.''

DOC.HEAD: Fires Engulf 600 Homes and Businesses; Death Toll In State Rises To Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with second death reported. Picks up 2nd graf pvs, `Wildfires, most...'. SUBS 10th-12th grafs, bgng `Hospitals reported...', with 6 grafs to add detail on latest death. Picks up 13th graf, `Late Thursday...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA1,2,3, XPAY2
DOC.TEXT: Milder winds and temperatures gave firefighters the upper hand today in a wildfire that engulfed 524 homes and businesses in Santa Barbara County and in other blazes that burned more than 90 homes. Two Californians died in the fires _ a state prisoner serving as a firefighter and a 37-year-old Santa Barbara woman found near the wreckage of her home in a burned-out neighborhood, authorities said today. Wildfires, most set by arsonists, charred more than 18,700 acres by Thursday in a six-county area north, east and south of Los Angeles. Arson was blamed for the Santa Barbara fire and another that charred 66 homes in the Los Angeles suburb of Glendale before it was contained. Losses could surpass $500 million in Santa Barbara County and $30 million in Glendale, officials said. ``You're just lucky to have your life,'' said Kay O'Brien, who fled her Santa Barbara home with her husband carrying only family pictures and a retirement watch. The home and all their possessions were lost. A county survey completed late Thursday found 524 structures destroyed, including 315 single family homes. Officials previously said 567 homes and businesses had been destroyed. Calm wind and overnight temperatures in the 50s helped 800 firefighters subdue the blaze. Officials hoped to contain the fire by noon Saturday, said Juanita Freel, spokeswoman for the U.S. Forest Service. ``It's pretty calm out there now,'' Robert Ooley, a Santa Barbara County fire spokesman, said today. ``It's still smoldering somewhat, but it's nothing like before. It's certainly on the downside now.'' Elsewhere, firefighters controlled blazes in Utah and at Yellowstone National Park in Montana, but large fires raged in Arizona, Texas and Colorado. In Arizona, where six firefighters died Tuesday, a lightning fire in the Tonto National Forest destroyed a cabin built in the 1920s by Western novelist Zane Grey. In California, Gov. George Deukmejian declared states of emergency in the Santa Barbara and Glendale areas. The governor also authorized separate $50,000 rewards for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the arsonists in both blazes. Hospitals reported admitting 13 people for fire-related injuries and treating 55 others. Karen Terrill, spokeswoman for the state forestry department, said in a statement this morning that a state prisoner died as a result of injuries suffered while fighting a Riverside County fire. The victim was Victor Ferrara, 22, according to spokeswoman Patty Perez of the San Bernardino Medical Center. Ferrara, who died late Thursday, was burned when his crew was overrun by wind-driven flames, Ms. Terrill said. In all, 1,200 state prisoners are helping in the firefighting effort. In Santa Barbara, the body Andrea Gurka, 37, was found this morning in a creek bed behind her home in the area where the fire began, said county fire spokesman Charlie Johnson. ``She apparently had attempted to flee her residence when it was being overrun by flames Wednesday evening,'' Johnson said. Late Thursday, in the suburban community of Claremont, 30 miles east of Los Angeles, an arson-suspected blaze burned out of control along brush-laden hillsides and consumed 400 acres, authorities said. Police blocked several residential streets although no homes were evacuated. Police in Glendale were looking for two young men after witnesses said they saw one of them toss a butane lighter from a moving car into the brush off the road where the fire started, said Chris Gray, a Glendale Fire Department battalion chief. The 4,000-acre arson fire that broke out late Wednesday in a valley between Santa Barbara and the nearby town of Goleta was one of the worst on record here. Damage to homes alone was estimated initially at $190 million, and the figure was expected to top $500 million, said county Supervisor Bill Wallace. No more homes appeared threatened today. Authorities have said an incendiary device was found at the fire's origin, but they haven't given details. The Santa Barbara City Council voted Thursday to call off the July 4 fireworks at the city beach. Mayor Sheila Lodge implored residents not to celebrate with their own fireworks. Santa Barbara, which posted a record 109 degrees Wednesday, has tinder-dry foliage. A U.S. Forest Service helicopter dropping water on flames crashed Thursday afternoon in San Marcos Pass. The pilot suffered only scrapes and bruises. Firefighters surrounded 60 percent of a 4,500-acre wildfire in Corona in Riverside County today, but not before it destroyed eight homes, said Capt. David Parks of the California Department of Forestry. The blaze was set as a controlled burn June 19 in the Cleveland National Forest but jumped fire lines three times, officials said. A 2,500-acre blaze burning today near Lake Henshaw in San Diego County forced the evacuation of a Boy Scout camp and 20 homes, authorities said. Four earlier brush fires in the county blackened about 1,700 acres before firefighters contained the blazes. An arson blaze in the Carbon Canyon area that straddles Orange and San Bernardino counties blackened 6,640 acres and destroyed at least 14 homes. Officials hoped to control the blaze late today, state Department of Forestry Capt. Jerry Hendershot said. ``To make matters worse, fireworks go on sale today,'' said department spokeswoman Sharon Sellers. ``We're not happy about that.'' A man described as a transient was arrested for investigation of arson in the Carbon Canyon blaze. Authorities said he sparked the blaze while trying to make coffee with two camp fires. In east-central Arizona, officials said the 24,000-acre Tonto National Forest fire was about 50 percent contained this morning. The fire that began with a lightning strike has destroyed about 50 homes and forced the evacuation of more than 1,200 people.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Mandela Tired, Considering Shortening U.S. Visit by One Day
DOC.TEXT: A tired Nelson Mandela was considering shortening his U.S. anti-apartheid crusade by one day, a tour official said Friday. ``It's being discussed right now on the plane. He's tired. That's all,'' said Katie Broeren, a member of the Mandela advance team waiting at Los Angeles International Airport for his arrival from Detroit. Los Angeles is the seventh of an eight-stop tour of the United States. Mandela, who was jailed for 27 years for opposing the white minority-ruled South African government and its system of racial separation, was scheduled to attend rallies in Los Angeles on Friday and go to Oakland on Saturday for the last stop.

DOC.HEAD: Author's Artifacts Lost in Cabin Fire
With AM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Few of the irreplaceable Zane Grey artifacts and memorabilia were removed before a forest fire destroyed the Western author's historic cabin, its curator says. ``We didn't get a whole lot out,'' Ila Patten said Thursday from her daughter's home in Mesa, while awaiting to hear whether her quarters near the cabin also had been destroyed. The warning that the cabin site was threatened came sometime after 2 a.m. Wednesday. Ms. Patten's two daughters and six children were visiting at the time. The danger led to ``a mad scramble'' to get the children, three dogs and some of the memorabilia into three cars, Ms. Patten said. Just after they had begun grabbing some of the most valuable museum items, a sheriff's deputy told them they must leave immediately, she said. ``We just got a few things that weren't complicated to get out,'' she said. Items saved included about 10 first-edition books by Grey, three firearms, spurs, bridles, chaps, hats, photographs and posters of movies based on Grey's books, she said. Furniture, hunting trophies, fur rugs and ``tons of books'' were left behind and lost, she said. ``We had cabinets and bookcases full of them.'' Grey, a dentist, wrote 98 books. Among his best-known melodramatic tales of the West was ``Riders of the Purple Sage'' in 1912. He died in 1939 at age 67.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush Rdp, Bjt
Bush Concerned About Deadlock in Mideast Peace Process
DOC.TEXT: President Bush expressed concern Friday over the deadlock in the Middle East peace process and said the United States has no intention of abandoning its pursuit of a settlement despite recent setbacks. ``We're not going to sit here and do nothing,'' Bush told a news conference. The United States will persist even if the year-long effort to set up Israeli-Palestinian talks gets ``totally stiff-armed,'' Bush said. Bush refused to characterize a letter he had received Thursday night from Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir in response to an earlier message the president had sent. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler also refused to comment. But reports from Israel said Shamir, in his letter, expressed renewed interest in opening a dialogue with Palestinians. ``I am concerned about a deadlock in the peace process,'' Bush said. His letter to Shamir inquired about the Israeli leader's intentions now that the political paralysis in that country has ended with the formation of a new government. ``We will be analyzing the Shamir response very, very carefully and hopefully,'' Bush said. He added that he places high priority on finding enough flexibility in the letter to get talks started. ``It is essential; the status quo is unacceptable to everybody,'' Bush said. The opening of talks between Israel and the Palestinians, he said, ``has to happen.'' According to sources, Shamir in his response reaffirmed his commitment to his own proposal for elections among Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank and Gaza Strip. He also said he continues to support efforts by Secretary of State James A. Baker III to implement the plan. A key stumbling block has been whether to exclude Palestinians who had been deported by Israel from participating in proposed Israeli-Palestinian discussions on the election plan. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the prime minister did not specifically exclude Palestinians deported from the territories. Israeli radio, meanwhile, quoted Shamir as saying he disagrees with the participation of deportees and Arabs from Jerusalem in the talks. Israel has opposed participation by a representative from East Jerusalem because to do otherwise might suggest that the status of the city was open to negotiation. The Israeli radio broadcast said Shamir also told Bush he is ``ready to continue to cooperate with Secretary Baker to advance a dialogue with a Palestinian delegation that will be composed on a name-by-name basis.'' Israeli television said Shamir ruled out participation by deportees ``chosen by the PLO.'' There were published accounts Friday that Shamir had rejected U.S. proposals for Israeli-Palestinian talks. In apparent response to those reports, the 21-nation Arab League issued a statement accusing Shamir of ``intransigence'' and an ``irreversible commitment to stonewalling.'' The statement said the United Nations should send a Security Council team to the occupied territories and should start preparing for an international conference. ``This is the only course available to salvage the peace option in the Middle East,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Central Committee Approves Documents for Communist Congress on Monday
With AM-Soviet-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned top Communist Party leaders on Friday that they must avoid a split at next week's key congress that is to plot the party's future course, a spokesman said. Gorbachev and his allies argue that disintegration of the party's pro-reform movement would weaken it against conservatives who dominated last week's founding congress of the Communist Party of the Russian republic. The Central Committee, the policy-making body of the 19-million member party, tentatively approved a report that Gorbachev will deliver Monday at the 28th congress of the Soviet Communist Party, where conservatives will be strongly represented. But the 249-member committee ordered the Politburo to ``rework it taking into account discussion'' during a three-hour, forty-minute closed-door Kremlin meeting, said Alexander Kapto, head of the Central Committee ideological department. As the national congress approached, Gorbachev's moderate and reformist allies appeared to be on the offensive. The state news agency Tass warned that dumping Gorbachev as party leader could spell ``disaster'' and a Politburo member said hard-liners were pursuing a ``suicidal'' course. Gorbachev was also trying to head off a split threatened by the radical Democratic Platform, whose members want faster reforms within the party and have instructed their delegates to walk out. Speaking to reporters at a news conference after the plenum, Kapto quoted Gorbachev as saying the crucial issue is ``to ensure the consolidation of party members.'' The congress also will debate whether the president should be allowed to also serve as party leader _ as Gorbachev does now. Conservatives want Gorbachev to give up his party job. The moderates appeared to be having some success stemming the conservative tide before the congress. The most prominent hard-liner on the Politburo, Yegor K. Ligachev, said in an interview with the Rabochaya Tribuna newspaper that he had ``absolute confidence'' in Gorbachev's authority and that the congress would focus on the fate of the country and the party rather than on individuals. In the weeks leading to the congress, the party has been in increasing disarray. Kapto said 130,000 members had recently quit the party but declined to specify over what period. The 4,683 delegates to the congress will vote on party leadership posts, including the general secretary and Central Committee. And it might vote on whether to change the name of the senior post to chairman and create two new jobs, vice chairmen, Kapto said. The committee did not discuss the question of postponing the congress, as proposed this week by reformer Boris N. Yeltsin in order slow the conservative thrust. Its inaction means that the congress will proceed as scheduled Monday. Yeltsin later told state television that ``all of our arguments are ahead of us.'' Delegates spent the day registering for the congress. Kapto said the meeting was expected to last about 10 days, but could end when the delegates wanted. The congress is to assess the state of economic reform, relations between the party and trade unions as well as the results of last week's congress of the Communist Party of the Russian Federation, by far the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. Conservatives lambasted Gorbachev at the congress, and its 2,700 delegates will represent the republic at the Soviet party congress. Moderates originally had scheduled the congress as a means of cleaning hard-liners out of leadership posts, but conservatives controlled delegate selection and were threatening to dominate the session. A Gorbachev ally, Yevgeny Primakov, a non-voting member of the Politburo, which runs the party on a day-to-day basis, accused the conservatives of ``suicide policies.'' ``And to oppose perestroika is suicidal for any political leader now,'' said Primakov, who is also a member of Gorbachev's advisory Presidential Council. The strength of conservatives in the party has raised threats of a walkout by radical reformers, who support Gorbachev's ``perestroika'' reforms aimed at restructuring the economy by introducing market mechanisms and greater political freedoms. The congress also was to discuss the party's falling influence among the workers that is supposed to represent, Kapto said.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Post Tiny Gain
DOC.TEXT: New-home sales last month rose a meager 0.4 percent, at an annual rate, but were still at virtually their lowest level since the economy emerged from its last recession 7{ years ago. The government said Friday that the increase _ from an annual sales rate of 530,000 homes in April to a rate of 532,000 homes last month _ was the first gain in six months. since the despite their first increase in six months. Most analysts attributed the continuing sales weakness to double-digit mortgage rates but some said flagging consumer confidence also has become a major factor as the job market weakens and wage growth slows. The Commerce Department reported new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 532,000 units in May after falling 5.2 percent the previous month. But the April decline was even worse than the 1.6 percent drop first reported last month. And the rate of sales in both months was the lowest since 521,000 rate in December 1982. The 1981-82 recession ended that November. The pace of sales during the first five months of 1990 was down 9.6 percent from the same period last year. Actual sales in 1989 totaled 650,000, down from 676,000 units in 1988. Analysts also expressed concern over the high inventory level. While May's 8.2-month backlog slipped from the 8.4-month inventory in April, it matched the 8.2-month level of July 1982, during the last recession. The backlog ``suggests that we're going to have some problems down the road until sales pick up a little bit,'' said Thomas Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association. Robert Villanueva, forecasting director for the National Association of Home Builders, said the ``uncomfortably high'' level of unsold houses also ``suggests that housing starts will continue to be weak in order to bring starts in line with demand.'' The National Association of Realtors, which monitors existing home sales, reported earlier this week that resales of single-family homes had declined 1.2 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.29 million. Existing home sales have fallen every month this year except for March, when they were unchanged. But Holloway and other analysts predicted falling mortgage rates will stimulate home sales in the months ahead. ``Rates have fallen about half of what they went up and that has to have some positive effect on sales,'' David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said. ``They may not go up by much, but they will go up over the course of the year.'' Mortgage rates peaked this year at 10.67 percent at the beginning of May before falling to 10.33 percent at month's end, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Martin Regalia, an economist with the National Council of Savings Institutions, cited consumer caution as another reason for the weakness in the housing market. ``When consumer uncertainty increases, big discretionary purchases _ big new cars, big new houses, those kinds of things that can be delayed _ are the first to get delayed,'' he explained. The Commerce Department said the median price of a new home in May was $128,500, down 3.7 percent from the April cost. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. The average price of a new home was $150,400, down 2.5 pecent from the previous price. Sales in the sluggish Northeast market, which had risen 9.3 percent in April, fell back 5.6 percent in May to 84,000 units at an annual rate. Some analysts had said the April pace could not be sustained. Sales also fell in the South, down 1.0 percent to 199,000 units. Sales rose elsewhere. They were up 7.9 percent to 96,000 units in the Midwest and 4.8 percent to 152,000 units in the West.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Impounds Records in Hubble Probe; Senator Raps Attitude
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To add reference to shuttle troubles, inserts 4 grafs after 6th graf, He promised
DOC.TEXT: NASA is impounding decade-old equipment and records as it begins investigating design defects that have crippled the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, a senior agency scientist told a Senate panel Friday. But the official, Lennard A. Fisk, said he was not certain that all of the vital information would be found. And the chairman of the Senate subcommittee looking into the situation said it was symptomatic of broader problems at the space agency. Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., accused NASA of having an attitude that emphasizes big, exciting new projects at the expense of the mundane work necessary to make sure old ones are carried out properly. ``NASA's eyes are bigger than its stomach,'' Gore charged. Later, he added: ``We have been assured now for 12 years that everything was all right. We owe it to the taxpayers to find out what went wrong, how to fix it and make sure it never happens again.'' Fisk, the senior NASA scientist, told the Senate Commerce science subcommittee that the agency has assembled a review board of ``world-renowned experts'' led by Lew Allen, head of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif. He promised ultimately to give ``as clean a possible answer as we can.'' But he also said, ``I am somewhat concerned that we are going to try and reconstruct an event that took place a decade ago.'' In further troubles for NASA, while Fisk answered questions about the problems of Hubble, engineers at the Kennedy Space Center discovered a new problem with the space shuttle. A hydrogen leak in space shuttle Atlantis was found during a special test and NASA space flight chief William Lenoir said the shuttle fleet was being grounded until the leak was corrected. The leak was similar to a leak that led to postponing a flight last month of the space shuttle Columbia. Lenoir said NASA will not launch any of the shuttles until engineers have isolated the leak, corrected it and tested to make sure it is fixed. Scientists are virtually certain the telescope's problem is that images collected by its two main mirrors do not focus precisely enough, an error caused in the grinding of the mirrors. That work was done by the Hughes Danbury Optical Co. of Connecticut between 1979 to 1981, Fisk said. In the context of putting together a very complex observatory, ``we did not expect this to be part of the problem,'' Fisk said. Achieving precise specifications in mirrors is ``a routine part of an optical system.'' The mirrors were tested individually, but were never tried as an assembly in what NASA calls ``an end-to-end test,'' he said. ``The end-to-end test was judged not to have a good cost-to-benefit ratio,'' Fisk said. And he reminded Gore, ``That was a very turbulent time in the history of the Hubble Space Telescope'' replete with cost overruns and management problems. Fisk sought to put the best face on the problem, saying that while some kinds of scientific work have been seriously compromised, other valuable work can still be accomplished until 1993, when the problem might be repaired by a space shuttle mission. ``We will adjust the observing program to emphasize the things that Hubble does well today,'' such as ultraviolet imagery, Fisk said. He said the telescope's effectiveness should be measured by its discoveries over its entire 15-year lifespan, and promised: ``You will marvel at the discoveries that are going to come from the observations Hubble is capable of today. ... Do not assume that Hubble is crippled from doing first-class, world-class science that cannot be done in any other way.'' But Hervey Stockman, deputy director of a Baltimore-based consortium of university astronomy departments, said the problem has already caused a change in the underlying philosophy that governs what the telescope should be used for. Plans had been for the most critical, exacting and potentially valuable explorations to be made during the Hubble's first year of operation, in case something were to go wrong later. Many of those projects involved deep-space imaging of complex or dim formations. ``Those programs naturally have suffered,'' Stockman said. He said the consortium, the Space Telescope Science Institute, was heartened that 50 percent of the current program remains alive and that correction of the Hubble's problem should be relatively simple.

DOC.HEAD: Electoral Council Proposes Nov. 4 Vote in Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The independent Electoral Council on Friday proposed general elections be held Nov. 4, about two months later than had been anticipated. The council published its long-awaited draft electoral law, establishing the ground rules for Haiti's first free and fair balloting since popular protests toppled the regime of Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier in February 1986. The draft was presented at a press conference and delivered to political parties, which were invited to propose changes. A revised law will be given within a week to President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot for official proclamation. Jean Casimir, secretary general of the council, told a press conference the 162-article law will reconcile ``a divided nation'' by ensuring equality of rural and urban voters, guaranteeing equal chances for all candidates and providing for voter security. The United Nations and Organization of American States will provide technical and vote-verification assistance in this Caribbean nation of 5.5 million residents, he said. Haiti is one of the poorest countries in the Western Hemisphere, with an annual per capita income of about $330. Many Haitians doubt credible elections can be held this year due to an upsurge in violent crime that began with the installation of the nine-member Electoral Council on May 2. Haiti's last attempt to hold independent elections, on Nov. 29, 1987, was aborted when thugs supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters at polling stations. Last week's attack on the Council of State, which governs alongside Pascal-Trouillot, cast further doubt on plans for general elections, which some politicians had said would be held in September. Two human rights organizations said this week that ``the military continues to function without any control of civilian authority.'' A visiting delegation from the Americas Watch and the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees, both based in New York, stated: ``The dangerous combination of massacres in the countryside, arbitrary criminal violence in Port-au-Prince and now the direct attack on the Council of State threatens to transform future elections into a mere voting formality rather than a manifestation of the will of the people.'' Jean-Robert Sabalat, president of the governing council, told reporters Friday the army had ensured the security of council members. Earlier in the week he had complained of the lack of police protection. Since the ouster of President Jean-Claude Duvalier in 1986, Haiti has been ruled by five successive governments. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's caretaker government, subject to council veto power, was established on March 13, after a popular uprising toppled dictator Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril.

DOC.HEAD: Search for Other Solar Systems Still Likely for Hamstrung Observatory
With AM-Hubble Trouble, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle fleet is grounded. The Hubble Space Telescope is crippled. But, hey, how about some good news: the observatory still may search for other solar systems that might harbor alien life. ``It's entirely possible we can still do that,'' despite a flaw that prevents proper focusing of the telescope's mirrors, said Jim Westphal, principal scientist in charge of research using the Hubble's main camera. ``We should know a week from now.'' ``If this is true, it is both welcome news and an indication that science can progress even while the big parts of the Hubble program and the space program in general are down,'' said Louis Friedman, executive director of The Planetary Society space exploration advocacy group. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced Friday it was grounding the nation's space shuttle fleet because a hydrogen leak was discovered in a second shuttle. Two days earlier, the agency said an apparent error in manufacturing one of the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope's mirrors left them unable to focus light correctly. Three of the telescope's five instruments will be able to do 50 percent to 75 percent of their planned studies. But the main camera _ the wide-field and planetary camera _ will be of little use until shuttle astronauts make repairs in 1993, said Ed Weiler, a top NASA scientist. The faint-object camera will be able to conduct about half its planned research, he said Thursday. Westphal said later, however, that the wide-field camera still may be able to carry out plans to study six to eight nearby stars for several years to see if they wobble _ a sign they are being tugged by gravity from orbiting planets. For that purpose ``we don't really care how sharp the image is'' because the telescope simply must accurately determine the star's position relative to stars around it, Westphal said by phone from Maryland, where he was helping NASA officials deal with the Hubble's troubles. ``If lots of stars have planets, then the chances that some of those planets might have life on them is better, and ultimately the chance there might be intelligent life somewhere is greater,'' he said. The Hubble couldn't detect life on other planets even if it worked perfectly, but Westphal said that by finding planets, it could bring scientists one step closer to ``the answer to one of the most interesting of all questions: is there anybody else out there.'' The search potentially has ``enormous implications for understanding our evolution and the evolution of planetary systems, ultimately leading one day to learning whether there are inhabitable planets around other stars,'' Friedman said. ``The key question here is whether life is unique.'' During the past decade, astronomers found indirect evidence that more than three dozen stars seem to be surrounded either by flattened disks of dust _ possibly young solar systems in the process or forming planets _ or by planet-like objects known as brown dwarfs. The stars Westphal hopes the telescope can observe are much closer and are considered ``nearby,'' or within 10 light years of Earth. That's almost 60 trillion miles. Trying to see a Jupiter-size planet orbiting a nearby star often has been compared to a person trying to see a speck of dust miles away when that speck is sitting next to a 1,000-watt light bulb. Despite the focusing problem, the Hubble's main camera still should be able to search for planets outside our solar system five times more effectively than any telescope on Earth, Westphal said. Test photographs show about 85 percent of the light that enters the camera ``is not properly focused, but about 15 percent is where it belongs, and makes a nice little sharp image,'' he explained. ``So we anticipate that we can probably use that little sharp core to watch for stars to wobble.''

DOC.HEAD: Milwaukee City Council Censures Embattled Alderman
LaserPhoto MI1
DOC.TEXT: City Council on Friday censured an alderman who was accused of fabricating a poisoned sausage scare and has threatened to terrorize the city with a black militant group he formed. The council's symbolic action, approved 11-3, rebukes Alderman Michael R. McGee for his past statements and asks him to promote ``harmony and understanding'' in the city. McGee, 40, who earlier this week resigned his council committee posts over the sausage incident, wore the black fatigue uniform of his Black Panther Militia to the meeting, which he called a ``lynching.'' ``This hearing means nothing to me whatsoever. Whoever votes for this, I could care less,'' he said during a speech from the floor. ``It just confirms my statements of how racist this city is.'' The censure was urged after McGee reported June 22 he received an anonymous phone call from a militant underground group claiming that products of Usinger's Famous Sausage Inc. had been injected with rat poison. The warning forced Usinger's to recall 80,000 pounds of meat from 150 stores. An inspection by the company found none of the meat was tainted. Usinger's and other downtown companies along Third Street have opposed McGee's proposal to rename all of street for the late civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. Segments of the street are already named for King. Mayor John O. Norquist and others alleged McGee fabricated the scare to gain media attention. The mayor called the alderman a ``demented fool'' and said the sausage scare was a ``hoax.'' McGee has said he will sue Norquist for slander. But during Friday's meeting, he withdrew a motion asking the council to censure Norquist and other aldermen for their statements against him. Earlier this year, McGee started the Black Panther Militia, which he says will use terrorist strikes beginning in 1995 if conditions in Milwaukee's inner city _ including segregation, unemployment, crime and teen-age pregnancy _ don't improve. McGee, one of three blacks on the 16-member council, has repeatedly cited studies showing Milwaukee is one of the worst U.S. cities in terms of teen-age pregnancy and black neighborhood isolation. He says his militia has about 500 members, including many young street gang members. The censure vote was the first in Milwaukee history, City Clerk Ronald D. Leonhardt said. Norquist on Friday said the censure, saying McGee should have been punished ``for his reckless calls for violence against his community.'' McGee did not vote. One of the other blacks on the council voted against censure; the other was not present. One of the three alderman to oppose the censure, John Kalwitz, said McGee had not been given due process and the censure would not help poor residents in McGee's district. ``No amount of censure or reprimand, condemnation or denouncement will change the stark reality of Alderman McGee's and others assessment of the social and economic conditions we find in the city of Milwaukee,'' Kalwitz said.

DOC.HEAD: Teens Plead Guilty to Studds Beating
DOC.TEXT: Two suburban teen-agers said Friday they were so drunk on a recent night out that they couldn't find their parked car and decided, for no reason, to beat up a pedestrian: Rep. Gerry Studds of Massachusetts. James L. Byrne and Thomas E. Carter Jr., both 19, pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court to a misdemeanor charge of assault on a member of Congress stemming from the June 7 beating of the Democratic congressman. The attack took place shortly after midnight as Studds was walking home alone from a dinner party at a friend's house. ``We were pretty intoxicated. We were looking for the car. I guess we were pretty frustrated,'' Carter told Magistrate Patrick Attridge. ``I took the first swing. Jimmy (Byrne) followed after that.'' Byrne's attorney, Michael McCarthy, described their inebriation more bluntly. ``They were drunk as skunks,'' he said. Studds was punched in the face, knocked to the ground and kicked, according to prosecutors and witnesses. He suffered bruises and lacerations to the face and body but was not hospitalized. Byrne and Carter face a maximum possible sentence of one year in jail and a $100,000 fine. Sentencing was set for Sept. 7. ``You just picked him out of the blue?'' Attridge asked. Both answered yes. They said they had no idea Studds was a congressman and found out only after the arrest. Both live in suburban Maryland.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For the second time in 1{ years, fire roared over the hills near Carol Kemp's home. And for the second time, her home was spared. ``We've been extremely fortunate, just very fortunate,'' Ms. Kemp said Wednesday after a brush fire devastated part of this Los Angeles suburb. Ms. Kemp's home was first threatened in the Dec. 8, 1988, blaze that scorched 350 acres and again Wednesday when a blaze marched through the hilly community, destroying expensive houses. Kemp was at work when she got word of the latest fire. She arrived home to find smoke and flames engulfing houses, and turned on a sprinkler system to douse the hillside around her house. ``There was tremendous smoke _ at times it blotted out the sun,'' Kemp said. ``My personal feeling, once it looked like we were going to be all right, was for my neighbors,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress OKs Coins for Mount Rushmore Facelift
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Friday gave final congressional approval for the government to mint commemorative coins next year to finance a face lift of Mount Rushmore. By voice vote, the Senate approved legislation that calls for U.S. Mint to strike a series of gold, silver and other coins honoring the national memorial's 50th anniversary. The bill now goes to President Bush for his signature. The U.S. Mint supported the Rushmore bill after Congress whittled down a long list of commemorative coins proposed by members. Supporters expect sales of the coins to raise $35 million, which will be split equally between the Mount Rushmore Memorial Society and the U.S. Treasury. The society plans to use the money for repairing the stone carvings and renovating the visitors center at the base of the mountain. Extreme temperatures in the Black Hills of South Dakota have caused cracks in the sculpted faces as the rock expands and contracts. The most serious of the cracks runs across George Washington's face. The Mint will issue a half million $5 gold coins, 2.5 million silver dollars and the same number of nickle-copper half-dollar pieces. There will be a $35 surcharge on the gold coin and surcharges of $7 on the silver dollar and $1 on the half dollar.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Racism Bill Adopted; Survey Assesses Europe's Bigotry
DOC.TEXT: In a move widely believed aimed at right-wing leader Jean-Marie Le Pen, the National Assembly approved a strict anti-racism law Friday that would bar anyone convicted of promoting racism from holding elected office for five years. The law also would require news media that report racist statements to give targeted groups the right to respond, and it classifies as a crime the propagation of ``revisionist'' history questioning the existence or extent of the Holocaust. The bill now goes before the Senate, which refused to consider an earlier version. But the assembly has the power to enact it into law if the Senate rejects it a second time. In France, the debate about racism has been closely linked with debate over immigration. It took another twist last month after the discovery of desecrated graves in a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras, southern France. Le Pen, leader of the far-right National Front, has advocated deportation of North African immigrants and called the Nazi gas chambers ``a detail'' of history. His party and the mainstream center-right parties have accused the Socialists of failing to control immigration. The Socialists have accused Le Pen's party of creating a climate of racial animosity. But the government has bowed to public opinion by proposing tighter curbs on immigration and shelving a plan to give immigrants voting rights in local elections. Under the racism bill, anyone convicted of practicing or promoting racial discrimination could be barred from holding any elected office or government job for five years. The bill passed on a 308-265 vote, supported unanimously by the governing Socialist Party and the Communist Party and opposed unanimously by centrist and conservative lawmakers. Le Figaro, a leading conservative newspaper, denounced the bill as an infringement on freedom of the press and freedom of opinion. ``Faced with this proposition, the infinite silence of practically all jurists, and practically all historians, is frightening,'' Le Figaro said. Le Pen has also called the proposed law undemocratic. He was charged with racial defamation Thursday for a remark about ``international Jewry'' in a newspaper interview. Le Pen said he was being prosecuted for one sentence in an interview published by the daily newspaper Present in August 1989. He said that ``international Jewry plays a non-negligible role in creating an anti-national spirit.'' Meanwhile, Liberation, a left-of-center daily, said Friday that France ranks as the No. 1 offender in a survey of Western European racism to be published next month by a European Parliament inquiry commission. Trailing France, in order, were Britain, Italy, Belgium and West Germany, Liberation said. Among European community members, racism was least prevalent in Ireland, but that was likely due to the minimal presence of immigrants from outside Europe, the newspaper said. Germans and Belgians were the most likely to describe themselves as racist, the report's author, Glyn Ford, was quoted as saying, ``but the violence and racial hatred in these two countries is nothing compared to the level in France, Britain and Italy.'' Quoting Ford, a British member of the Europarliament's Socialist group, Liberation said France had recorded 20 racist murders since 1986. ``Too often, the penalties imposed or steps taken against these killers were so light that immigrants felt there was no justice for them,'' Ford was quoted as saying. According to Liberation, the upcoming report expresses concern about far-right sympathizers in the French police who may have colluded with perpetrators of racist attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Passport Bill Passes Crucial Step in House of Lords
DOC.TEXT: A controversial bill that could allow tens of thousands of Hong Kong residents to enter Britain when the colony comes under Chinese rule in 1997 passed its most important legislative hurdle in the House of Lords on Friday. The British Nationality bill, approved 15 days ago by the elected House of Commons, had a second reading in the unelected upper chamber of Parliament. It will now go through the House of Lords committee stage.
