The second reading is traditionally the most important stage for a bill in the House of Lords, because that is the point at which it is most likely to get killed. The Lords can approve bills, amend them with the Commons' approval or reject proposed legislation. The Chinese government's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy students in Beijing in June 1989 led many of Hong Kong's nearly 6 million people to worry about what might happen to them when they come under China's rule. But when the possibility was raised in London of granting British residence to the 3.25 million people in Hong Kong entitled to British passports, there was a revolt by some members of the governing Conservative Party. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd has said he wants key people to remain in Hong Kong after the handover and the best way to do that is to give them the security of knowing they have a British passport if they dislike the realities of Communist rule. Under the bill, 50,000 Hong Kong residents and their households would be selected on a point system from a wide variety of fields to receive British passports. Estimates have been made that the new law could give the right of settlement to a total of 225,000 people. During the Lord's second reading, Dr. John Habgood, the Archbishop of York, said he had recently visited Hong Kong and found that church congregations had dropped by 30 percent because citizens were leaving the colony. ``We did not find very much trust in the British intentions,'' Habgood said. ``It was sad to find the word `betrayal' used over and over again.'' Habgood said fears of a mass exodus to Britain were groundless because many Hong Kong residents found British society too restricted. ``Most people are not interested in coming here. They don't particularly like Britain. If they had to live elsewhere they would rather go to Australia, Canada or the United States,'' Habgood said, adding that he supported the bill as it represented the most that was ``politically possible.'' Liberal Democrat Lord Bonham-Carter called for other countries to grant Hong Kong residents the right of abode. ``I believe that we should also appeal to our partners in the United States and the Commonwealth to join us in providing an insurance policy,'' he said. An opposition Labor Party member, Lord Mishcon, said he realized Britain could not grant the right of abode to all of Hong Kong's 6 million citizens but the government should do more to guarantee democracy. ``We must use all the pressure we can to get agreement to it by China's government,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: VA Patient Mistakenly Receives AIDS Victim's Blood
DOC.TEXT: A mix-up of two patients with the same last name caused the wrong man to receive the AIDS-infected blood of the other, hospital officials said. ``This is an absolute tragedy. We are devastated by this,'' said Dr. Darwin Palmer, chief of infectious diseases at Veterans Administration Medical Center. The error was discovered within an hour, he said. ``If this patient, who is very ill, lives long enough, he will unfortunately have a good chance of developing the AIDS virus infection,'' Palmer said. The hospital immediately notified the patient about the error Wednesday and offered him high-dose antiviral therapy, including the drug AZT, in an effort to stave off infection, Palmer said. The hospital said it would not release either man's identity or name the ailment the wrongly injected man suffered from. The male patients had recently undergone a rare blood test within 24 hours of each other, Palmer said. The blood test, an Indium White Blood Cell Scan, uses a radioactive tracer to find sources of infection. Blood samples are taken and treated with the chemical indium, then returned to the patient to see where the trace element shows up in the body. Usually a patient's name, identification number and armband are checked and the patient is questioned about the test before injection, Palmer said. ``I have to assume they did all these things, but they didn't look closely enough,'' said Palmer, also a professor at the University of New Mexico School of Medicine. The question of liability remains undetermined, but it appeared several people were involved in the mistake, Palmer said. ``We are investigating very hard to see where the slip-up occurred, to see it doesn't occur again,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Parliament Votes for 100-Day Independence Moratorium
DOC.TEXT: The Lithuanian parliament on Friday agreed to a 100-day moratorium on its declaration of independence in an exchange for an end to the economic blockade ordered by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Lithuania's president, Vytautas Landsbergis, said he expects the 10-week-old blockade by the Kremlin on all supplies of oil and most natural gas to the breakaway republic to be lifted on Saturday. Further negotiations between Gorbachev and Lithuanian leaders over the status of this Baltic republic of 3.8 million residents are to continue under Friday's compromise. Asked if he was happy with the result of the long debate, Landsbergis told reporters: ``No, it's too complicated.'' Earlier in the day, he backed off his reservations about accepting a compromise to endorse the moratorium. The 100-day moratorium, passed by a vote of 69-35, will take effect at the start of negotiations with Moscow. Landsbergis would not say how soon those talks could begin. Supporters said the deal allows Soviet President Gorbachev to save face while giving Lithuania its freedom. Top Lithuanian officials said in two face-to-face meetings with Landsbergis this week that Gorbachev gave up his demands Lithuania completely rescind the March 11 declaration of independence and return to the Soviet Union fold, subject to the complex Soviet secession law. Gorbachev's willingness to work out a deal with the Lithuanians comes just days before a critical Communist Party Congress, where there may be a challenge to his party leadership by traditionalists. The moratorium will cover only the declaration of independence itself, and none of the laws passed since then. Legislator Jonas Tamulis said the moratorium will have little effect because its provisions are repeated in the subsequent legislation. Soviet officials have not commented on Lithuanian reports about details of the agreement, but Lithuania's leadership assured deputies the main elements had been approved by Gorbachev. Landsbergis said in answer to deputies' questions that Gorbachev made it clear his only demand was a moratorium on the declaration itself. The final wording of the resolution was not significantly different from the draft presented to Gorbachev on Wednesday night. Lithuanian deputy Audrius Rudys warned parliament to act before the congress, because ``conservatives are on the attack.'' ``We may be at that historic point in time where we could decide the whole future of Lithuania,'' Rudys said. ``We need to think what would happen if another person came instead of Gorbachev? Would he be better disposed toward Lithuania? What if it's Polozkov?'' Communist Party conservative Ivan K. Polozkov was elected leader of the huge Russian republic's Communist Party two weeks ago. The Russian republic is the largest and most populous of the Soviet Union's 15 republics. The Soviets in mid-April began blocking all oil and most natural gas shipments. Authorities also cut off supplies of sugar, fish, coffee, tea, and dried and citrus fruit, Lithuanians officials said. About 50,000 of the estimated 1.1 million workers in Lithuania lost their jobs due to the shortages of fuel and raw materials. Despite the damage done to Lithuania's economy by the embargo, it is in evidence only slightly in the capital city of Lithuania. Many workers are still earning vacation pay, heat is unnecessary in summer, and a thriving black market is providing plenty of gasoline for private cars at five times the official price. Because of this, many Lithuanians opposed the moratorium. ``I think we lost,'' said Alexandra Vasiliauskiene, a retiree who was demonstrating against the moratorium outside parliament. ``The blockade will not be lifted.'' Another demonstrator, Ona Butkiene, 58, burst into tears when she heard the parliament's decision. ``The communists have won,'' she said. Several opponents of the resolution said they feared they were being tricked. Legislator Klemas Inta said if the Kremlin has not removed the blockade by Monday, he will demand the resolution be rescinded. Parliament was sharply divided on the issue of trusting Gorbachev to follow through on the deal. Opponents delayed the vote by arguing over minute wording changes. Some wanted to see what direction the Communist Party Congress in Moscow would take before they voted. Many legislators gave their approval only after Landsbergis dropped his own long-standing doubts shortly before the vote. ``Two years ago, we chose the peaceful route to independence, the route of negotiations,'' Landsbergis told parliament. ``Now the condition for negotiations is a moratorium.'' The resolution adopted by the parliament suspends ``legal actions flowing from this act,'' but it made clear other decisions adopted after the declaration will remain in force. That includes replacement of the Soviet Constitution with a Lithuanian document. The resolution also says the Lithuanian parliament can prolong or cancel the moratorium. It says the moratorium will expire automatically if parliament is unable to fulfill its duties. That was a reference to some legislators' fears that the compromise offer would give Soviet authorities an opening to replace the legislature. Lithuania and its Baltic neighbors Latvia and Estonia were independent from Moscow between the two world wars, but were absorbed back into the Soviet Union by Josef Stalin in 1940.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoners Bolster Firefighting Forces
With AM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,200 inmates who live by a brutal code of each man for himself in prison stood together Friday as trained firefighters against Southern California blazes that had killed one of them. Despite the danger, the inmates say they prefer the job over the alternative. ``It's better than doing time behind the wall. You eat better; it's less violent. There are better surroundings,'' said inmate firefighter William R. Marcott. On Wednesday, 16 inmates were overrun by a wildfire in Riverside County. Victor F. Ferrara, 22, serving time for assault with a deadly weapon, died Thursday night at a San Bernardino hospital, said state prison spokesman Tip Kindel. Four remain hospitalized, one in critical condition. In Arizona, a blaze Tuesday killed five inmate firefighters and a supervisor. ``Hearing about the others makes you wonder. It scares you. Getting killed crosses your mind, especially when you go on a big-campaign fire,'' said Marcott, 30, who is serving time at Green Valley Conservation Camp near Sacramento for assault with a deadly weapon. Marcott fought a Los Padres National Forest fire last year during which an inmate firefighter was killed, the first fatality in the California inmate firefighting program since it began in 1946. The state prison system and the state Department of Forestry and Fire Protection jointly operate the program. ``It's one of the most highly praised programs. It gives inmates the chance to pay something back to the community,'' said Department of Corrections spokeswoman Christine May. The inmates also benefit ``by developing an esprit de corps that they've never had before, except maybe in gangs,'' said Lt. D.M. Reynolds, a program spokesman. ``They become a team. It teaches them the work ethic.'' The 1,200 inmates on the fire lines Friday are among 3,700 who are housed at 40 conservation camps throughout the state, where they do other manual labor when not fighting fires. About 300 of the inmates are women who work in segregated crews. ``It's a less structured environment,'' May said. ``We call the camps prisons without walls.'' The inmates in the camp program, about half of them volunteers, are screened to be sure they are physically fit and not likely to flee, and are given four weeks of classroom and field training. Most have 30 months or less to serve on their sentences, and receive one day off their terms for each day they work. They also earn $1 an hour for battling fires. Supervised by unarmed state firefighters, they can spend days or weeks on the fire lines, working in 12- or 24-hour shifts with hand tools, back pumps, and chain saws. ``You hike in miles on foot sometimes and once you're there, it's a lot of work with hand tools,'' said Marcott. ``Sometimes you're far away from the fire and other times you're right there at the flames.''

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Arabs Claims Kinship With Mandela's Cause
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Samir Odeh waved his makeshift green, black and white Palestinian flag and praised Nelson Mandela after the African National Congress leader's rally at Tiger Stadium. ``ANC, PLO. Fight apartheid, don't let go,'' Odeh and friends chanted as the sell-out crowd of 49,000 left the stadium Thursday night. Hundreds of pro-Palestinians stood at their seats, clenched fists thrust skyward in salute to Mandela. Many carried posters of Mandela embracing Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat. Racial segregation in South Africa and life in the Israeli-occupied territories are parallel, oppressive, situations, said members of the Detroit-area's 250,000 Arab-American community. Arab-Americans worked alongside black leaders for Mandela's 17-hour visit to Detroit. They sold and bought rally tickets, picked youngsters to meet with Mandela's wife, Winnie, during a children's reception, and felt the same pride of recognition as Detroit's 750,000 blacks. ``Arab-Americans feel the fight in South Africa is their fight,'' said Ismael Ahmed, director of the Arab Community Center for Economic and Social Services. ``He could have just spoken about the African cause, but he's upheld the struggle for Palestine,'' Ahmed said. ``Six of every 10 Arabs here have lived here less than 10 years. It's not theory here. Apartheid-like activities are very real to these people.'' Mandela, who was released in February after serving 27{ years of a life sentence in South Africa for sabotage, never mentioned Palestine during his Detroit stop. Earlier during his U.S. tour, he praised Arafat, Libya's Moammar Gadhafi and Cuban leader Fidel Castro for their support of the African National Congress. Those comments wiped none of the shine from Mandela's Detroit appearances as they had earlier Thursday in Miami. Mayors of the Miami area's major cities refused to greet Mandela upon his arrival at Miami International Airport. About 300 anti-Mandela demonstrators, mostly Cuban-Americans, waved placards blasting him outside the Miami Beach Convention Center, where Mandela addressed union leaders. Ahmed said that while there are differences between the black and Arab communities in Detroit, they have worked to overcome them. In Miami, Dade County Commissioner Charles Dusseau said there is less tolerance between blacks and Cuban-Americans. ``There is a lot of friction in Miami because the Cubans and the blacks are fighting for the same piece of the pie,'' said Terry Ahwal, a board member of the American-Arab Anti Discrimination Committee in Dearborn. Though Mandela never mentioned the snub he received in Miami, he praised the love-in Detroit held for him. ``I don't think we could have gotten a better reception than we did,'' Mandela said Friday before departing for Los Angeles. ``It has been warm and flattering. In fact, we could stay here and not go back to South Africa.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Asks Soviets To Help Avert Famine In Angola
DOC.TEXT: The United States has asked the Soviet Union to support a plan for delivering food to starving people in Angola, the State Department said Friday. State Department officials went to the Soviet Embassy on Thursday to discuss possible plans for famine relief in Angola and the Soviets promised to respond, said department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. The discussion follows letters written earlier this week by Jonas Savimbi, the leader of Angola's U.S.-armed rebels, to President Bush and to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev asking them to consider a joint food airlift. Savimbi also proposed that ``corridors of peace'' be created in Angola, through which international relief convoys could pass with guarantees of safe passage from rebel and government forces. The State Department praised the idea of the relief corridors and urged the Soviet-backed government of Angola to agree. ``We have raised this (Savimbi's) proposal with the Soviets, noting that it would facilitate the delivery of humanitarian relief to civilians of both sides of the Angolan conflict,'' Tutwiler said. The International Committee of the Red Cross estimates that some 250,000 Angolans are in immediate danger of starvation due to recent droughts and the 15-year civil war. Angola's government says more than 1.5 million are at risk. The United States and the Soviet Union agreed recently on a joint food airlift for Ethiopia, with U.S. food to be flown on Soviet planes.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Plans to Pay Compensation to Arab Victims of Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Israel plans to pay about $38,000 in compensation to each family of the seven Palestinians slain near Tel Aviv by an Israeli gunman, a defense ministry spokesman said Friday. The decision was made ``as a special gesture in light of the tragic circumstances'' surrounding last month's attack, said Danny Naveh, a spokesman for Defense Minister Moshe Arens. On May 20, Ami Popper, an Israeli civilian, opened fire on a group of Arab workers from the occupied Gaza Strip, killing seven and wounding 10. The slayings, near the Tel Aviv suburb of Rishon Letzion, inflamed tensions throughout the occupied lands and touched off a wave of rioting in which seven other Palestinians were shot and killed by soldiers. Popper, who was dishonorably discharged from the army last year, said he acted out of anger over a disappointing love affair. He also claimed he was sexually abused by an Arab as a child. Psychiatrists have determined Popper is fit to stand trial. Naveh, reached by telephone, said Israel would pay a total of $270,000 or about $38,000 to each victim's family. Also Friday, a Palestinian inmate was found slain in a prison in southern Israel, apparently after he was accused of collaborating with Israeli authorities, a prison spokeswoman said. An Arab inmate confessed to the murder, said Prison Services spokeswoman Shulamit Meiri. The slain prisoner was identified as Daoud Annah Abu Khader, 39, of east Jerusalem. He was serving a two-year term on charges of illegal organizing and was due to be released in November. Israel radio said Khader was strangled to death. Khader's death raised to 227 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs on suspicion of collaborating with Israel since the start of the 30-month uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 722 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or settlers, and 45 Israelis have been slain by Arabs during the uprising. In the Gaza Strip town of Khan Yunis, Mohammed Salim Shurab, 12, arrived dead at Nasser Hospital Thursday night after sustaining an electric shock while trying to hang an outlawed Palestinian flag on an electricity pole, Arab reports said. Uprising activists called a commercial strike Friday to mark Shurab's death, saying he was ``a martyr who died in struggle'' against Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Book Suggests Shamir Wanted Man Who Spilled Atomic Secrets Killed
DOC.TEXT: A chapter of a book published Friday in a newspaper suggests Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir wanted Mordechai Vanunu killed before the former nuclear technician could spill Israel's atomic secrets to the world. Shamir's spokesman, Avi Pazner, dismissed the report as ``pure gossip.'' A chapter of the book, ``Three-Way Treason,'' by American journalist Louis Toscano, was printed Friday by the daily newspaper Maariv. The book has not been published. Vanunu, 36, a former technician at the Dimona nuclear reactor, is serving an 18-year jail sentence for treason and espionage for his revelations, which were published by the Sunday Times of London in 1986. His case has been championed worldwide by human rights groups, who consider him a hero for the anti-nuclear cause. Vanunu's information suggested Israel had stockpiled 100 nuclear weapons and could produce neutron and hydrogen bombs _ giving it the world's sixth-largest nuclear arsenal. Israel has always declined to answer directly allegations of its nuclear capacity. Most of the proceedings against Vanunu in Israel have been shrouded in secrecy, including details of how he was brought to Israel for trial. Maariv and its editors noted that Toscano, who once worked in Israel for the United Press International news agency, was denied interviews with Vanunu and all the Israeli leaders connected to the affair. The newspaper said Toscano based his story on discussions with sources in the United States, England, Israel, Great Britain, Italy and Australia. According to Toscano's book, Israel's secret Mossad intelligence agency tracked Vanunu in Sydney, Australia before he sold his story to the British paper. Vanunu had moved to Sydney after being laid off from the reactor in October 1985. While in Australia he made contacts with journalists. The book says Israeli officials initially were skeptical about intelligence reports coming from Sydney concerning Vanunu's contacts, doubting he could do much damage because he had been only a low-level technician. But after obtaining some of the photographs Vanunu was trying to sell, the Mossad dispatched a seven-member squad to follow him in Australia, the excerpt says. The prime minister of Israel at the time, Shimon Peres of the left-of-center Labor Party, learned of Vanunu's attempts to sell information to the Times in Sydney in August 1986, the book says. Peres promptly convened with Shamir, then foreign minister, and the defense minister, Yitzhak Rabin, to discuss the case, it adds. Shamir was quoted as voicing dismay that Vanunu had been allowed to work at the reactor despite his alleged past links with far left-wing groups. Peres is quoted as responding:``But let's concentrate on what we do now.'' Shamir is said to have shrugged and replied ``It is clear, it isn't it?'' and after a moment of silence, Peres said, ``No, we don't kill Jews.'' ``Vanunu is a traitor,'' Shamir allegedly insisted, ``and there is only one way to handle this type of person.'' Rabin is quoted as saying it was ``too late'' for such a solution. The excerpt says the Israeli leaders later decided to ``let Vanunu tell his story to the world,'' and take action later, despite Shamir's objections. The excerpt indicates the decision may have been taken in view of an Israeli intelligence report in 1985 that suggested Israel should inform neighboring Arab countries of its nuclear potential as a deterrent.

DOC.HEAD: Feds In Maine Confiscate Photograph, Call it Pornography
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents. Birgit in 6th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A photograph of a nude father and son is pornographic, say federal officials who seized the print and want to destroy it, even though it has been widely exhibited and published as a work of art. ``It's not an obscene photograph _ not even close,'' said Robert E. Mittel, a Portland lawyer who is fighting to get the picture by photographer Walter Chappell out of the hands of authorities. U.S. Attorney Richard S. Cohen has a different view of the black and white print, called ``Father and son,'' which was taken in the early 1960s and shows Chappell in the nude with an erect penis as he holds his infant son. ``I'm not an artist,'' Cohen said Friday. ``I'm generally very liberal on these things, but I do personally find it quite offensive.'' The signed picture of Chappell, who lives in El Rito, N.M., was seized this winter by U.S. Customs officials at the Canadian border crossing in Houlton. Two friends of the owner, Birgit Lenderink, were trying to take the picture from Ms. Lenderink's old home in Canada to her current home at a meditation center in Vermont. Mittel would not say where his client lives because she does not want to be bothered by reporters. Once the picture was confiscated, Assistant U.S. Attorney Jonathan Chapman filed an action titled ``United States of America v. One Obscene Photograph.'' Chapman is seeking permanent federal custody of the print so it can be destroyed. ``The defendant is a mounted and framed photograph which is a lascivious exhibition of adult male genitals touching a young child,'' says Chapman's filing, which calls the picture ``obscene and immoral.'' At the Museum of Modern Art in New York, a curator of photography found the federal action disturbing. ``This picture has been around for nearly 30 years,'' Peter Galassi said by telephone. ``In the photographic world, it's a picture that's been known for a long time, along with other pictures by Chappell. It's very surprising to see all of a sudden that the U.S. government is upset by this picture.'' The print has appeared in a coffee-table picture book of American nude photography published by Harper & Row, Mittel and Galassi said. ``Harper & Row does not publish pornography,'' Mittel said. No court dates have been set. Cohen's office has sent a copy of the photograph to the obscenity unit at the Justice Department to see what officials there think. Chappell did not immediately return a phone message that The Associated Press left on his home answering machine in El Rito, a farming community about 40 miles north of Santa Fe. The artist did not want to discuss the controversy but might issue a statement in a few days, said art dealer Andrew Smith, who handles much of Chappell's work. The case in Maine comes as other issues of expression have stirred nationwide controversy, including flag burning, the lyrics of the rap group 2 Live Crew and the sexually explicit photographs of the late Robert Mapplethorpe. Mapplethorpe's work often has been cited in the debate over proposed restrictions on the types of art that can receive federal funding. Proving the Chappell picture is obscene might be difficult in Maine, where voters in 1986 rejected a statewide obscenity ordinance, observers say. ``It's an interesting case in light of the other issues that are looming nationally in terms of censorship and other issues affecting art grants,'' said Dick Dyer, a Maine Arts Commission spokesman who called Chappell a legitimate artist. ``He is a nationally recognized photographer,'' Dyer said. ``The idea of obscene art is really an oxymoron. If it's art, it can't be obscene.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Appeals Judge's Refusal to Halt Fatal Monkey Experiments
DOC.TEXT: A physicians group went back to court Friday seeking to block fatal government experiments on three monkeys seized in a 1981 raid on a Maryland laboratory. Meanwhile, spokesmen for a California congressman and the interim head of the National Institutes of Health said their bosses would meet July 10 to discuss the experiments. The Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine filed an appeal Friday with the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, seeking review of a lower court judge's denial of a temporary restraining order to halt the experiments. The monkeys are being cared for at Tulane University's Delta Primate Research Center in Covington, La. The physicians' group has sued the National Institutes of Health alleging scientific fraud and misconduct involving the experiments on the monkeys. The NIH said it would conduct no further experiments on the monkeys until the appeals court rules. It said until the experiments are conducted, the animals will be allowed to live unless their conditions deteriorate ``to such an extent that the researchers' ability to obtain accurate data would be compromised.'' The three monkeys are among seven remaining animals seized from a Silver Spring, Md., laboratory in 1981. They were part of a study of stroke and spinal cord injury rehabilitation financed by NIH. Researchers had cut the sensory nerves to the left arms of the animals. Unable to feel pain, the monkeys have bitten and otherwise injured their arms, sometimes severely, according to officials at Tulane, where the monkeys were moved in 1987. Researchers want to anesthetize the monkeys, remove portions of their skulls and monitor their brain responses to certain activities. The animals would be put to death while under anesthesia. Scientists want to learn whether the parts of the monkeys' brains that ordinarily would sense feeling and movement in the arms have taken over other functions. The July 10 meeting was scheduled for acting NIH director Dr. William F. Raub and Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., to discuss the experiments, spokesmen for both said. Neither knew specifics of the planned session.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges U.N. to Repeal 1975 Resolution on Zionism
DOC.TEXT: President Bush joined Congress on Friday in urging the United Nations to repeal a 1975 resolution declaring Zionism as ``a form of racism and racial discrimination.'' Bush said ``it is long overdue'' for all members of the U.N. General Assembly to renounce the resolution, which he called a ``pernicious proposition.'' The president made his comment in a written statement as he signed a joint congressional resolution urging the repeal of the U.N. statement.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Tie Hopes for '92 Win to State Victories This Year
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Party leaders on Friday tied their hopes for reclaiming the White House in 1992 to a populist economic appeal and an effort to score significant gains in crucial state races this year. Democratic leaders admit such optimism may appear unfounded given President Bush's record high popularity and the shortage of Democratic presidential candidates. Yet the Democratic state chairmen who are gathered in Portland this weekend for a two-day conference maintained that issues are breaking in ways favorable to Democrats. The dearth of Democratic presidential contenders could work to the party's favor in the long run, they say. ``The best news is we don't have people running around the country running for president,'' said Ohio Democratic Chairman James Ruvolo, president of the state chairs. ``In 1990, the action is in the states. It's not in Washington.'' Ruvolo said both parties' hopes for 1992 _ and the entire decade _ rest with winning state and local elections that will decide who benefits from the post-Census redrawing of legislative and congressional districts. Victories in major redistricting battlegrounds _ the gubernatorial races in Florida, California, Texas and the Midwest _ would give the party the local leaders and grassroots organizations needed to upset Bush in two years, he said. ``How we do in 1990 is more important than who's running for president,'' Ruvolo said, sounding a theme repeated by other state party leaders. ``If we do our job in November, the outlook for a Democratic candidate in 1992 will be that much better.'' The absence of declared Democratic presidential candidates has left the job of shaping the party's message largely to the national party apparatus. National party Chairman Ronald Brown is using this weekend's meeting to lay out an economic agenda he believes can get Democrats out from under the ``tax and spend'' label pinned on the party during the 1980s. ``It's clear to me that we're on a roll as a party,'' Brown told the state chairmen. ``When you take two issues _ the Cold War and taxes _ away from the Republican Party they don't have much to run on.'' Until clear candidates emerge, Brown is resting the party's hopes on a populist message blaming Republicans for the burgeoning savings and loan crisis and other alleged mismanagement he says has been billed to low- and middle-income voters. ``We have decided to take the gloves off on that issue,'' said Brown. He was dedicating a major speech Saturday to shaping the Democratic attack on the S&L issue. The upbeat talk was tempered by the realization that Bush's favorability ratings in polls surpass even those of Reagan. Still a party pollster maintained that Bush's support is wide but thin, and that Democrats could use the right economic message to break a dismal record in recent national campaigns. Many of the state chairmen said Bush's reversal on taxes and growing public anger at the cost of the S&L bailout have given the Democrats sudden hope for 1992. ``Bush is extremely vulnerable in '92,'' said Paul Goldman, chairman of the Virginia Democratic Party and a close adviser to Gov. Douglas Wilder, a hot prospect for the national ticket in 1992 or 1996. ``The credibility of the Republican Party on fiscal matters is rapidly eroding and the American people are taking notice.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Welcomes Benin Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: Benin Prime Minister Nicephore Soglo met on Friday with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and discussed his country's transition from Marxism-Leninism to multi-party democracy. The State Department said Baker expressed support for the reform process in the West African country. The visit is the first by a Benin prime minister to Washington in 22 years.

DOC.HEAD: 2,000 Bhopal Gas Victims Rally, Crying for Justice
LaserPhoto DEL2
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster gathered near the home of Prime Minister V.P. Singh on Friday and demanded money and medical relief. ``I want justice. I want something,'' 60-year-old Azghar Ali cried feebly, his voice lost in the crowd's shouting. The victims once again came from their central Indian hometown to demand faster economic relief and medical aid to help them fight the debilitating effects of methyl isocynate gas. The chemical leaked from a pesticide plant of Union Carbide Corp. in Bhopal on Dec. 3, 1984, killing more than 3,000 people and injuring about 20,000 others in the surrounding slums. Most of the victims were poor laborers. Ali, a sign painter, lived near the factory and was sleeping when the gas enveloped his shantytown. Today, Ali, a bundle of bones and mottled skin, cannot work because he cannot walk 100 yards without wheezing uncontrollably. He lives in a tin shed, survives on the charity of his neighbors and waits for government relief. Compensation suits against the U.S.-based multinational have been held up for six years because of litigation in Indian courts and changing government policies. The victims have received only $88 from the Indian government that was distributed immediately after the disaster. The government of Rajiv Gandhi, Singh's predecessor, reached a Supreme Court-supervised settlement with Union Carbide in February 1989 and agreed to accept $470 million as compensation for the 500,000 claimants. The government orginally sued Union Carbide for $3 billion. Several newspapers and political activists called the 1989 settlement a sellout. Subsequent petitions in the Supreme Court delayed disbursement of the money. Singh's government, which took office in December, said it will challenge the $470 million settlement and re-open the case in an effort to pin criminal responsibility on Union Carbide. Criminal charges were withdrawn when the Gandhi government accepted the $470 million settlement from the company, based in Danbury, Conn. On March 5, Singh's government said it would pay interim compensation of $12 per month to each of about 500,000 people living near the site of the gas leak. The Supreme Court later asked the government to pay an additional $44 as monthly compensation to 3,110 totally disabled people. But that has not helped Ali yet. ``The speed of disbursement is so slow that at the current pace it will take at least two years before all the victims start getting relief,'' said Abdul Jabbar Khan, who organized the protesters' train journey from Bhopal, 355 miles south of New Delhi. Khan, who has organized dozens of protest marches in Bhopal and visits to New Delhi, said only 42,000 beneficiaries have received money so far. On Friday, Khan, convener of Bhopal Gas Affected Women's Industrial Group, presented a memorandum at the prime minister's residence. The marchers were stopped a half-mile away by a police barricade. They camped on the road, waiting for Singh's reaction. ``We just hope to get something from V.P. Singh. The rest is on Allah,'' said Parveen Jahan, 25, whose only child died in infancy a few months after the gas leak. She said she suffered a miscarriage a month ago because the gas ``has made me incapable of bearing children.'' Other women rushed to Mrs. Jahan as she began sobbing silently, her tears falling on crumpled medical records of her dead baby and of her miscarried fetus.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Paramedic Rescue Team Parachutes to Boat off Peruvian Coast
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. paramedic rescue team parachuted from a military plane on Friday to treat an American yachtsman who suffered an asthma attack while sailing off Peru. Three paramedics jumped from a U.S. Air Force C-141 transport plane to the boat, 1,950 miles west of Trujillo, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said. Trujillo is a coastal city 305 miles northwest of Lima. The American, sailing in a 50-foot boat, radioed for emergency assistance on Wednesday, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The identity of the yachtsman or how many people were on the boat with him was not clear, according to the Embassy spokesman. In San Bernardino, Calif., a spokesman for Norton Air Force Base _ from where the plane left early Friday _ said the 45-year-old man was on the boat with his wife. The rescue was coordinated by the Honolulu Rescue Center, the Embassy spokesman said. The paramedics will stay on the boat until it reaches port, the Embassy spokesman said. He did not know where the boat would dock.

DOC.HEAD: South African Gov't Leader Suggests Two-Chamber Parliament
DOC.TEXT: A top government official said Friday that a post-apartheid political system might include two houses of Parliament _ one elected directly and the other weighted in favor of minorities. Constitutional Development Minister Gerrit Viljoen told government television that a new constitution could have one chamber elected by a simple one-man, one-vote system. A second chamber would give equal voting power to different groups, even though the groups may be unequal in size, Viljoen told the South African Broadcasting Corp. The second chamber could have veto power on major policy decisions, Viljoen said. He did not say if the groups would be defined along racial lines or by other means. Viljoen's comments on Friday and a speech he delivered Thursday night provided new details of the government's thinking as it prepares to negotiate a new constitution with black opposition groups. Those goals include: _ Equal voting rights for all citizens. _ A bill of rights. _ A strong, independent judiciary with well-defined powers to uphold the constitution. _ A system that does not allow minorities to ``paralyze the normal course of government.'' Viljoen said the white-led government was not wedded to any particular constitutional model. But he said any new system must prevent the 28-million black majority from dominating minorities, such as the 5 million whites and the country's nearly 4 million mixed-race and Asians. ``Experience worldwide has simply taught that proper recognition of minority interests in the context of heterogenous states is in the interest of all,'' he said late Thursday. President F.W. de Klerk has said that a simple one-person, one-vote, majority-rule system would replace white domination with black domination. He wants a constitution that allows whites and blacks to share power. However, the African National Congress and other leading anti-apartheid groups want a one-person, one-vote system with no special privileges set aside for whites or other minorities. The government and the ANC, the largest opposition group, held their first talks in May. The ANC says that before full-scale constitutional negotiations begin, the government must allow an estimated 20,000 ANC exiles to return and also release from prison about 3,000 activists convicted of politically motivated crimes. Under the current apartheid system, whites control politics and the economy. Blacks have no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Would End Covert Aid to Khmer Rouge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs Cranston comment after 3rd graf pvs, The committee's
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Intelligence Committee has voted to cut off covert U.S. aid to the non-communist alliance fighting Cambodia's Vietnam-backed regime, government sources said Friday. The action, first reported by the Wall Street Journal, reflects growing congressional concern that U.S. support is at least indirectly helping the Khmer Rouge, the strongest military force in the alliance and the party that was responsible for the slaughter of more than a million Cambodians in the 1970s. The committee's move came during a closed-door session on Thursday to draft the Central Intelligence Agency's budget for 1991. The United States has for several years provided covert military aid to the resistance, according to sources. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., said Friday he hoped to begin a public debate over U.S. policy toward Cambodia by holding hearings in his Foreign Relations East Asia subcommittee next month. ``We'll be discussing the whole U.S. policy toward Cambodia, and examine the lunacy of working with people allied with the Khmer Rouge,'' Cranston said in an interview. ``I think we have a moral imperative to be more constructive than we've been.'' But several sources said that support for the covert program is much stronger in the House than in the Senate, and that it may ultimately be preserved for another year. A surprisingly strong majority of the House voted 260 to 162 on Wednesday to continue a $7 million-a-year program of overt non-lethal aid to the non-communist resistance. The covert military program is believed to be two to three times that size. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., argued that it is in the U.S. interest to sustain the elements of the resistance that are militarily weaker, such as the faction led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk which the United States supports. And House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla., argued that it was useful to maintain even the ``figment'' that there is a political alternative to the Khmer Rouge available if peace talks can lead to elections. The provision the House approved contains a directive that the overt aid be cut off to any group ``engaged in a pattern of military cooperation and coordination designed to assist the Khmer Rouge.'' But intelligence sources said U.S. information about what actually happens inside Cambodia is sparse, primarily depending on what can be learned through the military in Thailand and through the members of ASEAN, the regional defense alliance.

DOC.HEAD: Fires State By State
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES California damage and injury estimates; ADDS Texas.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The hand of man and the forces of nature combined to create raging infernos in the West. Here is a state-by-state look at the fires and their damage:
DOC.HEAD: ARIZONA
DOC.TEXT: Lightning-ignited Tonto National Forest blaze, charred 21,000 acres and blackened portions of the Coconinno and Apache-Sitgreaves national forests above and below the Mogollon Rim. The fire burned the historic Zane Grey cabin in its spread eastward and forced hundreds from summer-home sites. Six firefighters died Tuesday while fighting the fire. A half-dozen lightning-caused fires blackened about 3,500 acres in southeastern Arizona. Those included a 1,200-acre fire about 15 miles north of Sonoita and a 1,600-acre fire in the Whetstone Mountains and roughly six miles east of the 1,200-acre fire.
DOC.HEAD: CALIFORNIA
DOC.TEXT: Hot, dry winds fanned the flames, which scorched 14,000 acres of brush in a four-county area that lies north, east and south of Los Angeles. The Santa Barbara County fire destroyed 500 homes and other buildings and charred 3,500 acres in Santa Barbara. Authorities blamed the fire on arson. In Glendale, a Los Angeles suburb, a fire that was contained after destroying or damaging 55 hillside homes Wednesday, was also arson. In El Cerrito, Riverside County, 60 miles east of Los Angeles, a fire destroyed 15 homes and closed Interstate 15. A 150-acre fire near Hemet, also in Riverside County, injured 17 firefighters, three seriously. In the Moreno Valley area of the county, fire destroyed three homes. A controlled burn that got out of hand when winds unexpectedly changed bore down on the city of Corona after destroying 12 homes and charring 2,200 acres. An arson blaze in the Carbon Canyon area of Orange County spread over 6,640 acres to the San Bernardino County community of Sleepy Hollow, where 14 homes were engulfed.
DOC.HEAD: COLORADO
DOC.TEXT: The Horsefly Fire, in heavy timber, about 30 miles southwest of Montrose and five miles north of Norwood in the Uncompaghre National Forest, swept over 1,000 acres. The Goodell Fire in Larimer County, on Sheep Mountain east of Red Feather Lakes in the Roosevelt National Forest, spread beyond 200 acres and threatened a big game winter range, but no private land or development. Like the Horsefly Fire, the Goodell was burning in rugged terrain with poor access, and high winds and heat posed a big threat to containment efforts. Twelve miles northwest of Eagle, a 15-acre blaze was burning above 9,500 feet in steep terrain.
DOC.HEAD: MONTANA
DOC.TEXT: Yellowstone National Park recorded its first forest fires of the summer, but a spokeswomen said they were small and under control. In 1988, fires charred over 700,000 acres of the 2.2-million acre park.
DOC.HEAD: UTAH
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters controlled brush fires throughout the state as weather conditions eased. A 350-acre brush fire 14 miles west of Eureka was controlled Wednesday. A 30-acre brush fire 10 miles southwest of Emery near the Fishlake National Forest also was brought under control. A 65-acre fire near the Bear River in Cache County was under control, as was a 10-acre blaze in the Lake Mountains west of Utah Lake and a fire in Sevier County.
DOC.HEAD: TEXAS
DOC.TEXT: Encroaching flames pushed firefighters back from the front lines of a blaze that spread across 3,150 acres of the Guadalupe Mountains National Park, some 50 miles east of El Paso in far western Texas. No injuries were reported. The blaze will probably burn about 5,000 acres before being brought under control, said Jim Payne, a spokesman for the Interagency Incident Command Team. Crews from California, Montana and Arizona were helping fight the fire.

DOC.HEAD: Logistics Headquarters Directing Firefighting Traffic
With AM-Fires, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Federal coordinators Friday scrambled to keep on top of the wildfires in the West. ``We've got a substantial level of activity, but we've still got lots of resources ready to go,'' Boise Interagency Fire Center spokesman Arnold Hartigan said. The center is a joint effort of the U.S. Forest Service, Bureau of Land Management, National Park Service, Bureau of Indian Affairs and National Weather Service. It monitors wildfire activity on public land nationwide and coordinates logistical support for firefighting efforts. Hartigan said about 7,600 firefighters and 3,000 support personnel worked on fire lines Friday in California, Arizona, Colorado and western Texas, near the New Mexico line. They were battling blazes sparked by arsonists and some 49,000 lightning strikes recorded throughout the West in the previous 24 hours. Hot, dry conditions were hampering efforts. But Hartigan said a wetter than normal May delayed onset of the region's fire season, and moist air moving into the Southwest held the promise of relief for fire crews over the weekend. ``We're hoping for the start of the monsoon season in Arizona and New Mexico sometimes this weekend or next week. But to the north, that increases the chance of thunderstorms with dry lightning in Colorado, Utah, Nevada and southwest Wyoming,'' he said. Hartigan said the fire season is expected to extend until October throughout most of the West, but could last until November or even early December in Southern California. ``The major problem there is urban interface, people building homes right in the trees and up into the brush and wildlands,'' he said. ``Cedar and wood-shake shingles also are a big problem, and too many people still don't clear brush away from their homes.''

DOC.HEAD: Energy Ministry Says Venezuela Not Planning to Leave OPEC
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Ministry said Friday that Venezuela has no plans to withdraw from the OPEC, a position the president of the state-run oil company has reportedly advocated. Andres Sosa Pietri, the president of the state oil company, was reported to have said OPEC quotas are hampering the development of Venezuela's oil industry. ``Venezuela has never had any intention of leaving OPEC,'' said a ministry spokesman. ``On the contrary, our aim is to strengthen it in view of increasing demand.'' With a quota of 1.94 million barrels per day, Venezuela is OPEC's fourth largest producer, following Saudi Arabia, Iran and Iraq. Friday's edition of the daily newspaper El Nacional quoted Sosa Pietri as telling top leaders of the governing Democratic Action party that OPEC quotas were ``against Venezuela's best interests.'' Oil company executives have complained that OPEC quotas restrict the expansion of Venezuela's oil industry and that Venezuela should not respect the quotas when certain OPEC members disregard them. The other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates.

DOC.HEAD: Excommunication Now Rare But Hovers Over Abortion
With AM-Abrtion-Excommunication, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Publicly imposed excommunication has become a rare penalty in Roman Catholicism, but it's considered automatic for those who unrepentantly obtain abortions. Sociological studies indicate it likely applies to hundreds of thousands of Catholics in such circumstances. It also has become a potentially explosive issue between bishops and politicians. The penalty, barring a church member from Holy Communion and benefits of other church rites and prayers, were formally imposed this month on an abortion clinic director in Corpus Christi, Texas. Such individually specific punishment is seldom decreed in the church these days. ``It certainly is not commonplace,'' said Sister Sharon Ewart, a canon law expert of the U.S. Catholic Conference in Washington, D.C. However, there was a 1986 case in Providence, R.I., in which a Planned Parenthood director was publicly named as automatically excommunicated. Other cases may seem similar, yet are different. It's a complex, variously conditioned process. Last November, San Diego Bishop Leo Maher barred from communion a pro-choice state senate candidate, Lucy Killea. But Ms. Killea, who was subsequently elected, wasn't excommunicated from other church involvement. That also is the case for an estimated 5 million to 6 million divorced and remarried Roman Catholics. Those in that category had been automatically excommunicated until a change made in 1977. At that time, U.S. bishops, with approval of the late Pope Paul VI, revoked an 1884 decree by the American bishops automatically excommunicating divorced, remarried Catholics. Although that no longer applies, such Catholics still are barred from communion unless they secure an annulment of previous marriages, or some other pastoral resolution of their cases. Current church canon law No. 1398 prescribes automatic excommunication of those who secure an abortion and do not afterward change their stance _ meaning that they repent and seek absolution. Another canon, No. 1329, provides for automatic excommunication of ``accomplices'' to abortion, that is, those who enable someone to obtain an abortion who could not have done so without their help. That canon was applied in the Corpus Christi and Providence cases, and there is considerable debate over its implications in reference to politicians who uphold laws permitting abortion. New York's Cardinal John O'Connor touched off a recent furor in saying such politicians were skirting grounds for excommunication. Persons excommunicated remain baptized church members, and except in certain severe cases traditionally invoked by the pope, may continue to attend church and associate with other members. The penalty can be lifted through confessional repentance and determination to change conduct.

DOC.HEAD: Bicycle Patrol Added in Tulsa
DOC.TEXT: Police in black shorts. Patrol vehicles that cost $710. What's going on here? Tulsa police Thursday put five officers on 21-speed, lightweight aluminum bicycles. Sgt. Jerry Isaacs said the bicycles will give officers greater mobility, especially in the parks along the Arkansas River. They will be faster than officers on foot patrol and able to go places that cars cannot. ``It's designed to bring policing closer to the streets,'' said Mayor Rodger Randle. ``We'll use the bicycles whenever possible,'' said Officer Neal Walters, who proposed the idea two months ago. ``Only driving rain and extreme cold will keep us off them.'' The officers assigned to the program have a little different uniform than do their counterparts in cars. They wear black shorts, regulation olive green shirts and bright blue helmets. Similar programs are used in Seattle and Fort Worth, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Wins Top Male Ballet Honor; Houston Ballerina Takes Female Award
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban dancer on Friday won first prize at the International Ballet Competition and the principal dancer of the Houston Ballet took the top female award. Jose Manuel Carreno of Havana, accepting the Grand Prix City of Jackson award of excellence, said it was a fitting end to two weeks of intense competition. ``I'm more nervous now than when I danced,'' said Carreno, who received a $10,000 prize. Martha Butler won the $7,000 gold medal in the senior female category and said she looked forward to getting away from dancing for a while. ``I don't feel like dancing right now,'' Butler said after the award ceremonies. ``I want to just relax and let all the pressure off. Maybe go down to Aruba and lay on the beach.'' The silver medal, for the senior male winner, with a purse of $5,000, was shared by Luis Ortigoza of Argentina and Pierre Quinn of Canada. The silver medal for senior female, went to Simona Noja of Romania. Third place bronze medals with a prize of $3,000 were awarded to Toomas Edur and Irma Nioradze, both of the Soviet Union. Fourth place bronzes, worth $2,000, went to Vladimir Malakhov of the Soviet Union and Irma Morales of Mexico. In the junior division, no male dancer won the gold or silver medals. Diana Perez of Puerto Rico won the $2,500 gold medal in the female category. The $1,500 silver medal went to Irina Dvorovenko of the Soviet Union, while $1,000 bronze medals were given to male dancer Morihiro Iwata of Japan and Lauren Gelfand of Boston. The competition, which rotates every year among Jackson, Moscow, Helsinki and Varna, Bulgaria, attracted 150 competitors this year from 20 countries, organizers said. Ben Stevenson, the artistic director of the Houston Ballet and Butler's coach, received a $1,500 special choreography award. A special award of $1,000 for achievement in choreography was given to John Alleyn. French dancer Stephanie Elizabe of France won the $500 Robert Joffrey Award of Merit.

DOC.HEAD: French Firm to Help Launch `Instant Lottery' in USSR
DOC.TEXT: A French company announced plans Friday to launch the Soviet Union's first ``instant lottery,'' hoping the lure of big prizes will sell hundreds of millions of tickets for the benefit of a charity group. The lottery is scheduled to begin by the end of July, with an initial distribution of 200 million tickets, said Georges-Robert Parisot, president of the international section of the Societe Internationale Des Jeux, the company that runs the French national lottery. He said the tickets are to be sold in the Soviet Union by the Soviet Children's Fund, which was established several years ago to look after the interests of children. The fund is officially independent, but has close ties to the government. Parisot told The Associated Press the biggest prizes in the instant lottery would be 25,000 rubles _ equivalent to $42,000 at the standard exchange rate or $4,200 at the tourist exchange rate. He said the tickets will sell for five rubles apiece _ $8.30 at the standard rate, or 83 cents at the tourist rate. Although the first order is for 200 million tickets, Parisot said he expected billions would be sold in the Soviet Union, which has a population of almost 300 million. He said 57 percent of ticket sale proceeds would be paid back in prizes, with the remainder going to the Children's Fund and administrative costs. The French company, which will print the tickets and run the lottery, will keep a percentage of the administrative costs. There has been a longstanding lottery in the Soviet Union, but the best prizes are often appliances or _ infrequently _ automobiles. An accord signed by Parisot and an official of the Soviet Children's Fund proposed the creation of a joint French-Soviet company by March 1991 to expand lottery operations in the Soviet Union and to establish a facility for printing lottery tickets in the Soviet Union by 1993. In an instant lottery, a participant learns immediately whether he or she is a winner by scratching away a covering over part of the ticket. In traditional lotteries, the ticket purchaser must await some sort of drawing to determine if he or she has the lucky number.

DOC.HEAD: Moore Says She Steered Barry Back to Topic of Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with woman scorned suggestion by Mundy; the Rev. Stallings excluded
DOC.TEXT: Rasheeda Moore testified under cross-examination Friday she repeatedly steered Marion Barry onto the subject of drugs after the mayor said he did not want to use cocaine the night he was arrested in an FBI sting operation. Moore denied a suggestion by Barry's lawyer that she trapped the mayor in the sting operation or that her motive for working with the FBI was because Barry had abandoned her for another woman. Moore broke the FBI's instructions and tried to persuade the mayor to use drugs, she admitted under a second day of questioning by defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy. Midway through the FBI videotape of the sting operation, Moore asks the mayor if he wants to use drugs. ``No, not tonight,'' Barry replies on the tape. But Moore brings the subject back to drugs repeatedly after that. ``You felt you were going beyond your mandate not to persuade, influence, coerce or beguile'' Barry into using drugs? asked Mundy. ``I did,'' said Moore. ``Why did you do that?'' asked Mundy. Moore said she got ``overcarried'' in performing her duties for the FBI that night. ``In your zeal to get Mr. Barry,'' Mundy said accusingly. ``For all you knew, he had been off drugs since May'' 1989 when Moore went to California. ``Not in my zeal,'' insisted Moore. ``I was not out to get Mr. Barry.'' ``What was your intent?'' asked Mundy. ``Working this operation'' with the FBI, replied Moore. Mundy suggested Moore had been badly treated by the mayor. Was she angry at Mr. Barry because he didn't return her calls throughout an eight-month span in 1989, Mundy asked. No, Moore said. Was she angry because the mayor was involved with another woman, Maria McCarthy, or because Barry had slapped Moore when they broke up their romantic relationship? asked Mundy. No, she wasn't, Moore insisted each time. On the videotape, Barry tells Moore at one point that ``Maria'' is interested in having sex with the mayor. Walking up to the witness stand, Mundy stood next to the former model and showed her a segment of the transcript of the recorded conversation during the Vista sting. The former model inexplicably shouts ``Oh, Maria, Maria,'' just before FBI agents and police detective crash into Moore's hotel room to arrest Barry for cocaine possession. ``If there was no vengeance on your mind'' why would Moore say such a thing? inquired Mundy. ``I have no idea,'' responded Moore, suggesting it was ``Out of nervousness.'' Had Moore been scorned? a reporter asked Mundy after the day's court session. Mundy agreed immediately and quoted the old proverb: ``Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned.'' Moore insisted that Barry repeatedly used code language about drugs in carrying on their conversation. And she said he acted on his own in buying crack cocaine from an undercover FBI agent and smoking it. ``He was comfortable, he was being himself'' during the visit, she said. Moore, the government's star witness in Barry's drug and perjury trial, testified previously that she and the mayor used drugs together ``over 100 times'' and had an intimate relationship from shortly after their 1986 meeting until mid-1988. The jury spent much of Thursday watching a videotape showing Barry arriving at Moore's hotel room last Jan. 18, eventually smoking the drug and being arrested. Mundy is pursuing an entrapment defense, contending the mayor was illegally lured to the downtown Washington hotel room that ex-model Moore was staying in as part of her cooperation with federal authorities. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about drug use. One of the possession charges stems from his arrest in the sting operation at the Vista Hotel. During the day, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson barred the Rev. George Augustus Stallings from attending the trial. Stallings, a Barry supporter, broke with the Vatican by starting his own African-American Catholic church, saying Rome has not been serving the needs of black Catholics. Mundy and the American Civil Liberties Union asked the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia to overturn Jackson's exclusion of Stallings and his Thursday order turning away Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan. Jackson said the presence of Stallings or Farrakhan could be disruptive.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Gubernatorial Candidate Names Wife As Running Mate
DOC.TEXT: For months GOP gubernatorial candidate William S. Shepard searched in vain for a running mate. So he asked his wife. He will name Lois Shepard as his lieutenant governor candidate when he files officially for the race on Monday, The Sun reported Friday. Shepard made his decision after months of being turned down by prominent Republicans unwilling to give up their current offices for what most consider to be a hopeless race to defeat incumbent Gov. William Donald Schaefer. The Sun said Shepard's decision sent state Republican leaders into a frantic effort to change his mind, suggesting that a husband-and-wife team would be regarded as frivolous. Sources said Shepard responded by threatening not to run at all. Shepard said he recognized his choice was ``a trifle hazardous,'' but added: ``I could have picked someone on the basis of form. I could have picked someone who would raise no eyebrows, but, given the importance of the job, I would rather put forth a substantive person ... Looking at Lois' candidacy on the merits, people will conclude what I have concluded.'' Mrs. Shepard has been a real estate agent in Potomac, where she and her husband live, a high school teacher, a Reagan-Bush campaign worker and chairwoman of a voters group known as Republicans Abroad. She also served as director of the Institute of Museum Services, a federal agency that awards grants to the nation's museums. She served four years until Oct. 1, 1989. Schaefer, who was greeted with the news when he returned from Europe Thursday, at first said: ``Awwww, come on.'' Then he added, ``That's very nice.''

DOC.HEAD: Sunshine Prevails But Midwest Gets Thunderstorms
DOC.TEXT: The sun shone on most of the nation Friday, while scattered thunderstorms hit the Midwest. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered from parts of Nebraska through much of Illinois and into Ohio early Friday afternoon. Thunderstorms associated with the same weather system produced heavy rain in Wisconsin and northern Illinois overnight. Showers and thunderstorms developing ahead of a warm front were over the northern Atlantic Coast states early Friday afternoon. Showers and thunderstorms were developing in southern Florida, and along the Gulf Coast. A few showers and thunderstorms pelted northern Minnesota and the Dakotas. The heaviest rainfall total for the six-hour period ending at 2 p.m. EDT was two inches at Peoria, Ill. Thunderstorms developing along a stationary front produced severe weather in the north-central United States early Friday morning. There were nearly 70 reports of large hail and damaging winds in Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Illinois and Michigan. Thunderstorms in North Dakota early Friday morning produced tennis ball- size hail southeast of Dickinson. Thunderstorms in northern Illinois early Friday morning produced about two inches of rain at Rockford and Chicago, and produced wind gusts to 58 mph at O'Hare airport. In southwestern Wisconsin, heavy rains early Friday morning caused mudslides which downed some trees, closing state Route 35.State Route 131 at Barnum was also closed due to the threat of a bridge washout. Friday morning's low for the nation was 39 degrees at Craig, Colo. and West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Proposes Compromises in Letter to Bush
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Friday he hoped his latest letter to President Bush on the peace process would ``open a new chapter'' for the Middle East, an aide to Shamir said. The letter is viewed in Israel as the right-wing government's first formal acceptance of certain proposals by Secretary of State James A. Baker III aimed at holding Israeli-Palestinian peace talks in Cairo. Sources in the Bush administration said officials are taking a close look at Shamir's letter and may set up a meeting between Baker and Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy. At issue is the future of the 1.7 million Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip that Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East War. Shamir sent the letter in response to one from President Bush inquiring about the prime minister's intentions now that he has formed a new government. The last Israeli government, headed by Shamir, collapsed in March in disagreement over whether to approve Baker's formula for Israeli-Palestinian talks. Israel has proposed holding elections for Palestinians to select negotiators for an interim peace settlement of limited self-rule. Baker's proposals were raised last year as a way to start implementation of the plan. But negotiations became mired in Israel's objection to talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization, which Israel considers a terrorist organization and Palestinians consider their legitimate representative. Pazner said Shamir's ``very lengthy'' seven-page document to Bush this week proposed a new method for choosing Palestinian negotiators acceptable to Israel. Shamir wrote ``that every Palestinian living in the territories can take part in a Palestinian delegation on a name-by-name basis,'' Pazner said. That formula is seen as a possible way to side-step Israel's objections to speaking with representatives of the PLO and Israel's refusal to allow representation for East Jerusalem Arabs. East Jerusalem was captured along with the West Bank during the 1967 war. Israel annexed East Jerusalem and declared an undivided Jerusalem its eternal capital. Shamir's proposal would apparently permit the inclusion of Palestinians who are formally registered as residents of the West Bank or Gaza Strip but who also maintain residence in Jerusalem. ``Mr. Shamir expressed today his hope that his letter and the forthcoming answers and reactions from the United States will open a new chapter in the peace process in the Middle East ... and will make possible further contacts in order to move things forward,'' Pazner said. Earlier Friday, Levy, Shamir's leading rival in the right-wing Likud bloc, took a tougher stance toward the United States, accusing Washington of trying to dictate Middle East policies to Israel. ``We really want a friendship with the U.S., but we will not overlook the potential dangers we face,'' he said in an interview with the Yediot Ahronot daily newspaper. ``We will not be good children and will not agree to let them dictate to us what to do with our lives and remind us that we are small and dependent,'' said Levy. Asked whether the annual $3 billion in U.S. aid influenced American attitudes toward Israel, Levy said he feared Americans had forgotten Israel was a valuable ally and begun to think of it as ``a parasite.''

DOC.HEAD: Mall Owners: Fame Doesn't Aways Bring Fortune
DOC.TEXT: Fame didn't bring fortune to the Stamford Town Center because the shoppers were gawkers when filming began for the movie ``Scenes From a Mall.'' ``Usually, noontime is our best time,'' said Yvette Barnard, assistant manager of CHOPS, a woman's clothing store. ``But the center court is all crowded with people watching the filming.'' ``Scenes From a Mall,'' a Touchstone Pictures film directed by Paul Mazursky and starring Woody Allen and Bette Midler, has been filming in the Town Center since June 15. The story is a bit different, however, at the Domain home furnishings store, according to manager Susan Rose. ``I have no complaints. Business is definitely up,'' Rose said. ``The people coming in here are seriously looking to buy.'' Since the shooting began, her store has risen to No. 3 in the 10-store Domain chain, Rose said. It previously hovered in mid-range. ``My feeling is, how often does this happen in Stamford? I think we should just roll with it and enjoy it,'' Rose said. Touchstone, a subsidiary of Walt Disney Studios, says filming is scheduled to finish July 6.

DOC.HEAD: Mudslides Kill 18 in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Mudslides triggered by heavy rains swept away houses in the northeastern city of Recife, killing 18 people, officials said Friday. Fire Department Lt. Gelmires Candido de Oliveira said torrential rains fell for nearly 12 hours, causing earth on hillsides to slip away and crush seven houses in Recife's poor north zone. ``The peak hour for the mudslides was 1 a.m., when most of the victims were in bed sleeping,'' Oliveira said from Recife, a coastal city of 1.3 million people 1,500 miles northeast of Rio de Janeiro. TV film footage showed the remains of one house that collapsed and buried a family of four under rubble and mud. The rain stopped early Friday. But Oliveira said the fire department continued to evacuate residents from endangered houses in high-risk areas of the city.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Demand End to Student Strike, Threaten Counter-Actions
DOC.TEXT: Farmers threatened Friday to block the capital with tractors and combines if students do not end a two-week sit-in strike, the state-run BTA news agency reported. The students are protesting allegations of election violations and have demand the removal of the head of state television. In Sofia, about 70,000 signatures have been collected to back the students' demands. At least 40 people, including teachers, parents and other supporters of the students have gone on a hunger strike outside of Parliament. The Union of Cooperative Farms said farmers would go on a five-day strike and would send combines and tractors to block all thoroughfares leading into the capital if the student protests were not ended by July 5, BTA reported. The farmers' declaration came as the leadership of the governing Socialist Party formally nominated incumbent Premier Andrei Lukanov to form a new government, BTA reported. The Socialist Party, which was formed by reform-minded former Communists, won 211 of Parliament's 400-seats in national elections earlier this month. Lukanov's nomination to form the next government was largely considered a formality.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item on Michener to CORRECT spelling of author's last name in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Author James Michener has some advice for Wyoming residents: build a wall around the state to ``keep the goons out.'' Michener, the author of ``Centennial,'' told about 100 people on Thursday the state needs to resist the temptation to corrupt its natural resources, and prevent incursions on Yellowstone or Grand Teton national parks. Michener, who spent some time in Wyoming in the 1970s researching ``Centennial,'' said steps are needed to preserve the state's natural beauty. One of his suggestions was buying a ranch and preserving it so children in 50 years will be able to see what ranch life was like. ``I said a few years ago I would build a wall around Wyoming to keep the goons out,'' he said. ``I guess I still think that.'' Michener, 83, was in Wyoming at the invitation of its first lady, Jane Sullivan, to help the state celebrate its centennial. ``We should keep this as a treasurehouse for the rest of the country,'' he said. Wyoming will become increasingly popular as a haven from the accelerating pace of life, Michener said.

DOC.HEAD: T-Shirts Seized
DOC.TEXT: Law enforcement officials Friday seized more than 350,000 allegedly counterfeit T-shirts, shorts and sweat shirts in what they called the largest crackdown on illegal merchandise in the nation. A six-week investigation dubbed ``Operation Dizzy Fox'' resulted in no arrests but thousands of Bart Simpson T-shirts, Georgetown University sweatshirts and other items were confiscated in raids that took 18 hours to carry out. District of Columbia deputy police chief Rodwell M. Catoe, U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens and several attorneys representing companies like Disney and Hard Rock Cafe, Inc. showed reporters a garageful of clothes seized from 30 street vendors and 13 other businesses in Washington. The investigation and seizures were made in cooperation with the Customs Service, the Justice Department, the Postal Service and city officials working with manufacturers and copyright owners. Stephens said a dent was made in illegal trade that takes nearly $5 million in revenue from city businesses through violation of the copyright laws. The shirts and other items in the garage would bring about $2 million on the street, sold over several months, he estimated. ``We want to put the public on notice there was going to be more criminal actions conducted throughout the country,'' said Robert Baum, an attorney representing holders of such copyrights as ``The Simpsons,'' ``Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' and ``Guess?'' The information gained in ``Operation Dizzy Fox'' will be presented to a grand jury, Stephens said. He said his investigation is targeting ``the nature of the enterprise'' and distributors rather than the vendors themselves. He said his office is focusing on possible money-laundering and interstate trafficking of goods, a charge that could result in $1 million in fines and five years in jail. Stephens said some of the largest illegal garment industries in the nation are located in New York, Los Angeles and Washington. He didn't say what he would do with all those shirts once their usefulness as evidence is over.

DOC.HEAD: 56 Nations Approve $240 Million Environmental Fund
DOC.TEXT: Representatives from 56 countries on Friday approved a $240 million environmental fund for developing nations and established a ban on chemicals that deplete the Earth's protective ozone layer by the year 2000. But many countries accused the United States of foot-dragging in negotiating changes to a 1987 Montreal Protocol, which controls the production and use of ozone-depleting chemicals. Cabinet ministers from at least 12 countries, pointing to recent scientific studies on the speed in which the ozone layer is being destroyed, urged a ban on halons and chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, by 1997. The United States, Japan and the Soviet Union insisted the deadline for such a ban be the year 2000. Delaying the ban for three years would allow the release of 11 billion more tons of chemicals into the stratosphere, environmentalists said. The 1987 protocol had called for a 50 percent cut in the chemicals by 2000. Like that protocol, Friday's actions have no penalties for violations and no enforcement powers. The new treaty bans CHCs by that year and increases the list of ``controlled'' chemicals from eight to 20. ``We believe it is necessary and possible to do better than this timetable,'' said West German Environment Minister Klaus Topfer. ``Unfortunately, three countries refused to go along.'' William Reilly, administrator for the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, said he was pleased with agreement. ``I think it was a very successful conference,'' he said. When the treaty parties meet again in 1992 they will ``see if a case can be made for accelerating the schedule,'' he said. The conference agreed to a phase-out schedule that would cut CFCs by 20 percent in 1993 and 50 percent in 1995 before the final ban. The 30-page amendment to the Montreal protocol also banned carbon tetrachloride by the end of the century and eliminated methyl chloroform by 2005. In another move, the conference approved an unprecedented $240 million fund to assist developing nations build industries that do not rely on chemicals that deplete the ozone. The fund, sponsored by developed nations, is seen by many as a model for solving other, more costly environmental problems. China and India will each receive $40 million over the next three years after they sign the protocol, which they have said they will do. Bringing those two populous countries into the treaty was considered vital. The fund will be controlled by an executive committee made up of developing and industrialized nations that will each serve three-year terms. CFCs, used in refrigeration, insulation, cleaning solvents and as aerosol propellents, rise into the stratosphere where they break down in constituent chemical parts. One of these, chlorine, destroys the thin shield of ozone that filters out harmful ultraviolet rays and helps preserve the Earth's flora. About 100 countries attended the two-week conference. Only the 56 parties to the Montreal protocol were allowed to vote on the agreement. The conference was seen as a precursor to more difficult negotiations that will take place soon on global warming and reducing the use of fossil fuels.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Grounds Shuttle Fleet Until Hydrogen Leak Problem Fixed
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th graf: ``Lenoir said,'' to CORRECT spelling Nicholson sted Nicholsen
DOC.TEXT: NASA is grounding its three space shuttles until engineers can find and fix a hydrogen leak that has now been detected in two of the winged spacecraft, the agency announced Friday. Engineers conducting a test loading of hydrogen rocket fuel into the propellant tank of space shuttle Atlantis found the second leak early Friday morning. A similar leak found on Columbia last month forced postponement of its astronomy mission. NASA spaceflight chief Bill Lenoir said Atlantis, which had been scheduled for launch in mid-July, now will be rolled back to the hangar so engineers can remove its fuel tank and try to locate the leak. Columbia's leak also was found while it was on the launch pad, just six hours before its scheduled May 30 liftoff. It, too, was rolled back to the hangar.
