Lenoir said the agency had no choice but to keep the space shuttle fleet on the ground until the problem is fixed. He designated Leonard Nicholson, deputy director of the space shuttle program at NASA headquarters in Washington, to take charge of the leak investigation. ``We can't fly until we can get hydrogen into the tank and we're not going to put hydrogen in the tank until we can do it safely and we've got a problem getting over that hump right now,'' Lenoir said in a news conference at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Lenoir said he ``would hesitate to use the word grounded'' in reference to the shuttle fleet, but he added: ``There's no question that we won't fly until we understand it (the leak), have it fixed, have tested it, verified it and we're ready.'' The NASA executive said that the leak problem could be resolved in two weeks, but that it could take longer if engineers determine a new design is needed for what is called the ``umbilical'' of the space shuttle. This is an assembly of pipes and valves that directs the flow of propellants into the tank from a ground supply and, at launch, from the tank to the shuttle engines. Crews drained liquid hydrogen from the shuttle tanks and left them open to evaporate any remaining hydrogen before a purge with inert helium to carry away any remnant. The vertical service structure was to be wrapped around the shuttle on Saturday pending further work on Monday. NASA launched space shuttle missions in February and April and was planning for six more this year. Atlantis' mid-July mission was to be a secret military flight. Columbia's mission in May was to be a 10-day flight with a cargo of astronomical instruments. That mission was postponed until August. Other flights had been set for August, October, November and December. But the hydrogen leak problem already was causing a reshuffling of the schedule and some missions seem certain to slip into next year. Lenoir said the first priority is correcting the leak to assure the safety of the space shuttles. ``If that costs us a flight, I'm sorry,'' he said. Even as engineers were searching for the shuttle leak, other NASA officials were being grilled in a Senate hearing about the focusing flaw discovered this week in the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., suggested at the hearings that NASA had not maintained a good system of quality control and was more interested in getting funds for new projects than efficiently completing projects already underway. ``NASA's eyes are bigger than its stomach,'' Gore charged. On the Hubble problem, the senator noted, ``We have been assured now for 12 years that everything was all right. We owe it to the taxpayers to find out what went wrong, how to fix it and make sure it never happens again.'' In Florida, Lenoir said that because the hydrogen leaks on Columbia and Atlantis occurred while the vehicles were being fueled on the launch pad, ``it seems likely that these are related and of a similar class.'' This puts into question the safety of the umbilical system on Discovery, the third shuttle. Discovery is scheduled to carry a science spacecraft called Ulysses into orbit in October. A delay in that mission could cause the craft to not be launched for years because its success depends upon the alignment of other planets. Ulysses is scheduled to go into a polar orbit of the sun. Robert Crippen, chief of the shuttle office at NASA, said the leaks are coming from umbilical parts that have proven reliable through 31 shuttle flights. Liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen are the propellants used in the space shuttles' main rocket engines.

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Rarity: Premier, Opposition Leader Agree to Cooperate
DOC.TEXT: In a rare show of unity, Quebec's premier and a provincial opposition leader agreed Friday to establish a non-partisan parliamentary commission to map out Quebec's political future. ``At a crucial time in its history, Quebec is united,'' Premier Robert Bourassa said following a 90-minute meeting with the head of Parti Quebecois, Jacques Parizeau. The meeting was in response to the defeat of the Meech Lake accord, which would have designated Quebec a ``distinct society.'' All 10 provinces and the federal government had to ratify the constitutional amendment by Saturday midnight but Newfoundland suspended debate on the issue and the accord expired. The accord was an attempt to gain French-speaking Quebec's signature on Canada's 1982 constitution. It had little practical impact but became a symbol of enormous importance to the 6.5 million Quebecois, who make up one-fourth of Canada's population. ``What we have done is an important first step in defining what Quebec wants _ not as far as the rest of Canada is concerned _ but what Quebec wants as far as Quebec is concerned,'' said Parizeau. The parliamentary commission will be composed of representatives of labor, business, universities, municipalities and members of political parties. The leaders of the two parties will meet with their caucuses July 10 to set guidelines for the commission, which will travel around the province to sound the opinions of Quebecois on a variety of issues that include some Quebecers' desire to secede from Canada. The leaders said they hoped the commission would begin work this fall and produce a non-binding report by the end of the year. Both leaders said it would be up to Bourassa to use the commission's recommendations as a basis for a referendum, an election or as a bargaining chip to resume negotiations with the federal government over possibly reconsideration of a special status for Quebec within Canada's federation.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Troops Kill 31 Rebels, 14 Policemen Found in Mass Grave
DOC.TEXT: Government forces killed 31 Tamil rebels in battles Friday and the bodies of 14 policemen were discovered in a mass grave, military officials said. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said two soldiers were also killed in the renewed round of fighting in Sri Lanka's seven-year-old civil war, which has engulfed the island nation's north and east, where the ethnic Tamil minority predominates. The latest deaths raise to 1,764 the number of combatants killed since fighting between Tamil guerrillas and government forces resumed June 11 after a 13-month cease-fire. An undetermined number of civilians also have died. Military officials reported several battles in the east, and said at least 18 rebels were killed in search operations conducted by the army. Also in the east, the bodies of 14 policemen who were shot to death were found Thursday, the officials disclosed Friday. The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam rebels overran a string of police stations along the eastern coast starting June 11 after a Tamil man in the port city of Batticaloa told the rebels he had been manhandled by Sinhalese police. At least 850 policemen were captured by the Tamil Tiger rebels. Officials have said at least 330 of the policemen have been killed, and the fate of the others is unknown. Government forces launched an offensive after the police stations were captured, forcing the rebels to retreat into the jungles and swamps in the east. Military officials believe the Tigers' retreat may be a tactical move to launch a protracted guerrilla war. In the north, at least 13 rebels and two soldiers were killed in a gun-battle in the district of Vavuniya, the officials said. Fighting also continued around Jaffna Fort, an army installation in the heart of rebel territory, the officials said. At least 225 policemen and soldiers have been holed up in the fort since the fighting started. Loss of the fort would be a major blow to the government, which now has only four military installations in the north under its control. In the east, authorities clamped a curfew on Batticaloa, and began house-to-house searches for rebels, residents said. A Tamil doctor, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said soldiers ordered all males aged 12 to 50 to report to military officials in the predominantly Tamil town, once a rebel stronghold. While thousands of men gathered at schools, churches, mosques and temples, the soldiers conducted house-to-house searches, said another resident, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. The Sri Lankan army and police are dominated by Sinhalese, whom the Tamils accuse of discrimination. Ethnic Sinhalese, who are mostly Buddhists, comprise 75 percent of the population, while the predominantly Hindu Tamils comprise 18 percent of the country. At least 12,700 people have been killed since the rebels took up arms in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Irving Wallace Dies of Cancer at Age 74
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to RECAST lead, UPDATE with quotes from Sidney Sheldon and Leon Uris, minor editing; picks up 13th graf, `Wallace was...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Wallace-List
LaserPhoto NY38
DOC.TEXT: Author Irving Wallace, who borrowed plot lines from current events to create such best-selling novels as ``The Prize'' and ``The Plot,'' died Friday. He was 74. Wallace died of pancreatic cancer shortly before 1 p.m., said Ron Wise, spokesman for Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. ``His wife and son and daughter were at his side at the time of death,'' said Wise. Wallace entered Cedars-Sinai on Tuesday in serious condition. Funeral arrangements were pending. Born in Chicago in 1916, Wallace also edited many non-fiction books, including ``The People's Almanac'' and ``The Book of Lists.'' Before his fame as a novelist was established with ``The Chapman Report'' in 1960, he wrote screenplays for ``The West Point Story'' in 1950; ``Desert Legion,'' ``Gun Fury,'' ``Meet Me at the Fair'' and ``Split Second'' with William Bowers in 1953; and ``Bad for Each Other'' with Horace McCoy in 1954. Fellow author Sidney Sheldon said he and Wallace were close friends for three decades. He described Wallace as ``a very good writer. His books were very well researched.'' ``He was very unusual in that he was not at all competitive, which most writers are. He enjoyed other people's success. He was a very warm man, a very generous man, and he's going to be missed by his family and many friends,'' Sheldon said. Considered by The Saturday Review magazine to be one of the five most widely read authors in the world, Wallace has sold more than 194 million copies of his 33 books. Some of those titles are: ``The Fabulous Originals'' (his first published book), 1953; ``The Sins of Philip Fleming,'' (his first novel), 1959; ``The Fabulous Showman: The Life and Times of P.T. Barnum,'' 1959; ``The Man,'' 1964; ``The Plot,'' 1967; ``The Word,'' 1972; ``The Pigeon Project,'' 1979; ``The Seventh Secret,'' 1986; and ``The Celestial Bed,'' 1987. Wallace lived in a 17-room home on 1{ acres in Brentwood, which was the setting for the Briars, the fictional community featured in ``The Chapman Report.'' Wallace's wife and children are also authors of note. His wife, Sylvia, has helped write four books, including ``Empress'' and ``The Intimate Sex Lives of Famous People.'' Son David Wallace, who writes under the name David Wallechinsky, has written 12 non-fiction books, including the best seller ``Midterm Report,'' a follow-up to the best seller ``What Really Happened to the Class of '65.'' Daughter Amy, a psychic healer as well as an author, worked with her mother on ``The Intimate Sex Lives of Famous People'' and recently wrote ``The Prodigy.'' ``He was ... obviously a very, very clever man, very soft-spoken. He seemed very much of a family man, bringing his whole family in the writing,'' said novelist Leon Uris. ``He seemed to be a very content man. I didn't feel any great surges of anger coming from him, and obviously he was a marvelous storyteller.'' Uris said he fell out of touch with Wallace 10 years or so ago, but remembered sharing his early success. ``I met Irving in 1953 when we were both at Warner Bros. I had written `Battle Cry,' and he had written some ... literary books that weren't going anywhere. He came out with `The Chapman Report' just shortly after that, so we both ran a victory lap at the same time in Hollywood and kissed the studios goodbye.'' Wallace was particularly proud of his independence as an author. ``The big motivation for me was the desire to be independent, to get up when you want, write what you want and work where you want,'' he said in a 1984 interview with The Associated Press. He said he'd had only two bosses in his life _ Ronald Reagan, his superior officer in the Army's wartime propaganda film unit, and Jack Warner, who hired him to write movie scripts for Warner Bros. Writing was the job that provided him with his independence, but Wallace said he loved his work. ``Writing is what I enjoy. I'm a person of ideas and I like to spread them around.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Has Fun in the Rain
DOC.TEXT: President Bush didn't let foul weather interfere with his vacation Friday. The president went boating, golfing and fishing in a chill rain as he began a five-day stay in at his oceanside Kennebunkport home. Bush escaped a heat wave in Washington with temperatures in the high 90s only to find leaden skies and temperatures in the 60s. Shortly after arriving at their oceanfront home at Walker's Point, Bush and his wife Barbara went out with national security adviser Brent Scowcroft in the president's speedboat Fidelity in pursuit of mackerel. Bush later told reporters at the Cape Arundel Golf Club that Scowcroft had bagged a ``boat record'' mackerel, while Mrs. Bush came close twice and the president himself had one get away. ``Barbara had two on, right up to the boat. I had one. Didn't get 'em in,'' Bush said after he teed off in the rain with Scowcroft and club pro Ken Raynor. As he sped off down the fairway in a golf cart, Bush said, ``We're going for a time record today for 18.'' But Bush had to settle for a time around the course of 2 hours, 11 minutes, about 20 minutes slower than his speediest outing on the same course last summer. It was after 7 p.m. as he rode back to the clubhouse, light was fading but Bush still wasn't finished. He and Raynor strolled down from the modest green clapboard clubhouse and tried their hand at fishing in the Kennebunk River. While Raynor put on a display of fly fishing, Bush spin-cast his line for striped bass. Both men came up empty-handed, the president finally calling it a day after 15 minutes when his line snagged in a tree branch.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Approves Funds For WIC Program
DOC.TEXT: Some 250,000 pregnant women and infants can remain on a federal nutrition program aimed at giving a healthy start in life for babies from poor homes under a bill approved on Friday by the Senate. ``This is about children,'' said Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger. ``Every dollar we spend on the WIC program saves $3 later in health care costs.'' The Senate voice vote after midnight followed House approval of a bill to boost from 1 percent to 3 percent the amount states can borrow against next year's allocation for the Special Supplemental Feeding Program or Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC. That sends the bill to the president. The 3 percent borrowing capacity would infuse $66 million into the program, which provides food or vouchers that can be used to buy food at local stores. The states administer the program using federal funds, but unexpectedly high food prices absorbed so much of the $2.1 billion appropriated nationwide for this year that some states started cutting all but the most desperate participants from the program. The National Association of WIC Directors said earlier this week that 250,000 women and children would be eliminated by the end of the fiscal year, Sept. 30, if $72 million were not added to this year's appropriation. ``This is probably the most important bill we've passed in the last few months because it directly goes to feeding women and children and it directly helps people who need help,'' said Hall. About 4.5 million women and children are enrolled in the program. Hall said that's only half the number that could be getting help under the law's eligibilty requirements if the government were willing to provide the money. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., sponsor of the Senate bill, said WIC ``is universally acclaimed as one of our nation's most successful nutrition programs.''

DOC.HEAD: Polish Police Enter Ministry to End Sit-In By Farmers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with protest march, Walesa returning to Poland. Pickup 13th graf pvs, `The Solidarity...'
DOC.TEXT: Police used a sledgehammer to break into the Agriculture Ministry on Friday and ended a 3-day-old sit-in by hundreds of farmers demanding guaranteed prices for their products. Officers broke open a locked ministry door shortly before 7:30 p.m. Scores of police carrying truncheons then entered the building in central Warsaw. Several hundred farmers walking in a peaceful procession came out about a half-hour after police entered. They carried a protest banner and were singing the patriotic-religious hymn ``Rota'' and the national anthem. A few demonstrators had to be pulled out, but police said in general they did not encounter resistance. They said there were no arrests or injuries. The protesters later marched about a half-mile to a statue of pre-World War II peasant leader Wincenty Witos before dispersing. The government said in a communique that it resorted to force only after efforts to persuade the farmers to leave of their own volition failed. Earlier in the day, the estimated 600 protesters agreed to allow ministry employees to enter the building. But the government steadfastly refused to negotiate with the farmers as long as they remained inside. ``This form of protest ... is violating elementary principles of order in the country,'' a government communique said. The farmers are demanding minimum price guarantees for their products as shelter from the government's economic reform program, which is turning Poland's centrally controlled socialist economy into a market-driven system. They occupied the government Wednesday after a march through Warsaw and closed the building to employees Thursday. Agricultural Minister Czeslaw Janicki and his deputies were permitted inside Friday morning as the workers waited outside. Two dozen police vehicles then surrounded the building. The farmers, who clustered in several ministry conference rooms, said they would not conduct talks until the police were removed. But they appeared divided over whether to agree to admit the workers, and reversed their decision several times before allowing them in at mid-afternoon. Curious spectators, sometimes breaking into debate, waited outside the entrance to the block-square ministry. Signs hung outside proclaimed, ``There is no freedom without justice'' and ``We will never abandon the soil of our roots.'' Solidarity leader Lech Walesa returned to Poland from Vienna on Friday and said he would be available if asked to help resolve the conflict. The Solidarity leader's personal appeal won suspensions of two other challenges to the reform program _ a strike by railway workers that disrupted transport across northwest Poland in May, and a blockade of the main Warsaw-Gdansk highway by dairy farmers in mid-June. The economic reform program cut most subsidies, lifted price controls, let interest rates rise to reflect the level of inflation, and opened the economy to private ventures. It has led to price increases of up to 1,000 percent in a year, leading to a drop in consumption. There is also a glut of food donations from Western nations, which rushed to offer support to the new Solidarity-led government. Nearly half of Poland's 2.5 million private farms are plots of about 12 acres or less, and farmers say they have neither the time nor the transport to seek competitive markets for their products. Poland's leaders have repeatedly refused demands for special treatment by various sectors of the economy, saying that yielding once would produce a torrent of requests from other groups. The government compares demands for minimum farm prices to the system of subsidies that the Communist regime used to pay farmers and keep consumer prices well below the actual cost of production.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped American Miner Released in Ecuador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD comment from U.S. Embassy; CLARIFIES Felix's post. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Colombian guerrillas Friday afternoon freed Scott Heimdal, the American gold miner who was kidnapped in Ecuador two months ago, a government spokesman said. Heimdal, who had been held in the Colombian jungle across the border from Ecuador, was turned over to Ecuadoran authorities on the San Miguel River, said Luis Felix, vice-minister of the Interior. The river, 110 miles northwest of Quito, runs along the border between the two countries. Heimdal, 27, of Peoria, Ill., appeared in good health, Felix said. The prospector arrived in Quito on a government airplane at 5:30 p.m. (6:30 p.m. EDT) and was examined by doctors, he said. Felix said the kidnappers, who had been demanding $612,000 for Heimdal's release, settled for the $60,000 in Colombian pesos. Heimdal's parents had raised the $60,000, mostly in community donations from Peoria residents, to ransom their son. Late Friday, Patricia Norman, the U.S. Embassy press attache said Heimdal was ``with his family here in Quito, with his mother and father.'' Norman said the family was in seclusion at an undisclosed site in this capital city 9,000 feet high in the Andes mountains. According to Norman, the Heimdals had no immediate plans to leave Quito. ``This situation that was a cause for public worry has ended happily, thanks to the collaboration of Heimdal's family and the national police,'' Felix said. In Peoria, Heimdal's sister, Linda, said she was overjoyed by the news. ``I can't believe it, I just can't believe it,'' she said, unable to hold back tears and laughter. She said she learned of her brother's release after the State Department telephoned her aunt in Rochelle, Ill., with the news. Heimdal's parents, Roy and Marge, flew to Quito last week to take charge of negotiations for their son's release. They said they wouldn't leave the South American nation until he was freed. Heimdal was in charge of starting up dredging operations for IMINCO, a gold mining company. He was abducted on April 27 as he left the company's camp in a dugout canoe to return to Quito. In the attack, 100 miles northeast of Quito, the guerrillas shot and killed the captain of the boat and wounded one passenger. A second passenger was kidnapped along with Heimdal and was later released with the ransom demand. Felix said Heimdal had been held ``in a densely jungled area cut off from the outside world and full of guerrilla groups and drug traffickers.'' Wednesday, the government ordered IMINCO to suspend its operations, the company's owner, Jeffrey Fino, said. Fino, also an American, said work had stopped at the mine after Heimdal was kidnapped.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Defends New Tax Stance in Comparing Himself to Lincoln
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 29th graf, bgng: Bush did xxx to CORRECT that Emancipation Proclamation took effect one month after Lincoln's message to Congress.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he knew he would be skewered for flip-flopping on tax increases but, comparing himself to Abraham Lincoln, declared ``I'm thinking anew'' for the good of the country. Bush said he had changed course on the politically explosive issue to break a deadlock in deficit-reduction talks with the Democratic-controlled Congress. ``Look, I knew I'd catch some flak on this decision,'' said Bush, who has been harshly criticized by many Republicans for abandoning the ``read-my-lips, no-new-taxes'' slogan that helped him win the presidency. ``I've got to do what I think is right and then I'll ask the people for support,'' Bush said. Justifying his change, the president said the economy was slower and the deficit now was worse than ``any of us visualized'' when he made his pledge two years ago. However, the Congressional Budget Office estimated in March 1988 that the fiscal 1991 deficit would be $159 billion _ very close to what the administration now says is the case. Bush made his comments at a news conference before departing for a long holiday weekend at Kennebunkport, Maine, and trips to London and Houston for two summit meetings with Western allies. His last piece of business was to veto landmark legislation guaranteeing workers up to 12 weeks of annual, unpaid leave for childbirth, adoption or family illness. ``I strongly object ... to the federal government mandating leave policies for America's employers and work force,'' Bush said. Questions about his reversal on taxes dominated Bush's news conference, but he also emphasized his opposition to giving cash aid to Moscow to bail out the sickly Soviet economy. ``It is hard for the American people to say, `Why put X-billions of dollars of money into the Soviet economy when it's not reformed, when they're spending 18 percent of their gross national product on military and when they're spending an estimated $5 billion in Cuba,''' Bush said. ``Some of our allies might not be as concerned about that last point as we are,'' Bush added. He also said he was reviewing a letter from Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir proposing severe restrictions on which Palestinians Jerusalem would negotiate with. ``I'm concerned about a deadlock in the peace process,'' he said. ``There's got to be discussion with the Palestinians.'' Bush suspended an 18-month-old dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization last week until the PLO condemns a failed terrorist raid on an Israeli beach. Bush also made a determined defense of his son, Neil, the target of a conflict-of-interest investigation by federal regulators in the collapse of a Colorado savings and loan. ``I have _ what dad wouldn't _ full confidence in the integrity and honor of my son. And I will stay out of anything to do with the investigation but this is a fine young man,'' the president said. While many Republicans roasted Bush for his decision on taxes, Democrats hailed him as a statesman. ``He's starting to act like a president,'' Rep. Daniel Rostenkowski, D-Ill., and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said after Bush's news conference. Sen. Jim Sasser, D-Tenn. and chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, objected to Bush comparing himself with Lincoln. ``That would be an overstatement in my judgment,'' Sasser said. Bush was asked by reporters if his reversal on taxes would damage his credibility. ``No, not in the long run,'' Bush said. Acknowledging the heat he has taken for his decision, Bush said, ``I think that the arrows have been flying _ front, back, sideways _ but that's what I get paid for. ... ``We've got a very important national problem and I think the president owes the people his judgment at the moment he has to address that problem,'' Bush said. ``And that's exactly what I'm trying to do.'' In light of his change, Bush said he could understand why voters might charge that he had never intended to keep his no-new-taxes promises. ``I think it's wrong but I can understand it. I'm presented with new facts. ``I'm doing like Lincoln did _ think anew. And I'm thinking anew,'' he said. Bush did not elaborate on his reference to Lincoln, but was apparently referring to Lincoln's second message to Congress, on Dec. 1, 1862, one month before the Emancipation Proclamation took effect. Emphasizing the need to free the slaves and keep the Union intact, Lincoln said, ``As our case is new, so we must think anew and act anew. ... And then we shall save our country.'' Bush also likened himself to former President Reagan, who after winning major tax cuts in 1981, had to go back to Congress the next year for the largest tax increases ever. He said Reagan ``did what was right. And so I think that we're on the right track.'' ``If I had control of this Congress, both houses, we might not even be talking about this today,'' he said. Without a deficit-reduction agreement, Bush said, automatic spending cuts totaling $100 billion could take effect Oct. 1, with ``draconian'' reductions in defense and domestic programs such as student loans. Bush's declaration earlier this week that ``tax revenue increases'' were an essential element of any deficit-reduction package was an important impetus for the budget negotiations with Congress. The negotiators met again Friday and searched for savings in Pentagon spending but reached no agreements. The president's statement directly contradicted his 1988 speech in accepting the Republican presidential nomination. Bush said then: ``And I'm the one who will not raise taxes. ... My opponent won't rule out raising taxes. But I will. ``And the Congress will push me to raise taxes, and I'll say no, and they'll push, and I'll say no, and they'll push again. And I'll say to them: `Read my lips. No new taxes.'''

DOC.HEAD: `Falsettoland,' A Musical by William Finn, Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: It has taken William Finn nearly a decade to complete his musical trilogy about Marvin, a sexual sad sack who, when we last saw him nine years ago, had left an angry wife and a confused young son for a male lover. But judging from the show that has found its way onto the tiny stage of off-Broadway's Playwrights Horizons, the wait has been worth it. The new 80-minute musical, which opened Thursday, is called ``Falsettoland,'' and it's a compelling, hugely entertaining piece of contemporary musical theater directed with energy and wit by James Lapine. But ``Falsettoland'' is something more, too, darker and deeper than ``In Trousers'' and ``March of the Falsettos,'' the first two Marvin musicals. This final installment of Finn's tale about modern Manhattan life deals, among other things, with death and more specifically, AIDS. And Finn, with the help of the ever-resourceful Lapine, has pulled off the balancing act between satire and seriousness brilliantly. The characters are much the same group Finn brought to life in ``March of the Falsettos.'' The musical begins in 1981 where ``March of the Falsettos'' ended. There's Marvin, still as indecisive as ever, equivocating over his relationship with Whizzer, that lover of yesteryear. There's Trina, Marvin's embittered ex-wife, and their son, Jason, who has problems trying to accept his father's sexual preferences. And there's Mendel, Marvin's psychiatrist, a man who had eventually married Trina in ``March of the Falsettos.'' Talk about confusing relationships. Finn has added two more characters _ Marvin's next-door neighbors, two lesbians. One is a doctor, the other a caterer of kosher cuisine, both occupations, it turns out, of increasing importance as the plot unfolds. The story revolves around Jason's bar mitzvah, or rather his unwillingness to have a bar mitzvah, and his parents' squabbling over the celebration. Intertwined with their arguments is Whizzer's illness, a fact Finn faces unflinchingly. As in the other two musicals, Marvin stands at the center of ``Falsettoland.'' In ``March of the Falsettos,'' Marvin grew up _ or at least tried to. In ``Falsettoland,'' he goes a step further, accepting life and death. His philosophy is anchored in one of Finn's more poignant lyrics, ```We laugh. We fumble. We take it day by day. What more can I say.'' It turns out Finn has a lot to say. And some of it is very funny. He has captured perfectly the frenzied, self-centered neuroses of New Yorkers at work and play. And without being didactic, he deftly condenses, as well as personalizes, the history of AIDS in New York. There are somber moments in the musical, but they are never ponderous. Finn's gift for melody overflows, enhanced by Michael Starobin's evocative orchestrations. The composer jams some 17 numbers into the short musical, which is mostly all sung. Finn's lyrics are appropriate, too, sometimes surprisingly simple but affecting, and at other times sassy and sophisticated. As Marvin, Michael Rupert, who also appeared in ``March of the Falsettos,'' turns nebbish into charming, not an easy task. Rupert's Marvin is a sympathetic, appealing character, instead of just a nerd. Faith Prince handles the role of the exasperated ex-wife with skill, a woman who could come off as the villain of the musical, but instead earns our admiration as someone trying to ``keep sane while the rules keep changing.'' Chip Zien, as the psychiatrist, serves as the evening's voice of reason and common sense. He actually is the one person attuned to everyone's problems. Stephen Bogardus, who has the show's best voice, is fine as Whizzer, and Danny Gerard is surprisingly unaffected as the troubled, but precocious Jason. Heather MacRae and Janet Metz offer distinctive portrayals as the solicitous next-door neighbors. Playwrights Horizons, long a champion of new plays, is on something of a roll with musicals. Its last production, ``Once on This Island,'' was the best musical of last season. That show moves to Broadway next October. And Stephen Sondheim's new musical, ``Assassins,'' opens at Playwrights in November. Meanwhile, its audiences will have much to savor in Finn's fascinating ``Falsettoland.''

Sometimes plays can fool you. Just give them time. Donald Margulies' work in ``What's Wrong With This Picture?'' is a case in point. Just when you think his comedy, now on view at off-Broadway's Jewish Repertory Theater, will be trapped forever in terminal television sitcom-land, the plot careens into something quirky, original and very funny. The evening begins after a funeral for Shirley, a Brooklyn housewife who has choked to death on Chinese food. There are your standard Jewish family members and your standard Jewish family jokes. Grandma complains, grandpa forgets and husband and son feel guilty about the dearly departed. But Shirley refuses to stay dead, and neither does the play. It blossoms into a tantalizing tale of trying to hold onto the past. Stephen Mailer is exemplary as the surly but not unsympathetic son. Michael Lombard, as the despairing husband, plays up the guilt as if he were a violin virtuoso and Lauren Klein is tough but warm-hearted as the practical wife back from the beyond. ``What's Wrong With This Picture?'' is an oddball, entertaining excursion through some very familiar territory.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: New grafs 2 and 8: ``The Treasury,'' with Treasury Department inspector general investigating allegation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday expressed confidence in his son Neil's integrity, but promised not to interfere with regulators who are investigating the son's role in the collapse of a Colorado savings and loan. Meanwhile, the Office of Thrift Supervision on Friday asked the inspector general of the Treasury Department to look into allegations that a Washington official ordered a delay in the seizure of the S&L, thrift office spokesman William Fulwider said. At a White House news conference, Bush said he had ``full confidence in the integrity and honor'' of his 34-year-old son. He sympathized with his predicament, describing him as ``probably the most sensitive of the four boys, maybe the second-most sensitive.'' ``It's not been easy for him. ... But he's a good kid. ... He's held his head up,'' the president said. At the same time, Bush promised not to interfere with regulators, who are examining conflict-of-interest allegations concerning the younger Bush. Neil Bush served on the board of directors of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver from 1985 to 1988. The institution, which collapsed at a cost of $1 billion to taxpayers, made loans _ which were not repaid _ to several of Neil Bush's business partners. ``I will stay out of anything to do with the investigation, but this is a fine young man,'' the president said. The Treasury Department is investigating allegations made by a former regulator in a June 19 hearing of the House Banking Committee. Kermit Mowbray, former president of the Federal Home Loan Bank in Topeka, Kans., told the panel he received a call from Washington in October 1988 ordering him to delay the seizure of Silverado. He did not say who made the call. The thrift was seized in December 1988, after the November presidential election. Bush was questioned about his son after citing the escalating cost of the S&L crisis as a key reason for his willingness to accept a tax increase as part of a deficit reduction package in fiscal 1991. ``I'm convinced that if he's done something wrong, the system will so state. If he hasn't, I hope it's fair enough to say, `Hey, the boy did nothing wrong,''' Bush said. ``... The system is going to work, whether it's the president's son or somebody else.'' The president also challenged ``those that allege misconduct ... to speak up and say what it is.'' However, the thrift office has so far refused to release its specific charges against Neil Bush. Timothy Ryan, director of the office, said earlier this week that he intends to issue a policy within a week or two outlining the circumstances under which the agency will release charges against an individual before they are settled. Ryan also said he will make any decisions on the Neil Bush case independent of the administration.

DOC.HEAD: Tears, Laughter Greet News Scott Heimdal Free
With AM-Equador-Kidnapping
DOC.TEXT: Tears, screams and laughter filled the home of Roy and Marge Heimdal on Friday as news reached Peoria that Scott Heimdal had been freed by South American kidnappers after two months in captivity. ``I can't believe it,'' shrieked Heimdal's sister, Linda Heimdal. ``This just blows me out of the water.'' She broke the happy news to her 21-year-old sister, Angie, as they embraced in the doorway of the modest rented home in a middle-class neighborhood of this Illinois River city. ``Oh my God,'' Angie Heimdal said, stunned by the news. ``What's going on?'' The sisters shared a long embrace, wiped away tears and tried to let the information sink in. They talked of joining their parents in Quito, Ecuador, and alternated between laughter and crying. ``I feel great,'' Linda said through tears of joy. ``We were told the negotiations were taking a good turn. But we never expected this. I just can't believe it. I'm so happy I can hardly stand it. It's wonderful.'' The family's plea for help in raising money for Heimdal's ransom generated more than $60,000 in less than four days. Money continues to pour in from around the country, along with cards and phone calls from well-wishers. Angie Heimdal said she was surprised her brother had been released so quickly. ``I can't wait to see him,'' she said. ``I want to hit him and hug him. It's going to be weird to see him again.'' Scott Heimdal, who was abducted April 27, was in seclusion with his parents in Quito, Ecuador, the U.S. Embassy there said. Neither sister has seen their 27-year-old brother in 18 months; he last visited their Peoria home for an extended Christmas vacation. At the time, he stayed in Peoria for about three months, returning to his work operating a river dredge for the International Mining Co., at a remote spot in northern Ecuador near the Colombia border. Angie Heimdal, a student at a local community college, recalls staying up late with her brother, watching television and mainly hanging around with him while he completed paperwork that allowed his return to Ecuador. Linda Heimdal, a fifth-grade school teacher from St. Clair, Mo., last saw her brother on Super Bowl Sunday 1989. Both sisters talked fondly about their daredevil brother, who raced motorcycles, loved to camp and fish as a Boy Scout and dabbled in karate among other exotic interests before a stint in the Army. Both said they hoped Scott could be home July 5 for his birthday. ``We'll have a heckuva party,'' Linda Heimdal said.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Gives Imprisoned IRA Member Right to Asylum Hearing
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on Friday allowed an imprisoned member of the Irish Republican Army to reapply for asylum in the United States to avoid deportation to Northern Ireland. Joseph Doherty, 35, has been imprisoned in New York for seven years. He faces a life sentence in Northern Ireland for the 1980 slaying of a British Army officer and for a prison escape. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned a June 1989 ruling by U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh denying Doherty an asylum hearing. The decision gives Doherty the chance to try to prove his crimes were political, that he faces severe persecution in Northern Ireland and should be granted refuge in the United States. ``He is entitled to a hearing on his claim for political asylum and he may well be entitled to political asylum,'' said Doherty's attorney, Mary Pike. ``Mr. Doherty is not going anywhere anytime soon, certainly not to the United Kingdom.'' Deborah Corley, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney's office in New York, said the government was reviewing the decision and had no immediate comment. Immigration laws allow political asylum if a foreigner can demonstrate a ``well-founded fear of persecution'' on political, religious, racial or social grounds. Withholding deportation, a separate action from asylum, is mandatory if a person can show his life would be threatened in the other country. Doherty fled to New York in 1982 after several years on the run in Ireland. He was arrested by the FBI in 1983, and the British government requested his extradition. A federal judge barred extradition in 1984 because Doherty's crimes were political. Doherty has admitted that he took part in killing the army officer, but said he did so for political reasons. Doherty has won decisions before two federal appeals courts, two federal judges, an immigration judge and three immigration appeals courts. But the immigration court decisions were overturned by then-Attorney General Edwin Meese III and Thornburgh. The appeals court said the Justice Department intervention apparently was the first on grounds that asylum or deportation would endanger U.S. foreign policy interests. The three-member appeals court ruled that Thornburgh ``exceeded his discretion'' in denying Doherty's claim to asylum. Doherty in September 1986 asked to be deported to the Republic of Ireland, where he faced a 10-year prison sentence rather than life in prison in Northern Ireland. The request was granted by a U.S. immigration judge and upheld by an immigration appeals board despite objections by the Justice Department. But Meese in December 1988 overturned the request to be deported to Ireland. The Federal Board of Immigration Appeals subsequently allowed Doherty to apply for asylum, but not to change his designated country for deportation. The appeals court Friday also upheld Meese's action, but that ruling has less impact since Doherty withdrew his request to be deported to Ireland in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Striptease Nightclub Makes Fashions Show Debut
DOC.TEXT: The Crazy Horse Saloon, Paris's most celebrated striptease nightclub, seems an unlikely venue for a fashion show. But its first parade of swimwear and bodystockings was a hot success. The styles may not set the fashion world on fire, but the strippers won over the audience when they showed off the new ``Crazy Horse'' line Tuesday night to the beat of country-rock music. On display were 38 bathing suits and ``bodies'' (as the French call bodystockings) by Nicole Olivier, a Lyon-based lingerie manufacturing firm. Strippers with stage names such as Akie Masterpiece and Vanity Obelisk modeled revealing swimsuits, including one ``monokini'' baring the bosom. Others were decorated with sequins and ball-fringes, had daring cut-outs, or trailed suggestive metal ``tails.'' Nicole Olivier, formerly known for lingerie, has 300 outlets throughout the world, according to spokeswoman Arlette Colomb. ``Then our marketing department came up with this Crazy Horse idea to boost our sales,'' said Ms. Colomb. ``So we set up a franchise with the nightclub.'' One of the world's most famous nude cabarets, the Crazy Horse has built a reputation for high-class entertainment during 39 years of existence. ``I'm delighted with the swimsuits and the association,'' said Crazy Horse owner, Alain Bernardin, who founded the club in 1951 on the posh Avenue George V. ``The original was truly saloon-style,'' recalled Bernardin. He also garnered ideas from a visit to Canada, where he heard about an Indian called Crazy Horse and admired spiffy red-coated Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Genial ``mounties'' still preside at the Crazy Horse front door. Bernardin gradually increased his showbiz techniques with sophisticated lighting, attractive women and top choreographers, and lured dancers from the Paris Opera to prance on his stage. By the mid-1970s, the show was so popular that Bernardin converted the saloon into a conventional theater with red carpeting and comfortable seats. ``We like to consider our show a form of art,'' said Bernardin, who recently married one of his former star dancers, Lova Moor. Commercially, the Crazy Horse is far from crazy. Last year it sold 225,000 tickets, ranging in price from about $75 to $120 or more, depending on seating and choice of drinks. The Crazy Horse sells T-shirts and other souvenirs. And now the risque new swimwear can be bought in stores around the world at about $120 a suit or bodystocking.

DOC.HEAD: Tucker to be Nominated
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate Joyce Elaine Tucker, an Illinois state human rights official, to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the White House said Friday. If confirmed, she would serve the remainder of the term of former EEOC Chairman Clarence Thomas, whom Bush has named to the federal appellate bench. Mrs. Tucker is director of the Illinois Department of Human Rights in Chicago. The EEOC is charged with monitoring discrimination in the workplace.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Dissident Likely to Move to United States, Officials Say
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 6th graf, ``Meanwhile, it,'' to incorporate Nixon material from a0707 AM-Fang-Nixon
DOC.TEXT: China's most famous dissident, Fang Lizhi, likely will move to the United States after a transition period in England to appease Chinese authorities, U.S. officials said Friday. The officials also said China's decision to let Fang and his wife leave the country after a year-long standoff reflects a victory for moderates within China's leadership. Fang was allowed to leave China last Sunday after spending one year as a fugitive with his wife at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. He went to England, where he will be a visiting fellow at Cambridge University. U.S. officials have declined to discuss any detail of the agreement they helped arrange between Fang and Chinese authorities for the astrophysicist's departure. Fang's decision to go to England was his own and there was no pressure on him to choose England over the United States, said one official. But the official, speaking on condition he not be named, said Fang's choice of England ``likely made it easier for the Chinese'' to let Fang go, given the ``enmity'' they felt toward the United States for granting refuge to the Fangs. Meanwhile, it was learned that Richard Nixon twice pressed Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, last October and in April, to release Fang as a gesture of goodwill, according to documents made available to The Associated Press on Friday. Fang was wanted by Chinese authorities in connection with his alleged role in fomenting pro-democracy demonstrations last year that culminated in a sweeping crackdown which left thousands dead or imprisoned. The physicist's son, Fang Zhe, will be leaving China within days to come to the United States, said the official. Fang apparently insisted on assurances that his son, an undergraduate at Beijing University, be allowed to leave the country. Fang's other son is a student at Wayne State University in Detroit. Fang has a six-month permit to stay in England, which could be extended if he wished, the U.S. official said. ``But Fang will probably feel more comfortable here,'' with two sons in the United States and the many friends he has here, said the official. U.S. officials say they see some evidence that the decision to let Fang leave was the result of a struggle within China's leadership which was won by more moderate officials. Hardliners within the leadership had argued that sanctions by Japan and the West to protest the Chinese crackdown would soon be lifted and would not affect the country's economy, said one U.S. official. The hardliners' position appears to have been undermined largely by a deterioration in China's economic performance. The CIA reported to Congress this past week that China was in the worst economic slump of a decade, with rampant urban unemployment, a drop in foreign investment and a $1 billion decline in tourism revenue as a result of the crackdown. Fang's release appeared timed to reach out to the seven major industrialized countries, whose leaders will be meeting in Houston, Texas, on July 9 for their annual summit. Japan is expected to propose an easing of the sanctions against China. In addition, the U.S. Congress is debating whether to approve an extension of trade benefits to China ordered by President Bush last month. Despite misgivings in Congress, lawmakers are unlikely to muster sufficient votes to overrule Bush's decision.

DOC.HEAD: Revamped ``Today'' Dips Slightly In Ratings
DOC.TEXT: NBC's revamped ``Today Show,'' which rose slightly in the ratings in its first week with its new look, slipped a little in the Nielsens last week, audience estimates showed Thursday. ``Today'' dropped two-tenths of a ratings point. It had a 3.1 rating, well behind ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' ABC's show, now first in ratings for 25 weeks, averaged a 4.0, unchanged from the previous week. The ``CBS Morning News'' remained a distant third with a 2.1 rating. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. ``Today'' has added former ``Today'' star Joe Garagiola as a co-anchor and Faith Daniels as its news anchor. The show's anchorman, Bryant Gumbel, and co-anchor Deborah Norville took last Friday off. Garagiola, although hired to co-anchor the show on a Tuesday-though-Thursday basis, has been filling in this week for Gumbel, who is on vacation and is to return to work next Monday. The show's executive producer, Tom Capra, told an industry luncheon Wednesday that he thinks the ratings slide of ``Today'' has stopped and the show is going to make a comeback. He also critized New York newspapers for their critical coverage of the show's woes, saying, ``I think we have been treated shabbily.''

DOC.HEAD: Friend: World War II Officer Confided About Smuggled Medieval Art
DOC.TEXT: The late World War II Army officer accused of stealing priceless German art treasures at the end of the war stumbled onto them during a battle and simply shipped them home in a plain brown wrapper, a friend says. Owen Hunsaker, a college classmate of Joe T. Meador, said his friend agonized over whether to return the stolen Medieval artworks, but loved them too much to part with them, The Dallas Morning News reported Friday. He said Meador was running for cover during fighting near Quedlinburg, Germany when he ended up in a mine shaft and discovered an ``Aladdin's Cave.'' The Army lieutenant filled his jacket with ``as many treasures as he could hold,'' Hunsaker said. He then mailed the artworks home in a box wrapped in plain brown paper and marked ``old books.'' Hunsaker, 71, of New York said Meador told him the story during a visit in 1948. They had been college classmates in the 1930s and kept in touch until a few years before Meador's death in 1980. The religious treasures stored in the mine shaft for safekeeping from retreating Nazi forces disappeared in April 1945. They belonged to Quedlinburg Cathedral. Lawyers for the Quedlinburg church contend Meador stole the treasures and kept them in his hometown of Whitewright, Texas, a tiny town about 60 miles north of Dallas. The church wants the treasures returned and has asked a federal judge to prevent Meador's heirs from moving or disposing of the artworks, believed to be stored in nearby bank vaults. Hunsaker's account is the first offering an explanation of how Meador allegedly discovered and shipped the artworks that include a bejeweled gold-covered manuscript, crucifixes and ancient coins. The artworks were gifts to the church from Germany's earliest kings. During Hunsaker's 1948 visit to Whitewright, Meador took the so-called illuminated manuscript ``wrapped in an old Texas quilt'' from a bedroom closet, he said. ``It was unbelievable,'' said Hunsaker. ``I knew I was touching ancient history.'' He said it had an elaborate cover of gold encrusted with jewels, highlighted with a silver figure of Christ with his hand risen in blessing. Hunsaker said he frequently urged Meador to turn over the artwork to authorities. ``When he looked at it he'd get a dreary, transported look on his face because he knew what he had _ he loved it _ and he couldn't part with it. He struggled with that a lot,'' Hunsaker said. Meador considered taking the artworks to Mexico to obtain phony ownership papers, but abandoned the plan because he feared border police, he said. ``Joe knew he had a hot potato,'' Hunsaker said, ``He couldn't let everybody know about it, and he certainly couldn't sell it.''

DOC.HEAD: Strikers Shut Down Honduras' Only Oil Refinery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE wth Chiquita offering to begin negotiations Saturday; Edits to Trim; Pickup 7th pvs, `Both Zaldivar...'
DOC.TEXT: Strikers shut down Honduras' only oil refinery Friday in solidarity with a walkout at the U.S.-based Chiquita fruit company and a company official said the country would be out of fuel in three days. Union leaders at another major U.S. company, Castle and Cooke, a subsidiary of Standard Fruit of New York, threatened to strike Monday if ``Chiquita Brands doesn't accede to its workers' demands,'' said Mauro Gonzalez, a union leader. Chiquita and Standard Fruit control virtually the entire Honduran banana industry. Late Friday, Chiquita notified a special labor relations board it was willing to start negotiations Saturday to end the strike, a leader of the banana workers' union said in an interview. The four-member board consists of two congressmen, Deputy Labor Minister Porfirio Gomez and Deputy Interior Minister Roque Pascua. ``The situation is improving,'' said union president Rene Ayestas. Workers shut the gates of the refinery in Puerto Cortez at 6 a.m. after working all night to get out a final shipment of gasoline, said Manuel Crespo, head of Texaco Caribbean Inc., a subsidiary of Texaco Inc., of Harrison, N.Y. ``If there isn't a rapid resolution to the strike, Honduras will be out of fuel in three days,'' he said. The Head of the refinery workers' union, Roberto Zaldivar, said: ``The refinery is paralyzed and the fuel supply is cut as of today.'' Both Zaldivar and Crespo spoke in telephone interviews from Puerto Cortez, 186 miles north of the capital near the coastal city of San Pedro Sula. Texaco's 2,000 workers are the second wave of what could become a nationwide strike. On Thursday, 10,000 Chiquita employees went on strike for higher wages. Affiliated unions representing tens of thousands of workers have said they may join the strike in solidarity. President Rafael Leonard Callejas said he had been in nearly constant contact with union leaders for days in a bid to stave off a crippling national strike. ``I hope there will be a satisfactory resolution today for the good of the country,'' the president said in a brief interview. Callejas has been plagued by labor unrest since he took office in January but the current strike is the most serious. The president said Friday he has asked other unions not to join the walkout. There are fears protracted labor unrest could destabilize Honduras, one of the poorest nations in the Western Hemisphere with a yearly per capita income of $740. Juan Ferrera, president of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry appealed to the government to refrain from using force to end the strike. ``Political talent and negotiation should predominate in this moment of crisis in the government, not repression,'' he said. A presidential commission has been in La Lima, headquarters of Chiquita, for days trying to negotiate a settlement. La Lima is near San Pedro Sula. The strikers want a 60 percent raise. Their last raise was in 1984 and Honduras has suffered annual inflation of about 50 percent since then. But Chiquita has said it won't give its workers, who make an average of $15.32 a day, any more money. ``The strike is illegal; it doesn't make sense. We aren't going to pay higher salaries to our workers,'' Chiquita Vice President Eduardo Aragon said Thursday. The Cincinnati-based company's full name is Chiquita Brands International Inc. The head of Chiquita Brands in Honduras, Karl F. Koch, said Friday the company would dock strikers' pay. Bananas are Honduras' most important crop export and Chiquita controls 60 percent of the market. The company, formerly United Brands and, before that, United Fruit, has enjoyed a near monopoly on Honduran bananas since 1912. Texaco enjoys a complete monopoly. In addition to running the nation's only refinery, it controls all 100 service stations in Honduras. Texaco refines 8,000 of the 12,000 barrels a month the nation consumes and imports the rest already refined. Honduras was the first Central American nation to be dubbed a ``banana republic'' because of the vast influence of the U.S. fruit companies. Although that influence has declined, this impoverished, indebted nation of 4.8 million residents still heavily depends on its neighbors to the north.

DOC.HEAD: President: Kidnapped American Will be Released Soon
DOC.TEXT: President Rodrigo Borja said Thursday he was confident the Communist guerrillas holding kidnapped American gold miner Scott Heimdal would release him soon. Heimdal, 27, of Peoria, Ill., was kidnapped April 28 while riding in a dugout canoe near the small mining camp where he worked in the jungle 100 miles northeast of Quito. Heimdal's parents, Roy and Marge, arrived in Quito on June 18 to take charge of negotiations to free their son. Borja said he was receiving reports on the progress of talks to free Heimdal, who reportedly is being held in a rebel camp across the Colombian border. ``I think the negotiations are going well,'' he said in an interview. ``I'm confident that he will be returned safe and sound.'' Borja's remarks were the first he's made to the foreign press concerning the kidnapping. Borja did not say to what extent Ecuadoran authorities were involved in efforts to release Heimdal. The kidnappers, who have identified themselves as members of the People's Liberation Army, asked the equivalent of $612,000 for Heimdal's release, according to his employer, the IMINCO mining company. Heimdal's parents raised about $60,000, mostly in community donations, and that money has reportedly been turned over to the kidnappers. Heimdal was in charge of starting up dredging operations for IMINCO, and was leaving the company's camp to return to Quito when he was abducted.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Expect Hanoi to Account for Hundreds More
DOC.TEXT: Administration officials told Congress on Thursday the Vietnamese government can account for hundreds more of 2,302 American service people still missing from the Indochina war. But there is no compelling evidence that any Americans still live in captivity in Southeast Asia, they said. From evidence that the Vietnamese stored the remains of U.S. casualties and carefully collected their identification documents, ``we must conclude that a serious effort on their part could result in an accounting for many hundreds more of our men,'' Rear Adm. Ronald F. Marryott, deputy director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, testified to a House panel. The agency independently confirmed 10-year-old information that Vietnam stored 400 or more U.S. remains in a warehouse, said Marryott. This was first reported more than a decade ago by a Vietnamese mortician who said he personally prepared more than 260 bodies for storage, he said. In addition, U.S. experts found that ``a substantial number of the remains repatriated by the Vietnamese showed signs of long-term storage,'' the admiral told the Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs. Captured Vietnamese documents described how Americans who died or were killed were to be buried, while their personal effects and documents, along with the exact location of burial, to be forwarded to Hanoi, Marryott said. This provides ``convincing evidence that the Vietnamese can be much more forthcoming than they have been in accounting for missing Americans ... I think you will agree we are justified in expecting them to provide this documentation,'' he added. ``We believe the Vietnamese government has information in its possession that could help resolve the fate of a significant number of missing Americans,'' testified Assistant Secretary of State Richard Solomon.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Coast Guardsmen Indicted On Drug Counts
DOC.TEXT: Seven current or former Coast Guard petty officers were indicted Thursday on federal charges they kept drugs seized at sea, authorities said. The charges in two indictments stemmed from Operation Tempest, a continuing investigation by the Justice Department's Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force. The investigation centered around alleged drug activities by Guard members formerly stationed at Islamorada, in the Florida Keys. Four other Guard members were charged in 1988 on cocaine charges. Leonard Freedman, regional director of Customs' office of internal affairs, said the Guard members had betrayed their duties in the war against drugs. In one indictment, six defendants were charged with conspiracy to possess cocaine, possession with intent to distribute, and trying to cover up the seizure and possession of six kilograms of cocaine. They were James S. Atkins, 26, Springfield, Mass.; David G. Barr, 24, of DeLand, Fla.; Kevin W. Bland, 29, Rockport, Mass.; Ralph R. Carr, 25, Clearwater, Fla.; Thomas J. Kumes, 24, of Concord, Calif., and Stephen M. Savastuk, 29, of Bradenton, Fla. All but Carr face a maximum 85 years in prison and $500,000 in fines if convicted on all counts, said U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen. Carr was also charged in the same indictment with lying to a federal grand jury when he denied ever participating in the pilfering and subsequent distribution of cocaine. Carr could face up to 90 years in prison, Lehtinen said. Bland, Carr and Kumes have been on active duty. The others are no longer in the Coast Guard, authorities said. The other indictment charged Paul J. McGuirk, 34, of Davie, with conspiring to possess at least 50 kilograms of marijuana. McGuirk was also charged with lying in a Customs Service job application when he denied being involved in drug activities or having associates so involved. He could face up to 45 years in prison, authorities said. Some defendants have surrendered or will be arrested, authorities said. No date had been set for their first court hearings on the charges. The investigation was a combined operation of the U.S. Attorney's office, the Seventh Coast Guard District, the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Customs Service.

DOC.HEAD: Hussein Warns Iraq Is Ready For War
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein reiterated in an interview broadcast Thursday his threat to use chemical weapons against Israel if it ever used its nuclear weapons against his country. In the interview on ABC's ``PrimeTime Live,'' Hussein was asked to explain an earlier declaration that, ``whoever threatens us with the atomic bomb, we will annihilate him with binary chemical weapons.'' ``I said clearly this: If Israel were to attack Iraq or the Arabs we shall respond back,'' Hussein said. ``You are saying that only if Israel threatens nuclear weapons, would you respond with chemical weapons?'' anchor Diane Sawyer asked. ``Yes, this is what I said.'' He refused to say whether he was seeking nuclear weapons himself. ``I say to you clearly now that Iraq is not in possession of nuclear weapons,'' Hussein said. ``And in search of the technology?'' ``I shall not answer that,'' he replied. ``But I say also clearly that it is the right of every nation and every people to defend itself.'' Hussein also said he his country did not want a war, ``because Iraq knows what war means. So if we expect an adventure, we expect it from Israel.'' The Wall Street Journal on Thursday quoted Hussein as saying war was inevitable unless the United States blocks what he perceived as Israel's aggressive policies. He added that other countries are mistaken if they believe Iraq is too tired from eight years of fighting with Iran to ``indulge in a new war.'' ``Their assessment is totally wrong,'' he said. ``We shall respond to an Israeli attack whenever it comes and wherever.'' In the ABC interview, Sawyer also asked Hussein about the cult of personality he has built around himself, including a law that authorizes the death penalty for insulting the Iraqi president. ``In your country, the law does not punish whoever tries to insult the president?'' Hussein asked. ``No, it certainly does not,'' Sawyer replied. ``Half the country would be in prison. Three quarters of the country.'' ``And no measures would be taken against anybody insulting the president?'' ``To the contrary, they get their own television show.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Ager Acquitted in Mother's Death
DOC.TEXT: A jury found a 19-year-old woman innocent Thursday of recruiting her former boyfriend to kill her tyrannical mother. The jury acquitted Karin Aparo on a charge of accessory to murder and declared it was hopelessly deadlocked on a second, less serious charge of conspiracy. Superior Court Judge Thomas H. Corrigan declared a mistrial on the conspiracy charge. The verdict came after 35 hours of deliberations over nine days. As the jury filed into the courtroom, foreman Richard Meister winked at Aparo. She broke into a smile, hugged her attorney, Hubert Santos, and started to cry as Meister announced the verdict. She later hugged two of the jurors, saying, ``I owe them my life.'' Aparo's father, Michael Aparo, embraced her outside the courthouse and smiled broadly. Meister and other jurors said they didn't believe the testimony of Dennis Coleman, Aparo's former boyfriend. He confessed to the murder, was sentenced to 34 years in prison and agreed to testify against Aparo. ``I found it personally hard to believe that somebody would kill for a girl that was two-timing him,'' said juror Michael Ward. He said jurors doubted Coleman's motives in testifying. ``He was very sly. He was very calculating,'' he said of Coleman. ``It could be revenge. It could be parole. Revenge _ considering he was sold out by her _ struck me right away.'' Aparo testified during the four-week trial that although she had fantasized about killing her 47-year-old mother, Joyce Aparo, she had nothing to do with the murder. Aparo insisted Coleman acted alone out of misguided jealousy when he broke into the Glastonbury condominium she shared with her mother on Aug. 5, 1987, strangled Mrs. Aparo in her bed, drove her body to Bernardston, Mass., and dumped it under a highway bridge. Aparo said Coleman blamed her mother for destroying their relationship and believed Mrs. Aparo had encouraged Karin to have an affair with another man. ``This boy was already twisted in my mind and he had enough motive all of his own for the murder,'' said the jury foreman. Assistant State's Attorney James Thomas portrayed Aparo as a cold and manipulative woman who was the driving force behind the murder plot. During four days of testimony, Coleman said the teen-ager had begged him to kill her mother for more than a year. ``There's not a whole lot of justice in what happened today,'' Coleman told WFSB-TV in a telephone interview from jail. ``You want to call somebody shrewd, you want to call somebody a liar, that would be her.'' To have found Aparo guilty of accessory, the jurors would have had to find that she asked Coleman to kill her mother or somehow helped him commit the crime. On the conspiracy charge, the jury would have had to find that Aparo had an agreement with Coleman to kill her mother. Aparo had faced up to 60 years prison term on the accessory and up to 20 years on the conspiracy charge. Hartford State's Attorney John Bailey said his office will decide within two or three weeks whether to try Aparo again on the conspiracy charge.

DOC.HEAD: Train Derails, Evacuation Ordered
DOC.TEXT: Freight cars containing potentially flammable vapors derailed on the outskirts of this southwest Ohio town Thursday, forcing 200 residents to evacuate for the day. Nine CSX Transportation cars derailed, said Police Chief Gary Long. The tracks are on the same line on which a CSX tank car carrying phosphorus derailed and burned near Miamisburg for several days in 1986. That accident resulted in the evacuation of about 35,000 people. Thursday's wreck was about 10 miles south of Miamisburg. Carlisle is between Cincinnati and Dayton. CSX spokesman Lindsay Leckie in Jacksonville, Fla., said two of the derailed cars were empty but had last carried liquefied petroleum gas. Carlisle Fire Chief Frank Clay said the cars contained vapors. ``We do have a very warm day. We have outer shell damage to the tanks. And the temperature of the tanks is rising,'' Clay said. Jerry Fenlon, director of the Warren County Emergency Management Agency, said fear the vapors could explode had prompted the evacuation. Clay said the two tank cars were safely righted on the tracks about 8:20 p.m. and the evacuees were allowed to return home. The derailment happened about 9 a.m. Leckie said another derailed car carried automobiles, one had a load of coal, and the rest were empty. Authorities did not know how the cars derailed. Leckie said there were no leaks, fires or injuries. He indicated the cars were in good condition. Ohio Environmental Protection Agency spokeswoman Jennifer Lane Maier said the EPA did not consider the derailment an environmental threat. The 65-car train was en route to Willard in northwest Ohio from St. Louis. It last stopped in Cincinnati. The derailment started with the 55th car.

DOC.HEAD: Report Rules Pilot Error, Haze Caused Smith Crash
DOC.TEXT: Pilot error in hazy conditions was ruled the probable cause of the plane crash last summer that killed U.S. Rep. Larkin Smith and his pilot, according to a federal report released Thursday. The National Transportation Safety Board report indicated that pilot Chuck Vierling, who was not rated to fly on instruments, probably lost control after encountering conditions that required them. Vierling, 58, of Gulfport had expressed concern about the haziness before leaving, the report said. Vierling had flown Smith, R-Miss., to Hattiesburg on Aug. 13. On the return flight to Gulfport, the Cessna 152 crashed into woods near New Augusta in southeastern Mississippi. The airplane was about 10 miles off course when it sheared off the top of a pine tree and crashed. Smith, 45, had represented the 5th Congressional District since January 1989.

Nelson Mandela received a tumultuous welcome in the nation's industrial heartland, revitalizing the South African anti-apartheid leader's U.S. tour after political leaders in Miami rebuffed him. In Florida on Thursday, Cuban-American mayors snubbed Mandela because of his support for Cuban leader Fidel Castro. But later in the day, Detroit showered Mandela with affection and at least $1.5 million to support his dream of a racially united South Africa. ``We appreciate your efforts, especially in this time of industrial retrenchment. In the face of your problems and difficulties, you have not forgotten us. We will never forget you,'' Mandela told a crowd of 49,000 at Tiger Stadium. Detroit was the sixth stop on Mandela's eight-city U.S. tour and the only Midwestern city.

An error in the grinding and polishing of the main mirrors aboard the Hubble Space Telescope has been pinpointed as the cause of a focus flaw that crippled the $1.5 billion orbiting observatory. An official of Hughes Danbury Optical Co., which manufactured the mirrors, said Thursday night that experiments with signals from the Hubble have confirmed that a mistake was made in the tedious three-year process of making the primary and secondary Hubble mirrors. ``With fairly high certainty, we have concluded that ... the shape of one of the mirrors is not correct,'' said Terence Facey, a Hughes Danbury engineer who helped NASA isolate the source of the Hubble focusing problem. He said it was not known which mirror is flawed, but that may be discovered by searching the Connecticut company's records of tests conducted during the months of grinding and polishing required to turn foot-thick, spherical glass blanks into the telescope mirrors.

Police groups who have campaigned against semiautomatic assault rifles are getting the credit following a narrow vote by the Senate to maintain curbs on nine such weapons in an omnibus anticrime bill. ``Why we won is that law enforcement did a better lobbying job than the National Rifle Association,'' Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., said Thursday after the Senate voted 50-48 to maintain the curbs. Tougher penalties for federal firearms violations, sexual abuse of children and selling the new narcotic drug ``ice'' also went into the bill as senators worked past midnight this morning. The Senate also rejected efforts to drop numerous death penalty provisions in the anticrime bill. It did vote to let Indians decide for themselves whether to impose capital punishment for murders committed on reservations.

Sipping sacred rice wine in a shrine to the sun goddess, Emperor Akihito's youngest son and his college sweetheart were wed today as millions of Japanese watched on television. Flanked by imperial ritualists, Prince Aya, 24, and Kiko Kawashima, 23, knelt together in the Imperial Palace shrine to the goddess Amaterasu, from whom legend says the royal family is descended. Miss Kawashima, a graduate student, is the second commoner to marry into the royal family, and the marriage was seen as another step in bringing the imperial palace and Japan's people closer together. The ceremony also was being hailed as the public's first taste of the new imperial era, called Heisei or ``achieving peace,'' which began with the death of Emperor Hirohito on Jan. 7, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Opium Trade Flourishes in Bekaa Valley
DOC.TEXT: Spring is poppy-picking time, and schools around this ancient Roman city put up signs reading ``Closed for the opium season.'' Principals, teachers and students go into the fields of east Lebanon's fertile Bekaa Valley to harvest the ``afyoon,'' the opium poppies whose sap is the base for heroin sold in the United States, Europe and the Middle East. ``We have to make a living,'' said a school principal working in the fields, who identified himself only as Hussein. ``How can I support a family of six on 50,000 pounds ($80) a month?'' The Bekaa once was the breadbasket of Lebanon, but traditional agriculture has given way to more profitable crops. About 20,000 Bekaa residents, including 700 students as young as 8, earn $4 a day each for harvesting the sap from poppies during the month-long season. Farmers said 40,000 kilograms of the extract would be refined this year into 4,000 kilos of heroin worth hundreds of millions of dollars at street prices in the United States. A kilo equals 2.2 pounds. Burma, the world's leading opium producer, is expected to harvest at least 40 times as much as Lebanon. Sources in Baalbek said there were up to 10 heroin-processing laboratories in the Bekaa, three run by Frenchmen. They said several Westerners were seen regularly at the homes of the area's drug dealers. The Bekaa has long been a major source of narcotics. For years, it produced large quantities of high-grade hashish that Lebanon's private armies, Christian and Moslem, smuggled to make money for weapons. After 15 years of civil war, the central government has become almost powerless to curb the drug trade and hashish has given way to opium. Farmers said hashish, made from marijuana, was less profitable and more difficult to transport because of its greater bulk. Growers can sell a kilogram of opium extract for $100 to the clans who run the narcotics business in the Bekaa, but a kilo of hashish fetches only $8 to $20, depending on quality. Farmers in Baalbek said this year's yield was their best yet, which reduced the price of raw opium to half the $200 a kilogram it brought last year. Drug-dealing clans have long-standing links to the militias and to the Syrians, who occupy the Bekaa, so the civil war rarely touches the valley. The clans sell heroin to major drug cartels for about $350,000 a kilogram. Western narcotics agencies say the Lebanese heroin trade is worth about $1.4 billion a year, but banking sources in Western Europe, where much of the drug money is laundered, give estimates of up to $5 billion. Interpol, the international police agency based in Paris, estimates global narcotics profits at $500 billion a year. A recent U.S. State Department report described Lebanon as a ``key processing and transit point for heroin,'' but its narcotics production is far short of Colombia, Pakistan, Afghanistan and the Southeast Asia's ``Golden Triangle.'' Anti-drug agencies are concerned about Lebanon because militias control much of the country and operate illegal ports that are one of the main conduits for smuggled drugs. Syrian army officers in the Bekaa Valley ``profit from the trade and protect it,'' the State Department report said. About 25,000 of the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon are based in the Bekaa and north Lebanon. ``No one bothers us, not the Syrians nor the Lebanese,'' said Mahmoud Shallash, a Syrian who works in the poppy fields. ``This is a free zone.'' Along with the Bekaa villagers, hundreds of Syrians, mostly women, cross the border with their families to ``work with the afyoon.'' Ihab, 13, said he was doing it ``to buy a bicycle.'' Did his parents know what he was doing? ``They grow the stuff themselves,'' Ihab said. Jazieh al-Ali left her husband behind in a village near Aleppo in northern Syria to work in the fields. She and two of her six children make $390 a month. Her husband, a government employee, is paid $214.
