DOC.HEAD: `American Masters' Celebrates Preston Sturges
DOC.TEXT: The loopy, over-the-top 1940s screen comedies of screenwriter-director Preston Sturges have a manic energy and ironic style that identifies them even without a screen credit. It's fitting that ``American Masters,'' the distinguished PBS documentary series on American creative artists, opens its fifth season tonight with the little-known life of the first screenwriter to establish himself as a director. A colleague, Frank Capra, said Sturges was ``a strange guy. Carried his own hill with him, I tell you.'' Where Capra's movies exalted the decent common man, Sturges' lampooned a public willing to believe anything it was told. His farces are filled with press agents, politicians and confidence men who traffic in American values without believing in them. Despite their comic invention, his plots always contained a savage, bitter truth. In ``The Great McGinty,'' Brian Donleavy plays a cynical bum who rises to wealth and political power through a corrupt system, only to be tossed back into the gutter when he becomes an honest man. In ``Sullivan's Travels,'' Joel McCrea plays an idealistic film director who travels incognito to experience poverty and suffering, then gets an overdose of it. In ``The Miracle at Morgan's Creek,'' Betty Hutton is a young woman who gives birth to sextuplets without knowing who their father is. ``The wildly factitious story,'' wrote critic James Agee, ``makes comic virtues of every censor-dodging necessity. Thanks to these devices, the Hays office has been either hypnotized into a liberality for which it should be thanked, or has been raped in its sleep.'' Agee also wrote that Sturges' life read as dizzily as his screenplays. The son of a Chicago stockbroker, Preston had a miserable childhood trailing his flighty mother on a marathon of European museums and theaters. His mother, Mary Desti, an intimate chum of Isadora Duncan, gave the ballerina the long scarf that snagged on a sports-car wheel and broke her neck. She also founded the Paris cosmetics firm where Sturges worked as a teen-ager. After serving in the Army Air Corps in World War I, he returned to cosmetics and invented a kiss-proof lipstick. He then worked as a free-lance inventor and was a complete failure by age 30, when his appendix ruptured. After six weeks in the hospital, he decided to become a playwright. He discarded his first play. His second, written in six days and called ``Strictly Dishonorable,'' was a big hit on Broadway and ran for 557 performances. Sturges went Hollywood. After writing 13 screenplays, Paramount Studios let him direct his screenplay of ``The Great McGinty,'' which became the sleeper hit of 1940 and established him as Hollywood's wonder boy. It was an uneasy success, for it threatened the studio system and made others in the industry jealous. Sturges, as prodigal with his talent as his money, made a string of great films and a string of bad ones. He left Paramount to work with Howard Hughes, beginning the precipitous decline of his career. By 1950, he was spent. He died of a heart attack at the Algonquin Hotel in New York City on Aug. 6, 1959. The sympathetic portrayal on ``American Masters'' is a terrific introduction to Sturges. It is liberally intercut with clips from his greatest pictures and includes telling interviews with his friends and contemporaries. The series has a promising lineup for the summer months. Next week, ``American Masters'' examines the career of actor and director John Cassavetes. On July 16, the series profiles director Martin Scorsese. In addition to an extensive biography and interviews, the Scorsese profile looks at his new film ``Good Fellas,'' the adaptation of Nicholas Pileggi's ``Wiseguy.'' Other ``Masters'' profiles scheduled are composer Cole Porter, newsman Edward R. Murrow, musician Charlie Parker, record producer John Hammond and author Isaac Bashevis Singer.

Elsewhere in television ... FOUR MORE FOR ``48 HOURS'': CBS has added four correspondents to the staff roster at ``48 Hours'' to bolster anchor Dan Rather and correspondent Bernard Goldberg. Phil Jones, Harold Dow, Erin Moriarty and Richard Schlesinger will be called on to make regular contributions to the ``reality'' newsfeature program. The show airs on Thursdays during the summer months, but will move to the 10 p.m. EDT Saturday time slot in the new season.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Increasingly Takes Advantage of First Lady's Popularity
DOC.TEXT: When President Bush needs a sure-fire applause line to spark up a lackluster speech, he can count on his wife, Barbara. It's not that she offers snappy comments. It's the mere mention of her name that evokes applause. On his many politicking sorties out of Washington, the president increasingly brings greetings from ``Bar,'' relays her regrets that she couldn't be there, praises her dedication to the cause of literacy, brags about her Wellesley graduation speech or gripes about her affinity for the vegetable he hates _ broccoli. His most recent and best crowd-pleasing boast is about the first lady's triumph in the Wellesley commencement address flap. Mrs. Bush's June 1 speech to the graduates generally was acclaimed as a smash hit. When she first was announced as the speaker, some students objected strongly, arguing that she is well known largely because of her husband rather than her own accomplishments. Afterward, Bush immediately began gloating about the warm response to Mrs. Bush's simple, direct talk. He was reminding audiences about it recently. ``I thought it came out pretty well _ Bar Bush, seven; Wellesley, you know what,'' he said at a Charlotte fundraising dinner for Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. And noting a lively batch of anti-Helms protesters outside the fund-raising dinner, he commented, ``They're upset because they think that the only reason I was invited to speak this evening is because I'm Barbara Bush's husband.'' That brought a roar from the Helms loyalists. Bush even has taken to quoting his wife. At a recent ribbon-cutting for a children's facility at the National Institutes for Health in Bethesda, Md., the president cited the Wellesley speech. The devotion that led to the new NIH home for seriously ill children and their families, he said, reminded him of Mrs. Bush's sentiment that ``family is the key to everything.'' ``She told the graduates there ... `You will never regret not having passed one more test, not winning one more verdict or not closing one more deal. You will regret, however, the time not spent with a husband, a friend, a child or a parent.''' The NIH crowd applauded. But then, the audiences always warm to the mention of the first lady, whose popularity surpasses even her husband's high public opinion-poll ratings. Early in his presidency, Bush used to tell audiences that he was pleased to learn they requested a visit from the most popular and well-known person in America. But, sorry, he would tell them, Barbara couldn't make it today. On a trip earlier this month to several Midwestern states, Bush worked Mrs. Bush's birthday into a series of fund-raising speeches benefiting Republican candidates. ``I wish that Barbara were here on her birthday, the hero of Wellesley,'' he told an Omaha, Neb., luncheon. ``I'm very very proud of her,'' he added. Talking about his wife also gives the president a chance to poke fun at himself, a technique that tends to go over well. For example, Bush would like to golf a lot better than he does, and made note of it while playing in a tournament in Kingwood, Texas. ``Barbara wanted to be here,'' he said, ``but didn't want to see her husband cry.''

DOC.HEAD: Summer Fun Becomes High-tech for Thrill-Seeking Americans
DOC.TEXT: Many of the old scenes of summer _ kids with fireworks, families huddled in cars at drive-in movies, the Good Humor man and his truck _ are fading from the American landscape. But while summer is different now, the lust for fun, be it in a video arcade on or a hang glider, is ever strong. ``In the 1950s, the status of your vacation was determined by how far you could drive and still survive,'' says Michael Marsden, a professor of American Studies at Bowling Green State University in Ohio. ``Now it's how much you can pack into it. People go away for vacation and come back exhausted.'' Americans, jaded by a world where science fiction quickly becomes fact, are starved for intense experiences that feed all their senses, Marsden says. ``We just don't sit around on the front porch anymore,'' he says. ``We're not interested in that. We're interested in living life.'' As society becomes more frenetic, summer might be the only time left for families to be together. But dual-income families have less time _ summer or winter _ to spend together, and households headed by single parents usually lack the funds and time to take even brief summer breaks. The situation could worsen as recreation becomes more high-tech and summer activities that once promoted togetherness disappear. Movies always have been an important summer ritual in America. Once, carloads of families and amorous teen-agers congregated almost religiously at drive-ins on humid summer nights. Now weeds grow over the drive-ins and moviegoers drive to chilly cinemas in shopping malls, where they can choose from a dozen or more blockbusters. Fireworks _ the kind launched by Dad at a July 4th picnic _ once exploded across the summer sky, then were mostly extinguished by stringent federal bans. Now kids fire off explosions themselves, albeit by computerized laser cannons on nearly lifelike video games. Even the Good Humor Man and his ice cream truck melted away when the vendors in spiffy white uniforms were replaced by college students in T-shirts and jeans. ``There used to be a nostalgia with the trucks and the uniforms. They were well-received by the community,'' laments Alice Durocher, head of Durocher Eterprises, a Chicago-based ice cream distribution firm. Alas, in the health-conscious 1990s, such a demise might have been inevitable. Ice cream is fattening, after all, and it's easier to get frozen yogurt in the mall after the movie at the multiplex. So in the brave new world of the high-tech summer _ where those long, lazy days are no longer so lazy _ what is the fast fun we seek? Summer still is movie time, especially since ``Jaws'' and ``Star Wars'' showed Hollywood that megabucks could be made from colossal science fiction and adventure films. Low-tech drive-ins, though, couldn't match the picture and sound of cinemas in screening the new special effects extravaganzas, and slid into decline, says Beth Cameron, who researches the fiscal health of leisure industries for Smith Barney in New York. Theme parks, ever popular, are being updated. Once pre-eminent, Disney World in Florida faces competition from new Universal Studios Florida. The tour employs a multimedia approach to create realistic scenes that can frighten and thrill audiences, unlike Disney's more gentle approach. ``They want to shock the pants off people,'' Cameron says. People apparently want to be shocked. Amusement parks and their daredevil rides continue to draw summer crowds. America, it seems, is undergoing a roller coaster renaissance. ``What's happening is rides in general and coasters in particular are getting bigger, faster, wilder and yet safer than ever before,'' says Paul Ruben, editor of Rollercoaster! magazine. ``I think everyone seeks adventure,'' Ruben says. ``A great roller coaster ride will make your heart pound, your adrenalin pump. It will make you feel alive.'' Some summer pleasures remain simple. That most hallowed of summer pastimes, baseball, still fascinates Americans. Little boys and girls still sign up for Little League, and their parents still play for softball teams sponsored by local businesses. And despite television, attendance figures for major league games are good, Marsden says. Sporting goods and camping equipment continue to sell briskly. Americans snapped up more than $44 billion in sports gear last year, says Glenn Bischoff, a spokesman for the National Sporting Goods Association in Chicago. But the implements of fitness, like everything else, have grown more complicated than a wooden Louisville Slugger. ``Ten years ago, you had barbells and stationary bikes,'' says Bischoff. ``Now you have stairclimbers, treadmills and rowing machines. People are always willing to pay for more bells and whistles.'' Americans, Marsden observes, want to tie up their summer recreation with high-tech gadgets. Fun that's too simple might not be so much fun, he says. ``Tennis become popularized and accessible, and then no one wanted to play,'' Marsden says. ``Now we've got bigger rackets, complex alloys. It's become fancier and more costly, so now people want to play again.'' The next high-tech summer thrills gadget may lie, literally, on the horizon. Para gliding, a cheaper and simpler version of hang gliding, is just sailing into this country from Europe. For about $2,000, an enthusiast can purchase a pack that contains a sophisticated nylon parachute that billows out into a wing when filled with wind. Put simply, the user dons the pack, runs downhill and into the wind and becomes airborne. ``This,'' says Peter Zimmerli, president of the American Para Gliding Association, ``is going to be big.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed, July 4

DOC.HEAD: Orlando Heads List of Popular Vacation Spots
With AM-Different Summer
DOC.TEXT: America has gone Goofy this summer. And Mickey. And King Kong. And Shamu. The tourist behemoth that includes Orlando and its environs draws 13 million visitors a year. And this summer should cement Central Florida's reputation as the nation's favorite vacation destination. Universal Studios Florida, a glitzy, high-tech version of the California attraction, opened officially June 7, and is expected to be a strong competitor to the year-old Disney-MGM studios. Either of the two movie parks would be the largest attraction almost anywhere else. But here they stand in the shadow of Disney World, with its EPCOT Center, and stand shoulder to shoulder with Sea World, Cypress Gardens and other older tourist attractions. Of course, not everyone can go to Disney World _ if they did, the lines would rival the queues that form for just about any staple in Moscow. So come vacation time this summer, some will go to their nearest beaches, some will flee to the mountains, some will stay at home and avoid doing the home projects they had planned. But some will join the crowds who flock to the popular vacation spots. What follows is a tour of a few of those spots, as selected by Voit Gilmore, president of the American Society of Travel Agents.
DOC.HEAD: CENTRAL FLORIDA:
DOC.TEXT: Too many Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles? An over-abundance of Dick Tracyana? Too much Shamu? Impossible. To meet the Universal challenge, Disney-MGM has introduced a live-character Muppet show, outdoor audience-participation performances of those aggressive Turtles and a rousing musical show based on the Dick Tracy characters. And Sea World is offering an all-new Shamu extravaganza, with two _ count 'em, two _ underwater cameras to capture the whale at work. Meanwhile, the $630 million Universal park, built on 444 acres, has had its problems. Audience-involvement shows featuring Jaws, King Kong and a San Francisco earthquake failed to operate on opening day. Technicians fixed up Jaws in a day or two. They are reworking the earthquake to make it more dramatic; it is not expected to open until mid-July. ``Kongfrontation,'' the massive-scale Kong attack on New York City, has overcome its computer problems. ``It will be the finest ride in the business, period,'' says the park's general manager, Tom Williams. Both parks have full movie and TV production facilities, with Universal boasting the largest sound stage complex outside Hollywood. ``I can't see anything in the near future that will hold down the crowds,'' said Charley Ridgway, Disney's publicity director.
DOC.HEAD: HAWAII:
DOC.TEXT: June, July and August traditionally are the heavy months for Hawaiian tourism, and this year officials expect an increase of 3 to 5 percent in the number of visitors, says Gene Cotter of the Hawaii Visitors Bureau. This is not ascribed to any new attractions _ no one has built a Kilauea adventure ride, with mock lava spewing on appreciative mainlanders. First-time visitors _ about 47 percent of the traffic _ usually zero in on Oahu, the main island, and possibly one other island, Cotter said. Their agenda is sightseeing _ luaus are still big _ and some beach time. The outer islands are prized by repeat visitors. There are few tourist attractions; instead, vacationers must be satisfied with the lush beauty of tropical islands. ``They really are beautiful places,'' says Mike Foley of the Polynesian Cultural Center.
DOC.HEAD: GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK:
DOC.TEXT: Forget Yosemite. Forget Yellowstone. Great Smoky Mountains National Park is the most popular national park in the country, drawing 8.5 million visitors last year. This partly due to an accident of geography _ the park is within a two-day drive of half the nation's population. But it also is testament to the park's 520,000 acres straddling the Tennessee-North Carolina border, its 16 6,000-foot mountains, its 975 miles of hiking trails (including 70 miles of the Appalachian Trail) and 700 miles of fishable streams. It is hard to believe that a park of this size could be crowded, but spokeswoman Nancy Gray said popular campsites are fully booked on weekends a month in advance, and traffic on the two main roads is growing. ``A high percentage of our visitors are the kind who stay in the car and do a windshield experience,'' she said.
DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK CITY:
DOC.TEXT: People still want to see the Statue of Liberty, Rockefeller Center and Times Square, but that's not all. They have a hankering to visit the New York Stock Exchange. ``Everyone wants to see that,'' said Jack MacBean, a spokesman for the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. ``I guess because it's been in the news so much lately. All I know is that they had to reorganize their whole tour schedule to handle the crowds.'' Dave Hetland of Merced, Calif., and his daughters Christy, 19, and Heather, 16, were among those eager to see the bastion of capitalism. ``We've seen it in the movies,'' said Christy, who was posing for pictures with her sister outside the Rockefeller Center skating rink. ``It'll be neat to see what it's really like,'' her sister added. They also wanted to view the United Nations, take a walking tour of Greenwich Village and see ``Les Miserables'' on Broadway. Myron and Holly Civils of Miami added one more stop: Trump Tower. Were they going to see the place or the man? ``The place, but if I get to see the man I'll be just as happy,'' Mrs. Civils said.
DOC.HEAD: ALASKA:
DOC.TEXT: In New York, they're flocking to see the market that crashed in 1987. In Alaska, vacationers are boarding sightseeing boats that will take them to the site of another disaster _ Bligh Reef, where the tanker Exxon Valdez went aground last year. The resulting spill frightened the Alaskan tourist industry; visitors had declined by 40,000 a year in 1987 and 1988, and there was reason to believe tourism would join wildlife and the shoreline as victims of the black goop. It didn't happen. Exxon poured thousands of dollars into tourism advertising to counteract the pictures of polluted Alaska, and the state launched a successful campaign to explain the size of Alaska and point out the many uncontaminated places. Tourism rebounded to the level of 1986, when more than three quarters of a million visitors came to Alaska. More than half of the Alaska visitors arrive with a package or charter tour. Typically, these include lodging at Anchorage; a train ride north to Denali National Park to see North America's highest peak, Mount McKinley; a Prince William Sound boat tour to see glaciers; ``flightseeing,'' seeing Alaska by air from small planes; and fishing excursions to the Kenai River or south central bays.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed AMs, July 4

For Release Tuesday AMs, July 3 ^Blacks Candidates Seen Making Minimal Gains in November Elections
DOC.TEXT: Blacks are winning historic nominations for key state offices as more experienced candidates enter the fray. But few analysts expect them to make more than minimal gains in the November elections. Black candidates are ``a couple of election cycles away from winning a lot of things'' but one or two wins are within reach in 1990, said Democratic political consultant Bob Beckel. One of the races being watched most closely is the North Carolina Senate race, where black Democrat Harvey Gantt is challenging Republican Sen. Jesse Helms. In another high-profile contest, Andrew Young is vying for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in Georgia. Currently, the nation has one black governor, no black senators and 24 black U.S. House members. Most of the primary election victories for blacks have come in the South, where the black population is the greatest. The pattern there seems to be following that of Virginia's L. Douglas Wilder, who last year became the nation's first black elected governor. Like Wilder, many in the current crop of black Democratic candidates and nominees cut their political teeth in local office or government appointments. Wilder, who had served in the state legislature, ran and won as an incumbent lieutenant governor. ``These are mostly black political leaders who were not in the civil rights movement, who came into politics through elected offices starting at local city council and mayors and on up,'' Beckel said. ``I just think it's a process of finally coming into their own,'' he said. Cheryl Miller, senior researcher at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a black think-tank, doubts there will be any significant victories this year among the black statewide and primary runoff winners. But she said the early primary votes signal ``the glass ceiling is not continuing to be an obstacle in the movement toward statewide candidacies by blacks,'' and give encouragement to others who might consider running for statewide office. In North Carolina, Gantt, the former two-term mayor of Charlotte, defied conventional wisdom in last month's runoff election and became the nation's first black Democratic Senate nominee. Gantt faces a formidable opponent in seeking to unseat Helms, who raised $17 million in his 1984 race and already has sounded the financial alarm to his supporters. But Democratic leaders say Helms is vulnerable, and point to polls showing support for his re-election at just 28 percent to 33 percent and early surveys showing Gantt gaining on or leading Helms. ``We see North Carolina as one of the best opportunities for a Democrat in 1990,'' said Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee spokeswoman Anita Dunn. ``I'm a betting man and I think people who write off Gantt's chances in North Carolina are wrong,'' said Beckel. ``That race looks as difficult now as one Doug Wilder's race looked about eight or nine months before the election.'' Democratic state Sen. Theo Mitchell won his primary and earlier this month became South Carolina's first black gubernatorial nominee for a major party since Reconstruction. But he is considered a distant long-shot in his general election campaign against popular GOP Gov. Carroll Campbell. Opinions are divided on whether Andrew Young will emerge from a Democratic primary and likely runoff to become the party's gubernatorial nominee in Georgia. Young, whose roots are in the civil rights movement of the 1960s, faces a strong challenge from Lt. Gov. Zell Miller and others in the July 17 primary. Young, the former mayor of Atlanta, has angered some blacks by breaking ranks and refusing to join a lawsuit filed by blacks seeking to abolish runoff elections in the state. Additionally, said pollster Claiborne Darden, ``Andy has not cemented a moderate to conservative image'' like Wilder. On the Republican side, Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris beat out a white supremacist to get the nod for the lieutenant governor's spot on the GOP ticket in Arkansas. It marks only the second time a black has been a major-party nominee for a constitutional office in the state. Harris, who runs a government grant program, has never held elected office but is getting assistance from the Republican Party and expects a real boost after a visit from Vice President Dan Quayle early this month. Republican Party spokeswoman Leslie Goodman acknowledges the party is playing catch-up in recruiting blacks but said the GOP is working vigorously to fulfill party chairman Lee Atwater's ``political and moral imperative'' to include minorities. The GOP also is fielding black statewide candidates for lower-level offices in Oklahoma and Rhode Island but most of the party's outreach energy is aimed at congressional campaigns. Former federal housing aide Kenneth Blackwell's drive to fill the congressional seat left open by retiring Ohio Democrat Thomas Luken is a ``top target'' for Republicans, according to Republican National Committee co-chairman Jeanie Austin. The former Cincinnati city councilman and mayor is up against Lukens' son, Charles. In another race being closely watched, black businessman Al Brown is challenging Democratic Rep. Romano Mazzoli in Louisville, Ky.

DOC.HEAD: From Shotgun House to Country Club, Singing the Blues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dialect is cq in quotes throughout
DOC.TEXT: It's been a long haul from a ``shotgun'' house on a Tennessee cotton farm to the Country Club Hills address of Koko Taylor's new home. Born and raised in a long, narrow cabin on a sharecropper's farm outside Memphis, Taylor, 61, moved last month into a new home in the posh Chicago suburb of Country Club Hills. Between addresses spans a lifetime of the blues. The latest chapter includes the release in April of a new album, ``Jump for Joy'' on Alligator Records, and her appearance in ``Wild at Heart,'' director David Lynch's new black comedy, which won the Golden Palm award as the best film at the 43rd Cannes Film Festival. ``They called up Alligator and wanted a woman blues singer to sing two songs,'' Taylor said in a recent interview as she prepared to move from her South Side bungalow. ``And I went out there (to Los Angeles) to do the part, and man I ain't stopped grinning yet, because I was so happy about it and I'm still happy about it. I can't wait for the movie to come out, because I think I'm going to be the first one at the theater. First time I had ever been live in a real movie.'' Taylor filmed a scene in the movie in which she appears with a band in a nightclub where a fight breaks out. She performs two pieces written by Lynch and described by Taylor's manager and Alligator president Bruce Iglauer as ``grotesque-cabaret-blues-influenced ballads.'' Neither Taylor nor Iglauer plan to make movies a new direction for a career that started with family jam sessions on homemade instruments in Tennessee. Although Iglauer said he would like to see Taylor portray herself in a film, performing the blues is the staple that keeps Taylor's life together. ``The only thing I have in mind is to keep on doing what I'm doing, and making people happy all over the world with my music is my dream and what I enjoy doing most,'' Taylor said. That dream was nurtured in Tennessee cotton fields. ``I used to listen to the radio, and when I was about 18 years old, B.B. King was a disc jockey and he had a radio program, 15 minutes a day, over in West Memphis, Ark. and he would play the blues. And I would hear different records and things by Muddy Waters, Bessie Smith, Memphis Minnie, Sonnyboy Williams and all these people, you know, which I just loved. ``My oldest brother made himself a guitar by putting hay bailing wire, tying it on a nail in the back of our little shotgun house. And my little brother made hisself a harmonica out of a corn cob and, of course, I was the vocalist. And we would all get together and jam and sing and play music and entertain ourselves,'' she said. ``Also, in the meantime, my dad said everybody in the household had to go to church. So, every Sunday, I went to church and I grew up singing gospel. I would sing in the church choir every Sunday. So, what it amounted to was, you know, we would sing gospel on Sunday and blues on Monday.'' Taylor began adding the blues to the rest of her week after coming to Chicago with Richard ``Pops'' Taylor, her husband of 35 years who died last year. They set up house on the South Side, home to a bustling music scene and cradle of the raw-edged, urban sound of Chicago blues. The roster of local bands playing in the 1950s and '60s in this clubland was a who's who of blues talent _ Muddy Waters, Howlin' Wolf, Elmore James, Buddy Guy and others. ``I started going to these local clubs, me and my husband, and everybody got to know us,'' Taylor said. ``And then the guys would start letting me sit in, you know, come up on the bandstand and do a tune.'' That was for fun; the blues as a business began about 1963 when composer Willie Dixon, working for Chess Records at the time, heard her singing with Howlin' Wolf's band. ``He said, `You know, you can really sing the blues.' He said, `I never heard a woman sing the blues like you sing the blues.' He said, `That's what the world needs today is more womens to sing the blues.' He said, `We got plenty men singing the blues, but it's more women.''' Taylor's best-selling record to date was ``Wang Dang Doodle,'' written by Dixon and recorded _ reluctantly _ by Taylor in 1964. ``I thought it was the silliest sounding song I had ever heard talk of,'' she said, acknowledging now that the record's success got her career rolling. It is still rolling along. Taylor still tours nine months a year, doing mostly one-night stands. She has recorded 12 albums, and ``Jump for Joy,'' her sixth for Alligator, is winning critical acclaim. She's been nominated for a Grammy Award for seven of her last eight records and won for best blues recording in 1984. ``The thing with Koko is the combination of the talent as a musician and the talent as a performer, because in blues, you can't really separate them,'' Iglauer said. ``And the third part of that is Koko's professionalism. And by that, I don't just mean showing up on time, I mean it's her willingness to perform.'' In addition to performing, one of Taylor's other interests for the future is to return to the book she is writing to chronicle her life. ``I don't know if the book will ever be published or not, but if it don't, I'll just know I wrote it and I'll enjoy doing it,'' she said. There's been a resurgence in the popularity of the blues, and Taylor is reaping the benefits. ``I believe that the blues are going all the way to the top, because right now blues is getting more recognition than it has ever gotten in the past and that's all it needs and that's all it takes, because the blues never got the recognition,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Township Jive in America: They Came, They Sang, They Conquered
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Simon Mahlathini delicately replaced the half-smoked Camel in its pack. The growling singer of South Africa's township jive would save the cigarette until after the interview. The gesture was indicative: With worldwide acclaim coming to his group 26 years after its founding, Mahlathini still has the thrift born of life in South Africa's deprived black townships. He and his three Mahotella Queens still cling to their identity as the musical heart-and-soul of township music. ``Nothing has changed,'' said Mildred Manxola, the boisterous anchor of the trio that accompanies Mahlathini. ``White people are enjoying our music. They don't understand the words, but they hear the beat. ... For us, to see them dancing means they really understand it.'' Founded in 1964, the group fell on rough times in the 1970s, while funk and disco flourished, and broke up. But they reunited in the early '80s and started traveling the world, testing other styles, finding new audiences and re-igniting interest in ``mbaqanga,'' a relentless dance music that blends traditional Zulu rhythm and words, street music and international pop. The 53-year-old Mahlathini, born Simon Nkabinde, is called the ``Lion of Soweto'' for his raspy singing. The Queens _ Manxola, Hilda Tloubatia and Nobesuthu Shawe, all in their mid-40s _ are called Mahotella for the ``many hotels'' they've graced over the years. The four are backed by their producer's eclectic Makgona Tsohle Band. The group is now nearing the end of its second North American tour _ a 50-city whirlwind in 2{ months. Their first venture last year had a modest half-dozen stops. ``I'm very excited that our music has been accepted,'' said Mahlathini, a soft-spoken, almost shy, man who started performing at age 12. ``Even at home (the music) is getting bigger now. ... They are going back to our roots in the life of South African music,'' he said in an interview. The music, cooked up in the caged environment of South Africa's townships (racially segregated cities where the majority black population lives), has elements of reggae, soul and even gospel, in addition to African. The driving bass lines, joyous percussion and wailing saxophone join with the Queens' playful, sometimes dissonant, harmonizing to make an uplifting sound designed for dancing. Mahlathini, quiet and reserved off-stage, becomes a spry performer on-stage with his rumbling voice and staccato expressions. All four, clad in native Zulu leopand skins and headdresses, spice the music with non-stop, choreographed dance steps. But maintaining the style may be something of a challenge as they face Western audiences. The demand for incorporating Western sounds into African music has increased since compatriots Ladysmith Black Mambazo gained wide attention in the West on Paul Simon's ``Graceland'' album. Collaboration with the British group Art of Noise already has left a definite electronic mark on Mahlathini's latest album, ``Paris-Soweto.'' Even producer West Nkosi, who helped refine mbaqanga in the '60s and discovered Ladysmith Black Mambazo, envisions using more Western styles and pitches the practitioners of township jive as a do-anything ensemble. ``We will never say no to anybody who wants us to do something together, because we want ... to show them we are a jack-of-all-trades, that we can do anything,'' said Nkosi, whose band name in Zulu is translated, ``The band that knows eveything.'' Mahlathini's 1987 ``Paris-Soweto'' album (distributed by Celluloid in Europe and Polydor in the United States) featured a redo of its trademark tune, ``Yebo,'' with Art of Noise's driving bass beat and electronically created yelps. Whatever the approach, it hasn't overrun the group's native sound, which is raking in wildly receptive audiences in Japan, Australia, Europe and the United States. ``We thought the Americans would enjoy our music. To our surprise, we find that they're going mad. They won't let us go off the stage,'' Nkosi said in an interview. ``This music is there to relieve anything that might have disturbed you mentally or in your heart. You find that you are offending yourself if you listen to this music sitting down.'' The group sees its music as psychological aid for its listeners, much like it was in the townships during the worst of apartheid. ``Our people were unprivileged. The only freedom they had was in this music,'' Nkosi said. ``We design it to educate our children how to live with other people and what's happening presently to them and how to respect one another.'' London-based EMI records produced Mahlathini's first album of township music in 1952, then Nkosi spotted him in 1964 playing weddings. Nkosi enlisted the Queens in Durban and produced the group's first album in 1964 under the white-owned South African label Gallo. But getting the music out was, and remains, a problem, he said. Blacks couldn't go into white stores to buy the albums and few black stores existed. Township radio stations were on the air only a few hours a week, and white clubs were restricted, forcing the group to find its audience personally. ``We used to go to record stores and play in front, and then give the (record) number to the audience,'' Nkosi said. ``We went to the mines (to) find people coming from all over South Africa.'' Nkosi split with Gallo and later, in 1987, took the group to Europe where it recorded ``Paris-Soweto,'' featuring the delightful ``Kazet'' and the raucous ``Yebo!'' But no matter where the popularity will take Mahlathini and the Mahotella Queens, the group will never forget where it came from. ``From the very beginning it was for the people,'' Nkosi said, ``It was for the struggle.''

DOC.HEAD: Midyear Market Scoreboard: Hi-Tech Wins, Banks Lose
DOC.TEXT: Health care and computers are up, and banking is down, as Wall Street investors appraise the economic and business outlook for the early 1990s. At least that's the verdict they rendered via their choices of stocks to buy and sell through the first six months of the year. Medical and biotechnology stocks ranked No. 1 among the 80-plus industry group indexes calculated by Dow Jones & Co., with a 28.59 percent gain for the first half through June 22. Others in the top 10 included Software and processing stocks in the technology sector, up 18.48 percent; pharmaceuticals, up 10.20 percent, and computers, up 9.59 percent. The health-care groups prospered in part because spreading recession fears sent money managers at investing institutions scrambling after growth stocks with limited exposure to the business cycle _ for example, drug manufacturers. Computer and other technology stocks, meanwhile, benefited from a rally after a languishing spell in the late 1980s. That meant dramatic bounces in a good many smaller, depressed high-tech issues. But it also promoted strong showings by such big names as International Business Machines Corp. and Compaq Computer Corp. IBM, which traded as low as 93] last December, climbed past 120 in June to help lift the Dow Jones industrial average to record highs. ``For the longest time institutions thought IBM's earnings were suspect,'' said William LeFevre, an analyst at Advest Inc. ``But there came a time, when IBM's earnings picture cleared up and when its stock price got down to the point where its dividend provided a 5 percent yield, that institutions began buying IBM again.'' The stock's comeback will have to continue a lot longer, however, if it is going to top the peak of 175~ it reached in 1987 before the market crash of that year. For its part, Compaq hovered around 120 in late June, sporting a gain of 50 percent since New Year's. Many bank and thrift institution stocks started the '90s where they left off in the late 1980s, trying to heal the wounds of bad real-estate loans and what many observers described as a ``credit crunch.'' The list of the biggest percentage losers among NYSE issues included Bank of New England, Far West Financial, American Savings Bank of New York, Citytrust Bancorp and Southeast Banking, all down 50 percent or more. Furthermore, bank stocks' frustrated fans got no fresh encouragement this spring when American Telephone & Telegraph made a flashy foray into credit cards, which have been an oasis of profits in the banking business. In the hindmost ranks of the Dow Jones industry groups through June 22, money-center banks showed a loss of 12.63 percent, and a composite of regional banks was down 16.71 percent. By sector of the country, eastern banks fell 26.34 percent; southern banks 18.80 percent; central 9.25 percent, and western 2.47 percent. Faced with weak real estate markets and crimped credit conditions, homebuilding stocks also suffered, falling 19.90 percent. Stock traders who sought safety from that kind of financial stress in gold-mining stocks also took a pounding. Dow Jones's precious metals group fell 16.50 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Life Improving in Some Rio Slums
DOC.TEXT: Life is getting better in the slums of Rio, which symbolized the worst of Third World poverty for decades. Brick homes are replacing wooden shacks. Modern services, even banks, are becoming part of the scene. Few wealthier Brazilians are aware of this because they wouldn't have the courage to set foot in a ``favela,'' as the slums are called. ``Most people think this place is overrun with bandits and drug dealers and that I live in a rundown shack,'' said Antonio Trajano of Rocinha, the largest shantytown in Latin America. ``They don't believe it when I tell them I'm not afraid to go out at night.'' In a nation where half the 150 million people have had to get along on less than $100 a month, the poorest of the poor crowded into makeshift slums that ring the major cities. City governments generally ignored the shantytowns, leaving them without plumbing, running water and electricity. Gunfights between police and drug traffickers became commonplace. Conditions were especially hard in Rio, where nearly one-fifth of the metropolitan area's 10.5 million people live in slums. Areas of abject poverty remain, but many of the larger slums have changed dramatically in recent years. In Jacarezinho, a large shantytown across the city from Rocinha, Elias Lima said the neighborhood looks nothing like it did when he was born there 41 years ago. ``The streets were dirt, the houses were so slipshod they blew away with a major storm and there wasn't even a store to buy a loaf of bread,'' he said. ``Now, Jacarezinho has concrete buildings as tall as five stories and I can buy anything I need at a store right here in the neighborhood.'' Lima, who owns a party supply shop called Magic Balloon, put up a two-bedroom brick home with the help of neighbors, a common way of building in the favelas. Trinidade Carneiro, 28, who works in a nearby pharmacy, said a friend from a wealthy neighborhood came to visit and was amazed. ``She didn't know we had schools, restaurants and clubs here, and she was surprised to see I lived in a comfortable brick house with indoor plumbing,'' Ms. Carneiro said. Major improvements in Rio's shantytowns began when populist Leonel Brizola was governor in 1982-1986. Power, water and at least partial sewerage networks were installed in the bigger slums and the main streets were paved. More than 90 percent of slum homes now have electricity and about 80 percent have running water, said Licia Valladares, a sociology professor at the University Research Institute of Rio de Janeiro who is an expert on the favelas. She said most new houses in the larger, older slums are built of brick and concrete. ``The new favelas that spring up are in primitive condition, but many of the older ones are almost completely urbanized,'' Ms. Valladares said. Much of Rocinha, a hillside community of 200,000 with a sweeping view of the ocean, now resembles a working-class neighborhood more than an outpost of the dispossessed. Butchers, bakers, doctors, lawyers, appliance stores, pharmacies, furniture stores and day care centers are plentiful. Rocinha even has its own theater group, Boca Aberta (Open Mouth), which performs on a regular schedule. ``We have the same quantity and quality of goods available here as in most middle-class neighborhoods,'' said Trajano, who is 68 and owns a small grocery. Rocinha, which means Little Farm, is the first favela with banking services. A branch of the Bank of the State of Rio de Janeiro opened last November. ``Not only is it safe here, but we've got the best clients in the city,'' said Robson Antonio Viana, the manager. ``We haven't had a single bounced check since we opened, which is unheard of.'' Many residents say they suffer discrimination because of where they live. ``When you go to look for work, there's no problem until you say you're from Rocinha,'' said Romildo Marques dos Santos, 32, a security guard now unemployed. ``That's enough not to get the job. Dos Santos said the police are especially hard on slum residents. ``I left here one evening in my car to buy some toothpaste and I forgot my documents,'' he said. ``The police stopped me and were convinced I was involved with the drug trade, and held me in jail for three days.'' Similar stories are told in Jacarezinho. Lucia Ferrenho da Silva, 17, said she kept her address secret from her last boyfriend, a middle-class Rio resident she met at a soccer game. ``I told him I lived in a neighborhood near here and always met him downtown,'' she said. ``I would only have told him I lived here if we had gotten serious.'' Life is not idyllic in Rocinha and Jacarezinho. The possibility of drug-related violence is constant, garbage pickups are irregular and the sewer system is incomplete. Rep. Benedita da Silva of the leftist Workers Party, who grew up in the Chapeu Mangueira slum and is the only ``favelado'' in the 570-member national congress, said $50 billion would be needed to modernize all the slums in Brazil. Many favela residents say their neighborhoods need only a few improvements. ``If the government spent a little bit of money to fix things up, this would be the perfect place to live,'' Trajano said.

DOC.HEAD: Vanguards Become Victims, But Forces Of Change Irresistible
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds publishable Editor's Note
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Jim Abrams, chief of the Beijing bureau of The Associated Press, is completing a four-year assignment in China. These are his reflections.

The drama of changing China has had touches of the heroic and the farcical. Too often, it is haunted by tragedy. It is a story that in the past four years, indeed over the past 40, has been marked by consistent themes. The forces of change, given center stage, speak out and are suppressed. The suppressors relax their vigilance and the adversaries rise again.

June, 1986. Shao Yanxiang, a poet, says it is ``the best period of literary creation'' in modern Chinese history. Anyone ``can write the way he wants'' and the ``100 Flowers'' concept of free expression introduced by Mao Tse-tung in 1956, has finally come true. Mao may have expressed the concept, but those who took his advise and spoke out were persecuted. Mao's successor, Deng Xiaoping, allowed a brief flirtation with free expression in the 1979 Democracy Wall movement. Some who bared their souls are still in prison. In 1986, however, the state-run movie industry awards prizes to ``The Black Cannon Incident,'' a scathing indictment of bureaucratic stupidity. Zhang Xianliang's semi-autobiographical novel ``Half of Man Is Woman'' shocks Chinese readers with its frank look at political repression and sexual desire. Rambo, Superman and Pavarotti play to overflow crowds. Chinese are cast as eunuchs and Red Guards in the film ``Last Emperor.'' The door to the West appears firmly open.

January, 1987. Thousands of students demanding democratic reform trudge through the snow-covered midnight streets of Beijing to Tiananmen Square. Asked if he is afraid of the police, one replies, ``We are students. They would never hurt us.'' The student movement, constrained by harsh winter weather and lack of leadership, is short-lived, but the repercussions are serious. Hu Yaobang, Deng's heir apparent, is purged as Communist Party chief for his pro-student leanings. A chilling campaign is launched against ``bourgeois liberalization,'' or attraction to Western ideas. Old socialist heroes are resurrected, such as the late footsoldier Lei Feng, a cartoon-like figure who devoted his life to doing good deeds and loving the party. A new anti-hero, astrophysicist Fang Lizhi, is discovered and kicked out of the party for telling students to question their leaders. Sartre and Lawrence are pulled off bookshelves and writers are told to write for the masses. ``There has been nothing worth reading twice,'' one said later in the year. ``Most writers are very cautious and keep their work on a very small scale.''

November, 1987. Proponents of reform triumph. Premier Zhao Ziyang, who favors reform, is named party chief at a national congress. His mentor, Deng, gives up most of his posts and forces aging conservatives to retire. Zhao, asked about infighting between conservative and reform groups, says: ``The two factions have merged into one.'' A star of the congress is Guan Guangmei, a middle-aged woman who took over eight moribund state-run food shops in a northern city and built a thriving business. ``I will not be a capitalist,'' she says, ``but the state allows some people to get prosperous.''

June, 1988. Deng's market-oriented reforms appear entrenched. China must push ahead with price reform, the party newspaper Party's People's Daily says, to avoid ``rampant black markets, heavier burdens of government subsidies and worsening of the social mood.'' ``Socialism is not a cake that can be ordered and there is no fixed pattern for socialism,'' says social scientist Li Honglin. In a year, Li will be imprisoned for making such statements.

February, 1989. President Bush, after meeting Chinese leaders in Beijing, expresses confidence that, ``when future generations of Chinese and Americans look back upon this time, they'll say that the winds of change blew favorably upon our lands.'' Chinese leaders, possibly distracted by growing economic problems and moves by conservative Premier Li Peng to slow down reform, evince a startling tolerance of political and artistic expression. Economists propose radical changes in the system, intellectuals sign letters calling for the release of political prisoners and state television broadcasts a documentary questioning the very essence of Chinese culture. ``None of us knows how long this will last,'' says self-described ``free artist'' Yang Wei, ``but it's a good time to be creating.'' An avant-garde art show, preceded by an exhibit of nude paintings at Beijing's main museum, features a waterbed filled with dead fish, huge balloons shaped like breasts and a woman artist who shoots her own work with a BB gun. Tolerance has its limits. Police forcibly prevent Fang Lizhi from attending a banquet given by Bush. Fang says of the government: ``It is weak and it is frightened. All I wanted to do was shake the hands of the president and Mrs. Bush.''

May, 1989. An elderly woman blocks the path of a truck carrying soldiers ordered to end the pro-democracy demonstrations, which had drawn crowds of up to 1 million. She says to the soldiers: ``The students are very weak. How can you have the heart to suppress them? Beijing supports them. If you advance, it will be over my body.'' Two weeks later, on June 3, the soldiers advance over the bodies of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of unarmed people. Deng praises the army for quelling a ``counterrevolutionary rebellion'' intended to overthrow the party and the socialist system. Thousands of political activists are imprisoned. Zhao is purged and accused of supporting student agitators. Millions of students and workers face long hours of political indoctrination, hearing over and over again that ``without the Communist Party there would be no new China. Only socialism can save China.'' Lei Feng, the supermodel, returns with a vengeance. Class struggle and imperialist threats are revived and, according to official reports, students rush to bookstores to buy the works of Marx and Lenin. Artists are told their works must be based on the idea of ``from the masses, to the masses.''

October, 1989. Tiananmen Square, four months after the demonstrators were driven out, is taken over by 100,000 soldiers, workers and students who dance and sing paeans on the 40th anniversary of Communist Party rule in China. Deng and other leaders watch from the rostrum of Tiananmen Gate as 30,000 fireworks explode in the sky. Thousands of police and soldiers patrol nearby streets to keep uninvited guests away and prevent sabotage. Many are in riot gear, carrying automatic rifles and electric prods.

June, 1990. Thousands of armed police seal roads around Beijing universities to prevent commemoration of the first anniversary of the military crackdown. Students, powerless but defiant, break bottles and hold a small campus demonstration. ``Millions of Beijing residents peacefully spent this Monday in busy work and pleasant rest,'' the official Xinhua News Agency said. Tiananmen Square, still guarded by several thousand soldiers, is closed to the public for four days leading up to the anniversary. A Beijing court, citing the need to ensure social stability and ``severely attack criminal elements'' before the Asian Games in Beijing in September, orders the mass execution of 11 convicted criminals.

No one predicts when the current ideological spasm will give way to a new period in which ideas are encouraged rather than suppressed. Some say it may take the death of Deng and a subsequent political crisis. China has continued to change, in both profound and humble ways. In four years, its 1.1 billion people have been introduced to stock markets, bankruptcy, contract labor, private housing, compulsory education through the 9th grade and opinion polls. They have Kentucky Fried Chicken off Tiananmen Square, Mickey Mouse on television every Sunday. Golf courses are built next to the Ming Tombs and Hilton Hotels rise in the hearts of ancient cities. Free markets, run by 17 million private entrepreneurs, continue to thrive. Beijing residents who once ate cabbage all winter now have cucumbers, green peppers, carrots and broccoli. Peasants are saving for TVs, city people for video players and telephones. The leaders in Beijing can force people to study Mao, but they can no longer halt the national drive for richer and freer lives. That's irreversible.

DOC.HEAD: Maybe There's More Heroin Here. But, Where Is It?
With AP Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Sylvia fidgeted with an unlit cigarette, telling how she has spent 35 of her 49 years ``firing'' heroin into her veins. Lately, she said, it's been harder and harder to find decent quality heroin. ``There's only man-made chemicals out there,'' said Sylvia, which is not her real name, tugging a robe closer to her thin frame. ``If there were better stuff out there, word would get around.'' Yet the Drug Enforcement Administration says there is better stuff out there _ that bumper crops of opium overseas are flooding the United States with pure, cheap heroin. If that's so, no one seems to know where the drug is going. Health care workers, for example, say the number of people who wound up in emergency rooms and morgues because of heroin actually decreased last year. And officials at another federal drug control office say there's no evidence of a heroin epidemic. It's possible that emergency room doctors and medical examiners may not yet be seeing the effects of purer, cheaper heroin. Another theory holds that because of the drug's increased purity, people are getting high by smoking and snorting it. Those methods are less likely than injection to cause overdoses that require medical care, so more people could be using the drug without coming to the attention of authorities. A third possibility is that the influx of heroin could be overstated. The DEA doesn't think so. ``The heroin situation is booming,'' said Felix Jimenez, who heads the agency's heroin desk. ``It's here. It's absolutely here.'' His predecessor, Ed Heath, said the DEA is not being alarmist, it just wants to be prepared: ``We don't want to play catch-up like we did with cocaine.'' But David Tell, deputy chief of staff of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, said such warnings are ``an exaggerated gloom-and-doom prediction.'' ``Is more heroin coming into the country? Maybe,'' said Tell. ``Are more people using that heroin? I would guess quite the opposite.'' Sylvia, for one, has given up her search for better heroin. She recently entered the detoxification program at the Francis Scott Key Medical Center, part of the Johns Hopkins Health System here. If heroin on the streets is now more pure, one might expect more addicts to accidentally overdose, landing in the emergency room or the morgue. However, the number of heroin users who died or who required emergency room treatment last year leveled off in most U.S. cities and even decreased in some. That's according to figures compiled by the government's Drug Abuse Warning Network, which had tracked steady increases during the 1980s. Only two of the 21 cities surveyed regarding emergency room visits bucked the downward trend: The number nearly doubled in San Francisco and increased 10 percent in Baltimore. Even in New York City, which has the nation's largest concentration of heroin addicts, the number of heroin-related emergency room visits declined the last two years. The number of heroin-related deaths fell in many cities, including Boston, Detroit, New York, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C. But the preliminary report from a panel of medical examiners found some startling exceptions: In Chicago, the number of heroin-related deaths skyrocketed 655 percent from 1987 to last year. In San Diego, the number rose 77 percent. Another way to track new drug trends is by monitoring people who've been arrested. But tests of arrestees nationwide found no noticeable change in heroin use from 1988 to the fall of 1989, according to Justice Department Drug Use Forecasting studies. No one knows exactly how many people use heroin in the United States. The 1982 official estimate of 500,000 heroin addicts has never been updated. A 1988 Household Survey of drug use found 1.9 million Americans aged 12 and older said they had used heroin at least once, said Mona Brown, spokeswoman for the National Institute on Drug Abuse, which conducted the survey. But that number is considered conservative because the survey does not cover the homeless or people in jail. It's unclear whether there are lots of new users. Dr. Don C. Des Jarlais, director of chemical dependency research at Beth Israel Hospital in New York, said heroin today is ``mostly used by people who have used in the past.'' Heroin users calling the Washington Area Council on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse hot line are 28 years old and older, said epidemiologist Dr. Michael Stoil of the council. ``That tells me it is not being picked up heavily among the youth.'' The DEA is concerned that street heroin's high potency could attract new users who can get high just by smoking or snorting it, without using dangerous intravenous needles. About 75 percent to 80 percent of heroin users at Francis Scott Key's adolescent detoxification unit smoke the drug, said Dr. Archie Golden, who runs the program. Fifteen percent snort it and a few inject it. Many are likely to turn to needles eventually, warned Diana Potter, a nurse with the adult unit. ``Sometimes the kids come in and they'll say, `Oh, I'm never going to use a needle,' you know,'' Potter said with a knowing laugh. ``We tell them, `A little bit down the road, you keep this up, you will be using a needle.' '' The DEA cites several reasons for arguing that there is an influx of heroin. Studies show global opium production is on the rise, and even though the amount of heroin seized by federal agencies is increasing, the street price is going down. The State Department's International Narcotics Control Strategy Report estimates worldwide opium production this year will total as much as 4,734 metric tons, about double the 1986 estimate. DEA tests of street samples in a half-dozen cities found that the cost per milligram of pure heroin dropped from $3.01 in 1988 to $1.79 last year. Average purity increased from 23.6 percent to 25.2 percent, compared with single digits a decade ago. Though the amount of heroin confiscated can fluctuate from year to year, the trend recently has been toward much larger seizures. From 1982 through 1987, the DEA and Customs Service each confiscated 200 to 440 kilograms of heroin a year. Since 1988, the annual seizures have ranged from 279 to 829 kilos. But even huge seizures ``didn't cause a ripple in the market,'' Heath said. ``Case activity is going up,'' Jimenez said. ``Quantities are going up in every seizure.'' He rejected the notion that drug agents may simply be doing a better job. ``This means more heroin is coming into the country,'' Jimenez said. Dr. Donald Jasinsky, who runs Francis Scott Key's adult detoxification program, suggested that there simply may be a lag between the influx of heroin and hospital and morgue cases. ``You may have to have drug users using for awhile before ... you see an increase in public health and social problems,'' Jasinsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Policemen in Medellin: Profitable Targets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE number of policemen killed; picks up 3rd graf `Policemen say'
DOC.TEXT: A policeman in the Medellin cartel's hometown goes to work each day with an assault rifle, a bulletproof vest and a prayer. The drug lords will pay $4,300 to anyone who kills him. So far this year, more than 130 have been slain. Policemen say they live on nerve and in fear of being the next victim. Some routinely arrive home with pistol drawn in case an assassin lurks in the shadows. Dozens of of the victims were murdered while off duty. Police in Medellin are part of a national force of 80,000 men, which is part of the military and under Defense Ministry jurisdiction. The government, which declared war on drug traffickers last year, has sent 1,800 reinforcements in recent weeks to augment the normal force of 2,600. The killings continue at an average of one a day in this city of 3 million, Colombia's second-largest. If the same percentage of police officers was killed in New York City, which has a force of 26,000, the total would surpass 1,000. An Associated Press reporter talked with 30 Medellin policemen and accompanied seven on a patrol of a dangerous part of Medellin. An officer pointed out the spots where six comrades had been killed in the past two months. ``I get scared out here,'' one said. ``I see a movement in the shadows or hear a motorcycle moving toward me and the hair stands up on the back of my neck. I wonder if this is it. I wonder if I'm the next victim.'' None wanted his name used, figuring it would be a death warrant. High-ranking Medellin police officials refused to be interviewed about the dangers their men face. The patrolmen said the drug cartel's tactics had caused 300 police resignations in three months and recruiting was difficult. ``I'm ready to quit if I don't get a transfer out of here soon,'' a 20-year-old policeman said. ``We're just statistics.'' He and the others said they were frightened, and exhausted by working up to 18 hours six days a week, but most said they would not quit. ``You can die of hunger, too,'' a 12-year veteran commented. Their families are destroyed along with the policemen. An officer's widow gets only half his $95 monthly salary as a pension, said a spokesman for the national police in Bogota. Three widows said they could not support their children on that. ``My children don't get milk, they don't get meat, they don't know what eggs taste like,'' Ruth Duque said. ``When they get sick, we just pray. There isn't any money for medicine.'' Mrs. Duque's situation is even worse because she gets no pension at all. Her husband was killed March 23, 1988, before the pension law was passed. She said she makes the equivalent of about $102 a month working in a drugstore. She feeds her son and daughter, aged 4 and 3, one meal a day of rice and beans. Colombia's minimum wage equals about $100 a month. A quart of milk costs 75 cents and a one-pound loaf of bread $1. Unemployment is over 30 percent in Medellin, according to sociologists at the local university. The government says the rate is 10 percent, but doesn't count thousands of people who mow lawns, work as sidewalk peddlers or have other part-time jobs. ``I've been looking for a job ever since my husband was killed,'' said Socorro Rua. Her husband was killed May 19 by a man who stuck a gun in his ribs on a crowded bus. Her 15-year-old daughter, Liliana, turned her head away and tears coursed down her cheeks. Mrs. Rua also has a 6-year-old son, Carlos. They live in an apartment complex built by the government for policemen. The shabby three-room apartment costs only $20 a month, but even that may be out of reach because officials have told her the pension paperwork will take a year. Another widow, Carmen Montoya, said she had high hopes for their children when her husband was alive, but ``now we just try to get by day to day. My little boy wanted a toy car for his birthday. I cried when he asked me, because I knew I couldn't afford it. They don't get anything at Christmas.'' ``My little girl used to chatter and sing all the time before her daddy was killed,'' she said. ``Now she just stares and hardly says a word. ``I asked the police department to pay for a psychologist to see her, but they told me there is no money for that.'' Mrs. Montoya has two children _ Lina, 5, and Alexander, 3. She receives about $80 a month because her husband had 20 years on the force.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Justices Still in Control At Supreme Court
DOC.TEXT: Conservatives led by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist maintained their controlling grip on the Supreme Court in the 1989-90 term, but defections in some key cases slowed the court's rightward march. ``In the big cases, with occasional forays off the reservation, the conservatives still carried the day,'' said American University law professor Herman Schwartz. ``But when the liberals had control back in the '60s they didn't win them all either.'' In the just-completed term, the court refused to let family members assert a ``right to die'' and end life-sustaining treatment for permanently comatose relatives whose wishes are not clearly known; made it harder for girls under 18 to get abortions without notifying their parents; allowed students to meet in public schools for prayer and worship; and condoned police roadblocks to check for drunken drivers. Not all the decisions had such a conservative thrust. The court enhanced federal judges' power to supervise school desegregation efforts, eviscerated the political patronage system, upheld government affirmative action programs attacked as discriminatory against whites, and struck down a federal law that banned flag burning. Justices Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy, both conservative, sided with three liberal justices to overturn the law banning flag burning. Justice Byron R. White, another conservative, joined four liberals in the affirmative action and the political patronage decisions. ``It's a precarious majority, and disappointments occurred when one or another justice jumped off the conservative ship,'' John Scully of the conservative Washington Legal Foundation said. ``We definitely need the appointment of one more conservative justice to solidify our gains.'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor joins Rehnquist, Scalia, Kennedy and White in the five-member conservative majority. Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens are the court's liberals. Blackmun, in an interview in the term's waning days, said the conservatives ``this year have control of the court completely, and are making the most of it.'' Voting statistics for the term appear to confirm Blackmun's perception. In the 129 signed decisions, the five conservatives cast a total of 83 dissenting votes while the four liberals cast 168. One decision can yield, in addition to a majority opinion, several dissenting and concurring opinions. Of the 37 decisions reached by a 5-4 vote, the conservative-liberal split held in 19. ``Some of the 5-4 rulings had no ideological heat,'' Schwartz said. ``And there were a few significant crossovers.'' If the court can be said to have an ideological center, it is the domain of White, O'Connor, Blackmun and Stevens who _ depending on the issue _ are most likely to leave the respective conservative or liberal camps. Here, in summary form, are the major decisions of the court's 1989-90 term:
_States may ban abortions for most unmarried girls under 18 unless one or both parents first are notified or a judge's permission is obtained.

_Family members cannot assert a ``right to die'' for a permanently comatose relative unless there is clear evidence of the patient's wishes. _Police do not violate individual privacy rights when they set up roadblocks and briefly detain motorists in trying to catch drunken drivers. _Prison officials may force inmates to take powerful anti-psychotic drugs without first seeking court approval.

_Congress violated free-speech rights when it passed a law that banned flag burning. _Government jobs generally may not be awarded based on political party affiliation. The ruling, protecting the freedom of association and eviscerating the patronage system, applies to hiring, firing, promotions and transfers. _States do not violate free-speech rights when they limit corporate spending on behalf of candidates in political campaigns. _States may make it a crime to possess child pornography, even in one's home. _States may not prohibit grand jury witnesses from disclosing their testimony after the criminal investigation ends.

_Government affirmative action policies giving special consideration to blacks and other minorities in awarding radio and television station licenses do not discriminate unlawfully against whites. _Federal judges have the authority to order local officials to raise taxes to pay for school desegregation and to block any state law that would prevent such action. But the court said judges may not themselves impose the tax hike. _A federal judge exceeded his authority in imposing fines against individual city councilmen who blocked a housing desegregation plan. _Universities and colleges have no ``academic freedom'' privilege to keep confidential the peer review records when accused of discrimination in their faculty-tenure decisions.

_Schools that permit extracurricular clubs to meet on school property cannot bar student prayer and worship groups from having the same access. _States may outlaw the religious use of peyote, an illegal drug, by members of the Native American Church. The ruling said state laws neutrally applied to all citizens are not invalid even if they adversely affect one group's religious beliefs. _The sale of religious items may be taxes by states just like any other merchandise sales.

_People charged with child abuse do not have an absolute right to at least one face-to-face confrontation in the courtroom with their young accusers. The ruling lets states use various means to protect some children from courtroom trauma. _Police making a lawful arrest at someone's home do not need a court warrant to search the entire home if they have a reasonable suspicion of danger. _Overnight guests have the same constitutional protection as their hosts against unwarranted police arrests. _Prosecutors may not introduce evidence that was unlawfully obtained by police to rebut the trial testimony of any defense witness other than the defendant. _Statements obtained in violation of a defendant's Sixth Amendment right to legal help may be used to rebut his trial testimony. The ruling extended decisions that allow such use of statements obtained in violation of the defendant's Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. _Police videotapes of routine booking questions asked of suspected drunken drivers may be used as trial evidence even if the suspects were not given so-called Miranda warnings. _The requirement that police warn suspects of their right to remain silent and have a lawyer's help do not apply when jailhouse undercover agents try to trick suspects into making incriminating statements. _The justices, ruling in several cases, dramatically curtailed the right of defendants convicted in state courts to appeal in federal court.

_States may make the death penalty the only punishment possible for some convicted murderers by mandating it if at least one aggravating factor and no mitigating factor is found. The ruling upheld Pennsylvania's capital punishment law. _Judges may decide whether those convicted of capital murder are sentenced to death or life imprisonment. The ruling upheld Arizona's law. _Sentencing juries cannot ignore asserted mitigating factors even if they fail to agree unanimously that such factors are present. The ruling invalidated a key provision in North Carolina's law.

_The federal agency protecting the pensions of more than 30 million American workers has the authority to order employers to restore terminated pension plans. _States and private citizens may sue under federal antitrust law in efforts to break up business mergers. _Employers cannot assume that workers who cross a union picket line during a strike oppose the union as their collective bargaining representative. _Hospitals and nursing homes may sue states officials over reimbursement rates for providing Medicare services.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for AMs Sun July 1 and thereafter

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Scotus Term
DOC.TEXT: Here is a statistical sketch of the 1989-90 Supreme Court term: _The 129 signed decisions are the fewest since the 1980-81 term, when there were 123. Some terms in between produced more than 150. _Justice Byron R. White was the court's voice more often than any other member. He wrote 17 majority opinions. _Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the most opinions, 55. That includes majority, concurring and dissenting opinions. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the fewest, 21. _The chief justice, who believes most court decisions are too long and include too many separate views, authored 15 majority opinions, two dissents and four concurring opinions. He otherwise was content to join someone else's opinion. _Justice Thurgood Marshall was the most prolific dissenter, with 50 such votes. _White dissented the fewest times, 11. _There were 37 cases decided by 5-4 votes, compared with 32 the previous term. Seventeen of the 5-4 votes were announced in June.

DOC.SECOND: BC-Mandela-Tears and Dollars, Adv01-2 Takes, 1st Ld-Writethru,
