For release Sunday, July 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: For U.S. Blacks, Mandela Tour Brings Hero and Hope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 53rd graf, which is the 15th graf of the 1st Add, sent June 29 as b0702, ``When Mandela ...,'' to CORRECT ``was'' to ``were''
With LaserPhotos
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The writer, the AP's Southeast regional reporter based in Atlanta, followed Nelson Mandela's American tour through its first four cities.

In Harlem, Nelson Mandela unleashed a river of cash. And Mandela wasn't even there. The crowd of 100,000, most of it black, was waiting for the South African's arrival, listening to a warm-up speaker describe the needs of Mandela's African National Congress. ``I don't want this man to leave here without a piece of you going with him,'' he said. Suddenly, hundreds of bills _ $1, $5, $10 _ were passed hand-to-hand overhead, coursing through the crowd to the speakers' platform. ``I would like to stand here and cry for a thousand years,'' Malcolm X's widow, Betty Shabazz, told the crowd. It was a striking moment on 125th Street, but not an isolated one. It was like that all along Mandela's eight-city, 11-day tour of the United States, which ends Sunday. Black America has given Mandela joyful tears and dollar bills, and he has given them hope and pride and exultation. At receptions and rallies, from lamppost perches in Harlem and corridors in the U.S. Capitol, they spoke of an almost mystical aura. ``A power from above,'' said a 75-year-old New Yorker, Ormond Duncan. At the same time, the 71-year-old Mandela was a kind of cheerleader for black America, a badly needed one, many said. ``Morale is enormously lifted,'' said Georgetown University law professor Eleanor Holmes Norton after greeting Mandela at Washington's National Airport. Black businessmen at a Wall Street power breakfast and schoolkids in Atlanta shared a wish that the stately, steadfast South African would bring a better understanding of blacks _ and with it, basic respect still withheld by some. ``Other people are going to look at black people, especially black business owners, differently,'' said Bill Howell, who runs a petroleum products company in Brooklyn. Here, said so many, was a hero you could see and touch, even cry over. ``I just let it out,'' said 23-year-old Bernard Johnson, who wept at the sight of Mandela at a school rally in Boston's largely black Roxbury section, which has considered seceding from the city and renaming itself for the anti-apartheid leader. A Massachusetts legislator, Byron Rushing, sought to explain the powerful feelings: ``Some people consciously, and I think almost everybody unconsciously, is thinking ... this could have been in America, that Malcolm could have lived or that Martin could have lived.'' People wanted to reciprocate ``the gift'' of Mandela's visit, said Coretta Scott King, the widow of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., who met privately with Mandela in Atlanta. ``For him to actually come, it's like a dream that you had harbored in your bosom,'' she said, shortly after Mandela arrived in the United States. ``I would hope that most people of goodwill would see it as a triumph of good over evil.'' But she added, ``Not an ultimate one, because there's so many struggles left.'' In the crowds that cheered Mandela at every stop, people talked of personal struggles and many said that's why they'd come. They took time off work; many traveled hours by bus. Ophelia Abney of Charlotte, N.C., even rescheduled her husband's heart surgery so that she could attend an Atlanta rally. Resting against the iron fence at the White House, where Mandela was meeting with President Bush, the Rev. Robert Craghead, 58, put the occasion in a personal perspective. ``I grew up in a segregated situation _ the back of the bus, restricted places where blacks could fraternize,'' he said. As a young minister in rural Virginia 30 years ago, Craghead worked to desegregate public schools, to register black voters. Once, he said, he had to dissuade young black men from going home to get guns when Klansmen harassed participants in a courthouse registration drive. In the 1960s, he marched wearing a sign that said simply, ``I am a man'' _ and now, waiting at the White House gate, his sign bore Mandela's picture and the legend, ``Freedom Fighter.'' ``I've seen tremendous change in my lifetime,'' Craghead said. ``But I've also seen a regression in many areas.'' Perhaps, he said, Mandela's visit will re-energize the civil rights movement in this country. ``It can,'' he said, ``I don't know if it will.'' Yes, it will, insisted David Jordan, a Mississippi Delta activist buoyed by meeting Mandela. ``Those of us who've been scratching the surface, trying to make things better, it does give us inspiration.'' Jordan, president of the Greenwood, Miss., city council, was a guest at a congressional Black Caucus breakfast with Mandela, invited by Rep. Mike Espy. The first black elected since Reconstruction to represent Mississippi in Congress, Espy knows Washington's famous and powerful. Meeting Mandela, however, was on another level _ ``to listen to him, to shake his hand, to get his autograph.'' After years of effort against ``state-sponsored apartheid in Mississippi ... to a great extent the barriers that we have to overcome now are less racial and more economic,'' Espy said, calling Mandela an inspiration, ``a galvanizing figure.'' In Mandela's reverberating calls to ``keep the pressure on'' South Africa's government, many black Americans heard encouragement for efforts closer to home. Supporters of statehood for the District of Columbia circulated petitions at Mandela rallies there, comparing their lack of representation with South African blacks'. ``I don't see a lot of difference,'' said Krys Bailey. Roslyn Bacon, who climbed the base of a street lamp to cheer Mandela in Harlem, said his visit should stimulate blacks toward action on local issues. For example, ``If you say `keep the pressure on' that means keep the pressure on the boycotters,'' she said, referring to a protest over a confrontation between a Korean store owner and a Haitian customer in Brooklyn. ``And if you don't make the connection,'' said Ms. Bacon, a New York City schoolteacher, ``then Mr. Mandela's trip here doesn't mean anything.'' For others working with kids in poor, minority neighborhoods, his appearance among them alone may make a difference. In Roxbury, Bernard Johnson said some gang members helped with the school rally. ``Oh, yeah, they were inside,'' and heard Mandela urge them to stay in school, to become leaders, said Johnson, who works with a community group called Free My People. ``It will deter some of them. Some of 'em it won't. Some of 'em don't see the hope.'' Roaming the mobbed outfield of Yankee Stadium taking pictures two days earlier, Ricardo Wright, 30, said he'd use the photos to convey the excitement and the message of the Mandela rally to the kids in his Varsity Sports Academy in the Bronx. The message? ``You can fight for something,'' he said. ``You can believe in something. It can come true.''

DOC.TEXT: No ethnic group speaks with a single voice about any issue or individual, but criticism of Mandela and ANC policies was rare among U.S. blacks. The ANC says it aims to create a non-racial democracy and to distribute the nation's wealth more equally. Mandela, the ANC's deputy president who spent 27 years in South African prison for plotting to overthrow the white government, has said he favors a mixed economy. The ANC has been criticized by some other South African groups for letting whites play too large a part. Others have called the group Marxist and have faulted Mandela for praising such leaders as Muammar Gadhafi of Libya, Fidel Castro of Cuba and Yasser Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Espy, a Democrat, said Mandela wants Americans to understand that ``our enemies, the enemies of the United States, or so they've been portrayed by some members of the administration, are not the enemies of the ANC _ and that's something that we have to understand.'' He noted reports that a CIA tip led to andela's arrest. ``We've sort of been on the wrong side on a lot of these struggles ... and I'm glad to see now some moderation in our stance and some reflection of a legitimate struggle.'' Said Mrs. King, ``I think that the ANC today _ and as I've seen them over the last few years _ has enunciated a policy that they would like to negotiate. They are talking about peaceful negotiations and a peaceful settlement.'' As for Mandela, ``For tactical reasons, I would assume, he continues to talk about `the armed struggle,' but then he goes on to explain what he's talking about. And everything he's talking about is being achieved through peaceful means,'' she said. Mandela represents not ``mindless violence,'' but ``the ability to defend oneself,'' said Vicki Rawls of Atlanta, standing in the crowd across the street from King's tomb. ``Martin Luther King used weapons,'' she said. ``They weren't artillery. They used their bodies as weapons, their minds. When you're chased by dogs, bitten and beaten, you're using your body as a weapon.'' Standing in the same crowd, under the same fierce sun, Richard Smith raised a placard topped with a large peace symbol. ``We have a double, sometimes multiple standard, when it comes to violence,'' Smith said. ``There are people who'll tell you to be peaceful no matter what. But while they're telling you that they're ... denying your rights, denying you access.'' Will Mandela's aura and message endure here like King's? ``I bet it's going to anchor in with people here, a bit like the (1963) march on Washington,'' said Henry Hampton, who created the PBS television series on the civil rights movement, ``Eyes on the Prize.'' The U.S. crusade encouraged South Africans, and Mandela's visit to this country represents ``a closing of the circle,'' he said. When Mandela and King's widow met, Irene Morrison sensed that the circle was closing in other ways, that the future and past of the civil rights movement were coming together. She had escorted a group of high school students from Newark, N.J., to Atlanta on a college tour under a program called Upward Bound. ``I think Dr. King is here,'' Ms. Morrison said. ``A part of him is here in all the people.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sun, July 1

DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese trade negotiators agreed to drastic economic changes to help cut the $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan. The United States agreed Thursday to raise its tax revenues, while Japan said it would spend $1 trillion more on public works in the next decade. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said carrying out the reforms would be painful. ``However, these measures are intended to achieve a major reform of the Japanese economy in the consumers' best interests,'' he said.

Legislation that would triple federal spending to pursue savings and loan fraud won unanimous endorsement from members of a House Banking panel worried about angry taxpayers. The bill approved Thursday by the subcommittee on financial institutions authorizes spending of $152 million a year in 1991 and 1992: $136 million by the Justice Department and $16 million by the Internal Revenue Service. That compares with $50 million being spent this year.

House Speaker Thomas Foley denied that Democratic leaders implicitly agreed with President Bush to approve a cut in the capital gains tax if he supports a tax increase to balance the federal budget. ``We are all interested in reaching an agreement, but there were no preconditions and no agreements,'' Foley, D-Wash, said.

Copyright protection on Lotus Development Corp.'s popular 1-2-3 software extends beyond the computer program's inner-workings to keyboard commands and on-screen images that confront the user, a federal judge has ruled. The decision could make it more difficult for programmers to create software competitive with successful programs, a lawyer not involved with the case said.

Ivan Boesky is ``a pile of human garbage'' who lied repeatedly on the witness stand about dealings with John A. Mulheren Jr., his former friend and colleague, Mulheren's lawyer said. Mulheren, 40, is charged with 30 counts of conspiracy, securities and mail fraud and keeping false books in transactions with Boesky in 1985 and 1986. Boesky, who was convicted of insider trading offenses, testified against Mulheren as part of a plea agreement. ``Boesky, ladies and gentlemen, is a pile of human garbage,'' lawyer Thomas Puccio said in his closing arguments Thursday. ``And that is what the government of the United States had put up to testify against John Mulheren.''

T. Boone Pickens Jr. failed again to breach what he calls the closed Japanese business system, when shareholders of Koito Manufacturing Co. refused to grant him four seats on the company's 20-member board. The Texan oilman, who is Koito's largest shareholder with a 26 percent stake, has demanded higher dividends and the right for shareholders to vote on salary and retirement of board members. Koito says it could not accept board members who it believed is interested only in forcing the company to buy back stock at premium prices.

A former Nissan executive was elected president of Fuji Heavy Industries Co., giving Nissan effective control over the slumping manufacturer of Subaru cars. Fuji shareholders on Thursday approved the selection of Isamu Kawai, former president of Nissan Diesel Motor Co., a subsidiary of Nissan Motor Co., during a meeting here. Nissan, Japan's second largest automaker, is Fuji's largest shareholder, with a 4.2 percent stake.

A name partner in a Manhattan law firm was accused of using inside information to make $34,000 in illegal trading profits in the stock of WearEver-Proctor Silex Inc. In a civil complaint filed in U.S. District Court in New York, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged attorney Henry A. Singer, 52, with violating insider trading laws in 1987. Singer's firm, Morrison Cohen Singer & Weinstein, said in a statement that there is overwhelming evidence that there was no wrongdoing by him.

Polaroid Corp. and Minolta Camera Co. Ltd. said they have agreed to manufacture and distribute an instant camera in the United States. The camera, geared toward industrial users, will include a special close-up lens allowing picture-taking at a distance of 10 inches, Polaroid said Thursday. The agreement announced Thursday marks the first time Polaroid instant cameras have been available under another brand name.
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Drug and consumer-products issues led the way as the stock market posted its second straight gain. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had climbed 19.80 points in the previous session, rose another 16.58 to close at 2,878.71. The dollar closed mostly higher, as gold prices firmed. Bond prices advanced for the third consecutive session as the Treasury completed a new round of securities sales. Copper futures prices rose sharply amid speculation of a strike at an Arizona mine and supply disruptions from Zambia, the world's sixth-largest producer. Elsewhere, precious metals, orange juice and energy futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: New England Art of Lacemaking Slowly Dying
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Lace is making a comeback as a fashion staple, but it may be too late to save the industry in New England. The painstaking tradition of making fine Leavers lace is the most recent New England craft facing extinction. A generation of weavers who honed their skills for decades are approaching retirement, and mills can't find young workers willing to spend years learning the craft. The latest victim is the Deep River Lace Company, which closes its doors today after 56 years in business. ``It's unfortunate it's coming to an end the way it is,'' said Leo Denette, 70, one of the mill's four owners who started as an apprentice weaver at Deep River Lace in 1941, six months before Pearl Harbor. Deep River Lace was the last company in Connecticut and one of a handful in the country making the intricate, Leavers lace perfected in Nottingham, England, in the early 1800s. It takes three years to learn to operate Leavers looms and Deep River Lace could find no young people to take the place of its last five workers, who are all in their late 60s or early 70s. So the company is shutting down the last of its 16-ton looms, closing the doors of its red brick factory and becoming a part of New England's industrial past. Stanley Jakiel, 79, another Deep River weaver and owner, traced the mill's decline to the casual fashion trends of the 1960s. Demand for lace fell then, so the company never found the need to train new workers. ``The lace business went over the falls when ladies started wearing jeans,'' he says. Lace-making survives in the United States today, but it has moved South and adopted modern technology. A type of cloth called Rachel lace is produced on machines that take only two or three months to master. But Jakiel say Leavers lace is more intricate and better quality than the cheaper Rachel variety. ``It really takes 20 years before you know what you're doing,'' said Jakiel, who has been in the lace business for 60 years. ``It's all experience, there's no book on this.'' The huge Leavers machines stand 9 feet 6 inches tall and are of a design essentially unchanged from the prototype built by John Leavers, an English lace worker in 1813. Each loom contains 4,600 bobbins, which have to be threaded individually with thread as fine as a strand of hair. The threads are woven into lace by the rocking bobbins and metal bars that determine the pattern. Only about 150 Leavers looms are still in use in the United States, compared with 800 in the late 1940s and early 1950s, said John W. Hughes, manager of the textile engineering division of Bridgeport-based American Fabrics Co. More will fall silent when Rhode Island Lace Works in Great Barrington, R.I., closes its doors in August. Hughes helped build two of Deep River Lace's cast iron looms more than 30 years ago when he was an apprentice in Nottingham. Today, he brokers the sale of old machines, like the four Deep River Lace looms that already have been shipped to mills in Calais, France. Hughes says the craft is alive and well in Europe and Japan, where apprentices are eager to learn how to operate the complicated looms and designers are placing big orders. ``Lace is the hottest item in fashion right now,'' says Lita Konde, a professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City. ``Today, the European lace houses can't even keep their orders filled,'' she said. ``The dress designers are using it everything from cocktail and evening wear to swimsuits.'' France has always been the leader in lace production and French fashion houses like Christian Dior and Yves St. Laurent have incorporated the fabric into their spring and fall lines, Konde said. But the latest fashion craze won't benefit Deep River Lace. The owners' only hope now is to preserve the mill as a museum. ``Certain old-fashioned values should not be forgotten,'' said Charlotte D. Boline, who is trying to sell the mill to the state as a museum. ``The traditions of New England should be carried on so our children can see how things were done.''

DOC.HEAD: SEC-CFTC Battle: They're at it Again
DOC.TEXT: Verbal sniping between the federal agencies that oversee the securities and futures markets is heating up again. Commodity Futures Trading Commission Chairman Wendy Gramm says a study by the rival Securities and Exchange Commission on last October's 190-point stock market plunge is ``misleading'' and ``imprecise.'' SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden says the CFTC's study of the 1989 market mini-crash had ``significant methodological defects.'' He also likened it to saying ``except for the period of time between 7 a.m. and noon, Pearl Harbor day was a good day.'' ``We stand by our report and every word in it,'' Breeden told a small group of reporters Thursday. His sharp comments came in response to a letter Gramm sent to the chairman of a House subcommittee that oversees the CFTC. Both the SEC, which regulates stocks, bonds and the exchanges that trade them, and the CFTC which oversees the futures markets, have been locked in a war of words over which agency has jurisdiction over financial products that share aspects of both securities and futures contracts. The Bush administration is pushing legislation that would strip the CFTC of authority over stock index futures and give it to the SEC. In the wake of a 190-point plunge in the Dow Jones Industrial Average _ a key market indicator _ last fall, both regulatory agencies studied the causes of the trading slide, which occurred shortly after UAL Corp. announced financing for a management-led leveraged buyout had fallen through. Last month both agencies released their reports. The CFTC concluded that index arbitrage _ a computerized program trading strategy blamed by many for exacerbating the 1987 stock market crash _ was not a major factor in the stock slide. It also found no evidence of stock index futures market manipulation. Stock index futures, often used in program trading strategies by large institutional investors like pension funds, let investors trade on the movement of a basket of stocks without having to buy the underlying stocks. The SEC and other critics of index arbitrage claim it causes wild price swings, or volatility. Index arbitragers try to take advantage of small price differences between the stock and futures markets by simultaneously buying large orders in one market while selling in the other. The SEC study released last month found that index arbitrage and other program trading strategies accelerated the 6.9 percent market drop. An unusually high percentage of volume during the 90-minute slide was conducted through computer-program trading, the SEC study concluded. Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., chairman of the panel that oversees the CFTC, asked Gramm to explain the discrepencies between the SEC and CFTC reports. In a nine-page letter to English, Gramm said the two reports agree on most of the facts the SEC's report is misleading because it leaves some critical information out of its analysis. ``The most obvious case is their emphasis on sell volume and only perfunctory mention of contemporaneous buy volume by the same trader groups,'' Gramm said. Breeden, however, insisted the SEC report was more accurate because it focuses on the day's trading after the UAL announcement. Also, Breeden said the SEC report looks at the pattern of net activities _ both buying and selling. ``The CFTC report chose to analyze the level of index arbitrage averaged over the entire day. That's a little bit like saying that except for the period of time between 7 a.m. and noon, Pear Harbor Day was a good day and on average there weren't many problems!'' Breeden continued: ``There was a specific event, it began at a specific point in time and to try and disguise the developments that occurred during that period of time by averaging them in over a period of time that is totally irrelevent, demonstrates the significant methodological defects of the CFTC report.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Lawyer Attacks Boesky Credibility
DOC.TEXT: The jury deciding the fate of former Wall Street pro John A. Mulheren Jr. got the same request from prosecution and defense lawyers: Believe my witness. The language the two sides chose to convey that message was slightly different. In measured tones, Assistant U.S. Attorney Alfred Pavlis said Mulheren had greater motive to lie than the government's main witness, convicted felon Ivan Boesky, who already has served prison time. In an often fiery three-hour summation Thursday, Mulheren's lawyer, Thomas Puccio, called Boesky ``a pile of human garbage.'' Boesky's testimony was ``a sick joke.'' The admitted inside trader is ``the most incredible witness who's ever taken the stand in this country.'' ``He has lied so many times that he doesn't even remember how many times he's lied,'' Puccio said. The attack on Boesky's credibility was Puccio's main tactic throughout the trial in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, now in its seventh week. The defense maintains Boesky lied partly because he agreed to cooperate with the government, partly because it's his nature. Mulheren, 41, is charged with 30 counts of conspiracy, securities and mail fraud, and keeping false books and records in connection with allegedly illegal securities transactions with Boesky in 1985 and 1986. The case, expected to go to the jury today, centers on allegations that Mulheren manipulated the price of Gulf & Western Inc. stock and concealed the ownership of other securities to help Boesky cheat on his taxes and evade federal securities laws in 1985 and 1986. Pavlis on Wednesday portrayed Mulheren and Boesky as close friends and colleagues who schemed to break the law. Puccio said none of the trades Mulheren executed with Boesky were illegal. Puccio denied existence of a criminal conspiracy, saying Mulheren's firm even lost $50,000 on one series of trades with Boesky, indicating it was fully at risk to the whims of the market. Puccio cited the testimony by a parade of defense _ and some government _ witnesses who praised Mulheren's honesty and integrity and then compared that with Boesky's reputation. During his cross-examination of Boesky last month, Puccio had the onetime stock speculator admit he lied to government prosecutors and paid for inside information with cash-filled suitcases. Puccio attacked the deal under which Boesky pleaded guilty to one count of lying to the Securities and Exchange Commission and paid $100 million in cash and securities to settle his charges. He was released after serving two years of a three-year sentence. Mulheren is the first of several prominent Wall Street professionals implicated by Boesky to take his case to trial. Others involved in the government's four-year-old investigation have pleaded guilty, receiving sentences ranging from probation to four years in prison. Mulheren had close dealings with Boesky for several years, at one point helping Boesky's firm avoid insolvency. Boesky later named Mulheren as a trustee for his children, which the government has sought to use as evidence of their close ties. But the relationship between the men soured after Boesky's plea deal was announced in November 1986. In 1988, after learning that Boesky had implicated him in wrongdoing, Mulheren was arrested carrying an assault weapon, supposedly on his way to shoot Boesky. Mulheren's lawyers have said the incident was related to Mulheren's condition as a manic depressive. The incident was not revealed to the jury at Mulheren's trial. Mulheren testified in his own defense and denied any wrongdoing. Also charged is Leonard DeStefano, 34, a former trader at Mulheren's firm Jamie Securities Co. He is accused of conspiracy and record-keeping violations for allegedly inflating payments to Boesky to pay back profits from the alleged illegal deals. Both men face up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine on each count.

DOC.HEAD: Lotus Wins Copyright Infringement Suit
DOC.TEXT: Copyright protection on Lotus Development Corp.'s popular 1-2-3 software extends beyond the computer program's inner-workings to keyboard commands and on-screen images that confront the user, a federal judge has ruled. A spokesman for Paperback Software International, which lost the case along with subcontractor Stephenson Software Ltd., said the company would appeal Thursday's decision. ``If (the decision) is upheld in an appeal, it will have a serious affect on the software business,'' Michael Burdick, Paperback vice president of sales and marketing, said. He would not comment on specifics of the lengthy ruling. The decision could make it more difficult for programmers to create software competitive with successful programs, a lawyer not involved with the case said. ``In the future, if there's a product that becomes the accepted product in the industry, it will be very difficult to create a program that competes with it without being willing to retrain users extensively,'' Jack Russo, a Palo Alto, Calif., copyright lawyer told The New York Times in reacting to the decision. In his 115-page decision, U.S. District Judge Robert Keeton wrote that ``the user interface of 1-2-3 is its most unique element and is the aspect that has made 1-2-3 so popular. That defendants went to such trouble to copy that element is a testament to its substantiality.'' The attorney for Lotus praised the decision. ``In bringing this case we sought to protect the original creative expression that is a very large part of what people value in our product,'' said Tom Lemberg, vice president and general counsel of Cambridge-based Lotus. During the non-jury trial, which began in early February, Lotus product managers displayed three video screens to show the similarities in commands among Paperback Software's VP-Planner and Mosaic's Twin Classic program. Because the attorney representing Mosaic fell ill during the trial, Keeton chose to concentrate only on Paperback Software as the defendant. It was not immediately clear Thursday if the ruling would also apply to Mosaic. Defense attorneys had argued that the Lotus commands represented ``instructions for a machine rather than the expression of an idea.'' The ruling would not affect programs that have different screen images and keyboard commands, like Microsoft's Excel software, Lotus executives said. Lotus officials also said the ruling would not affect companies that publish programs that are compatable with Lotus files. The company has no intention of trying to claim copyright infringement over compatable files, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Supermarket Video Services Announce Expansion Plans
DOC.TEXT: The creators of two new video services that will connect advertisers with shoppers in the supermarket say they are moving toward securing their space in grocery aisles and checkout lanes. The Checkout Channel and the Shoppers' Video network are examples of recent media innovations that are being touted as more effective than traditional media outlets at helping advertisers reach prospective customers. Among other recent examples of these new media have been commercially-sponsored TV shows for schools and video programs and magazines designed specifically for doctor's waiting rooms and beauty parlors. ActMedia Inc., a Darien, Conn.-based marketing concern, and Turner Broadcasting System Inc., the cable television company that produces Cable News Network and Headline News in Atlanta, said Thursday they plan to begin an eight-week test in August of its new Checkout Channel. The service, which will consist of continuously updated news reports with commercials, will be tested in stores in the New York, Los Angeles, Detroit, Atlanta, Columbus, Ohio, and Charlotte, N.C., markets. Participating supermarket chains will be Kroger in Detroit and Columbus, A&P in Atlanta, Food Lion in Charlotte, Waldbaum's in New York and Vons in Los Angeles. Two stores from each chain will air the TV network. The Checkout Channel will air eight-minute news shows including 2{ minutes of commercials. The shows will be updated continuously and be shown on television monitors perched just above each checkout lane. If the test is successful, ActMedia and Turner Broadcasting hope to expand the service nationally in early 1991, reaching 5,000 stores by the end of 1992. ActMedia President Wayne W. LoCurto said he hopes to sign up 16 advertisers for the test at $125,000 each. Separately, the creators of the Shoppers' Video network said they plan to expand next month into Phoenix, Denver, Oklahoma City, Dallas and Houston. It was also announced that NYNEX Computer Services Co., a unit of the regional telephone company NYNEX Corp., had agreed to be responsible for installation, maintenance and operation of the service as it expands. The service, which displays computer-animated advertising on an average of 20 TV monitors scattered throughout supermarket aisles, has been tested for more than a year in 32 stores in West Texas and New Mexico. Gene Detroyer, president of New York-based Shoppers' Video, said the service expects to expand to 4,000 stores by 1992. ``We feel NYNEX's participation will assure supermarkets of the highest quality installation, maintenance and support as well as financial responsibility,'' he said. Neither Detroyer nor Mike LaTurreca, a spokesman for NYNEX Computer Services, would elaborate on their financial arrangement. The Shopper's Video displays silent ads continuously through the day, allowing 15 seconds per ad and repeating each ad every 11 minutes. The system has the flexibility to allow advertisers to tailor their message for each store, providing specific information on where the product is located in the store or special price discounts.

DOC.HEAD: Law Partner Accused of Insider Trading
DOC.TEXT: A name partner in a Manhattan law firm charged with illegal insider trading says the charges against him are ``factually inaccurate and legally deficient.'' In a civil complaint filed Thursday at federal court in New York, securities regulators accused attorney Henry A. Singer of allegedly using inside information to make $34,000 in illegal trading profits in the stock of WearEver-Proctor Silex Inc. According to the Securities and Exchange Commission complaint, Singer, a partner in the firm of Morrison Cohen Singer & Weinstein, was retained as counsel by WearEver's board to consider takeover offers. The SEC charged that while he was in possession of confidential corporate information about pending offers, Singer bought WearEver stock in the fall of 1987 and sold it on or about April 8, 1988. WearEver, a Glen Allen, Va.-based electrical appliance maker, was acquired by NACCO Industries Inc. on April 15, 1988. Singer, 52, of Harrison, N.Y., issued a statement through his attorney, Robert Morvillo. It said Singer ``was surprised by the SEC charges which he branded as factually inaccurate and legally deficient.'' The statement continued: ``There is substantial documentary evidence and corroborative testimony of several other witnesses which confirm that Mr. Singer did not purchase WearEver stock based upon inside information.'' In a statement issued by managing partner Robert Stephan Cohen, the law firm said: ``The SEC's decision to file a civil suit is inexplicable. We are convinced, without any doubt whatsoever, that Mr. Singer did not violate, either intentionally or inadvertently, any SEC rules or regulations.'' ``The firm stands behind'' Singer, Cohen added.

DOC.HEAD: Psychiatrist Admits Trading on Information from Patient
DOC.TEXT: A psychiatrist who pleaded guilty to insider trading admitted getting his stock tips during sessions with a patient. Dr. Robert Willis, 51, pleaded guilty Thursday to two counts of securities fraud for using inside information he obtained while treating the wife of financier Sanford I. Weill. ``I know what I did was wrong,'' Willis said. ``I didn't know it was against a specific law but I knew it was illegal.'' Willis was indicted last July on 46 counts of securities and mail fraud. Willis admitted he traded in BankAmerica Corp. stock after he learned from his patient that her husband, the former chief executive officer of Shearson Loeb Rhoades, was attempting to become chairman of BankAmerica. Mrs. Weill also told him during the course of their consultations that Weill's financial backers intended to invest in BankAmerica if he was successful. The indictment alleged he disclosed the information to his broker and bought $171,130 worth of common stock in BankAmerica. He sold the stock on Feb. 21, 1986, after a public announcement about Weill's attempt to become a BankAmerica executive, making a profit of $27,475 for himself and his family. Weill, who now heads Primerica Corp., was unsuccessful in his bid to join BankAmerica. Willis' attorney, Edward Brodsky, said Willis also was working on a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to pay back the illegal profits. Willis, who lives in Tenafly, N.J., has an office at 4 E. 89th St. in Manhattan. He faces up to 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines when sentenced Nov. 2. The doctor, who is still practicing, faces disciplinary action by state licensing officials because of his plea.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Nikkei Down
DOC.TEXT: Expectations of higher Japanese interest rates, linked to moves to ease trade friction with the United States, pushed down both the U.S. dollar and the key stock index in Tokyo trading today. The dollar closed the week at 152.85 yen, down 1.57 yen from Thursday's close of 154.42 yen. After opening at 153.20 yen, it ranged between 152.40 yen and 153.25 yen. In talks with U.S. negotiators that ended Thursday, Japan promised a major increase in public works spending over the next 10 years. Market players speculated that inflationary pressures might result and the Bank of Japan might raise its official discount rate, said Masahiro Yanagida, a dealer with Sanwa Bank. There also was speculation that U.S. monetary authorities might lower American interest rates, narrowing the difference between U.S. and Japanese rates and reducing the incentive to buy dollars with yen, he added. Japan's promised increase in public works spending is expected to boost demand here for U.S. products and construction services. In an effort to reduce the U.S. federal budget deficit, which fuels U.S. demand for Japanese products, President Bush promised to consider tax revenue increases. This has led to speculation of lower American interest rates. Japan's discount rate, the rate charged by the nation's central bank for loans to commercial banks, now stands at 5.25 percent, one of the lowest among major industrial nations. An official of the Bank of Japan, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the bank has ``no plans at all'' to change the current rate now. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 165.95 points, or 0.52 percent, closing at 31,940.24. The index shed 206.56 points on Thursday. A total of 500 million shares changed hands on the first section, up from the previous day's 450 million shares. Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with the New Japan Securities Co., said rising interest rates discouraged many stock investors despite the yen's rise. ``Short-term interst rates rose over concern about possible inflation ahead,'' Nomura said. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slid to 86.29 points from Thursday's close of 86.75. The yield stood at 7.340 percent, up from the previous day's 7.240 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Factory Town Prospers Despite Chrysler Closing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Blasting ceremony set for 3:30 p.m. EDT: prospects for PMs lead unlikely; also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: City officials, buoyed by a quick recovery from a 1988 auto plant closing that left 5,500 jobless, will destroy the last vestige of the plant with a ceremonial blast. The end of the Chrysler Corp. complex, which began building cars at the turn of the century, is an emotional passage for a city now shedding its factory town image for unprecedented economic growth. The plant's lone remaining smokestack was to be destroyed this afternoon. ``The last symbol of what had been will now be a memory in our past,'' Mayor Pat Moran said Thursday. ``The old symbols come down and the new symbols of Kenosha's rebirth can be seen.'' The keys to recovery have been a multimillion-dollar aid package from Chrysler, an aggressive retraining program for displaced workers and an economic development plan that has lured dozens of new businesses. ``The community's image is probably the best it's been in 100 years,'' City Planner Ray Forgianni Jr. said. ``The closing was almost like a catalyst. The handwriting was on the wall _ the economy needed to diversify.'' This city of 77,000 on Lake Michigan has erased many of the bitter memories of the December 1988 closing. Among the planned or already opened new facilities: a multimillion-dollar recreation marina taking shape just beyond the plant's lakefront site, a $45 million greyhound race track, a food company warehouse and a Navy research center. John Bechler, director of the Kenosha Area Development Corp., said some 15 manufacturing companies either opened or announced plans to do so in the past 12 months. The openings will mean about 1,350 jobs, he said. But hundreds of former Chrysler workers remain unemployed and many new jobs do not pay the same high wages and benefits autoworkers enjoyed for decades. Ron Danowski, a state labor department spokesman, said the average wage at Chrysler was $14.22. Former plant workers are now averaging $10.18, he said. About 3,250 workers sought job-placement assistance or job training through union programs, said Jack Ward, state coordinator for the UAW Job Development Training Corp. About 1,200 are employed and an additional 650 are in school or retraining programs, he said. Not everyone, therefore, will celebrate the smokestack destruction. ``For all the people who got screwed out of their jobs, it's a very sad day,'' said Rudy Kuzel, president of United Auto Workers Local 72. ``Despite all their hoopla about economic development, they haven't begun to do anything to help the people who lost their jobs.'' The plant was bought in 1917 by Nash Motors, predecesor of the American Motors Corp. At its height in the early 1960s, it employed more than 16,000. Chrysler acquired the plant when it bought AMC in 1987, and Chrysler offiials implied they would keep it open for at least five years. The aging plant was too inefficient, however, and it was closed. Chrysler, which employs 1,100 workers at another plant here, provided a $25 million trust fund for displaced workers and offered to give the empty buildings to the city. Chrysler agreed to level the complex after the city declined.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Higher Following Flurry in Futures Market
DOC.TEXT: Prices advanced on London's Stock Exchange Friday following a late flurry of activity in the stock index futures market. Traders said three major security houses were buying stocks related to the June Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index futures contract, which expired in the morning. At midday, the FT-SE 100 index was up 21.9 points, or 0.9 percent, at 2,377.6. In the futures markets, the June FT-SE 100 index contract expired at 2,379.0, up from its close of 2,357.0 Thursday. Some investors have been attracted by bargains uncovered by the market's slide since Tuesday. Additionally, traders reported some renewed interest in the advantages of Britain's eventual entry into the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System. Volume was 324.1 million shares, compared with 278.5 million shares at the same time on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Monetary Union in Germany Presents a Challenge to World Capital Markets
DOC.TEXT: The dawn of a united German economy with a common currency holds out hope to millions of East Germans, and a challenge to the rest of the world. Sunday's economic and monetary union of the two Germanies should give a big growth spurt to what is already the third-largest capitalist economy in the world, and the powerhouse of Europe. East Germany brings to the union more than 16 million consumers, an educated work force and a gateway to other Eastern European countries that are turning to the West for help in shedding more than 40 years of socialism. ``Germany long-term is one of the most attractive markets I can think of in the 1990s,'' says Heiko Thieme, an analyst at Deutsche Bank Capital Corp. Therein lies the challenge. Germany rivals Japan as the biggest surplus country. Its export earnings have been a critical source of capital for the world economy, especially debtors like the United States. Now, the money will be needed at home to overhaul roads, factories and the social welfare network in the East. Increased German borrowing to meet those needs will drive up interest rates at home, and a sharp reduction in German capital exports could mean higher rates around the globe. David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services Inc., estimates that upgrading East Germany's public infrastructure alone could cost $400 billion to $500 billion. Getting the country's manufacturing and service industries into competitive shape could cost even more, he says. ``The diversion of German excess savings from London, Paris and New York to rebuilding the east will increase the world level of interest rates, not just German borrowing costs,'' Hale says. Long-term German interest rates already have reacted to the expected surge in borrowing. They rose as high as 9 percent this spring from 7 percent when the Berlin Wall fell. Although they have eased slightly to around 8} percent, German rates remain above U.S. rates _ currently ranging around 8{ percent _ for the first time in more than a decade. That trend could persist, says Nicholas Sargen, international fixed-income analyst at Salomon Brothers. German rates are likely to remain in the 9 percent region while U.S. long rates ease toward 8 percent later this year because of the economy's weakness, he predicts. If it weren't for the increased competition from Germany for capital, U.S. rates probably would fall another half percentage point, he says. Reunification heralds a sea-change in global finance in the 1990s, just as the Reagan revolution of the 1980s transformed the United States from the world's biggest creditor into its biggest debtor, Sargen says. The big U.S. budget deficits helped fuel the longest peacetime boom in history. In contrast, Europe in the 1980s was marked by sluggish growth and relatively high unemployment, spawning the term Eurosclerosis. Today's Europe stands to be revitalized by German reunification, the transformation of other Eastern European economies and the creation of a single market in Western Europe in 1992, he says. The debt-hobbled U.S. economy, however, has turned sluggish. ``Europe and the United States basically traded positions,'' Sargen said. ``Europe becomes the most exciting part of the world.'' Deutsche Bank's Thieme also sees better growth prospects for Germany, but he believes concerns about higher interest rates are misplaced. Thieme says German rates reflect a fear that swapping the bulk of East Germany's almost worthless Ost marks for West Germany's strong deutsche mark will fan inflation. That's not likely because the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, is keeping monetary policy tight, he says. What's more, East German labor costs are low and should help restrain inflation while boosting growth, Thieme says. ``The unification is less inflationary. Interest rates will come down worldwide,'' he says. How should the United States compete with the new German juggernaut? By imitation, Thieme says. Mexico, he says, is ``the U.S.'s East Germany.'' A free-trade agreement with Mexico would give the United States access to a market several times larger than East Germany's, and with labor costs that are even lower, he says.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday July 2

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Strike At U.S. Banana Giant Threatens To Spread
DOC.TEXT: Some 60,000 labor federation members threatened to strike today if U.S. banana giant Chiquita Brands International Inc. did not answer its workers' wage hike demands. Chiquita's 10,000 union employees, who are members of the federation, struck for a 60 percent salary increase on Thursday, paralyzing operations. The president of the national legislature, Rodolfo Irias Navas, said the labor unrest could destabilize Honduras, the poorest nation in the hemisphere after Haiti with an annual per capita income of only $740. ``The crisis created by unionism is putting the stability of the government in danger,'' he said in a telephone interview. Workers at Chiquita make an average $15.32 a day, and have not had a raise for six years, while inflation has climbed at 50 percent annually. Their union asked the company for a higher pay in October. Its members include banana cutters, railway workers and administrative personnel. Company officials calculated the raise would cost $4.6 million a year and had not made a counterproposal Thursday after four days of negotiating. ``The strike is illegal; it doesn't make sense. We aren't going to pay higher salaries to our workers,'' Chiquita Vice President Eduardo Aragon said in a telephone interview. Company officials refused to comment further on the strike. The federation to which the union belongs said members of other unions would begin walking off their job today, beginning with 2,000 Texaco refinery workers. The refinery supplies the entire nation. Bananas are Honduras' leading export and the Cincinnati-based Chiquita, formerly United Brands, is one of the most powerful institutions in this nation of 4.8 million people. Other labor groups, including the 600,000-member Workers Confederation, have said they will strike if Chiquita refuses to negotiate. President Rafael Leonardo Callejas was trying Thursday to stop the strike from spreading. He sent a high-level delegation to the northern coastal town of La Lima, headquarters of Chiquita, to mediate talks between union and company officials. He also kept in close telephone contact with union leaders, military officials and key advisers. Callejas said he was sympathetic to the strikers, calling their demands for higher pay just. But he said there was no need for a strike. ``The unions are a fundamental piece of our democratic process,'' he told The Associated Press in a phone interview. ``But with me there is no need to strike because the unions can achieve their goals through dialogue, without resorting to force.'' The strike is the latest _ and potentially most serious _ labor unrest to hit Callejas' 5-month-old administration. About 4,000 health care workers have been on strike since June 11 to protest the privatization of support services in six of the nation's 19 public hospitals. The Honduran Private Enterprise Council aligned itself Thursday with Chiquita. ``The strike is illegal,'' said the council's president, Richard Zablah. ``The government has to decide if we live in a regime of law or of anarchy.'' Chiquita, which owns the country's only railroad, has enjoyed a near monopoly on the banana business here since 1912. It currently controls 60 percent of the bananas exported from Honduras. U.S.-based Castle and Cook controls the other 40 percent. The 70,000-member National Federation of Workers' Unions, Honduras' most powerful labor federation, includes the banana union and the refinery union among its 54 individual unions. Although most of the major labor groups in Honduras proclaimed their solidarity with the federation, the head of the 30,000-member Workers General Central, Felicito Avila, said his people would not join a sympathy strike. He said the current wave of labor unrest was creating a dangerously unstable climate and urged the company to negotiate with the union.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Truckers Protest Taxes, Fuel Costs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with details, protest fizzling. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A planned nationwide protest by Canadian truckers fizzled today when just six dozen trucks quietly lined roads at three border crossings into the United States. The planned blockade was to be the second demonstration in five weeks over high taxes and government policies the truckers say threaten their livelihood. About 45 truckers brought their rigs to a halt at the Ambassador Bridge between Detroit and Windsor, but police said the trucks were off to the side and were not blocking regular traffic. A brief scuffle broke out at 1:30 a.m. between protesters and two American truck drivers who tried to cross the border, but police stepped in and restored order. ``There is nowhere near the number we had last time,'' said Windsor police staff Sgt. Joseph Monteleone. ``They're just sitting there off to one side. Cars can still get back and forth.'' ``If the protest doesn't pick up steam, I would expect a lot of the truckers will go home.'' The drivers say they are losing work to U.S. truckers who pay less for fuel and have lower taxes and insurance costs. The Canadian Transit Company, which owns the Ambassador Bridge, is considering applying for an injunction that would declare the work stoppage illegal and send the truckers on their way. Meanwhile, about 24 trucks parked along the Peace Bridge between Fort Erie, Ontario and Buffalo, N.Y., shortly after midnight. ``They've been coming and going all night,'' said customs official Rick Wellman. ``There are a few on each side of the bridge, and they're asking others to join them.'' Another four trucks showed up at the Queenston-Lewiston bridge in Queenston, Ontario, by about 9 a.m., police said. Despite the truckers' call for a nationwide border protest, no other blockades were reported along the 4,000-mile U.S.-Canadian frontier. Canadian Transport Minister Doug Lewis met with non-union truckers in Ottawa on Wednesday, and later met with three union leaders representing 150,000 unionized truckers. The union leaders agreed to participate with federal and provincial governments and industry leaders in a study of the problems facing the industry. But Wayne Whitney, a leader of the non-union truckers, refused to take part because the study won't be complete until August. ``These truckers don't have that kind of time,'' he said. Whitney said Lewis rejected demands for a reduction in the fuel tax, a five-year tax exemption on new and used equipment, and a shorter depreciation period on rigs for tax purposes.

The stock market edged upward today, bidding to close out the first half of 1990 on a positive note. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 2.97 to 2,881.68 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 6 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 488 up, 413 down and 523 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 20.64 millon shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said many investors remain wary about prospects for second-quarter profit reports due from corporate American over the next several weeks. The figures are expected to show the continuing adverse effects of a sluggish economy. Several large industrial companies have already served notice that their earnings for the April-June period haven't lived up to expectations. DOC.HEAD: Campbell Soup Co. Announces Plans To Sell Businesses
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. announced today a major restructuring plan that will eliminate 3,000 jobs worldwide and includes the sale of U.S. and Canadian fresh foods and fresh produce businesses with combined net sales of more than $300 million. The moves will result in after-tax charges of $247 million against fiscal 1990 net earnings, the company said. Campbell plans to sell its Sumter, S.C. frozen poultry operation, which employs about 1,200 people. It also plans to close plants in Fremont, Neb., with 240 employees; a Pepperidge Farm Inc. plant in Grand Prairie, Texas, with 50 employees; and an equipment manufacturing center in Moorestown, N.J., which employs 51 people. In moves earlier this year, Campbell eliminated about 8,000 jobs. Campbell has faced increasing problems over the past year and has been frequently rumored as a takeover target because of its sluggish performance and depressed stock price. Some members of the founding family have urged a sale of the entire company. The firm has sought to remain independent by divesting underperforming businesses and closing plants, cutting costs and laying off hundreds of workers. The company said in a news release Friday that in addition to selling its U.S. Fresh Foods Group, it also plans to sell or close a number of other facilities and write off goodwill. ``Our strategy for strongly focused growth is exemplified by our decision to concentrate our efforts on hour high-margin dry grocery and frozen foods business,'' said Herbert M. Baum, president of Campbell North America. ``Our decision to exit the fresh foods and fresh produce business is a tough one because of the excellent potential in these businesses, driven by strong consumer trends.'' Campbell said it will sell the Fresh Food Group, which includes Blandon, Pa., Dudley, Ga., Fennville, Mich., Hillsboro, Texas; Howe, Ind., Jackson, Ohio; Pescadero, Calif., and West Chicago, Ill. The company also announced it plans to sell Mrs. Giles refrigerated salads, based in Lynchburg, Ca., and Marie's salad dressings, which has a plant in Thornton, Ill. Also to be sold are Domsea Farms Inc., a processor of salmon based in Pocatello, Idaho; the Win Schuler's cheese business in Marshall, Mich; and the McKellar Watt chilled food operation in Govan, Scotland. The firm recently announced plans to sell D. Lazzaroni & C. SpA of Italy; Campbell Seafoods Division, which operates in the United Kingdom and Belgium; the vegetable division of Campbell Foods PLC in England; and Campbell Irish Foods Ltd. and Mallow Foods Ltd., both of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Defends Abandoning His No-New-Tax Pledge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, new quotes; a longer version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he jettisoned his no-new-taxes campaign pledge in hopes of reaching an accord with the Democrat-controlled Congress on a plan to reduce the deficit and reinvigorate a sluggish economy. ``I knew I'd catch some flak on this decision,'' said Bush, who has been sharply criticized by many lawmakers in his own Republican Party. ``But I've got to do what I think is right.'' Speaking at a White House news conference, Bush said budget talks with congressional leaders are ``a make or break effort at responsible government.'' He said the negotiations are going well and expressed hope there could be an agreement within a few weeks. Bush won the White House in 1988 by campaigning as an ardent foe of new taxes. ``Read my lips, no new taxes,'' was the most memorable line of his successful drive for the presidency. But the president today likened himself to Abraham Lincoln. ``I'll think anew,'' he said, when faced with a deficit he said was worse than ``any of us visualized'' when he made his plegde. Republican congressmen have made it clear they feel betrayed by the president's reversal on a winning campaign issue. ``Arrows have been flying, back, front, sideways, but that's what I get paid for,'' he said. ``I can totally empathize with what they're going through.'' Bush's declaration earlier this week that ``tax revenue increases'' were an essential element of any deficit-reduction package jump-started budget negotiations with Congress. The president spoke shortly before leaving for a brief vacation at Kennebunkport, Maine. Next week, he travels to London for a meeting with NATO leaders, then on to Houston for the annual economic summit of industrialized nations. Asked about a Western package of economic aid for the Soviet Union, Bush cited ``the difficulties we have'' with such a proposal. ``There has got to be economic reform there ... all kinds of changes I believe (Soviet President Mikhail S.) Gorbachev wants to see take place but they have to be in place in order for aid to go forward.'' The president also defended his son Neil, whose connections with a failed Colorado savings and loan have come under scrutiny by federal regulators and congressional investigators. ``I have _ what dad wouldn't _ full confidence in the integrity and honor of my son,'' he said. The news conference was dominated by questions about the volatile tax issue. ``If I had control of this Congress, both houses, we might not even be talking about this today,'' he said. Without a deficit-reduction agreement, Bush said, automatic spending cuts totaling $100 billion could take effect Oct. 1, with ``draconian'' reductions in defense and domestic programs such as student loans. The deficit for next year could total $150 billion, not counting the cost of cleaning up failed S&Ls. In accepting the Republican president nomination in 1988, Bush said: ``And I'm the one who will not raise taxes. ... My opponent won't rule out raising taxes. But I will. ``And the Congress will push me to raise taxes, and I'll say no, and they'll push, and I'll say no, and they'll push again. And I'll say to them: Read my lips. No new taxes.'' Bush was asked how he could have made his no-tax pledge in 1988 when the deficit was already at record levels. ``The budget deficit is bigger, far bigger. I thought I could do a better job of getting spending down,'' he said. Bush refused repeatedly to discuss specific tax increases. ``I'm not saying what's on or off,'' he replied when asked whether he would consider an income tax rate increase. ``I have got strongly held preferences that people are familiar with,'' he said. ``More important than my posturing or protecting from arrows coming from one direction or another is getting a deal that is fair and good for the American people.'' Bush's decision earlier this week was embraced by congressional Democrats, but sharply criticized by many Republican members of Congress. Since Bush issued his statement, negotiators have said their talks have gone well, although few details of the negotiations have been disclosed. Democrats have proposed cuts in the 1991 defense budget five times greater than Bush's original proposal. The two sides also have discussed cuts in politically popular benefit programs such as Medicare and Social Security, accordin to officials involved in the talks.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pledges Not To Interfere With S&L Probe of Son
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Bush comments.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised today not to interfere in thrift regulators' investigation of his son Neil's involvement with a failed savings and loan in Colorado. Citing the thrift crisis as a key reason for his willingness to consider new taxes, Bush also renewed his pledge to pursue vigorously invidivuals guilty of defrauding S&Ls. ``My interest ... is to protect the depositor, put the people that broke the law in jail. ... The size of the savings and loan problem is terrible and we are trying very hard to go after the criminals and to have in place rules and regulations so that this will never happen again,'' he said. The president offered a warm personal assessment of his 34-year-old son. He described Neil Bush as ``probably the most sensitive of the four boys, maybe the second most sensitive'' and expressed ``full confidence in the integrity and honor of my son'' ``I will stay out of anything to do with the investigation, but this is a fine young man,'' he told reporters at a White House news conference. ``I'm convinced that if he's done something wrong, the system will so state. If he hasn't, I hope it's fair enough to say, `Hey, the boy did nothing wrong','' Bush said. ``... The system is going to work, whether it's the president's son or somebody else.'' The president also challenged ``those that allege misconduct ... to speak up and say what it is.'' The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, which is pursuing administrative sanctions against the younger Bush, has so far refused to release its charges against him. Some members of the House Banking Committee have accused him of having a conflict of interest while serving from 1985 to 1988 as a board member of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, Denver. The S&L, which collapsed at a cost of $1 billion to taxpayers, made loans to several of his business partners which were not repaid. Meanwhile, members of Congress, prodded by angry taxpayers, are moving swiftly to give the president even more money than he wants to pursue savings and loan crooks. The House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions voted 45-0 Thursday to endorse legislation authorizing spending of $152 million a year in 1991 and 1992, up from $50 million this year. Subcommittee passage came less than a week after Bush announced at a campaign-style appearance at the Justice Department that he would seek $100 million. However, Democrats immediately branded that amount as ``too little, too late,'' pointing out that the FBI has said it needs another 200 agents and the Justice Department another 100 attorneys. Assistant Attorney General Edward S.G. Dennis Jr., testifying before the vote, refused to endorse the higher amount. But he assured members, ``We can spend it responsibly.'' Republicans went along with the higher amount. The legislation also would make it easier for the government to prosecute S&L fraud and recover swindled money. Meeting beneath a huge banner reading ``Put the S&L Crooks in Jail,'' several panel members said they noticed growing anger among taxpayers about the thrift mess. ``This is an election year,'' Annunzio warned. ``... If you have a challenger, he is going to try to make an issue of the S&L scandal. He is going to try to paint you with a brush. We all are in that same position.'' Republicans noted that the banner had temporarily displaced a portrait of Fernand J. St Germain, D-R.I., former chairman of the House Banking Committee. St Germain was defeated for re-election in 1988 amid allegations that he improperly benefited from investments arranged by savings and loan interests. Dennis, who announced Thursday he was leaving as head of the Justice Department's criminal division to join a Philadelphia law firm, defended the administration's anti-fraud effort. He noted that since 1987 it has convicted 52 S&L defendants in the Dallas area alone. He said 530 failed institutions are under investigation, up from 206 in 1986. Rep. Stephen Neal, D-N.C., countered that the department has received more than 21,000 referrals of suspected fraud cases ``which are just lying there.'' One provision of the legislation sent to the full Banking Committee would require the Justice Department to investigate half of the cases by the end of this year and all of them by the end of 1991. Other provisions would: _Create a new federal crime: concealing assets from banking regulators. _Authorize prosecutors to seek court-approved wiretaps to investigate bank fraud. _Allow regulators to undo personal asset transfers by white-collar criminals trying to avoid liability for abuses at financial institutions. _Permit regulators to revoke or limit ``golden parachute'' contracts that provide lucrative severance packages to executives of failed institutions. _Give courts power to appoint a trustee to oversee the assets of individuals accused of fraud. That is aimed at preventing them from dissipating the money before a judge can order them to repay the government. _Prevent bankruptcy courts from discharging debts owed to the government by individuals who caused financial institution losses. _In fraud cases, override state laws that allow individuals just saying what's _ what we my _ you know, what's _ everything's on the table. We may have to do something here. And _ but if I were going to go back and say, ``Do it my way,'' we'd figure out a way that would be somewhat less controversial than this approach has been. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says New Tax Stance Reflects New Look at Deficit Problem
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 5 grafs Bush remarks on the budget talks; picks up 2nd graf pvs, House Budget...
DOC.TEXT: Congressional and White House budget negotiators resumed bargaining today in what President Bush described as a ``make or break effort'' to reduce the deficit. In a 40-minute news conference, Bush told reporters the negotiations are going well and expressed hope there could be an agreement within a few weeks. ``Things are moving,'' he said. The president defended his remarks Tuesday that ``tax revenue increases'' were needed to reduce the deficit, saying, ``What I consider it is a necessary step to get stalled budget negotiations moving.'' Bush called the talks with congressional leaders ``a make or break effort at responsible government.'' He spoke a day after Democratic budget negotiators suggested dramatic cuts in Pentagon spending that would be more than five times deeper than the reductions Bush prefers. House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta offered a plan on Thursday to limit the 1991 defense budget to about $290 billion. No decisions were made at the budget summit, which resumes today. The plan would cut defense spending next year $16 billion below what it would need to keep pace with inflation. The 1991 budget Bush presented in January cut military expenditures by $3 billion. ``We're convinced the situation in Eastern Europe is continuing to move in a progressive way toward peace,'' argued Panetta, D-Calif., after Thursday's bargaining session between congressional leaders and administration officials. ``In addition, the deficit situation is spinning out of control.'' Republicans said the cut would be much too deep. ``I truly believe it is way too draconian and can't be achieved,'' said a GOP negotiator, Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico. The reduction would surpass the $13 billion in defense cuts approved last month by the Senate Budget Committee and the $11.5 billion in military reductions passed by the House. Panetta said that to achieve the suggested savings, he would rely more heavily on cuts in weapons systems, Pentagon management and other overhead, and combat readiness than the administration prefers. As they were discussing defense cuts, budget negotiators from the Bush admiistration and Congress received added pressure Thursday in the form of a warning from Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. In a letter to congressional leaders, Brady warned that the government's authority to borrow money will have to be renewed before lawmakers recess for their August break. The federal debt is currently about $3.1 trillion. The government expects to spend about $176 billion this year on interest payments on that borrowing, about 17 percent of the federal budget. Legislation extending the government's borrowing authority, though routine, must be passed because the alternative is a first-time ever government default. The measure is considered an excellent vehicle to which any budget pact could be attached, thereby making it difficult for members to vote against. Negotiators would like to finish their work in time to attach it to the debt limit bill.

DOC.HEAD: Fiero Recalls Scheduled
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. has announced a four-month schedule for recalling 308,000 Pontiac Fieros to install parts designed to reduce the risk of engine fires. GM discontinued the Fiero in 1988. The automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in December it would recall the plastic-bodied, mid-engined cars because of engine fire problems. The automaker said Thursday it will begin notifying owners next month. Notification will be sent in July to owners of 1984 four-cylinder models; in August to owners of 1985-88 six cylinder models; in September to owners of 1985-86 four-cylinder models; and in October to owners of 1987-88 four-cylinder models, Pontiac said. The company said the repairs would be performed free of charge. The 308,000 cars are the number believed still registered, Pontiac spokesman Reg Harris said. The company built 328,000 Fieros from their introduction in July 1983 as a 1984 model to their demise at the end of the 1988 model year. Harris said 1,451 fires have been reported in the cars, 100 involving minor injuries. Dealers will make changes to prevent oil or other engine fluids from spilling on hot exhaust system parts. Also, four-cylinder cars made in 1984-86 will have new exhaust manifolds installed, similar to manifolds made standard on later models. The company urged owners to carefully monitor oil levels in the meantime, as described in owners' manuals of six-cylinder models and in special booklets mailed last fall to owners of four-cylinder models. Owners should have the cars checked immediately if they notice overheating, vibration or power loss, Harris said. In 1987, GM recalled 125,000 four-cylinder Fieros produced in the 1984 model year for alterations that included boosting oil capacity to four quarts from three. The company also urged owners to check the engine oil every time they bought gas.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Surge In Report Reaction
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices surged this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade amid active buying in reaction to a reduction in the Agriculture Department's estimate of soybean planted acreage. Corn and wheat futures were mostly lower in early trading. In a report released after Thursday's close of the market, the USDA pegged soybean plantings at 58 million acres, about 1.4 million acres below the agency's March projection and 1.6 acres below trade expectations. The USDA also lowered its corn acreage estimate by 200,000 acres to a higher-than-expected 74.6 million, reflecting planting delays caused by heavy spring rains in the Midwest. Many analysts had expected a corresponding increase in soybean acres to show that some farmers unable to plant corn switched to soybeans. William Biedermann, research director with the futures brokerage Allendale Inc., said the report's underlying survey, which was conducted during the first two weeks of June, might have been done too early to reflect the expected shift from corn to soybeans. At any rate, he said, crop production ultimately will depend on weather more than plantings. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 2} cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.28\ a bushel; corn futures were 1} cents lower to 1{ cents higher with July at $2.93{ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to { cent higher with July at $1.35{ a bushel; soybeans were 9\ cents to 11 cents higher with July at $6.17 a bushel. Cattle futures were lower but pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .03 cent to .20 cent lower with August at 72.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent to .35 cent lower with August at 84.07 cents a pound; live hogs were .02 cent to .18 cent higher with July at 60.67 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .30 cent lower to .55 cent higher with July at 59.50 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Says Claris Software Will Become Wholly-Owned Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: Claris Corp., Apple Computer Inc.'s software operation, will become a wholly owned, independent subsidiary of the personal computer maker, Apple Chairman John Sculley announced Friday. Claris, which develops and markets software for Apple's popular Macintosh and Apple II computers, has been a majority-owned subsidiary of Apple since April 1987, when Apple spun off its applications software operations to form Claris. At the time, Apple said it retained the option to turn Claris into a publicly owned company or to return the subsidiary to full Apple ownership. ``Software will increasingly become the factor which shapes competitive advantage in the 1990s,'' said Sculley, who also serves as Apple's chief executive officer. ``With that in mind, we have established a new, expanded role for Claris, which will become an important foundation for Apple in the future.'' Sculley said Claris will focus on three main areas: _Continued development and marketing of its applications software. _Development and marketing of extensions to Apple's system software, which controls a computer's basic operations, such as responding to keyboard commands and organizing files. _Development and marketing of products that link Macintosh with other computing environments. Claris will remain independent and maintain separate facilities and personnel. William V. Campbell, CEO of Claris, will report to Sculley.
