DOC.HEAD: Bush Vetoes Parental Leave Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 6th graf pvs, ``If our ...,'' and ADDS 3 grafs to UPDATE with reaction. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today vetoed a bill that would guarantee workers as much as 12 weeks unpaid leave for childbirth, adoption or family illness. ``I strongly object ... to the federal government mandating leave policies for America's employers and work force,'' Bush said, setting the stage for a major confrontation with Congress. In a written statement before leaving for a vacation, Bush said parental leave is an important benefit for employers to offer workers. However, he said, ``We must insure that federal policies do not stifle the creation of new jobs, nor result in the elimination of existing jobs.'' The issue of parental leave is a politically charged one. The Republican sponsor of the bill that Bush vetoed, Rep. Marge Roukema of New Jersey, has said it is a ``bedrock family issue'' that could backfire on Republicans. In vetoing the bill, Bush said America faces its stiffest economic competition ever. ``If our nation's employers are to succeed in an increasingly complex and competitive global marketplace, they must have the felxibility to meet both this challenge and the needs of their employees,'' he said. Judith Lichtman, president of the Women's Legal Defense Fund and head of a coalition of groups that lobbied for the bill, said: ``I'm stunned by the cynicism that this veto reveals. President Bush doesn't care about American families. He really only cares about big business.'' It was Bush's 13th veto. To date, Congress has not been able to muster enough votes to override him. The bill passed comfortably in the House, although the margin fell 46 votes short of the two-thirds majority that would be needed to override a veto. Senate passage came without a recorded vote. Sponsor Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said he was ``within two or three votes'' of a two-thirds majority. The new legislation would require business and government employers to provide workers with up to 12 weeks of unpaid medical leave or with leave so they could care for a newly born or adopted child or an ill child, parent or spouse. Employers would have to continue health coverage and then restore a returning employee to his or her previous job or an equivalent position. Ms. Lichtman said Bush seemed to support such family leave provisions during his presidential campaign. ``I held out hope he meant what he said in the campaign and he really did want to do something,'' she said. She said supporters still hoped they could muster the required votes in the House to override Bush's veto.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuelan Oil Monopoly Doesn't Deny Reports It Wants To Leave OPEC
DOC.TEXT: The state oil monopoly Petroleos de Venezuela S.A. said Friday it was obeying OPEC quotas, but did not explicitly deny reports that it was pressing the government to take Venezuela out of OPEC. ``PDVSA complies, and will continue to comply at all times, with the guidelines of oil policy laid down, or that will be laid down, by the national government,'' said a five-line statement faxed to The Associated Press. The daily El Nacional newspaper reported Friday that PDVSA wants Venezuela to leave the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Officials of the government party, Democratic Action, confirmed to the AP that PDVSA President Andres Sosa Pietri met with the party's excutive national committee Tuesday and told them that OPEC quotas were ``against Venezuela's best interests.'' At the meeting, Sosa Pietri said there was no reason why Venezuela should continue to follow OPEC since other cartel members were flouting them openly, according to the sources, who asked to remain anonymous. So far, there have been no comments from the Energy and Mines Ministry. Both Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez and Energy Minister Celestino Armas are staunch OPEC supporters. But PDVSA executives have been chafing under OPEC quotas for months, complaining that they hamper the Venezuelan oil industry's expansion. Increasingly, PDVSA executives have said, sometimes not so privately, that Venezuela should not respect quotas if other OPEC members are openly violating them.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close in Europe, midday prices in New York.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell against most major foreign currencies Friday in thin European trading after confirmation by U.S. President George Bush that taxes must be raised to help offset the nation's budget deficit. Gold prices were mixed in quiet trading. Dealers said the dollar's biggest decline was against the Japanese yen, which has been gaining in favor, thanks to firmer Japanese money-market rates, they said. The U.S. currency did not fall significantly against most European currencies, traders said, reflecting the market's continued jitters over German monetary union scheduled to take effect Sunday. Some traders are unconvinced that new U.S. taxes and a reduced budget deficit will mean lower U.S. interest rates, since other countries, such as West Germany and Britain, currently have higher interest rates. ``Internationally the U.S. can't afford to cut rates right now,'' said Jeff Earnshaw, deputy head of strategic trading at National Westminster Bank in London. As a result of the conflicting views, the absence of any concrete news on interest rates and the general uncertainties over broader fundamental trends in Europe and elsewhere, dealers said it is possible the dollar will continue range trading in the near term. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 152.85 Japanese yen from 154.42 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 152.30 yen, and in New York at midday, it was quoted at 152.275 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.7450 from $1.7400 late Thursday. In New York sterling was quoted at $1.74625. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.6653 West German marks, down from 1.6675; 1.4155 Swiss francs, up from 1.4125; 5.5945 French francs, down from 5.6015; 1.8737 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8772; 1,222.50 Italian lire, down from 1,224.25; and 1.1657 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1692. Other midday dollar rates in New York included: 1.6725 West German marks; 1.4145 Swiss francs; 1,222.00 Italian lire; and 1.16625 Canadian dollars. Bullion dealers said trading was listless with traders reluctant to take on new positions at the end of the month. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $353.25 a troy ounce, up from $352.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $352 from $352.60. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.40 to close at a bid $352.74. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $4.84 a troy ounce, down from $4.85 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Coffee Plant to Produce $211 Million in Economic Benefits
DOC.TEXT: An extra $211 million a year will flow into the Jacksonville area because of Maxwell House's decision to expand its plant here, a University of North Florida researcher says. Maxwell House ``is part of the star of the crown of the city's economic base,'' Louis Woods, associate professor of economics and geography at UNF, said Thursday. The coffee company announced Wednesday it was closing its plant in Hoboken, N.J., and expanding production at the Jacksonville plant by 40 percent. The company had announced several months ago that one of the two plants would close. Woods said the expansion will contribute $185 million more each year to industries that support the plant, such as transportation and longshoremen, while $26 million more will go to household incomes in northern Florida. In addition to the 50 new workers estimated at the plant, Woods said the expansion would bring another 1,300 spinoff jobs. The expansion involves a $30 million construction program, with a one-time $62 million injection into the local economy, Woods said. He said the construction phase is expected to create 1,110 jobs. Increasing production at the plant is expected to increase the amount of coffee beans moving through the port each year from 165 million pounds to 270 million pounds, said Gary Loveless, president of First Coast Manufacturers Association. The association was one of the backers of the ``Keep Max in Jax'' campaign aimed at convincing Phillip Morris Cos., the parent company, to choose Jacksonville over Hoboken.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Raises Car Prices
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler will raise prices on most of its 1990 passenger cars effective Monday, the No. 3 automaker said Friday. The company said suggested retail prices increases start at $60 for Dodge Daytona cars, which will have a base price of $9,805, and most Chrysler LeBarons, which will rise to about $12,555. The biggest planned increases are $160 on on Chrysler Fifth Avenue and Chrysler Imperial cars, bringing their base prices to $21,020 and $25,655. Destination charges also will increase, by $15 on most models and by $30 on Fifth Avenue and Imperial cars, Chrysler said. The company said the prices were increased to cover increased operating costs. Prices will not increase on Plymouth Sundance, Dodge Shadow, Eagle Premier and Dodge Monaco cars, and destination charges won't change on the Premier and Monaco, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: London Share Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose Friday as the successful completion of the June Financial Times 100 stock index contract was well received by the market. Dealers said there was some trepidation during the day that the contract's end would bring a wave of volatility to the market. But the close of the contract was well absorbed by the cash market, and the coming weekend and close of the quarter sent many players from the market. Most dealers said trading conditions were slack, as the bulk of business was conducted earlier in the day. At the close, the broad-based 100-share index was up 18.9 points, or 0.80 percent, at 2,374.6. At the final calculation, the narrower Financial Times 30-share index was up 12.1 points at 1,899.9. Volume was 461.9 million shares, compared with 448.1 million issues a day ago. The Financial Times 500-share index closed up 8.30 at 1,286.22. DOC.NOTE: $adv02
For release PMs Monday July 2
DOC.HEAD: Who Causes Inflation? Why The Fed Does
DOC.TEXT: Congress is considering a resolution that would direct the Federal Reserve to reduce inflation gradually to zero. But, says a critic, there is a major defect in the effort. The defect, says Richard W. Rahn, is that the resolution would, so to speak, appoint the fox to guard the chicken coop. The Federal Reserve, he says, is the cause of inflation, not its cure. Rahn doesn't equivocate. To him the issue is clear: ``The central bank, and only the central bank, causes inflation,'' and as you probably know, the Fed is the central bank of the United States. You might perceive something convoluted in such thinking, but oddly, says critic Rahn, the convoluted thinking is the conventional thinking. ``The whole notion that the central bank should be the economy's designated inflation fighter has the world upside down,'' says Rahn, whose professional position might suggest he is a defender rather than critic of convention. Rahn is vice president and chief economist of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. In testimony on House Joint Resolution 409, to establish price stability as a national objective, Rahn instructed Congress that the nation has a fiat money system controlled by government and ``outside the control of the rule of law.'' Government, he said, retains a monopoly over money by spending it and then forcing the Fed to accommodate the spending by manipulating the money supply and attempting to keep it from inflating the market economy. ``I believe that as long as the government maintains a monopoly over money and relies on an unaccountable, government central bank to manage that monopoly, inflation will persist,'' he told members of Congress. In seeking to accommodate that government spending, he said, the Fed ``whipsaws the economy between inflation and recession'' rather than pursuing a long-term policy consistent with stable economic growth. ``Sustained inflation is always a monetary phenomenon, and trends in the real economy, when divorced from changes in monetary growth, have little bearing on past, present and future inflation,'' he said. In short, if government kept spending in check, and if the Fed didn't feel compelled to accomodate that spending, there'd be no inflation. You could detect additional outrage in Rahn's testimony. Fed board members, he remarked, are ``political appointees who, once appointed, are left unaccountable for their decisions.'' When they testify before Congress, he said, they are sometimes ``purposely vague,'' even given to misinformation. In economics, statistics speak. The wholesale price index, Rahn said, stayed generally level from 1795 to 1913. Then what happened? In that year the Federal Reserve was established. From then until 1951, when the Fed became fully independent, the rate doubled. By last year, said Rahn, the rate had increased nine-fold from 1913. The fact of the matter, said Rahn, is that monetary policy _ call it Fed policy _ ``cannot offset, fine-tune, counter-balance or reserve the adverse economic effects of improper fiscal and regulatory policy.'' If Congress spends and borrows too much, the economy must pay the price in under-investment, reduced output and increased unemployment, he said. Fed policy, he said, ``can do nothing to shelter the economy...'' When the Fed seeks to counteract these policy mistakes, he said, it merely exacerbates the consequences. ``Inflation will be the direct result and then, ultimately, a recession will be induced as the Fed further reacts to the inflation it created by its original attempt to offset bad policy.'' Rahn would establish a monetary rule to limit Fed discretion and govern monetary policy; require that Fed policy be set and implemented in public _ not behind closed doors; and limit its authority in foreign currency markets. Moreover, so that monetary policy wouldn't gyrate to accommodate government overspending, he would commit Congress to restrain spending to no more than the inflation rate.

DOC.HEAD: Quarterly Loss Widens to $80 million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollars are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian corporate parent of the Federated and Allied department store companies Friday reported a loss of $80 million for the first quarter, up sharply from a $67 million shortfall a year earlier. The quarterly deficit for the distressed Campeau Corp. came after a huge deterioration in its financial condition last year. Toronto-based Campeau lost $1.7 billion in 1989 after losing $34 million in 1988. Campeau said the bankruptcy filing by Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. in January impaired revenue growth. The Cincinnati divisions, which operate strings of U.S. department stores including Bloomingdale's, Burdines, Jordan Marsh and others, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code on Jan. 15. Revenue from Campeau's department store operations was virtually flat at $1.59 billion in the three months ended April 30 compared to $1.6 billion in 1989's first quarter. Total first-quarter revenue for Campeau amounted to $2.26 billion, up 1.3 percent from a year earlier's $2.23 billion. The total included revenue from Campeau's real estate operations as well as from Ralphs Grocery Co., a West Coast supermarket chain that is not part of the bankruptcy case. Ralphs, which added 10 supermarkets during 1989 and completed 38 major remodeling projects, was the star performer for Campeau in the first quarter. It had an 8.4 percent quarterly revenue gain to $621 million from $573 million. Campeau's real estate revenue shrank to $50 million in the first quarter from $59 million. In a separate announcement Friday, Allied said it has reached agreement with Chemical Banking Corp. on new credit arrangements, giving it continued access to capital to finance operations while it reorganizes under court supervision. One of the two arrangements provides for borrowing power up to $700 million over three years. It will enable Allied to raise money through the commercial paper market, marking the first time a company in Chapter 11 has tapped this market, Allied said. The other arrangement extends an existing $300 million working capital financing agreement for two years, until May 5, 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Grain Farmers Raising Shrimp On The Prairie
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It was too hot and dry to grow corn and soybeans in 1988, so farmers Charles Kerchenfaut and Rob Read decided to raise shrimp on the prairie. More than 3,000 freshwater shrimp now comb the bottom of a 1,000-gallon tank to forage for commercial feed, or hide from their cannibalistic cousins in a homemade ``shrimp condo'' structure. ``It's just a research project right now,'' said Kerchenfaut. ``We've got to learn it before we can make a profit.'' But two, who are longtime friends and neighbors, have harvested about 300 shrimp up to six inches long and sold them to pet shops for use in aquariums. The shrimp sell for $5 to $7 each retail, but the men declined to say how much they receive wholesale. ``If we get the volume, it would be nice eventually to supply the food market _ most shrimp now come from overseas,'' said Read. ``We could hit the organic market _ these shrimp are 100 percent pure, raised in water without any toxins.'' The men said they got into shrimp production out of curiosity and because they had little else to do during the 1988 drought. Read raises grain on 2,800 acres with his brother; Kerchenfaut farms 1,200 acres. The green, plastic tank where the shrimp are raised is inside an old garage on Kerchenfaut's farm in Ford County, in east-central Illinois. Water is filtered continuously to remove waste; temperature and oxygen levels are monitored; feed is added twice daily; water quality is tested daily. The farming begins when week-old shrimp are shipped in plastic bags from suppliers in places like Puerto Rico and Hawaii. ``They're small,'' said Read. ``Pull out an eyelash _ that's what they'd be like.'' They do not grow at the same rate, but in three to four months many have reached market size _ several inches in length. One of the biggest challenges the men faced was the lack of information about raising freshwater shrimp in tanks. They read everything they could find about shrimp and called other producers and researchers. ``We spent about $1,000 on equipment,'' said Read. ``The phone bills were probably our biggest expense.'' Read visited scientists at Southern Illinois University, where Chris Kohler is conducting research at the Fisheries Research Laboratory to develop better feed and better ways for producers to raise shrimp. ``Just about all the shrimp you eat are marine (salt water) shrimp,'' Kohler said. ``The freshwater shrimp often are called prawn. I think they are quite tasty, and they bring a premium price.'' The farmers learned that shrimp are cannibalistic, hence adequate commercial feed and the condos for vulnerable molting shrimp to hide from the others. They also learned that temperatures below 62 degrees are fatal to shrimp, so when electricity was lost during the February ice storm, a generator was used to heat the shrimp building. ``The house was cold but the shrimp were warm,'' Kerchenfaut chuckled. Neither man has sampled the shrimp but Read says he plans ``to get one pretty quick.'' They are considering a summer cookout for neighbors, featuring home-grown sweet corn and shrimp. ``A lot of our neighbors are curious about what we're doing,'' said Read. ``I suppose some of them just think we're nuts.'' Not the local chapter of Future Farmers of America. Adviser Richard Long, who teaches at Ford Central High School, said about 35 FFA members will raise freshwater shrimp next fall. Kerchenfaut and Read will share their experiences.

DOC.NOTE: $adv02
For release Monday July 2
DOC.HEAD: England-France Tunnel Halfway There Despite Problems
LaserPhoto LON23 of June 26; Graphic
DOC.TEXT: It's been described as the largest current civil engineering project, a multibillion dollar link that will help revolutionize Europe's economy and physically end Britain's historic isolation, a dream born in Napoleon's day. The ``Chunnel'' between Britain and France is half-dug and scheduled to open on time in three years. But the three-tunnel thoroughfare under the English Channel is almost 60 percent over budget, embroiled in a contractor dispute and scrambling for more investment money. The project also has raised increasing hostility among many Britons, who fear it will provide an easy conduit for ills from the continent ranging from terrorism to rabid animals. ``We will have the money to finish the project,'' says Alastair Morton, British deputy chairman of Eurotunnel, the privately owned Anglo-French company overseeing the work. The Chunnel's June 15, 1993 scheduled debut will come six months after the 12-nation European Community formally drops remaining trade barriers and becomes a unified marketplace of 320 million consumers. But the project's success hinges on much more than just finishing the undug part. While the French are forging ahead with a high-speed rail link to their end of the tunnel, for example, state-owned British Rail is dragging. ``Britain becomes branch line of Europe,'' a Guardian newspaper headline declared after the government announced June 14 that it would not fund a high-speed rail link between London and the British end of the tunnel. It's not the first time the idea of a tunnel has irritated Britain's island identity. The British resisted an undersea bond with the continent envisioned nearly 200 years ago by a French engineer named Albert Mathieu. Napoleon wanted to build it but Britain warned him off. Tunneling actually was started in subsequent efforts in 1882 and 1974 but they were scrapped. The Chunnel project also has been marred by eight accidental deaths on the site. The British public demonstrates little enthusiasm for the Chunnel. Random samplings elicit fears that it will import rabies, terrorists, invading armies. ``There is an attitude in France that this is a great project in the national interest. In this country, the attitude to these projects tends to be the reverse,'' Morton told a recent news conference. Eurotunnel Chairman Andre Benard said the company has provided for any foreseeable problems, but stressed: ``We always made it very clear that this was a risk project.'' Giant boring machines are digging three tunnels toward each other from Folkestone, England and Calais, France, with the first underground meeting expected in November in the service tunnel between the rail tunnels. Tunneling is three months ahead of schedule on the French side, a week behind on the British. As of mid-June, workers had dug 53.2 of the total 91.9 miles. Chunnel trains will carry passengers, cars and freight between London and Paris in about three hours, roughly the same time as a flight including ground travel, and at least twice as fast as a car-ferry journey. Eurotunnel estimates that 28 million passengers and 17 percent of Britain's non-oil trade will pass through the tunnel in the first year. The Civil Aviation Authority says the tunnel should divert 5 million out of 53 million air passengers annually. This past Wednesday, shareholders approved a sale of an extra $906 million worth of stock to existing shareholders, who already have bought $1.7 billion worth. That step could clear the way for a bank syndicate's approval of additional credit Eurotunnel has requested, from $8.6 billion to $12 billion. Assuming banks approve, the project would have a total of about $14.6 billion in debt and equity financing. The company most recently estimated it would cost $13.1 billion to complete, vs. $8.3 billion forecast initially. ``History dictates that that will not be the last figure we hear. But the order of magnitude of increase will slow down,'' said Richard Hannah, a transport analyst with the London investment firm UBS Phillips and Drew. He expected the extra financing to come through. ``It's one of these situations where the more money you put in, the more you have to spend or else you're walking away from billions of pounds,'' Hannah said. Eurotunnel says it doesn't expect to p end of the century, and probably won't pay shareholders a dividend until 1999, four years later than envisioned. But stockholders haven'rofit before thet fared badly: The shares, first traded in November 1987 at about $6, have traded recently at $8.55. The more urgent worries for Eurotunnel have been costs, creditors and contractor feuds. In October, concern about the rising pricetag drove Eurotunnel's banking syndicate to freeze funds for three months until the company reached a truce with Trans-Manche Link, the consortium of 10 British and French contractors doing the construction, over responsibility for $1.7 billion in overruns. The problems led to Eurotunnel's second management shakeup since 1987. The British government's refusal to finance a rail link has presented another big obstacle. Eurotunnel says is can survive without a new link. But cnt that she won't spend taxpayers' money on a rail link. The French government, on the contrary, is spending roughly $2.8 billion building 210 miles of rail from Paris to the tunnel, with a branch to Brussels, where the EC is headquartered. Trains capable of 190 mph will link the tunnel's freight and passengers to another planned high-speed system. One reason the French are enthusiastic is that the tunnel surfaces in one of the most depressed areas of France. On the other hand, residents of Kent, in England's rural and prosperous Southeast, have campaigned strenuously against having high-speed trains screaming through their back yards.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Surge After Bullish Crop Report
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices climbed sharply Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade in the wake of an Agriculture Department report that unexpectedly reduced the government's estimate of soybean plantings. Corn futures ended narrowly mixed while most wheat futures retreated. In a report released after Thursday's close, the USDA pegged soybean plantings at 58 million acres, about 1.4 million acres below the agency's March projection and 1.6 million below trade expectations. The USDA also lowered its corn acreage estimate by 200,000 acres to a higher-than-expected 74.6 million, reflecting planting delays caused by heavy spring rains in the Midwest. Many analysts had expected the USDA to report a corresponding increase in soybean acres, confirming trade perceptions that farmers unable to plant corn had switched to soybeans. The soybean rally also reflected some private forecasters' predictions that hot, dry weather will move into the Corn Belt late next week. ``People were talking about putting a premium into the beans, just in case we have a drought this summer,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. At the close, wheat futures were 4} cents lower to 4 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.25} a bushel; corn futures were \ cent lower to 1 cent higher with July at $2.96 a bushel; oats were 1\ cents lower to { cent higher with July at $1.35{ a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 18} cents higher with July at $6.24 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Northern Telecom To Launch Hungarian Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: Northern Telecom will break into the Eastern European market Sunday as it launches a joint venture to manufacture and market digital telephone switching systems in Hungary. Under an agreement with BHG Telecommunication of Budapest and Austria Telecommunication Ges. m.b.h., Northern Telecom will provide technology for upgrading the Hungarian public telephone network and private systems. Northern Telecom Ltd., a Canadian company based in Toronto, is a major telephone equipment maker. Its extensive U.S. operations are based in Nashville. ``This is the first direct investment into an Eastern European country (for Northern Telecom),'' company spokesman Jeff Benson said Friday. Under the joint venture, the partners will market products that will be manufactured at a BHG Telecommunication plant in Budapest. Richard Lowe, a spokesman for Northern Telecom World Trade, said it is difficult to say how much will be invested in the venture. ``It will initially be a marketing function that will eventually expand into manufacturing,'' Lowe said. Switching systems are specialized computers that connect and switch phone lines. Benson said the Hungarian phone system consists largely of analog switching systems, an outdated technology that is being replaced by digital, or computer-language, switches. ``Their rather creaky national telecommunications system is currently comprised of equipment dating back to the 1950s and 60s,'' Benson said.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Confidence Declined in June, Survey Shows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT; Time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Consumer confidence declined significantly in June according to a monthly survey conducted by the Conference Board, the business group said Thursday. The group said its consumer confidence index for June stood at 102.5 percent, down almost five points from May. The year 1985 represents 100 in the index, which is based on survey responses. ``The drop in confidence primarily reflects increasing concern about jobs,'' said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center. ``Over the past three months, a growing number of people have reported that jobs are hard to get and there has been rising uneasiness about job opportunities in the immediate future,'' Linden said in a statement. Fewer than 24 percent of the survey participants reported that jobs were ``plentiful,'' a 3 percentage point loss from May. In addition, those who fear there will be fewer jobs over the next six months outnumber those who expect more jobs, continuing a pattern of the past few months, Linden said. ``Still, while the measure of consumer confidence is now lower than it has been in more than 2{ years, there are no indications of impending recession,'' Linden said. The board's survey of 5,000 U.S. households is conducted by National Family Opinion Inc. of Toledo, Ohio. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Soup Co. To Sell More Businesses
Graphic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. said Friday it would sell its U.S. and Canadian fresh foods and fresh produce businesses, closing or selling a score of plants in a strategy of focusing on the company's more profitable units. The restructuring _ the third in the past year _ affects about 3,000 jobs and includes the sale of businesses with annual revenue of more than $300 million. The moves will result in after-tax charges of $247 million against net income for the fiscal year ending July 29, although the company did not say whether it would post an overall profit for the year. ``We are clearing the decks of unprofitable and non-strategic businesses, while bringing our plant capacity more in line with manufacturing requirements,'' Campbell chief executive officer David W. Johnson said in a news release. Campbell stock jumped $1.37{ a share to $57.87{ in late New York Stock Exchange trading. Pavlos M. Alexandrakis, an analyst with Argus Research in New York, said the restructuring was no surprise on Wall Street. He noted that Johnson was brought in from Gerber Products Co. in January because of his experience in turning around beleaguered companies. Campbell's sluggish recent performance and depressed stock price have made it the target of frequent takeover rumors. Some members of the founding Dorrance family, which owns a major stake, have urged a sale of the entire company. Campbell posted a profit of $13.1 million, or 10 cents a share, in fiscal 1989, down from $274.1 million, or $2.12 per share, a year earlier largely because of previous restructuring costs. Revenue rose to $5.67 billion in fiscal 1989 from $4.87 billion. The company has tried to remain independent by divesting underperforming businesses and by closing plants, cutting costs and laying off hundreds of workers. In moves earlier this year, Campbell eliminated about 8,000 jobs. ``David Johnson is doing what he has to keep the company independent,'' said John M. McMillin, a food industry analyst with Prudential-Bache in New York. ``He's selling off the bad pieces of Campbell and trying to earn more with the good pieces.'' Campbell has been described as a laggard in the food industry, slow to update facilities and products. The company's dominance in the soup market has dropped in recent years and Campbell has struggled to gain an upper hand in the fast-growing dry soup market. ``Our strategy for strongly focused growth is exemplified by our decision to concentrate our efforts on our high-margin dry grocery and frozen foods business,'' said Herbert M. Baum, president of Campbell North America. Baum said it was a tough decision to exit the fresh foods and fresh produce businesses because they had strong potential. However, those businesses were not yet profitable enough to keep. The Fresh Food Group to be sold includes facilities in Blandon, Pa., Dudley, Ga., Fennville, Mich., Hillsboro, Texas; Howe, Ind., Jackson, Ohio; Pescadero, Calif., and West Chicago, Ill. The company also announced it plans to sell Mrs. Giles refrigerated salads, based in Lynchburg, Calif., and Marie's salad dressings, which has a plant in Thornton, Ill. Campbell plans to sell its Sumter, S.C., frozen poultry operation, which employs about 1,200 people. It plans to close plants in Fremont, Neb., with 240 employees; a Pepperidge Farm Inc. plant in Grand Prairie, Texas, with 50 employees; and an equipment manufacturing center in Moorestown, N.J., which employs 51 people. Also to be sold are Domsea Farms Inc., a salmon processor based in Pocatello, Idaho; the Win Schuler's cheese business in Marshall, Mich; and the McKellar Watt chilled food operation in Govan, Scotland. Campbell also said it was writing off $113 million of goodwill on its Freshbake Foods operations in the United Kingdom. The company announced in January it planned to sell D. Lazzaroni & C. SpA of Italy; Campbell Seafoods Division, which operates in the United Kingdom and Belgium; the vegetable division of Campbell Foods PLC in England; and Campbell Irish Foods Ltd. and Mallow Foods Ltd., both of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: EC Embarks On First Phase Monetary Union But Key Questions Remain
DOC.TEXT:
The 12 nations of the European Community embark Sunday on a plan for economic and monetary union that may eventually lead to a central EC banking system and a single currency. But the road to economic and monetary union, or EMU in EC jargon, will be bumpy. For most EC governments, EMU means one currency, one central bank, one Community-wide monetary policy. To make that palatable to skeptics, notably British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the EMU's final form has been left ambiguous. The EC executive Commission has drafted a three-staged plan. Under the first stage, starting Sunday, the EC nations will more closely coordinate their economic and monetary policies and lift remaining barriers to capital movements. All EC currencies will join the European Monetary Systems's exchange rate regime which limits currency fluctuations. Also, EC states will encourage greater private use of the European currency unit, a quasi-currency now used mainly as an accounting unit in EC budgeting. The next two stages, creation of an EC central bank and a single currency, are uncertain. The EC nations will open talks in December on amending the EC's founding Treaty of Rome. Some questions remain open: _How muchhree-month spree of 155 savings and loan rescues or closings that cost an estimated $29 billion. Slug AM-S&L Bailout. Sent as a0770. By Dave Skidmore.

DOC.TEXT: DeAnza Holding Corp., which owns DeAnza Bank, said Friday it has agreed to be acquired by Citicorp. DeAnza Chairman E. Harrison Williams said New York-based Citicorp agreed to pay DeAnza's shareholders twice the company's book value as of the day the transaction closes. DeAnza's common stock trades in the over-the-counter market. The deal is subject to approval by shareholders and federal banking regulators, Williams said. DeAnza, which has offices in Sunnyvale and Santa Clara, is a state-chartered bank with $35 million in assets. Citicorp has $230 billion in assets.

DOC.HEAD: Mergers Move Into Post-Junk Bond Phase
With BC-Mergers-Deals
DOC.TEXT: They say the takeover boom is over, but if that's so, how do you explain Philip Morris Cos.' decision to buy Swiss candy maker Jacobs Suchard for $3.8 billion or ConAgra Inc.'s $1.34 billion purchase of Beatrice Co.? Easy: The mergers and acquisitions business hasn't died, it has evolved into another stage. Dealmakers are doing a new kind of buyout, one that harks back to the days before the junk bond binge but has a few novel twists. If you ask investment bankers about the deals they're doing these days, two words keep surfacing: strategic and global. Philip Keevil, a managing director at S.G. Warburg & Co., the U.S. arm of the British investment firm, says it has been swamped in recent months, handling ``mostly transactions that are started by strategic acquirers.'' In a strategic deal, a company seeks to expand through acquisition of a firm in a similar or related industry. This is a far cry from the buyouts that dominated the merger wave of the 1980s because they are undertaken by companies interested in running a business, not investors looking for quick profits. Strategic transactions also differ from the megadeals of the '80s because they do not involve the sale of the risky junk bonds that helped finance _ and in some cases, undermine _ big buyouts. The acquiring companies are putting up much more equity to finance their transactions. So far, the biggest deals of 1990 have been strategic. When food giant ConAgra bought Beatrice, it picked up well-known labels including Swift's meats, Butterball turkeys and Wesson oil. Philip Morris, another food company, found a candy maker in Jacobs Suchard that would broaden its base. Even some recent hostile bids were strategic, including Georgia Pacific Corp.'s $5 billion purchase of rival paper producer Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., and Torchmark Inc.'s failed $6.34 billion offer for another insurance and financial services company, American General Corp. The emphasis on strategic moves is similar to the late 1970s and early 1980s, before junk bonds came into vogue. Most of the deals done in the old days were by firms looking for opportunities to expand. Now they want to expand not only in their own countries, but overseas. Today's market is global, and more acquisitions are what dealmakers call ``cross-border'' transactions. Among Warburg's recent deals was Reckitt and Colman PLC's purchase of the Boyle-Midway division of American Home Products Corp. for $1.25 billion. Reckitt and Colman, a British firm, had already bought U.S. businesses, including Durkee foods and Airwick air fresheners. The purchase of Boyle-Midway, a consumer products business, represented a further move into the U.S. market. Now, ``every business looks at their competitive position on a worldwide basis,'' said a prominent U.S. investment banker who asked not to be identified. ``You can't be in the car industry without looking at the worldwide car industry.'' American companies are joining in. Philip Morris' purchase of Jacobs Suchard, for example, offers international expansion to a U.S. firm. ``You're seeing more American companies doing business in the U.K. and the continent,'' said John Cutts, executive director for European mergers and acquisitions with the British investment firm Samuel Montagu & Co. Ltd. At the same time, ``You can't be a global company and not be present in the States,'' Cutts said. If this sounds like the mergers business has found renewed vigor, it hasn't. There is still plenty of evidence that in spite of so many strategic and global opportunities, the business has shrunk. U.S. merger transactions fell 50 percent over the first half of 1990 from a year earlier, the financial research firm Securities Data Corp. says. Through June 26, there were 2,110 transactions _ including mergers, spinoffs, share repurchases and minority stake purchases _ valued at $88.2 billion, down from 2,2420 deals worth $193 billion in the first six months of 1989. There's proof beyond the numbers. In June, Bankers Trust New York Corp. said it was reducing the corporate finance staff by 10 percent, the latest financial services company to cut personnel because of the drop-off in mergers. Several days later, one of the most prominent takeover strategists of the 1980s, the investor group Coniston Partners, said it was disbanding because of scarcity of financing and worthwhile targets. Coniston's three founding partners said they had to be realistic about the changing market for takeovers. These events can be traced back to the collapse last fall of the junk bond market. Prices for the risky high-yield securities plunged after the $6.7 billion debt-financed takeover of Federated Department Stores Inc. began to stumble. It's tough to sell junk bonds when there are few buyers. The change has forced investors and dealmakers to adapt. Investment bankers who have sought cross-border deals are flourishing. Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. is expanding its mergers staff, and so are Warburg and Samuel Montagu. Coniston's founders said they would still seek acquisitions, but via new forms of financing. They said they're also branching out into areas they hadn't focused on, such as real estate. Paul Tierney, one of the three Coniston partners, said he felt a little nostalgic about the end of the investor group. But when asked about the future, he responded, ``I feel great.''

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Down Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages are currently averaging 10.15 percent, down slightly from 10.16 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.45 percent this week, down from 8.50 percent the week before. The rates, compiled from a national survey, do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of Boston Adopts Stockholder Rights Plan
DOC.TEXT: The Massachusetts Legislature passed a bill allowing banks from outside New England to compete in the state. If signed by the governor, the bill would sweep away protections that Massachusetts banks currently enjoy against hostile takeovers by banks outside the region. Officials at Bank of Boston, New England's largest bank, have been outspoken critics of the bill. The measure was passed the same day Bank of Boston Corp. said it had adopted a plan to protect stockholder interests in the event of a hostile takeover. Bank of Boston spokesman Wayne J. Taylor said it was ``coincidence'' that the bank implemented its stockholder rights plan one day after a conference committee reached an accord on the interstate banking measure. The measure received final approval from lawmakers Friday. ``We're the last major Boston bank to adopt such a plan,'' Taylor said. Stockholder rights plans enable the board of directors to protect stockholders' interests in the face of takeover attempts, but a Bank of Boston executive said their proposal was not being implemented in response to any known takeover plans. ``Our primary objective in acting to protect the interests of our stockholders is to build long-term value in their investment,'' Ira Stepanian, Bank of Boston chairman and CEO, said in a statement. The banking bill approved on Friday would become effective 60 days after the governor's approval. The state's banking industry has been weakened recently due to heavy losses from troubled real estate loans. Bank of Boston said earnings plunged about 50 percent in the year's first quarter. Earnings dropped 78 percent for 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Mostly Lower in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures finished mostly lower Friday after an attempted rally failed to gather momentum in thin trading. Wholesale unleaded gasoline prices bucked the trend and the contract for July delivery closed sharply higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange. But the gain reflected maneuvers associated with the last day of trading for the expiring July contract rather than an improvement in demand. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, sagged 8 cents to $17.07 a 42-gallon barrel after jumping 47 cents on Thursday. Contracts for delivery during September through November also declined. Among refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, the July contract of wholesale unleaded gasoline surged 1.65 cents to 62.58 cents a gallon after rising 1.44 cents on Thursday. The August contract, which will become the near-month contract on Monday, fell 0.32 cent to 56.21 and subsequent contracts also weakened. The July home heating oil contract, which also expired, lost 0.36 to settle at 48.67 cents a gallon after adding 1.10 cents Thursday. August heating oil dropped 0.64 to 48.62 cents a gallon and later months also ended off. In natural gas trading, the August contract rose to $1.519 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.515 on Thursday. Contracts for later delivery were mixed. Energy analysts said the market opened strongly, taking a cue from overseas where prices of Brent North Sea, a key grade of oil on European markets, rose strongly. Speculation that workers in Norway's oil industry will strike this weekend as they have threatened encouraged buying. Christian Gohler, a Merrill Lynch energy analyst, said oil prices in the United States succumbed to technically-motivated selling before the market tried unsuccessfully to renew its rally. Gohler said volume was light.

DOC.HEAD: Wiper Patent Holder Cuts Damage Claim Against Ford
DOC.TEXT: A second trial to decide how much Ford Motor Co. should pay for infringing on intermittent windshield wiper patents began Thursday, with the patent holder asking less than half the $325 million he first sought. An attorney for inventor Robert Kearns told a U.S. District Court jury in opening arguments that the former Wayne State University engineering professor should receive $141 million. ``I thought I had a better chance to persuade the jury it was right,'' the attorney, Paul Janicke, said later. A federal court jury said in January that Ford on infringed Kearns' patents for the intermittent wiper system. In the damages phase of the lawsuit, U.S. District Judge Avern Cohn declared a mistrial May 9 after a jury failed to agree on how much Ford should pay. Robert Crandall of the Brookings Institute in Washington testified in the first damages trial that based on a formula involving Ford's profits on the wipers, Kearns should receive $325 million. Janicke said Thursday that Ford made $27 on each of 20.6 million intermittent windshield systems sold between 1971 and 1988. He argued that Kearns was entitled to $6.85 per system. Ford attorney Paul Wheeler said Kearns should receive about 5 cents per system, or just over $1 million. Wheeler said $140 million ``is more than Ford or GM or any car company paid for royalties on all inventions combined.'' The first jury ruled Ford's infringement wasn't willful. Willful infringement would have given Cohn discretion to double or triple whatever damages a jury set. ``This case has nothing to do with copying,'' Wheeler said. ``Ford designed the system, and some aspects overlapped Mr. Kearns' patent.'' The jury's decision is expected to have a sweeping impact because Kearns, of Gaithersburg, Md., has 20 other suits pending against companies including General Motors Corp., Chrysler Corp. and Toyota Motor Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell Friday in quiet trading on world currency markets. Gold prices, up moderately overseas, jumped sharply in thin U.S. dealings following purchases by a major commodity fund. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $357.90 a troy ounce, up $5.80 an ounce from Thursday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a troy ounce of gold at $357.50, up $6.40. Traders said the dollar lost ground amid anticipation of lower U.S. interest rates. ``The dollar is once again in a vulnerable position vis a vis the European countries, which have a demand for capital,'' said Ron Holzer, chief dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Because the demand for capital is high overseas, European interest rates have been edging up and in turn, attracting investors to European securites. President Bush's announcement that taxes must be raised to help offset the nation's budget deficit also served to push the dollar lower. To many market players, new taxes and a reduced budget deficit fuel the notion that interest rates will head lower, because lessening federal borrowing needs would reduce demand for credit. Traders are bracing themselves for next week, which they expect to be ladened with market-moving news. The German monetary union is scheduled to take effect Sunday and the Labor Department is to release the June unemployment report next Friday. ``Most of the market was happy to make a small profit at the end of the week,'' said Linda McLaughlin, a trader at Chemical New York Capital Markets Group. Dealers said the dollar's biggest decline Friday came against the Japanese yen, which has been rising due to firmer Japanese money-market rates. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 152.85 Japanese yen from 154.42 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it fell to 152.30 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 152.10 yen, down from 153.15 yen on Thursday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.7450 from $1.7400 late Thursday. In New York, sterling rose to $1.7490 from $1.7384. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6607 West German marks, down from 1.6730; 1.4150 Swiss francs, down from 1.4200; 5.5795 French francs, down from 5.6155; 1,219.75 Italian lire, down from 1,228.00, and 1.1634 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1699. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6653 West German marks, down from 1.6675; 1.4155 Swiss francs, up from 1.4125; 5.5945 French francs, down from 5.6015; 1.8737 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8772; 1,222.50 Italian lire, down from 1,224.25; and 1.1657 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1692. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $353.25 a troy ounce, up from $352.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $352 an ounce from $352.60. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.40 to close at a bid of $352.74 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.887 a troy ounce, up from $4.813 late Thursday. In London, silver slid to a late bid of $4.84 an ounce from $4.85.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 198.52 Friday, up 1.12, or 0.57 percent, from a week ago and up 1.24, or 0.63 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 186.30 Friday, up 1.03, or 0.56 percent, from a week ago and up 1.19, or 0.64 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 169.12 Friday, up 1.12, or 0.67 percent, from a week ago and up 0.81, or 0.48 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Fears Of Mining Strikes Stir Gains In Gold
DOC.TEXT: The threat of mining strikes in South Africa and the Soviet Union helped muster the depressed gold market to its strongest one-day advance in nearly three months Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange. On other commodity markets, silver futures also advanced; soybeans surged while grain futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mostly lower; and energy futures slipped. Gold futures rose $5.80 to $5.90 in New York with the contract for delivery in August settling at $359.90 a troy ounce. The thinly traded July contract ended at $357.90. It was gold's most muscular rally since April 6, when futures prices jumped $5.90 across the board. Silver futures settled 7.1 cents to 7.8 cents higher Friday on the Commodity Exchange with July at $4.887 a troy ounce. Analysts said the rally partly reflected trade buying to secure supplies ahead of a threatened general strike next week in South Africa and a threatened Soviet miners strike a week later. Further buying interest was stirred when the August topped $356, triggering a wave of technically inspired buy orders. Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc., said South African gold miners were unlikely to join the threatened general strike in large numbers because union participation is not strong among mine worker there. He also saw the Soviet strike threat as weak but said gold prices could advance another $5 on technical factors, especially if the dollar continues to weaken against other major currencies. Soybean futures climbed sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade in the wake of a report in which the Agriculture Department unexpectedly reduced its estimate of planted soybean acreage. Corn futures ended narrowly mixed while most wheat futures retreated. In a report released after Thursday's close, the USDA pegged soybean plantings at 58 million acres, about 1.4 million acres below the agency's March projection and 1.6 million below trade expectations. The USDA also lowered its corn acreage estimate by 200,000 acres to a higher-than-expected 74.6 million, reflecting planting delays caused by heavy spring rains in the Midwest. Many analysts had expected the USDA to report a corresponding increase in soybean acres, confirming trade perceptions that farmers unable to plant corn had switched to soybeans. The soybean rally also reflected some private forecasters' predictions that hot, dry weather will move into the Corn Belt late next week. But in a six-to-10-day forecast released late Friday, the National Weather Service predicted normal to above-normal rainfall in the Midwest July 5-9. Wheat futures settled 4{ cents lower to 3{ cents higher with July at $3.25} a bushel; corn futures were \ cent lower to } cent higher with July at $2.95{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent lower with July at $1.35{ a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 19 cents higher with July at $6.23{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly lower ahead of the USDA's quarterly hogs-and-pigs inventory, which was released after the close. The report showed 54.4 million hogs and pigs in the United States as of June 1, 3 percent less than on the same date a year ago. The number was near expectations and was expected to have little effect on futures prices Monday. Live cattle futures settled .10 cent lower to .13 cent higher with August at 73.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .35 cent lower with August at 84.02 cents a pound; live hogs were .37 cent lower to .20 cent higher with July at 60.40 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .97 cent to 1.55 cents lower with July at 58.20 cents a pound. Energy futures finished mostly lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange after an attempted rally failed to gather momentum in thin trading. The July gasoline contract bucked the trend, though, and closed sharply higher. West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished 8 cents to 23 cents lower with August at $17.07 a barrel; heating oil was .36 cent to .79 cent lower with July at 48.67 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .60 cent lower to 1.65 cents higher with July at 62.58 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Companies To Request Another Extension for Filing Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. said Thursday the companies will ask a bankruptcy court judge to extend for a second time a deadline for filing a reorganization plan. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. has been overseeing the sister companies' Chapter 11 proceedings since they began Jan. 15. Aug in May granted Allied and Federated a four-month extension of the exclusive right to file reorganization plans _ before creditors can suggest their own plans. The extension continues through Sept. 12. Rick Cieri, a lawyer for Federated and Allied, said Thursday the companies will ask for another extension. ``We'll certainly be seeking another one,'' Cieri said. David Heiman, a Federated-Allied lawyer, told Aug on May 9 that more time might be needed beyond Sept. 12 because the cases are complex. Federated and Allied have more than 200,000 creditors, about 100,000 employees and operate 260 stores in 28 states. The Cincinnati-based companies listed more than $7.7 billion in debts when they filed their Chapter 11 petitions. They inherited much of the debt from when Campeau Corp., of Toronto, bought Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988 in heavily leveraged deals. Lawyers told Aug that U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Lloyd King of San Francisco might rule at a hearing Friday on whether to transfer the Chapter 11 bankruptcy of Federated Stores Inc., the U.S. holding company for Federated and Allied, from San Francisco to Cincinnati for convenience in handling. The holding company, chaired by former Treasury Secretary G. William Miller, filed its Chapter 11 proceeding after Federated and Allied. Aug gave Federated permission Thursday to sell a twin-engine, Sabreliner 60A jet to a Mexican company, Arrendadora Havre S.A. de C.V., for $850,000. The judge selected a $1.7 million bid from Covington Capital Corp., a Larchmont, N.Y., developer, as the winning offer for a 147-acre property Federated is selling in Ohio. Aug also gave Federated permission to sell a total 67 acres in Augusta, Ga., and Memphis, Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: NCNB Names Bank President
DOC.TEXT: Kenneth Lewis has been named president of NCNB Corp.'s General Bank, NCNB Chairman Hugh McColl announced Thursday. The new national position combines all of NCNB's 936 branches, consumer banking and commercial banking in one organizational structure. Prior to joining NCNB Texas, Lewis, 43, was president of NCNB National Bank of Florida.

DOC.HEAD: ChemLawn Agrees to Cease Advertising Claims
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio-based lawn-care company reached an agreement Friday to settle a 1988 lawsuit in New York state alleging its advertising is false and misleading. ChemLawn Services Corp. can no longer advertise its lawn-care applications as ``safe'' or ``non-toxic,'' under the agreement with the state of New York, Attorney General Robert Abrams announced. ChemLawn also must pay the state $100,000 in costs, under the agreement approved by state Supreme Court Justice Leonard Cohen. Although New York is the only state to prohibit Chemlawn from making the advertising claims, Abrams said, ``I am hopeful that today's agreement will have an impact on the way lawn-care services are marketed and sold in other parts of the country.'' Under the agreement, ChemLawn, based in Columbus, Ohio, is prohibited from claiming that it ``does not and will not use products that are known or probable human carcinogens.'' The company admits to having used chlorothalonil, maneb and mancozeb, all of which are classified as probable human carcinogens, or cancer-causing agents. Chemlawn's vice president of environmental affairs, Stephen Hardymon, said he understood the three chemicals are ``under advisory review'' by the Environmental Protection Agency but haven't been classified as carcinogens at this time. He said none of the advertising at issue, contained in brochures touting the safety of ChemLawn's products, was false. ``We did not admit any false and misleading advertisements,'' Hardymon said. ``The settlement does not say that we did.'' He said ChemLawn settled the suit because ``it's cost us an awful lot of money, and we just wanted to get this behind us and move forward.''

Several large industrial companies have already served notice that their earnings for the April-June period haven't lived up to expectations. However, investors apparently have decided not to dump stocks in response to that prospect. Instead, they have been seeking out and bidding up stocks of companies in recession-resistant businesses, such as food and pharmaceuticals. DOC.HEAD: Allied Gets New Credit Line; FSI Reorganization Transferred
DOC.TEXT: Allied Stores Corp. said Friday that it has reached agreement with Chemical Bank on a $630 million line of credit to buy merchandise during its bankruptcy reorganization. Allied, which is under U.S. Bankruptcy Court protection from its creditors, said the three-year agreement allows for additional borrowing of as much as $700 million if necessary. Allied said it also agreed with Chemical Bank on a two-year extension of a $300 million working capital financing agreement negotiated when Allied filed a reorganization petition Jan. 15. The agreement would replace Allied's current $700 million borrowing agreement with Citibank, which expires July 31. Allied said it would ask U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. to approve the new agreements at a July 26 hearing. Allied and its sister Federated Department Stores Inc., which are owned by Toronto-based Campeau Corp., are reorganizing under Chapter 11 protection from creditors. The retailers listed more than $7 billion in debt, much of it from Campeau's takeover of Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. Also Friday, a federal bankruptcy judge in San Francisco ordered that the Chapter 11 proceedings of Federated Stores Inc. and three affiliated holding companies be transferred from his court to Cincinnati. Federated Stores Inc. is the holding company for Federated and Allied. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Lloyd King of San Francisco on Friday granted a request by Allied bondholders to move the proceedings. King ruled it would be more efficient to administer them in the same court as Federated and Allied. FSI lawyer Isaac Pachulski argued against moving the FSI reorganization, saying it was filed in San Francisco because a major FSI property, the Ralphs supermarket group, and a number of key officials are in California. Aug said Thursday his workload could accommodate the FSI proceeding in addition to the Allied and Federated reorganizations.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Officials: Accord Near on Multiple Listing of Existing Options
DOC.TEXT: Federal securities regulators said Thursday that a linkage system for the long-delayed multiple listing of options could be up and running by the end of the year. Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said four of the nation's five options exchanges have reached agreement on a system for linking the various trading marketplaces. Breeden and SEC Market Regulation Division Director Richard G. Ketchum said, however, that the proposed system would have to go through the time-consuming SEC approval process before it could begin operation. ``It's not a long period. I think we could still be looking at a linkage system being up by the end of 1990 or early 1991 of the type agreed to by the four exchanges,'' said Ketchum. Neither official would say what action the SEC will take later this month when a voluntary delay in multiple listings ends. ``We would have to reserve official judgement until we see a filing for a linkage system'' by the exchanges, said Breeden. He said only the Philadelphia Stock Exchange has not agreed to the proposed linkage system. Since January, at SEC request, the nation's options exchanges have delayed their phase-in of multiple listings for options already being traded until June 30. That was to allow extra time to come up with a linkage system. ``We wanted to take the time from January until June 30 to have an intensive review of whether a linkage system is feasible,'' said Breeden in an interview in his sixth floor office. ``We have concluded that it is unquestionably feasible. We have a specific system that four of the exchanges have agreed is a good one and should be built. The next step now would be moving toward implementation of a system,'' he added. An option contract is the right to buy or sell a certain security at a specified price for a set period of time. Options are traded on stocks listed on exchanges or traded over-the-counter via computer. Until earlier this year, most options on the stocks listed on an exchange could be traded only in one marketplace at a time. The privlege for trading a specific option, assigned by lottery, is not permitted on any other exchange. But a rule passed by the SEC last year abolished the limitations on multiple trading of options. All new options listed for trading after January can be traded on any options exchange. But Breeden asked the heads of the American Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board of Options Exchange, the New York Stock Exchange, the Pacific Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia exchange to voluntarilly refrain from multiple listing of existing options until June 30.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Rise for Fourth Straight Day
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices finished higher Friday for the fourth straight day after President Bush repeated his comments that a tax hike may be necessary to prod the stalled budget talks in Congress. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond rose 15-32 point, or $4.69 per $1,000 face amount. The 30-year bond had risen $13.13 in the three previous sessions. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, slipped to 8.40 percent from 8.44 percent late Thursday. The bond market's climb began Tuesday after Bush reversed his longtime opposition to a tax increase. He said tax revenue increases must be part of a broader budget agreement that would include spending cuts to reduce the federal deficit. On Friday, Bush expanded on his earlier comments, saying he knew he had to change course to break a deadlock in Congress. Justifying the change, the president said the economy was slower and the deficit was now worse than ``any of us visualized'' when he made his pledge two years ago. ``The market was in a slight downward correction prior to his comments,'' said Bob Sbarra, a senior vice president at the investment firm Carroll McEntee & McGinley Inc. ``While he didn't say anything new, I think what the market concluded was that he clearly wanted action.'' Sbarra said the financial markets believe that if a budget accord that includes spending cuts is reached, the Federal Reserve will ease interest rates to counter the potentially negative economic impact of the cutbacks. Lower rates usually boost the prices of fixed-return investments such as bonds. Traders said the market had little reaction to two reports indicating continued weakness in the economy, though the reports added to the price firmness. A weakening economy often prompts the Fed to ease interest rates. The Commerce Department said sales of new homes inched up 0.4 percent in May. While this marked the first increase in six months, home sales remained at their lowest level since the economy emerged from its last recession. In addition, the department revised downward its figure on new home sales for April, from a 1.6 percent decline to a 5.2 percent drop. Meanwhile, the Chicago purchasing managers group said its index of corporate purchasing activity fell to 53.3 in June from 56.0 in May. A figure above 50 generally means the economy is expanding. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments were up by [ point to 7-32 point, intermediate maturities advanced by between 3-16 point and 13-32 point, and long-term issues were up as much as { point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 2.46 to 1,162.53. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.98 percent as the discount slipped 1 basis point to 7.73 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8 percent as the discount lost 2 basis points to 7.60 percent. Yields on one-year bills dropped to 8.01 percent as the discount fell 4 basis points to 7.46 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 7{ percent, down from 8 5-16 percent late Wednesday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 3-16 point to 91}. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.50 percent from 7.51 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Court Halts Sales Of Galoob Video Game Enhancer
DOC.TEXT: A federal court on Friday temporarily halted sales of Lewis Galoob Toys Inc.'s Game Genie until a copyright suit by video game giant Nintendo of America seeking a permanent ban can be heard. Game Genie is a device which allows video game players to explore all levels of games by providing unlimited ``lives'' to game characters, increased firepower to game weapons or increased jumping ability. ``We are disappointed by the court's decision,'' said Steven M. Klein, executive vice president for Galoob, of the U.S. District Court injunction. ``We continue to believe that Galoob Toys has in no way infringed on any Nintendo copyright and we intend to seek an expedited appeal of the court's ruling immediately.''

President Bush vetoed a bill that would require companies to give as much as three months unpaid leave to workers with new babies or family illnesses. His action Friday set the stage for a new confrontation with Congress, where the bill has strong support from Republicans as well as Democrats. ``The president should be ashamed for vetoing this bill and making a mockery of the term `family values,' '' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo.

Campbell Soup Co. said it would sell its U.S. and Canadian fresh foods and fresh produce businesses, closing or selling a score of plants to focus on more profitable units. The moves announced Friday will result in after-tax charges of $247 million against net income for the fiscal year ending July 29. The company did not say whether it would post an overall profit for the year. The restructuring _ the third in the past year _ affects about 3,000 jobs and includes the sale of businesses with annual revenue of more than $300 million.

East Germans tried to unload their Communist currency on enough food to get through a historic weekend, but stores shut down to wait for the fatter profits of the free market. ``Our local department store is completely empty,'' said East Berliner Johanna Suska, who was spending the last of her East German currency Friday on food for the first week of monetary union. ``There is just some bread and milk, sugar and flour,'' she said.

President Bush expressed confidence in his son Neil's integrity, but promised not to interfere with regulators who are investigating the son's role in the collapse of a Colorado savings and loan. Neil Bush, 34, served on the board of directors of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Assocition of Denver from 1985 to 1988. The failure of the thrift is expected to cost taxpayers $1 billion. ``I will stay out of anything to do with the investigation, but this is a fine young man,'' the president said Friday.

New home sales in May rose at an annual rate of 0.4 percent, but were still at virtually their lowest level since the economy emerged from its last recession 7{ years ago. The government said Friday that the increase _ from an annual sales rate of 530,000 homes in April to a rate of 532,000 homes in May _ was the first gain in six months.

The Environmental Protection Agency banned the use of mercury in interior paints because of possible poisoning from inhalation and other exposure. ``EPA and the registrants of mercury paint preservatives have agreed to ban the use of mercury in indoor paint effective Aug. 20, 1990,'' said Linda Fisher, assistant administrator for pesticides and toxic substances. Manufacturers must eliminate mercury from all new interior paint formulas under the order announced Friday.

Five importers of chlorofluorocarbons were accused in lawsuits of violating federal restrictions on the use of chemicals blamed for the depletion of the Earth's ozone layer. One of the five firms, a New York commodities importer, agreed to pay a civil penalty of $101,935 to settle one of the five lawsuits filed by the Justice Department, officials said. The five companies were accused Friday of violating the Clean Air Act and regulations promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency to protect the ozone layer.

The 12 nations of the European Community embark Sunday on a plan for economic and monetary union that may eventually lead to a central EC banking system and a single currency. But the road to economic and monetary union, or EMU in EC jargon, will be bumpy. For most EC governments, EMU means one currency, one central bank, one Community-wide monetary policy. To make that palatable to skeptics, notably British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the EMU's final form has been left ambiguous.

Police used a sledgehammer to break into the Agriculture Ministry to end a 3-day-old sit-in by hundreds of farmers demanding guaranteed prices for their products. Officers broke open a locked ministry door shortly before 7:30 p.m. Friday. Scores of police carrying truncheons then entered the building in central Warsaw. Several hundred farmers walking in a peaceful procession came out about a half-hour after police entered. They carried a protest banner and were singing the patriotic-religious hymn ``Rota'' and the national anthem.

The stock market inched ahead Friday, capping the first half of 1990 on a positive note. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 1.98 to 2,880.69. Bond prices rose in reaction to President Bush's remarks supporting a tax increase. The dollar fell in quiet trading. Gold posted its strongest one-day advance in three months on the threat of strikes at mines in South Africa and the Soviet Union. Silver futures advanced; soybeans surged while grain futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mostly lower; and energy futures slipped.
