DOC.HEAD: Bank of New England To Sell, Consolidate Branch Offices
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. on Friday announced plans to sell or consolidate more than 95 branch offices to help streamline the financially troubled company. Under the plan, 39 Massachusetts branches will be consolidated into nearby offices and 13 branches will be put up for sale. In Connecticut, the bank plans to consolidate 19 branches and sell off six. Spokesman James Dorsey declined to disclose the value of assets involved or the amount the company hopes to make from the sales. He said about 450 employees will be affected. In April, officials announced plans to restructure the company by cutting the bank's assets from $32 billion to $20 billion and laying off 5,600 employees. The plan was adopted after the company took stock of its expansion in the mid-1980s and decided to cut $350 million in overall operating costs by the end of 1990. The bank, which has been operating under government orders since March, lost more than $1 billion last year. Much of the financial trouble stems from real estate loans that went sour along with the Northeast real estate market. ``We're going to see more (consolidation) not only at the Bank of New England but also at other financial institutions throughout the Northeast,'' said James Moynihan of Advest Group, a Hartford, Conn.-based brokerage firm. ``In the 1980s, we were looking at expansion and acquisition. In the 1990s, we're going to be looking at downsizing and consolidation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: United States, Britain Agree to Open Skies
DOC.TEXT: Britain and the United States have agreed to allow each other's airlines to fly among more cities, the countries said Friday. U.S. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner and his British counterpart Cecil Parkinson announced the agreement, which will allow two more routes from the United States to any British city, and an additional British carrier, Virgin Atlantic, on the London-Boston route. Britain is also given the right to operate two routes of its choosing between any regional British airports and any of the main U.S. gateway airports. ``The settlement we have reached provides opportunities for both sides' airlines and will benefit both consumers and the United Kingdom regions,'' Parkinson said. He said the two governments would now begin studying the liberalization of the U.S.-British aviation market.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Nearly $16 Million in `Cool Light' Suit
DOC.TEXT: A jury Friday awarded $15.9 million to an inventor who claimed GTE Products Corp. pulled the plug on his fledgling lighting business by stealing his idea for a cool lamp used in movie studios. A U.S. District Court jury agreed with George Panagiotou, a former rock band manager turned lighting entrepreneur who said he got the idea for his so-called cool light during his years as a Boston nightclub manager in the early 1970s. Panagiotou had charged that trade secrets for his cool light were unfairly appropriated by the Danvers, Mass.-based lighting giant, which then manufactured a similar product and sent Panagiotou's own company into ruin. The jury found that Panagiotou's invention of a reflector that cut the heat from movie lights was a trade secret improperly obtained by GTE, a division of GTE Corp. of Stamford, Conn., and that GTE officials falsely told Panagiotou they could make the reflectors needed for the lamp. But the jury also found that GTE did not use the secret to advance its own business interests, and did not profit from Panagiotou's cool light secret. Edwin McCabe, Panagiotou's lawyer, said the award would come to about $25 million with interest. Panagiotou, who has since started a successful home video light company in Los Angeles, said he was elated by the verdict. ``I feel fantastic, I feel great because it's over, it's behind us,'' he said. ``We certainly triumphed.'' Vincent D'Alessandro, a GTE spokesman, said the firm would appeal. ``We're disappointed by the verdict,'' D'Alessandro said. ``Our contention is that we've done nothing wrong. There was no secret, we didn't break a contract and we contend there should be no damages.'' Panagiotou, born in Romania of Greek descent, came to Boston at age 16, started working in the city's nightclubs and eventually helped form the rock band Aerosmith and managed such groups as Rush. He said in court records that he started developing the cool light when he realized how uncomfortable performers were under the wilting heat of the performance lights of the 1970s. Cool Light was used in the production of TV programs popular in the late 1970s and early 1980s including ``Lou Grant,'' ``Police Woman,'' ``Switch'' and ``Little House on The Prairie.'' Panagiotou filed the suit in California in 1984. The trial began last month and attracted such stars as Ed Asner and Michael Landon to testify on Panagiotou's behalf. According to court documents, celebrities such as Robert Wagner refused to act without cool lights once they had used them. Lawyers for Cool Light, Panagiotou's firm, argued that Panagiotou was tricked into a ``gentleman's agreement'' with GTE. Under the pact, Panagiotou would give GTE his production secrets, GTE would manufacture a special reflector for the lights, Panagiotou would place the reflector in the light fixtures at his expense at his own plant and then distribute it to customers. But soon after he revealed the unpatented secret, GTE discontinued the outside contracting of products made with some materials, including those used for the reflector. GTE stopped supplying Cool Light with reflectors, McCabe said. Cool Light consequently folded, while GTE started distributing products made with the secret, McCabe said. GTE had maintained that Panagiotou failed to show there had been any trade secrets, or that there had been a breach of contract. Since Panagiotou's company shut down, other types of lights have been used in Hollywood, McCabe said. But Panagiotou said he planned to once again make the cool light. ``We're certain we will produce the cool light again,'' he said. ``No one has filled that gap in the market. This time, they will be improved.''

DOC.HEAD: Arco Pays $800 Million to Settle $1.8 Billion Windfall Profits Tax Case
DOC.TEXT: Atlantic Richfield Co. said Friday it had paid $800 million to the Internal Revenue Service to settle a dispute over windfall profit taxes on Alaska oil, lifting a longstanding cloud over the company. The payment settles a claim for back taxes and interest that totaled $1.8 billion, believed to be the largest claim ever presented to a company by the IRS. In settling the dispute, Arco admitted no wrongdoing. Arco, the second-biggest producer of Alaska crude oil, said the payment will resolve all IRS claims for additional windfall profit taxes, including interest, on its North Slope production from 1980 to 1985. Arco had set aside reserves since the mid-1980s to cover settlements of disputes over Alaska oil. It said those reserves covered the huge payment. ``Arco is adequately reserved so the setlement payment will have no impact on earnings,'' said spokesman Al Greenstein. Arco disclosed in July 1988 that the government had presented it with a $1.1 billion back-taxes bill in the dispute over how the company valued oil that it produced in Alaska from 1980 to 1983. The bill consisted of $577 million in taxes, plus interest. This April, the company said it was also subject $212 million plus interest for 1984 and 1985. All told, the IRS had been demanding $1.8 billion in taxes and interest, Greenstein said. The IRS started investigating Arco in the mid-1980s after rival oil companies complained its internal pricing policies were unjustifiably minimizing its taxes, allowing it to charge less for gasoline than rivals in the competitive California retail market. Arco denied the allegations. The dispute settled Friday centered on the value assigned by Arco to crude oil it pumped from North Slope wells. The IRS contends Arco assigned the oil a value lower than it should have at that point, lessening the windfall profits tax, which is based on a benchmark price derived from past production on a given oil field. That lower windfall profits tax let Arco ultimately set prices lower on the retail gasoline it sold at the pumps, other oil companies complained. The settlement was the latest in a series of similar cases dating back to the mid-1980s for Arco and other oil companies. In 1986, for example, Arco agreed to pay the state of Alaska $243 million as part of a tax settlement covering the company's production on the North Slope and Cook Inlet fields. Still unresolved from that time is a dispute with Alaska over royalties paid on the same production. Alaska is demanding $320 million in that case, Greenstein said. Also that year, Arco agreed to pay $315 million in restitution and fines to settle allegations of violating federal oil price controls in the 1970s and early 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Begins Deliberating in Wall Street Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: Jury deliberations began Friday in the conspiracy and fraud case against John A. Mulheren Jr., the former stock speculator accused of engaging in sham securities transactions with Ivan Boesky. The panel of eight women and four men deliberated for several hours after receiving legal instructions from U.S. District Judge Miriam Goldman Cederbaum. The jury is to resume its deliberations on Monday. Mulheren, 41, of Rumson, N.J., is charged with 30 counts of conspiracy, stock manipulation, securities fraud, mail fraud and record-keeping violations in connection with a series of transactions with Boesky in 1985 and 1986. Also named is Leonard L. DeStefano, 34, a former trader at Mulheren's now-defunct Jamie Securities Co. DeStefano is charged with one count each of conspiracy and violating federal record-keeping statutes. The case included the first public testimony by Boesky, the former speculator who settled insider trading charges with the government in 1986 by agreeing to plead guilty to one felony and pay $100 million in penalties. Boesky was required to cooperate with the government in its investigation of Wall Street fraud. He was released from federal custody in April after completing two years of a three-year prison term. Mulheren is accused of manipulating the price of Gulf & Western Inc. stock by buying large blocks to help aid Boesky, who wanted to sell a large stake in the company he acquired. He also is charged with temporarily holding other securities for Boesky to help Boesky evade taxes and federal securities laws. Concealing the ownership of securities, also known as ``parking,'' with the intent to deceive is illegal under federal law. The trial is in its seventh week in U.S. District Court in Manhattan.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Sues Pathe Over MGM-UA Financing Deal
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. sued Pathe Communications Corp. for $100 million Friday, contending Pathe broke a contract giving Time Warner Inc. distribution rights to Pathe and United Artists films. The lawsuit was the latest development in the struggle by Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier who owns Pathe, to finnce his proposed $1.3 billion buyout of MGM-UA Communications Co. Time Warner agreed April 9 to lend Pathe $650 million toward the purchase in return for distribution rights to new Pathe and United Artists films and the valuable United Artists movie library. Time Warner also got a lien on the library as collateral. But Time Warner insisted that Pathe provide the rest in equity, at least $450 million of that from Pathe's own sources rather than borrowed money. Pathe had been trying to renegotiate the equity part of the deal, but announced Thursday it had reached an impasse with Time Warner. Pathe said it would continue to talk with Time Warner, but also would seek alternate sources of financing. Time Warner's lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court, alleges that Pathe ``acted as if the contract gave Pathe a one-way option to decide which of its obligations it would honor, which Time Warner rights it could ignore, and which conditions it would satisfy.'' Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons said no one at Beverly Hills-based Pathe had seen the lawsuit, and thus could not comment on it. Asked if it was a surprise, he said, ``Things had not in our view gotten that hostile, so I'm at a loss to explain it at this point.'' The lawsuit asserts that Pathe is ``creating a smokescreen to obscure the actual fact that Pathe was unable or unwilling to perform under the April 9 letter agreement and as an excuse to seek `alternative financing.''' MGM-UA's stock price fell Friday on the news that the main source of financing for Pathe's offer was in jeopardy. The stock, which fell 62{ cents per share to $17.25 on the New York Stock Exchange, already was trading far below the level expected if investors believed Pathe's $21.50-per-share offer would be completed as scheduled on Oct. 23, analysts said. Under Parretti's latest agreement with Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire who controls MGM-UA, $4 per share of the $21.50 is to be paid to MGM-UA shareholders on July 20. Parretti already has put $200 million into escrow, which will be used toward the distribution. He is to kick in another $53 million to get to the $4-per-share level. Many of those buying MGM-UA stock don't believe the deal will go through, said Jeffrey Logsdon, an analyst with Crowell, Weedon Inc. in Los Angeles. Instead, he said, they're gambling that they can pocket the $4, then get the rest of their money back and more when Kerkorian sells the studio to another buyer at a lower price. Pathe spokesman Parsons noted that the company already has the $200 million in cash down payments invested in the deal. He said the company was looking at ``a broad universe of options'' for raising the rest of the money. The lawsuit filed Friday by Time Warner Inc. and Time Warner Home Video Inc. accuses Pathe of breaching theatrical and home video distribution agreements for Pathe films. With respect to the video rights agreement, the lawsuit says Pathe entered into the agreement without telling Warner it already had previously granted the rights to another company.
